who go to SF parties.  If you feel that you can catagorize all the
east coast ravers as fashion freeks, your just closing your eyes.

a Scott Henry, Wink, Frankie Bones anyday and let them rock your 
house.  Not to mention that there are guest dj's from all over 
the country and world that rock things up.
  Dont close your eyes.  As a former east coast raver thats
the scene i grew up with and i dont feel i have any explaining to
do cause i did.

all live y everyday.

im babbling, sorry but this post pissed me off.

Purple Tiger Species Identification:

5'6" male, med build, auburn shoulder length hair...

One of two costume themes:

Purple and More Purple: boots, socks, tights, pullover (purple velvet),
        shades, mask, purple umbrella, claws (!!!).

Black Cyberpunk: leather doublet, black tightes, black skirt, leather
        bracers, black gloves, black boots (green & pink laces), mask,
        CLAWS!!!

Will wear SFRAVE Laminate (if obtained from Vince).  I may also wear
a bright orange cap that sayz "Wired" on the front.

Behavior:

         1. Dancing
         2. Sleeping
         3. Harassing Photographers By Taking Pictures Of Them
         4. Handing out self-published short story.

DON'T BE SHY!  I'll happily hook you up with as many other SF-RAVERS as
I can find.  I'm actually starting to get good at it.

I guess I didn't make my point sufficiently clear.  It's time to STOP
bashing the "other" whatever-it-is -- other coast, other style, other
scene.  Open your EARS.  The east coast has Josh Wink, Darshan (Essa 3),
Taylor 808/Prototype 909, Scott Henry, Dieselboy, and many many others.

The whole underground scene EVERYWHERE now is stale to the point of
being lame because people have stopped being open to what they haven't
yet experienced, and only rely on what they hear fourth-hand.

Open Your Ears, Open Your Eyes, Open Your Mind!

peace out

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep  1 04:08:36 1995

Date: Fri, 1 Sep 1995 03:50:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: GENESiS CLiMBER MoSPEADA <madox@netcom.com>
Subject: EAST WEST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9509010351.A27202-0100000@netcom23>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

gee, didnt i just make a few people upset ;)

i understand exactly what you guys are saying, that no one should be 
closed minded about a lot of things, but perhaps i didnt make my piont 
clear, the philosophy "wishing will make it so" (which is what seems to 
be your point of view) just doesnt work. i think that at a time, both 
coasts and all countries accepted eachother for whatever they had to 
offer, but times have changed. wishing that everyone shouldnt be closed 
minded just wont work. already too many new people in the rave scene are 
closed minded, and refuse to expand their minds that there are other 
places with things to offer. (an example of this are ravers in the US. a 
lot of them feel that the best music comes from europe, and that anything 
from the US just isnt good. on the other hand, people in europe feel that 
anything from the US is better than in europe (not all the time, but as a 
generalization)). my point is, that they have closed their 
minds about the west coast, and think that we are still back in the early 
90s for a lot of things dealing with raves. if they dont want to accept 
the west coast for what it has to offer to the rave scene, then why 
should we keep on trying to force it on them, and be nice, and open 
minded? when they have already closed there minds. i've talked to a lot 
of "ravers" from different places...toranto brags about its jungle 
capital of the world or whatever...east coast brags about being up on 
european fashon trends...no one talks about the west coast...my personal 
opinion is why try to force things, and be nice to everyone, when in fact 
everything rotates in a circular motion...sometime in the future, 
everyone will be open minded, and willing to accept other rave cultures 
for what is has to offer, in the time being, forget about trying to be 
nice, and concentrate on what needs to be done for us here in SF...

and btw, i know that the east has all those lovely artist, but an artist 
doesnt creat the scene nor the attitude of that scene...

(what are the odds im gonna get bashed again? god, cant even express an 
opinion about something with out the PC police gettin on you ;)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re: EAST WEST
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>i understand exactly what you guys are saying, that no one should be 
>closed minded about a lot of things, but perhaps i didnt make my piont 
>clear, the philosophy "wishing will make it so" (which is what seems to 
>be your point of view) just doesnt work. i think that at a time, both 
>coasts and all countries accepted eachother for whatever they had to 
>offer, but times have changed. wishing that everyone shouldnt be closed 
>minded just wont work. already too many new people in the rave scene are 
>closed minded, and refuse to expand their minds that there are other 
>places with things to offer. 

I couldn't disagree with this more.  You do realize that this is the
philosophy that has caused many of the world's problems.  "Well, since he's
not willing to listen to me, I'm not going to make the effort."  Jeez, with
this attitude _of course_ nothing is going to change.  Moreover, it's
stretching it pretty far to say "all East Coast ravers do so-and-so".
Stereotyping is not becoming of anyone, my friend.  This line of thinking
has lead to bigotry and racism throughout the centuries.  I know that this
isn't what you had in mind, but that's the way it comes across.  East coast
ravers are not East coast ravers.  West coast ravers are not West Coast
ravers.  They are all just people, each with his own set of values about
what is right or wrong.  I've met a lot of people this summer who were
visiting from the east coast who were every bit as friendly as people from
out here.

Instead of judging people by their "scene", try judging them by their
character.  

>if they dont want to accept 
>the west coast for what it has to offer to the rave scene, then why 
>should we keep on trying to force it on them, and be nice, and open 
>minded? when they have already closed there minds. 

'cause that's the way the world works.  You catch more flies with honey than
with vinegar.  Your attitude is just as destructive as theirs.

i've talked to a lot 
>of "ravers" from different places...toranto brags about its jungle 
>capital of the world or whatever...east coast brags about being up on 
>european fashon trends...no one talks about the west coast...my personal 
>opinion is why try to force things, and be nice to everyone, when in fact 
>everything rotates in a circular motion...sometime in the future, 
>everyone will be open minded, and willing to accept other rave cultures 
>for what is has to offer, in the time being, forget about trying to be 
>nice, and concentrate on what needs to be done for us here in SF...

To me, the rave scene is _about_ being nice, or more accurately, respectful.
That's what attracted me to it in the first place.  And saying "just forget
about it, in the future things will get better again" is only partially
true.  Things don't spontaneously get better in this world, you've gotta
work at it.  And being close-minded to others just because they happen to
come from area of the country X isn't going to help things any.

>
>and btw, i know that the east has all those lovely artist, but an artist 
>doesnt creat the scene nor the attitude of that scene...

And the attitude of a scene is never going to change if you don't help to
make it change...

Jake

> um, you know, not to sound mean or anything, but why do we need those 
> east coast DJs here? i've been to maryland a few times, and the "ravers" 
> there should be called lamers. to them, its not about the rave "scene" 
> and getting along with one another...etc...but its about what fashon 
> trend you are in, and if you dont dress like everyone else, or dance like 
> everyone else, you get laughed at, and shuned. im sorry, but if the 
> general poplulation at ravers there feel that way, then im sure the DJs 
> are on the same tip, and my personal opinion is why have them here? let 
> them stay there in their own concided(sp) world and think they are ravers.

that's where you're wrong. the dj's are not on the same tip - you also 
happened to be in one of the best/worst scenes on the coast. Baltimore 
has been hit hard by trendoids and shitty ('fiend') drug use. Most of the 
DJ's in the Balto/DC area are wicked and great people who are down with 
the scene. Ask anyone who is involved in some part of the scene directly 
who isn't a raver (promoters, dj's) and they will tell you the problems 
with the scene lie directly with most of the ravers. it's ridiculous.
Unfortunately it's one of the *best* scenes on the coast because they 
have amazing promoters who know what's up and throw parties to showcase 
*good* music, and excellent dj's who know what's up. people in baltimore 
have collaborated and hosted names the likes of mixmaster morris, the 
dust/chemical brothers, FSOL...it's almost on a par with SF as far as the 
*music* goes. Shame none of the 'listeners' give a shit about it.

For more information on Baltimore's (and the east coast scene's) 
troubles, check http://www.clark.net/pub/lovegrov/retina7/letters.html

it's in a hardcopy/online zine called Retina from Baltimore -- a great 
music resource.

mikebee

     Man, you are so far off base here that it's not even funny.
     
     Sure, big parties everywhere are full of fashion poseurs
     *EVEN IN SAN FRANCISCO, I'VE SEEN THE COMPLAINTS RIGHT HERE IN 
     SF-RAVES*.
     
     Why would it be a nifty idea to have some of the East Coast DJs out 
     here?  Simple:  musical variety.  Yes, the variety is coming way up 
     here in San Francisco compared to when I moved here over a year and a 
     half ago, but it sure would be fun to hear someone like Adam X or 
     Nigel Richards out this way.
     
     And as far as what kind of tip these guys are on:  I know them both 
     personally, and they're just as dedicated to good music and quality 
     rave experiences as the movers and shakers in the scene out here are.  
     Adam and his girlfriend Heather Heart throw frequent free parties 
     where they give new DJs and live acts exposure.  The two of them are 
     good to talk to, have a real love of music (albeit they are 
     opinionated, but aren't most of us?), know how to put on a good party, 
     and are just plain kind and sweet people.
     
     Also, there's a fair number of transplanted East Coasters out here, 
     and frankly, we get a little homesick at times.  So, it would be extra 
     special for us to get a chance to have Nigel, Adam, Josh, Carlos Tera, 
     etc. out here.
     
     Laura

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep  1 11:54:54 1995

From: tahsina@ix.netcom.com (TOM SHAHIN )
Subject: Ravers attitude/west coast
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Peace and Love everyone,
After reading the discussion on east coast ravers and the different
opinions on that issue, I had to mention something about my experience
with the SF rave scene.
I am originally from Chicago, been in the rave scene since 1989. I 
moved to California a year and a half ago, and been to many raves since 
then.
I met plenty of wonderful loving people that are hard to find these 
days. 
I thought this scene would be one of the most open minded scenes in the 
world, but again I found that alot of people who call themselves ravers
have problems opening their mind to new things, they can not deal with
people who do not dress and look like every one else. One of the main 
reasons I love the rave culture is the freedom and originality a person
would have. I enjoy fashion, and love to see how some people get 
creative with thier clothes, but again some ravers would not accept 
that because they think ravers should look a certain way.

The secound main isssue, is DANCING. I have not seen as many closed 
minded ravers in my life, having problems letting loose. If a raver has 
a unique dancing style, a lot of people would start having problems 
with that. Because, that raver does not dance the SAME. That raver is
threatning the JOHN TRAVOLTA spirit inside many dancers, then a very
common cute practice starts: people imitating that person, making fun 
of that person. If that does not help stop that person from dancing or 
leaving
the party some of the great ravers in history start bumping into that 
person to express the good raver attitude and may be the person would 
retaliate, then it is a good chance for them to teach that person a 
lesson in behavior by kicking that persons ass.
I would also like to mention the other bad element in the rave scene, 
CIRCLE DANCING. This element is showing the effect of subculture on the 
rave culture, people with gang banger lookS turning the sacred dancing 
experience into competition and trying to control the dance
floor. The sad part is that a lot of the first timers on the
scene, see that and think that this is how a raver should dance and
this is the attitude to have. Unfortunately, this is one of the 
deseases in the rave scene, I wish there was a way to block that 
element
and define it as an unacceptable practice. 
There is no certain way a raver should dance, being open minded and 
letting loose is the first step to achieve a sacred dance experience.

Sadly many SFR ravers were involved in some of these practices in 
Friends and Family, even that party was one of the greatest parties
we have had in a while, but there are few ignorant people sitting 
behind computer terminals.
Thank you all for taking the time to read this, and party with ya soon.
Tom

Okay, okay, I guess I oughta throw my 2 cents worth in here.  :)

>From what I've heard, especially in Canada, the scene ITSELF doesn't seem
to be very different all the way across the country.  It's ALL starting to
get overrun with poseurs and ppl whose main objective is to get just
totally fucked over on as many drugs as possible.  Here in Vancouver
especially, the larger parties are getting filled up with little twinkies
who can't comprehend that the rave scene has been around for more than two
years and get very snobby with ppl who are just getting into it now.

Unfortunately, it seems that the East Coast DJs are very unwilling to allow
other DJs into their "territory" as it were.  This saddens me, as out here
in the West we LOVE to have DJs from anywhere and everywhere.  Two
Vancouver DJs, Lace and Little T, recently went to Montreal and were
stunned by the unfriendliness of their east coast colleagues ....

I feel that I've been very lucky in recent months as I have been meeting
people from both this mailing list and from nw-raves, and with very few
exceptions you have all been completely amazing.  It reaffirms my faith in
the whole big picture.  :)

I have no solutions as to what to do about twits and tweekers ... if we let
them be and accept them, they'll groundswell and grow and take over, and if
we try to get rid of them or close them out, we're not being "open-minded"
.... it's a tough call.  I just try not to let them get me down.

k

eidrah@wimsey.com  *  karen_hardie@mindlink.bc.ca  *  karen@hyperreal.com

all the kids were into it.  There was no frontin'.

as what they *have* to be like.  Have a little more faith in party goers.

>Friends and Family, even that party was one of the greatest parties
>we have had in a while, but there are few ignorant people sitting

HuH?

When I first moved here, I was a bit unaccepting of the scene here.  But as
time goes on, you will see that this scene displays qualities nowhere else
to be found in the world (of course with a few rough edges).

-Jon

                     Dear fellow,
                I have to agree with you on some of your perspectives.
 I moved out here about 2 years ago from the D.C. area and the whole C.A. 
rave scene has given me a *very* realistic idea about what the whole rave 
scene is supposed to be about: unity, freedom of expression and just 
having a blast. I had only been to 4 or 5 parties out there on the 
East Coast, which were mostly around D.C.( Trax) or in Maryland. I wasn't 
provided with info. on which parties would be the best or the most 
undergound. I had to rely on the cheesy flyers that I could find at my 
local mall shops that would give way to all the $20 $ *UP* massive 
parties I found myself at. I did see alot of attitude related to who you 
knew and not who you were as a person.  I never made it up to the more 
hidden-underground parties that went off in N.Y. & Phili. so I don't 
know if there was a more positive vibe\not? The thing I've learned
from  raving out here has been to open myself up more, accept and love 
what I        opps!
discover and to accept all others from all walks of life.:). I won't say 
that one side of the U.S. is superior over the other. Perhaps the East 
thinks the same of us, you NEVER know. If all areas of the U.S. can teach 
one another something new and positive about the rave scene as a whole; 
we sure can accomplish alot. I see the East Coast DJ's visit out here as 
a learning experience. We would be able to find out if all our 
preconceived notions are true or if we just weren't looking in the 
right place during our stays there.  As a stated early on, I do agree 
with some of your thoughts but I would like to have the chance to test 
them.                          
                                    Reaganx

Dear All(Excluding Those Going To Burning Man)

	For those new the Bay Area, the events that will be happening dis 
weekend are Saturday Basics(Not My Favorite, But It's the Only Thing 
Going), Sunday Spundaes(I don't like supporting Clubs, but if I had to it 
would either be 1015 or DV8), this promises to be a killer, 
HOT(temperature wise) event, WARNING GET THERE EARLY, ELSE YOU WILL BE 
STANDING IN LINE FOR HOURS ON E, I ALMOST PUKED LASTTIME, but then again 
it did get me to the front of the line real fast.

	Whether you raving or not dis weekend folks, we live in one of 
the largest populations concentrations in the world, SF offers lots o cool 
stuff to see and do, eg museams, zoo's(a really good one from what I 
hear). So whether you are or not, go out and have fun, this may be just 
the weekend to experience Zomething(sorry Zime) different, so have 
FUN!!!. AS for me you may see me a Basics tonight, if someone would like 
to give me a ride I love to share expenses, otherwise you will see me at 
Spundaes. Later

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep  4 20:10:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA08639; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 20:10:42 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA08598; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 20:09:39 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu
	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA297650490; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 20:08:11 -0700
Date: Mon, 4 Sep 1995 20:08:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Amy's Burning Man experience! (long&detailed) pt. 1
To: both rave lists <nw-raves@hyperreal.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9509041913.A26668-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ahhh! I just stepped out of a nice looooong bath and for once I'm glad I 
live in Sacramento! :) (A whole hour and a half shorter driving time!)

So here is Burning Man in my experience - I'm looking forward to hearing 
about everyone's perception of the festival.

My friends Carol, Carolyn and I arrived at about 12:30 pm Saturday 
afternoon.  Driving out to the site was an adventure itsself....you are 
surrounded by nothing but the whitish grey playa of the dried up lakebed. 
We feel like we are in the middle of a Mad Max movie or something.  So we 
arrive and the place is just enormous!!  It was a little difficult finding 
our bearings. We stayed with friends of ours who were west of the main camp.  
We eventually found our way into Centeral Camp where the bulletin board was 
set up.  Sy was nice enough to post directions to exactly where their 
camp was going to be. ;) 

So we check out the main camp area while we are there. There is a radio 
station set up and all sorts of theme camps circling the area.  The most 
interesting IMO was the art cars.  The famous shark was there and the 
fin mobile and one with toys glued over every visible surface.  

So then we head out to our friends' camp to set up.  We  can see the 
rave camp from a distance; it was about a mile away from central camp.   
Our camp had a circle of RV's and vans 
and tents and my friend, dj BioJeff was spinning some wicked tunes on the 
decks they had set up.  It was posh with tarps overhead for shade and 
all kinds of lawn chairs and drinks.  The best part was the company - 
about 30 of us all just hanging out.  Many were tired from Friday 
night's raving, so we did a bit more exploring.

In the late afternoon I came back and noticed thunder and lightning in 
the distance with a HUGE dustcloud beneath the raincloud.  The thunder 
kept getting closer and the lightening more vivid.  Everyone in our 
campsite started rolling up the tarps and the turntables and soundsystem 
was put safely away.  I discovered that my tentpegs I bought were too 
big for my tent, so we put in our icechest and duffelbags inside to keep 
it from blowing away.  It had two pegs holding it in place!  Well, soon 
it started to rain and the wind picked up and we saw this wall of dust 
closing in.  Suddenly it bore down on us and it was like we went blind!  
We all scurried into the RV's and tents as the 70(?) mph wind/dust 
pummeled everything in site.  It shook the RV back and forth and we 
were all just in awe of what was happening and going HOLY SHIT as our 
quaint little campsite was being whipped around. It was over in a 
matter of 10 minutes or so and everything was pretty much okay.  My 
tent was still standing (it looked rather pathetic, though).

Looking East into camp where the storm traveled, a BEAUTIFUL full 
rainbow appeared.  It arched over the entire camp and then a second one 
appeared above it.  It was like Mother Nature showing us her powerful 
forces then showing us her beautiful gentleness afterward.  The camp 
looked truely magical at that moment. 

Okay, so that night we went to the rave camp and checked out the 
Frequency 8/SPAZ/Gateway set-up.  Wicked was set up about 1/4 mile(?) 
away and it looked like it wasn't going yet.  Meanwhile we danced to 
some really different sounding music.  It was like jungle and spanish 
salsa style mixed.  I liked hearing it because it was so different, but 
I don't think I could groove to it all night long.  So by then the 
Wicked lights came on and it looked like they were in full swing so 
Carol and I walked over and heard that steady hard beat going. Markie 
was spinning and he just fucking ROCKED!!  I even remember what time he 
really took off - it was just before 1:30. (or maybe because I was 
beginning to get ExtrEmEly happy!)  Then Garth goes on and I must say 
the first part of his set really sucked. Then some guy knocked over the 
turntables right onto Garth!  Yes, you heard me correctly.  I'm not 
sure of the entire story behind that, but someone on the list will fill 
you in. So after that, Garth was pissed and his set really took off and 
he bagan playing some faster, trancier stuff. The laser was going too, 
setting off beams of light straight out into nothing.  A few times it 
hit me, "my god, I am raving out here in the desert in the middle of 
frigging nowhere!! WHOA!!"  After Garth came Spun who did pretty good.  
Nothing stands out in my mind that was exceptional.  By then it is 7:30 
and I'm danced out.  So we head back and I fall asleep in a lounge 
chair in the early morning sun. Mmmmmm, it was heavenly!  In the quiet 
camp in the morning, the music from the rave camp traveles far, so I 
could still hear some music as I went off into dream land. 

End of part 1.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep  4 21:13:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA12844; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 21:13:52 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA12813; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 21:13:04 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu
	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA047214284; Mon, 4 Sep 1995 21:11:24 -0700
Date: Mon, 4 Sep 1995 21:11:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Amy's BM experience part 2
To: both rave lists <nw-raves@hyperreal.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9509042018.A26668-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Okay, where was I?  Oh yeah, Sunday.  It was really interesting to say 
the least.  About 10 in the morning, more lightening and clouds started 
coming our way.  Oh shit, we thought, so we began putting stuff away.  
We didn't see a dust cloud, though.  Then the rain started coming down 
and some of us frolicked in it for a bit til the lightening got a little 
too close for comfort. We scampered into the RV again just as the rain 
began coming down in torrents. This storm lasted quite a bit longer than 
the one on Saturday. We watched as puddles began to form around the tents 
and then HAIL began coming down.  It was about the size of Kix breakfast 
cereal. Finally it stopped and most of us stayed in the RV.  Brian 
McGonigle entertained us as he stomped around the campsite turning is 
Tevas into platform shoes with all the caked mud.  I finally went 
outside to squish some mud in between my toes.  It smelled like fish!  
I guess that would make sense, as the playa is a dried up lake bed!  

Then the fun began:  People everywhere were really getting into it - 
literally.  Lots -n- lots of naked folks and those with clothing 
covered themselves in it slipping and sliding away.  There was this 
Volkswagon Baja Bug that was pulling people in the mud behind it.  This 
one guy was naked and holding onto a rope as he slid on his butt!  New 
sport: mudsurfing!  I was boring and kept my clothes on and only got 
muddy up to my ankles....

An hour later me and some friends went exporing to see how the rest of 
the camp made out in the storm and to take more pictures.  Then we 
heard the powerful lure of a drum circle.  We followed the sound til we 
happened upon a huge group of about 150 people or so.  As we got 
closer, we discovered that in the center of this circle was a mud pit 
with about 30 or so naked people slithering, sliding and writhing 
together.  Combined with the incredible drumming that was going on, it 
was the most primal spectre I have ever seen in my life.  It was so 
mesmerizing and actually quite beautiful.  

At 5:30 that evening was the desert fashion show and we were lucky and 
got to be right in front to see everything.  All kinds of interesting 
couture from a little kid dressed as an eyeball to prancing drag 
queens.  Purple Tiger came out in an all (guess what color) purple 
velvet bodysuit, gloves, boots and sunglasses.  We all cheered loudly 
for him - he was magnificent! (bravo!!)

After the fashion show we went back to camp to rest up before the 
Burning of the Man.

We (Carol, Carolyn, Black Adder, Regan and I) headed over at about 8:15 
and already everything was changed!  
The entire centeral camp was gone and there were already thousands of 
people milling around in anticipation of the night's activities.  
The Man was standing in all his greatness with tubes of blue neon 
lining his legs, head, arms and ribs.  What a sight!  They "turn him 
on" :) every night, and he is like a giant blue beacon for all to 
see.  I guess they borrowed the laser from the rave camp (??) and 
it was flashing on the man and making neat patterns in the night 
sky.  We made our way to the man and were actually able to get 
toward the front so we could see everything. There was a drum 
procession going around the crowd, which surrounded the Man.  I 
couldn't believe there were that many people attending!  It looked 
like THOUSANDS!  This one guy had a jet car which was about the 
size of a small dune buggy, and boy was it LOUD!  Then we saw our 
Rasta friend, Vincent with his flame thrower.  Everyone around us  
thought he looked like one of the Ghostbusters with his orange 
protective suit and fuel harness on.  After much ceremony and just 
plain waiting around, the Man's arms were raised (great cheer from the 
crowd) and was finally lit.  The flames took awhile
to catch on, and for a moment, we were afraid the fire 
would fizzle out.  But Vincent saves the night by torching the 
Man's legs with his flame thrower. Only the left side of the man 
was doing any hard burning, the wind kept the fire from spreading 
evenly.  But it was still a spectacular sight with fireworks going 
off now and then.  Afer he burned awhile, the people began tugging 
on the giant ropes so he would fall to the ground.  They had to 
tug alot, and for a minute or two, the giant Burning Man danced!  
Poor guy only had one arm, but he was grooving just the same.  
Then he fell and the crowd rushed in to be a part of it.  We 
couldn't squeeze in, so we made our way to the Lingam sculpture, 
which was also to be burned.

Lingam is Hindi for a penis, and this sculpture was phallic in 
shape but the openings at the base and top of each "tower" looked 
like a vagina. There were lots of little penises swarming around 
each opening.  Well.  Before Sunday, you could crawl into one of 
the openings and look up into the sky.  The sculpture was pretty 
big. That night, the vaginas had been stuffed with wood and 
there were many nearly naked and totally naked painted up 
dancers who acted like little demons. It was really cool.  Then 
each opening (about 5 altogether, I think) was lit on fire.   
The smoke billowed out the tops like chimneys and once the fire 
really got going, fireworks inside were let off. It was quite 
impressive.  After burning awhile, the tallest vagina/chimney/penis 
(whatever you would call it) collapsed and it looked hella 
funny.  One guy screamed out "just give me 5 minutes!"   Then 
we went back to camp to rest a  little before dancing more. 

This is where I get boring. After such excitement during the 
last two days, raving all night and with no sleep, I was really 
exhaused. I guess I'm getting old...:( because I only made it 
til about 1:30 while Tracy was spinning.  She is a goddess on 
the turntables, I must say.  Much kudos to all you female dj's 
out there, while I'm at it! :) I'm sure someone shall fill us 
in on what I missed. 

Then we left this morning at around 10:30 or so. I was so damn 
depressed going home.  You know how you look forward to 
something for SUCH a long time and it finally arrives and the 
experiece comes and goes so quicky because it is so GOOD!  
Coming back to reality is sometimes a shock and it can be 
quite sad.  I've made a couple of posts in the past about how 
depressing it is to come back to the ugly "real world"  after 
raving.  If raving feels like a whole different planet, then 
Burning Man felt like a whole new universe.  It was an 
incredible experience I shall never forget.  I'm looking 
forward to more posts about others' experiences at Burning 
Man.  I'm sorry for taking up so much space and I hope I'm not 
being a story hog.  I figure everyone's story is going to be 
different.  I'm looking forward to reading them!

love,
Amy

|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu

anyone else here go to Basics on Saturday?
anyway, just got back to Santa Barbara after a weekend home with friends, 
and I was quite disappointed with Basics

first off, the building it was in was not noticeably ventillated unless 
you stood within 5 ft of the door to the outdoor chill area, but going 
outdoor was too cold, and indoor was too hot and stuffy, the fans that 
were indoor (once they were finally turned on) didn't help a whole heck 
of a lot..I saw a couple of people pass out because of this

my friend was pickpocketed at the rave..some money and rouhgly $125 worth 
of what he thought was exstacy, but we later learned after a friend took 
it, was probably sppe & cocaine ..not very pleasant expereicne for my 
friend, and his dayrunner is missing or stolen as well
but maybe it's just missing..his name is Shiloh, if anyone out there went 
to Basics and found a Dayrunner belonging to my friend, please e-mail me 
and I'll put you in touch with him..thanks

oh yeah, and the darn thing was $15 admission...just wasn't worth it to me
of course a couple of my other firneds made it more unpleasant for me..so 
maybe it was just them that has me in this mood

but if anyone out there who went cares to comment, please do
oh yeah, I understand Basics is a semi-regulary recurring rave..if this 
is so, have they used the same location before, the civic center in 
Concord, adjacent to the police station and municipal courts *joy*, the 
bulding just wasn't made of that many people to dance in with just a 
couple of fans circulating hot air

okay, enough from me
talk to ya later

Michael Ball                                            
u2fan@mcl.ucsb.edu

On Mon, 4 Sep 1995, Amy R Starkey wrote:

> 
> Okay, where was I?  Oh yeah, Sunday.  It was really interesting to say 
> the least.  About 10 in the morning, more lightening and clouds started 
> coming our way.  Oh shit, we thought, so we began putting stuff away.  
> We didn't see a dust cloud, though.  Then the rain started coming down 
> and some of us frolicked in it for a bit til the lightening got a little 
> too close for comfort. We scampered into the RV again just as the rain 
> began coming down in torrents. This storm lasted quite a bit longer than 
> the one on Saturday. We watched as puddles began to form around the tents 
> and then HAIL began coming down.  It was about the size of Kix breakfast 
> cereal. Finally it stopped and most of us stayed in the RV.  Brian 
> McGonigle entertained us as he stomped around the campsite turning is 
> Tevas into platform shoes with all the caked mud.  I finally went 
> outside to squish some mud in between my toes.  It smelled like fish!  
> I guess that would make sense, as the playa is a dried up lake bed!  
> 
> Then the fun began:  People everywhere were really getting into it - 
> literally.  Lots -n- lots of naked folks and those with clothing 
> covered themselves in it slipping and sliding away.  There was this 
> Volkswagon Baja Bug that was pulling people in the mud behind it.  This 
> one guy was naked and holding onto a rope as he slid on his butt!  New 
> sport: mudsurfing!  I was boring and kept my clothes on and only got 
> muddy up to my ankles....
> 
> An hour later me and some friends went exporing to see how the rest of 
> the camp made out in the storm and to take more pictures.  Then we 
> heard the powerful lure of a drum circle.  We followed the sound til we 
> happened upon a huge group of about 150 people or so.  As we got 
> closer, we discovered that in the center of this circle was a mud pit 
> with about 30 or so naked people slithering, sliding and writhing 
> together.  Combined with the incredible drumming that was going on, it 
> was the most primal spectre I have ever seen in my life.  It was so 
> mesmerizing and actually quite beautiful.  
> 
> At 5:30 that evening was the desert fashion show and we were lucky and 
> got to be right in front to see everything.  All kinds of interesting 
> couture from a little kid dressed as an eyeball to prancing drag 
> queens.  Purple Tiger came out in an all (guess what color) purple 
> velvet bodysuit, gloves, boots and sunglasses.  We all cheered loudly 
> for him - he was magnificent! (bravo!!)
> 
> After the fashion show we went back to camp to rest up before the 
> Burning of the Man.
> 
> We (Carol, Carolyn, Black Adder, Regan and I) headed over at about 8:15 
> and already everything was changed!  
> The entire centeral camp was gone and there were already thousands of 
> people milling around in anticipation of the night's activities.  
> The Man was standing in all his greatness with tubes of blue neon 
> lining his legs, head, arms and ribs.  What a sight!  They "turn him 
> on" :) every night, and he is like a giant blue beacon for all to 
> see.  I guess they borrowed the laser from the rave camp (??) and 
> it was flashing on the man and making neat patterns in the night 
> sky.  We made our way to the man and were actually able to get 
> toward the front so we could see everything. There was a drum 
> procession going around the crowd, which surrounded the Man.  I 
> couldn't believe there were that many people attending!  It looked 
> like THOUSANDS!  This one guy had a jet car which was about the 
> size of a small dune buggy, and boy was it LOUD!  Then we saw our 
> Rasta friend, Vincent with his flame thrower.  Everyone around us  
> thought he looked like one of the Ghostbusters with his orange 
> protective suit and fuel harness on.  After much ceremony and just 
> plain waiting around, the Man's arms were raised (great cheer from the 
> crowd) and was finally lit.  The flames took awhile
> to catch on, and for a moment, we were afraid the fire 
> would fizzle out.  But Vincent saves the night by torching the 
> Man's legs with his flame thrower. Only the left side of the man 
> was doing any hard burning, the wind kept the fire from spreading 
> evenly.  But it was still a spectacular sight with fireworks going 
> off now and then.  Afer he burned awhile, the people began tugging 
> on the giant ropes so he would fall to the ground.  They had to 
> tug alot, and for a minute or two, the giant Burning Man danced!  
> Poor guy only had one arm, but he was grooving just the same.  
> Then he fell and the crowd rushed in to be a part of it.  We 
> couldn't squeeze in, so we made our way to the Lingam sculpture, 
> which was also to be burned.
> 
> Lingam is Hindi for a penis, and this sculpture was phallic in 
> shape but the openings at the base and top of each "tower" looked 
> like a vagina. There were lots of little penises swarming around 
> each opening.  Well.  Before Sunday, you could crawl into one of 
> the openings and look up into the sky.  The sculpture was pretty 
> big. That night, the vaginas had been stuffed with wood and 
> there were many nearly naked and totally naked painted up 
> dancers who acted like little demons. It was really cool.  Then 
> each opening (about 5 altogether, I think) was lit on fire.   
> The smoke billowed out the tops like chimneys and once the fire 
> really got going, fireworks inside were let off. It was quite 
> impressive.  After burning awhile, the tallest vagina/chimney/penis 
> (whatever you would call it) collapsed and it looked hella 
> funny.  One guy screamed out "just give me 5 minutes!"   Then 
> we went back to camp to rest a  little before dancing more. 
> 
> This is where I get boring. After such excitement during the 
> last two days, raving all night and with no sleep, I was really 
> exhaused. I guess I'm getting old...:( because I only made it 
> til about 1:30 while Tracy was spinning.  She is a goddess on 
> the turntables, I must say.  Much kudos to all you female dj's 
> out there, while I'm at it! :) I'm sure someone shall fill us 
> in on what I missed. 
> 
> Then we left this morning at around 10:30 or so. I was so damn 
> depressed going home.  You know how you look forward to 
> something for SUCH a long time and it finally arrives and the 
> experiece comes and goes so quicky because it is so GOOD!  
> Coming back to reality is sometimes a shock and it can be 
> quite sad.  I've made a couple of posts in the past about how 
> depressing it is to come back to the ugly "real world"  after 
> raving.  If raving feels like a whole different planet, then 
> Burning Man felt like a whole new universe.  It was an 
> incredible experience I shall never forget.  I'm looking 
> forward to more posts about others' experiences at Burning 
> Man.  I'm sorry for taking up so much space and I hope I'm not 
> being a story hog.  I figure everyone's story is going to be 
> different.  I'm looking forward to reading them!
    I give you many thanks for your *descriptive* post. I couldn't of 
said it better:). Once I stop telling my futon how much I love it 
and get some sleep, I will post all about my adventures in "Mudsville".
Have a good night sleep all. I l0ve youuuuuuu!
                          Sending Hugs Galorreee,
                           Reagan


> 
> love,
> Amy           
>

> |     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu

From: Jonathan Mark Logan <gonzo@leland.Stanford.EDU>

Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950905121752.25736A-100000@elaine43.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

			
	
	Hmmmmm.......... Burning Man.  Now that I've slept and showered 
and gotten a stranglehold on reality again, I can wax nostalgiac about 
the cool weekend I had.  Amy's post pretty much covered the bulk of the 
details regarding the setting, the events, the happy atmosphere, and all 
the unabashed, creative weirdness.  I will thus spare you the bandwidth 
and just detail the highlights of my experience (great post BTW, Amy).
	My posse arrived at the site late Saturday afternoon.  Since 
there were a couple of non-ravers with us, we decided to stay at the main 
camp.  This was a good thing, cuz I got to see a lot of main camp stuff 
which I might otherwise have missed if I had raved nonstop.  It was also bad 
cuz I didn't find the SFRaves camp until Monday morning, just before I left--
aaaar!
	We went over to check out SPAZ and Wicked around 10:30 pm, but it 
had just rained, so nothing was going on.  That was a poopah.  So we went 
back to main camp and checked out a drum circle around a bonfire, where 
people were randomly burning things (like their clothes) and dancing around, 
hooting and grooving.  We watched firebreathers, dancers, nekked 
people, and marveled at the sights.
	My good friend Ain and I returned to the 
rave camp at around 1 am, where Wicked was going off in a major way. 
SPAZ, with its trancier sets, was pretty poorly attended, but nonetheless 
cool (I'm a guy who prefers hard trance to deep house anyday, but I also 
thrive on the energy and vibe of a really big crowd.  So, as much as I 
liked the tunes at SPAZ, the crowd at Wicked drew me in).  Unfortunately, 
Ain and I were so kaput from the day's drive that we just couldn't hold out 
for dancing that night.  We went back and slept to gain energy for an 
allnighter on Sunday.
	The next night, Burning Man burned, the lingum ejaculated fire (some of 
which 
landed on me and burned big holes in my shirt), and the whole tribal 
experience took off to the cosmos.  After many hours of primal catharsis, 
we headed for the rave camp to celebrate the fiery death of our fettered 
old souls and the phoenix-like rebirth of our new, free spirits.  Or, at 
least, that's what was supposed to have happened.  Whatever.  We had a 
blast, dancing like fools and meeting new, great people.  Except for the 
chilling cold of the morning, there was nothing to complain about.  In 
all, a fantastic, epiphanous experience.
	Oh, before I forget, here's a list of the most memorable events 
of the weekend:


	-Squishing my toes around in the mud after the mega storm on Sunday
	-The cute S&M couple, all decked out in leather, genital rings, 
	 a leash, and the submissive male of the pair, who was not 
	 allowed to pee unless he had permission from his mistress (she 
	 whipped him when he accidentally dribbled on her boots)
	-All the cool cars
	-Free exchange of drugs right in the middle of the main camp,
	 without shifty glances or nervous mistrust
	-Meeting Mutt&Jeff (Vince and Wayne) at the bonfire by Wicked 
	 around 5:30 am Sunday night/Monday morning, where I _finally_ got 
	 an SFR badge and HUGE hugs from those two great guys!  Thanks a lot!
	 The hugs were enough to stave off the desert cold until sunrise
	-Watching the sun rise over a 400 square mile expanse of flat, 
	 featureless, pristine nothingness	
	-Meeting Carolyn (was that your name? I asked you about three times), 
	 my first SFRaver of the weekend.  We talked at the porta potty about
	 Wicked, raving politics, the foul odor of the SaniHut temple, 
	 and other stuff for quite a while.  It made me mega happy.  
	 (To Carolyn (if that's your name): Thanks for the friendship.  
	 In case you remember me--I was the one who gave you starbursts at the 
	 porta potties, was wearing the shirt with the smiley, and who asked
	 you about women DJs in SF--drop me an email!  We can hook
	 up at a party again, where I can give you some more of whatever candy
	 I'm eating that's about to make me puke, and you can introduce me
	 to more SFravers!).
	-Leaving the playa on Monday morning, driving like madmen, following
	 a caravan of cars, each not knowing
	 where they're going, each hoping that the highway (and not a muddy 
	 demise) is somewhere out there, hidden in the middle of nothing



		Until next year (or the next party),

				jon

From: scarmike@tmn.com (Seth Carmichael)
Subject: I'm Burnt Man
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        So I'm back at work catching up on all the things I should have
done between Wednesday evening and today. Got home last night around
midnight from what was certainly one of the most amazing experiences of my
life. I only had 265 e-mail messages to wade through. I still haven't
touched most of them, but I managed to get up and be at work by 8:30, right
on time.
        What can I say about the Man? Well if you weren't there then you
missed the best party there has ever been. You can try and go next year,
but it will be all commercialized and full of the frat boy kids that I ran
into at the main camp a couple of times. Nope, you'll never get to be at
Burning Man '95, she shall go down in history.
        I have been trying to get the words stright enough to describe the
experience to people and it just isn't working, it was really beyond words.
Religious, or just plain spiritual is the best I can come up with. The
combination of all types of wheather, all types of amazing and interesting
people and spectacular music all out there on that new planet we colonized
for a few days leaving behind everything familiar. Well, I'll sit down a
write out all the events as I saw them later, but for now I hope those who
were not able to make recieve all the energy that this experience invokes
in me and I say next year go, no matter where you are or what you are doing
leave it, cause it will still be worth it.
        I've done a lot of crazy shit before, been a lot of places and had
some amazing experiences from the hills of Scotland to the Gobi desert of
Mongolia, but there is nothing on Earth like Burning Man. Peace, love, hugs
and all the happy shit eating grins you can get out of life.
                -Seth

P.S.- To those of you who were there I wish I had met more of ya. I was the
kid that did the sunrise ritual at the end of Garth's set and well into
Spun's....I don't talk much, but I love you cats anyhow. Vince, Jim and
Wayne you guys are the shit. Keep droping till you pop.

*Seth D. Carmichael(scarmike@tmn.com)*
*Global Business Network*
*PO Box 8395 Emeryville, CA 94662*
*510.547.6822 **510.547.8510 FAX*



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep  5 17:35:06 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA24856; Tue, 5 Sep 1995 17:35:06 -0700

	id RAA04301; Tue, 5 Sep 1995 17:31:12 -0700
Date: Tue, 5 Sep 1995 17:31:12 -0700
Message-Id: <199509060031.RAA04301@ix9.ix.netcom.com>
From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: Reflections on the now burnt man...
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk


There's no doubt going to be a spate of messages like this - so
I'll try and keep this one on the short side. Yes, this is about
the Burning Man.

Lavonne, Diane, Niels, Rob and I travelled drove down to Reno, got
ourself a Recrational Vehicle and set off for the Burning Man. Before
we began the arrangements for this trip, we never really knew each
other (I'd never met any of the people I travelled with) - now we 
do - thanks to the four of you for making the trip what it was.

Anyway, the journey down was fun, if uneventful - watching the land
change, from city to hills, mountains, desert was spectacular; the
differences (not just scenic) as you travel the few hundred miles 
are incredible. Finally you reach the Playa, and you're not in 
Kansas any more - Black Rock is other-worldly, massive, and
overwhelming. 

At the camp, our RV was part of the WBL circle - we were a late 
arrival to the group, and I didn't really feel part of the grand
scheme of things there. Still, what they did was wonderful; the 
parachute was tied, the trampoline set. After everything was in
place it was a space to be proud of. All involved must have put a 
lot of work into making things happen, it really showed. 

Now I'll stop with the chronological order, and jump around the 
weekend, and my feelings about it - I still need to think through
a lot of the things that happened the last few days, but I'd like
to get things written down before they go stale. 

Both the (major) sound systems at the event did a fine job - good 
setup, good music. Saturday night was the only time I feel that I,
and the party, truly went off. On Saturday, I got taken up, whirled
around, and I'll probably land again some time next week. Wicked
palyed some of the best music I've heard; the crowd went off, and
when the sun came up, and the crowd thinned I headed back to the
RV after having one of the better nights in my life.

The only unsettling thing about the Rave camp, were the rumors of 
animosity between the two crews - no idea what actually happened,
if anything. Hopefully it wasn't a big deal.

But what made the weekend different, more than another party, and
something truly different. I think its hard to pin this down. It
may be the environment. When the lightning struck, and you stood
out on playa laughing at the rain, feeling the static crackling 
up your arms, you felt close to something - a moment of being truly
alive. It may be the freedom, suddenly your in a place where you 
can 'be' without any of the restrictions of society. It may have
been the people, a bigger collection of the freakier side of 
humanity it would be hard to find. Its probably all of the above
and so much more. 

The Burning Man was true experience - good and bad, it brought 
things out I've been having problems with, making me deal with 
emotions I've been bottling up. I feel different today than I did
before leaving on Friday. After a while, everyday reality is 
going to wear down the glow I have from this experience, but
hopefully I'll be able to pull something from this that I can 
carry for a while.

Anyway, I'll wrap this up. Thanks to everyone who attended, everyone who 
was involved. Thanks in particular to the people I travelled with, a 
truly fine bunch,

Same again next year,
Gary

Magnificent, rough, beautiful, scary, crazy, funny, erotic, HOT, DUSTY, 
and perfect chaos!

Thanks Neils for the plastic-ware!  

I witnessed th most intense storm ever.  Double rainbows, lightening that 
seemed feet away, thunder that made you whoop and scream in reply, and 
wind that reduced campsites to piles of nylon and mud.  Welcome mamma nature!

Aaahhhh...the silky muddy hot-springs. 

I found the dirt and the sweat to become sensual and sacred after futile 
attempts to clean off.  Comfort zone has been pushed to new limits :)

Wow!  

Melissa

Hey all...

Here is a post from the Burning Man mailing list....and my reply.  It is

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 5 Sep 1995 21:13:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
To: { brad brace } <bbrace@netcom.com>
Cc: Paul Godwin <godwin@SIRIUS.COM>, burnman-list@well.com
Subject: Re: comparisons



> This was the first year that I actually made the trip. I had the
> impression that an earlier sense of temporal-community was being eroded by
> the transformation of BM into a rave of techno-pagans. Is that a fair
> assessment/guess? 

No, I don't think this is a fair assessment/guess.  I am a raver and this 
is my first time at Burning Man, also.  We ravers have been looking 
forward to Burning Man for such a long time....we are very spiritual 
open minded people who wanted more than just a "rave in the desert."  I 
can't speak for all ravers who attended, but I thoroughly appreciated 
the diversity that Burning Man brought. I learned alot about other 
people, other cultures, different music and different mindsets. BM is a 
learning experience not just for the ravers, but for the non-ravers who 
came out to the camp and experience our community.  On the mailing list, 
sfraves, those who went talk on and on about how much they learned, 
experienced and appreciated Burning Man.  We felt a unity there with 
EVERYONE, not just ravers.  I was hoping that the non-ravers at Burning 
Man would maybe learn something from us as well.  I don't think we 
"eroded" anything, we have added to the richness and diversity that IS 
the Burning Man project. 

On the topic of BM becoming too popular:  I'm glad I had the opportunity 
to go this year before it becomes what one person described as "10,000 
people with  3 day MTV coverage."  I'll still go again next year, but I 
won't expect it to be like it was this year.  As a raver, we have dealt 
with the same issues of the discomfort of change, so I can totally 
relate to those who maybe don't like presence of more people and more 
"techno-pagans".  I always say that the only constant IS change. 
That's just my 2 cents for the evening. 

namaste,
Amy

WOW.

What an incredible weekend. I just finally got home with all my bits and
pieces. (long story, I'll tell it later) I will probably put together a web
page with my whole long adventure as well as Wayne, Rusty, and Chris'
stories, with tons of pictures. but for now I just want to say a few of the
really high points. The feelings I had at and after the event, more than
the specific details. I could not believe how wonderful all the SFRavers
were, this is one hell of a group. Besides the incredible nights of
dancing, the time we spent during the days together, was just awesome.
Cruzing around the city, going to the hot springs, playing in the mud. Just
too cool. I'm glad everyone enjoyed the laminates, and I'm not stopping
until everyone of us has one. The hugs and thanks and love I felt from each
and every one of you, as a result of finally meeting one another was just
great, I can not express how I felt in words, but I still get goose bumps,
and kinda choked up, when I read your posts, or think back on it. It made
the work on the laminates worth it about 100 times over. Maybe 1000 times
over.

Thanks so much to all my new friends (at least new to the eyes, olds
friends to my keyboard and my heart).

BTW, I'm leaving town again in the AM for the other end of Nevada and will
be gone thru the weekend , so I will miss all your beautiful and smiling
faces this week. I will look forward to seeing all of you soon after that.

For all of you that I didn't see there, (and you out of towners), if you
want to send me an SASE, I will mail you back a laminate, or else look for
me at future parties, as I will always keep a supply on hand !!!!

Love you all,


Vince.
PO Box 576
Napa, CA 94559





The Happy Rasta Raver

Maui-YSH <ysh@netcom.com>:
> it didn't seem cool to me. Definitely caught the whiff 
> of thievery, and of that peculiar fear stench that only the most insecure 
> of young males displays as bravado.

Of course, young females *never* display their insecurity through some
ruse. And society hasn't programmed such predefined roles for women
that are just as offensive as male displays of bravado. (And simians
will take flight from my posterior regions.)

Look, dogs will sniff each others butts, and people will do equally
silly-seeming acts in their own domain of action. Men will continue to
try defining themselves through social measures such as "bravado",
women through social measures of sexiness and good looks. And dogs will
continue to sniff and be sniffed.

It's hard to know where human nature leaves off and years of social
programming begins (e.g. Barbie versus GI Joe) in this elaborate mating
ritual we call life. I don't think it's fair to completely fault "men"
for their programming, 'cause when you look in the mirror, chances are
you'll see the results of going with (or against) that self same
programming for your own gender. Just deal with it, try to recognize
it, and move beyond divisive male/female fingerpointing.

      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 02:18:44 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA11457; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 02:18:44 -0700
Received: from netcom18.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA11449; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 02:18:40 -0700
Received: from localhost by netcom18.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id CAA17338; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 02:15:43 -0700
Message-Id: <199509060915.CAA17338@netcom18.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: A Wicked Burning Man
Date: Wed, 06 Sep 95 02:15:43 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Was definitely way cool. Although the burning man, performances, etc
were great fun, my favorite parts was staying up all night Saturday and
Sunday raving at the Wicked system. On monday morning, Garth was out on
the dancefloor and I couldn't help but tell him "Your set on saturday
night ripped me a new brain!" Markie and Spun gave me a good
trepannation, power tools courtesy of the purple people pusher.

Saturday night was powerful, weird, trippy, shamanic. I finally think I
figured out why almost everybody that I talked to thought Saturday was
so twisted -- Electric charges building up tension as a storm gathered,
then the release as the storm shot it's proverbial load, followed by
the transcendence of a clear and electrically neutral sky popping our
brains open, exposing a single huge, new, blinking eye staring straight
into the hearts of space. You really feel directly exposed to the
universe out there in the middle of nothing, a dry ancient lake bed --
doing like Jimi Hendrix says "watching the sunrise from the bottom of
the sea" ...
 
I was talking to a woman who mentioned that during the storm build-up
she raised her arms in the air with someone else and a spark passed
between their fingers. There was a literal charge going on out there. I
believe those physical effects boosted A wide variety of
AlreAdy-Altered experiences into new reAlms -- the brain's functioning
is, after all primarlily electro/magnetic. This accounts, for example,
for a certain long-time member of this list claiming the feeling that
some kind of Alien contact had gone on that night.  I personally
thought it wasn't Aliens, we just happened to be lucky enough  to be
exposed to the vibe of spAce itself -- and spAce vibe isn't human!

Perhaps electricity accounts for the person seemingly possessed by the
DJs, continuously harassing them, knocking the needle off the
turntable, and finally jumping towards Garth knocking both turntables
into his arms. Perhaps the Kook thought he was Don Quixote; a valiant
knight tilting at turntables instead of windmills. Even more surreal,
in the silence that happened after knocking over the turntables, people
were wrestling the kook away from the dance-floor and some cut-down
hippie just had to get into the guys face gripping his collar and
*shouting* "do you realize what you've done, you've just killed the
vibe!!!" over and over again. THis just seemed completely ironic at the
time, I imagined that the hippie  sounded just like the teacher in
"Peanuts" to the Kook, not exactly a PLUR way of dealing with 
psychosis, IMHO.

Oh, and Kudos to Geoff White and Moonpup for handling this intense
situation with aplomb.

After this spark of crazed randomness, Garth just harnessed the
increasing tension/charge in the air. The kook caused us to race
downwards on our emotional rollercoaster and garth took advantage of
our velocity to boost us back into the stratosphere when he kicked in
that very appropriate song "Get your feet back on the ground" (who duz
that tune anyways?) song... The roller coaster sped downwards again
when out of nowhere, clouds and a massive storm caused a sudden
downpour -- the crowd near the  stage without any instruction or order
(like a thousand ants gathering food) managed to get a big tarp over
the DJ booth and the party continued without a hitch. THere was an
incredible feeling of vibe and community as people huddled under the
tarp near the DJ booth, arms outstreched to hold up the tarp, fingers
pulsing to keep pools of water from forming and dripping on the DJ.

And then the incredible elation of the crowd as the storm passed  just
as quickly as it arrived, leaving a completely clear and starry sky.
Some of us wondered whether the storm had actually happened at all,
because everything seemed relatively still and calm and beautiful;
within no time at all, there wasn't even a trace of water/mud around...

I could go on, but I won't bore you... lets just say that Saturday
night into Sunday morning was definitely the best Wicked I've ever
attended, far better than any full moon i've attended, perhaps even the
best rave I've attended. Sunday was great as well, on par with some of
the best FMRs (unfortunately, it wasn't as well attended as Saturday's
party, perhaps because a lot of people were beat from burning the man).

PS: what's that song that Garth played -- very dark -- with some guy
with a gravelly low, evil-sounding voice saying stuff like "you are
mine, my children, hahahaha". This caused Gary Burns to walk up to me
and in his scottish brogue proclaim,  "This is the most evil, evil song
I've ever heard". It was evil, and cool too. SO what's the name and who
duzzit?

PPS: Hi and thanks to RV mates Diane T, Gary B, Lavonne W, and Rob O!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 03:38:50 1995

Subject: Re: Burning Man, Let hear all. (reiterated) 
Message-ID: <Pine.OSF.3.91.950906032940.16328A-100000@pogonip.scs.unr.edu>

I thought for a bit about what I wrote earlier and felt like I had to 
explain myself. So here we go.
Have you ever had a dream that was so real and so intense that you 
couldn't really put it into words or write about it, but instead just 
held it in the back of your mind, lurking, for quite a while?
That was Burning Man, except it was *real*. Right after I got back I was
talking to someone and she asked me why I thought people went. I mumbled
some stuff about releasing creative energy and about getting reconnected
and balanced with the universe.  She just nodded and said that everyone
went for different reasons, and that those reasons ended up being the
basis for their experience.  Ironically, right as she she said this I
realized I went for one reason: Because I felt I was supposed to be there.

I tried to explain this to one of my friends before I left. She couldn't 
understand why I would want to go spend three days in the desert with 
people I had never met before. 
A big part of this experience is letting go of your comfort zones. Comfort
zones are things you are so attached to that they hinder your leap to your
next level of being. They can be material, people, places, anything. Once
you remove these comfort zones (which I guess can include your daily
facade) you get down to who you really are. And when you're surrounded by
a bunch of people who are getting down to who they really are, it can be
quite an experience. :)

In the words of Kurt Vaughnagan, "We are who we pretend to be, so we 
better be damn sure who we're pretending to be."

I think this whole weekend shook the foundations of a lot of people, and, 
if nothing else, "It was one hell of a party." :)
						      lv, Alex

      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------

Saturday night's Wicked at Burning Man was above and beyond the best rave 
I've ever been to, or heard of for that matter.
Interesting. Notice the word "rave" instead of "party". 
I did some thinking on the drive back about how people have switched to 
calling them "parties" instead of "raves". Sure, a party is more socially 
acceptable to those who aren't familiar with the idea of raving, but 
doesn't the connotations of the word kind of fit in with the change that 
most of us have noticed/commented on over the past year or so?
Raving incorporates a lot more meaning than partying does.
Partying is going out, getting fucked up (or not) and having fun.
Raving is all of that, and more. It's about finding yourself and 
perhaps others in the process. It's about the vibe. About PLUR. About 
energy. About letting it all go and just DANCING!!! 
A whole lot in one little word. In my own opinion, anyway. 
I'm curious if anyone else sees any relation. Comments?
							 lv, Alex


      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------

                    Groovy now that I've regained some natural reality again,
     I can spill my heart out about my BM experience. First I have to say 
that this has to be the best time of my life by far:). Not only did I 
meet alot more of you Beautiful SF ravers( thanks a bunjch to Vince and 
Wayne) but I meet soo many others that really didn't have a whole lot to 
do with the Rave scene, which broadened the whole experience:). Black 
Adder, Micheal "E." Clay & I arrived on the playa @ 5-6 P.m Saturday 
after going through one hell of a rain storm which gave way to a lovely 
double rainbow! After making it to the main camp after much troubl with 
that piece of shit bike:(, I begin to slowly melt into the community that 
would be ours for the next 3 days. A wave of emotion washed over me as 
tears of genuine joy and relief ran over my face. It was overwelming to 
see all of these people just having the times of their lives, running 
about like little chilrdren on their desert playground. I saw many sights 
that could out do the 7 wonders like that shark-shaped car and the bunny- 
motorcycle. We arrived at the Rave camp were we set up camp. Even though 
the camp was a bit away from all the action in the main I definately felt 
more settled and safe there. 
         One of the things I had been hearing about over and over again 
was the awesome hot springs which I was finally able to get to On Sunday 
morning. Holly shit!.they were  Heaven:):):). with some kind of funky 
smell to em'. That nite came the long awaited burn of the man. As people 
chanted the infamous " Burn the fucking man" a huge circle of tribal 
cladded people danced around the blue and pink neon man. At laast the 
moment came as you could feel a sheer sense of excitement and unity 
ripping through the crowd to bring the man to his knees. Due to the weird 
direction of the wind the right arm and side just wouldn't burn that is 
until Vince and his trusty flame - thrower finished of the job. Everyone 
went completely bizerk. Oh it was sooo fucking awesome!!! Then I beleive 
the man's Phallics(right?) were but to ashes.
          Soon our little group retired back to the Rave camp where some 
of us snoozed and some tore it up over at Wicked and Gateway. I did hear 
of a little tension between the two groups; but thought that both had 
ALOT to give to us Dancing fools. I spent most of my time over at Wicked.
Garth did an incredible job:). I wasn't there for the falling of the 
turntables; was that some wacky part of the festivities?:). I was 
energized for hours and hours. I got to meet the PURRFECT Purple Tiger. 
AHHH you cute Dear!!!
          AHHH shit I see that I am staring to run out of time and I 
din't want to take up to much more room here. I could write a book on 
what I went through at BM, I'll just save that for later! Before I went 
to Bm, I was dealing with  a few personal issues that after BM I feel 
that I have truly and realisticly come to terms with. I tell you it is 
going to take a *LONG* TIME for this glow to go away. I feel more at 
peace with myself now. I'll definately go again next year. Whether it 
will be "better" or not then; I'll never forget this whole 
thing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
                        Much love to all of you guys and gals.
                        See ya all soon
                        Hugs Galoooreeeee,
                        Reagan

  Hey guys.. I know this isn't rave related, but it's interesting.
As many of you know, the "Church of Scientology" is attempting to
control information on it that former members have exposed and
posted to Usenet.Their campaign has included threats and siezures
of peoples computer equipment.. (they claim their mind-control
techniques are "trade secrets") Here is a press release I read on
com-priv. There is a web page at http://www.xs4all.nl/~fonss that still has
a lot of information on the struggle on it.. It makes interesting
reading.

------ Forwarded Message
---------- Forwarded message ----------
>>Date: Tue, 5 Sep 1995 23:09:55 +0200 (MET DST)
>>From: announce <announce@xs4all.nl>
>>To: cypherpunks@toad.com
>>Subject: Scientology and police visit XS4ALL Amsterdam


>>From: XS4ALL Internet
      Postbus 22864
      1100 DJ  Amsterdam
      tel: +31 20 6222885
      fax: +31 20 6222753


        PRESS RELEASE
        -------------


    Police and members of Scientology church enter offices of XS4ALL
    ================================================================

Amsterdam - thuesday september 5, 1995.

Today at about 14:00, XS4ALL was visited by Mr. S. Braan,
bailiff. He was acting on behalf of the Religious
Technology Centre, better known as the Scientology Church, or
Scientology for short. He was assisted by a local police officer and Mr.
Hermans from the 'Nauta-Dutilh' legal firm that represents Scientology
in The Netherlands. Also present were two computer experts (Mr. Ootjes
and Mr. Van Suchtelen) a locksmith (to enter had we not been present) and
two American employees of Scientology, Mr. Weightman and Ms. Jenssen.

Scientology is filing for seizure of XS4ALL's computer equipment. Under
dutch law, this means that a bailiff comes in to record your assets. In
real-life, the computer-experts that were present have recorded the
types and serial numbers of all the computers in our offices. They did
not take any equipment, the continuity of XS4ALL's services is not in
jeopardy.


What is this all about?
-----------------------

The Scientology Church claims that the XS4ALL anonymous remailer was used
to disseminate documents over the Internet to which the church holds the
legal copyright. This has led the church to ask the president of the
district court of Amsterdam to grant permission for this seizure as a
prelude to legal procedures concerning damages suffered by the church.
The remailer in question has been disabled more than 2 months ago.

During the visit of Scientology to XS4ALL this afternoon, the remailer
was not the subject of any conversation. The organisation seemed totally
preoccupied with the information about Scientology that one of our users
has put on his home page. Part of this information is said to be a file
to which Scientology holds the copyright. If we were to delete the file
in question on the spot, they were willing to drop the seizure.


Responsability of Internet Providers
------------------------------------

XS4ALL categorically denies any responsability for contents of users'
homepages. The users decide for themselves what is on their homepage.
Since XS4ALL does not edit the homepages and has no mechanism of
control over the contents we strongly feel that the users themselves are
responsible for what they say on their homepage.

This whole affair demonstrates the need for clarity concerning the legal
postion of Internet Providers. We are shocked that our offices can be
invaded bij freshly flown-in U.S. cult members. If we as Internet
providers are held responsible for what our users say, that will
undoubtebly kill freedom of speech on the net.


Scare-tactics
-------------

XS4ALL is not alone in receiving this kind of attention from
Scientology. Scientology, a semi-religious multinational, is at war with
a number of people on the Internet. A non-organized group of people on
the net has started to openly discuss the activities of the church.
Until recently, the church has always managed to supress critical voices
by means of sheer intimidation and by engaging in endless legal battle.

One of the people that Scientology has a problem with is 'fonss', an
XS4ALL user that publishes the F.A.C.T.-net Kit on his home page
(http://www.xs4all.nl/~fonss). This kit (which can be found on numerous
homepages all over the Internet) consists of a large number of documents
that show the true face of Scientology.

One of these documents is a piece to which Scientology supposedly holds
the copyright and which has been added to the kit without the church's
permission.



Additional information can be found on the Internet:

http://www.cybercom.net/~rnewman/scientology/home.html
http://www.xs4all.nl/~fonss
news:alt.religion.scientology
news:alt.censorship
news:alt.clearing.technology




------ End of Forwarded Message

> Interesting. Notice the word "rave" instead of "party". 
> I did some thinking on the drive back about how people have switched to 
> calling them "parties" instead of "raves". Sure, a party is more socially 
> acceptable to those who aren't familiar with the idea of raving, but 
> doesn't the connotations of the word kind of fit in with the change that 
> most of us have noticed/commented on over the past year or so?
> Raving incorporates a lot more meaning than partying does.
> Partying is going out, getting fucked up (or not) and having fun.
> Raving is all of that, and more. It's about finding yourself and 
> perhaps others in the process. It's about the vibe. About PLUR. About 
> energy. About letting it all go and just DANCING!!! 

unfortunately, although 'raving' connotates that to you and me it has 
come to mean different things for people. i use the word 'parties'. 
because 'raves' is a bastardized word. and the connotation of 'raves' for 
some people (most people who aren't into raving and yet have heard of 
them) 'raves' = getting fucked on drugs. alot of people thought this at 
first, and it wasn't true. then alot of new ravers came into the scene 
(keep in mind, now i'm talking east coast, which is where i'm from. there 
are paralells between scenes but i'm speaking from my own experience) who 
heard 'raves' = getting fucked on drugs and made it true. in alot of 
cases (see our Baltimore discussion from last week) 'raves' now = getting 
fucked on drugs. people who originally went to raves for their own good 
consciousness-expanding/enlightened reasons saw the negative pr 'raves' 
were getting and dropped the word. too many negative connotations to 
bother with. i hope all this makes sense - nowadays I reserve 'raves' for 
very special parties that have that certain vibe and feel and look and 
sound...Friends and Family is a *rave*...most everything else i've been 
to in the past year have been just parties, unfortunately.

mikebee

hiya :)

The experience of Burning Man evokes a bastardization of a Ram Dass quote:

"To those of us that experienced it, no explanation is necessary..
 To those of us that didn't, none is possibe..."

>From last year I remember that it took at least a week to *process* the
experience before I could attempt to describe the intangibles within 
Burning Man. This year I assumed that it should be easier. In fact, it's
more difficult as both events have melted into one, even greater wonder.

To those of us that shared the experience... be still, and know.

love to all

hugz :)

At 02:15 AM 9/6/95 -0700, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>
>were great fun, my favorite parts was staying up all night Saturday and
>Sunday raving at the Wicked system. On monday morning, Garth was out on

Agreed.  The music, the vibe, and of course, the SOUND...all were
incredible.  I can honestly say that Wicked's presence was half the reason I
attended, and I wasn't dissapointed in the least...

>so twisted -- Electric charges building up tension as a storm gathered,
>then the release as the storm shot it's proverbial load, followed by

Dancing in the desert Saturday night with all those ppl, surrounded by
lightning was perhaps the most intense experience I've ever had.  I'm still
having trouble actually finding the words to describe it.

Many, many thanks to the Wicked crew for putting on such a show, and also
the other DJs like Jane, Spooky, Spun, Tracy, etc. who also delivered great
sets.  Thanx especially to Markie for not giving in Monday morning and
keeping the music going, despite the complaints of one man - what did the
newsletter say? "If your need for quiet is absolute, bring earplugs."  Next
time, we'll have to devise a way to keep the unwanted away from the system,
so they don't lift the needle off the record like they did to Spun or pull
various plugs...

Jim
