Subject: burnt
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 6 Sep 1995 14:52:27 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3670      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This was the fourth year I've come to the Burning Man.

It's been strange to watch it change.  The first year I came, there
were about 3-400 people, and the concept of everyone having a meeting
to figure out what was going to happen still worked.  Everyone helped
raise the Man, and everyone sort of knew each other.  The "rave" was
some people with two DAT players and a sound system.

The ritual of the burning was central; there was very little else
of any scale happening.

Over the years, it has roughly doubled in size each year, and the 
manifestations of chaos have grown quickly.  More people, doing more
stuff, and the character has changed.  It is still a TAZ of tremendous
magnitude, but the burning is almost anticlimactic, just another
spectacle amidst the crowds of Bud-swilling jocks who don't understand
why people who aren't 300 pounds and carrying a nightstick get to tell
them to move out of the way or they'll get killed by an M-100.

The Burning Man is an amazing thing, as always, but I miss what it was.
I miss being able to dance madly around the fire without needing security
to keep the crowds from trampling each other into the ashes.  I miss
the feeling of community, where the organizers don't have to spend all
their time worrying about people injuring themselves or others.  I miss
not seeing Nevada police on the playa.  Most of all, I miss that sense
of unity and purpose, where the Man burns for all of us and not just as
another distraction for the beer-swillers wandering around looking
for "nekkid chicks".  It was beautiful, and I miss it.  I'm not even sure
I'll go next year.

OTOH, it is still a beautiful experience for a lot of people, and I can't
think of anything that can be done differently (except having less bad bands
on center stage and bringing back the "No Spectators" sign).  Everything
good eventually gets overrun by consumers; enjoy it while you can and don't
be a passive consumer yourself.  I'm glad it's as cool for people now as it
used to be for me.

PS:  There is great antipathy amongst the organizers for the rave camps; 
evidently a lot of people tried to get in without paying, claim that they
were "setting up the sound system", etc. in much greater numbers than the
rest of the populace.  $40 seems like a lot, but _each_ porta-potty is about
$100 _a day_ (x 3 days, x at least 40 of them, you do the math), there are 
BLM land use fees, *insurance*, and The Man (materials
alone run several thousand).  BM has _never_ made money, and that's including
the fact that no one is paid for their time constructing, planning, cleaning
up, or anything else.  They have turned down many offers of corporate
sponsorship (from Bud, etc.) in order to maintain integrity in the face
of lack of cash.  It looks bad when people in an big and obviously rented
vehicle claim they can't come up with money.  (Note: I don't know who
this was, or care: I just know it happened.)
	The second problem they have stems from, yes, the noise.  Even being
2/3 of a mile away doesn't make much difference to the Purple People Pusher,
and they feel that one small group having such a huge impact on the sound-
scape of the festival, especially all night, is out of balance with the rest
of the performances, installations, and other events.  There is serious talk
about not sanctioning a rave camp at all next year, in which case I would 
suggest Wicked/SPAZ/whoever do their own event out there.  It sounds like
most people spent most of their time at the rave camp anyway, and it would
certainly save $ for the attendees.

I do not necessarily share these views, but I think people should know
about what's up and why.

// g

> ==================	KFJC Summer Chill!!	=======================
> 
> DJ's Mr. Goodwrench, Ronnie Libido, and Fitz Ludlow will be spinning the best
> of the above genres, plus you'll get plenty of cool videos and lighting
> effects. All of the DJ's have selected some very unique music to create a
> special mix of sounds for this event.
> 
> There will definately be music with beats, but there will also be drones, 
> weird electronic sounds, and maybe some spoken word; in short, music for your
> head. Regulars at the Gardening Club will be somewhat familiar with the style
> of sounds we will play. If you have ever been to this most righteous club in
> S.F., or want to find out what it's like without going up to the city, come on
> down!
> 
> This all happens at the Foothill College campus in room F12 which is in Los
> Altos Hills. The date is Saturday September 9,1995 starting at 8PM. Admission
> is $5 with a $2 discount if you bring a bean bag chair or throw pillow to kick
> back on.
> 
> Directions: Take highway 280 South from San Fransisco. Take the El Monte Road
> exit west. Follow the signs to room F12. From San Jose, take 280 North and
> take the El Monte Road exit West. Follow the sign to room F12.
> 
> The proceeds benefit radio station KFJC 89.7FM. The above DJ's have regular
> air-shifts on this local radio station and regularly play the types of music
> listed above.
> 
> For more info check out:     http://www.cygnus.com/kfjc/
> 
> I definately hope to see people come out and support the ambient scene and
> alternative radio.
> 
> 
>

> 
> 
> This was the fourth year I've come to the Burning Man.
> 
> It's been strange to watch it change.  The first year I came, there
> were about 3-400 people, and the concept of everyone having a meeting
> to figure out what was going to happen still worked.  Everyone helped
> raise the Man, and everyone sort of knew each other.  The "rave" was
> some people with two DAT players and a sound system.
> 
> The ritual of the burning was central; there was very little else
> of any scale happening.
> 
> Over the years, it has roughly doubled in size each year, and the 
> manifestations of chaos have grown quickly.  More people, doing more
> stuff, and the character has changed.  It is still a TAZ of tremendous
> magnitude, but the burning is almost anticlimactic, just another
> spectacle amidst the crowds of Bud-swilling jocks who don't understand
> why people who aren't 300 pounds and carrying a nightstick get to tell
> them to move out of the way or they'll get killed by an M-100.

Funny...I read a post here on SFRaves that stated, and I paraphrase"...if 
you didn't make it to bm this year then you're outta luck...next year 
it'll be full of [stereotype here] and all commercialized..."  what 
struck me about this persons statement was that it was probably HIS first 
burning man, and probably never thought how the bm pioneers might look at 
he/she being new, or how the scene had changed for a bm pioneer.  Just 
shortsighted I guess.  In any case, sad but true g-man, things change, as 
do times.  What was once intimate is now overexposed, what was a family 
is now a loose coly connected community.  I don't know what the cure is 
other than some form of elitist behaviour.  SHort of that, Bud & Miller 
Lite will probably have the last sya, that is, if MTV doesn't do one next 
year.

I am sorry I didn't get a chance to go, but as the stories, both good and 
bad filter in, I know I had a good time staying here in SF for that 
weekend.  I am thankful though, that ALL of my friends had a good time 
(those who went anyway), and most importantly, they came back alive.

BM next year?  I dunno...after all is said and done, I would probably do 
just as well to buy some records...

Was it all that?  I guess I'll wait till next year to see.

PEace...

> 
> I do not necessarily share these views, but I think people should know
> about what's up and why.
> 
> // g
>

At 02:52 PM 9/6/95 -0700, Grigsbeast wrote:
>
>PS:  There is great antipathy amongst the organizers for the rave camps; 
>evidently a lot of people tried to get in without paying, claim that they
>were "setting up the sound system", etc. in much greater numbers than the
>	The second problem they have stems from, yes, the noise.  Even being
>2/3 of a mile away doesn't make much difference to the Purple People Pusher,
>and they feel that one small group having such a huge impact on the sound-
>scape of the festival, especially all night, is out of balance with the rest
>of the performances, installations, and other events.  There is serious talk
>about not sanctioning a rave camp at all next year, in which case I would 
>suggest Wicked/SPAZ/whoever do their own event out there.  It sounds like
>most people spent most of their time at the rave camp anyway, and it would
>certainly save $ for the attendees.

Seems to me that this antipathy is wholly unwarranted.  Did not the
newsletter itself promise "72 hours of non-stop music" or something along
those lines?  They knew the music would be non-stop, or at least those who
bothered to read the whole thing knew it, and that's the reason the rave
camp was set up so damn far from the main camp.  We were all informed that
BM is first and foremost a party, and everyone knew from the start where the
rave camp was going to be set up - speakers were pointed away from the main
camp, except for the far east fringes, which might have caught some sound
from the Wicked camp.  Besides, many, many more ppl than just those staying
in the rave camp attended and danced and partied, and were resposible for
leaving a vast number of beer bottles and various other shit about when they
retired to their own camps for the night - shit which many of us spent time
cleaning up.  I would venture to say that the vast majority of us did pay,
and in return I think we deserved a few more than the *3* porta potties that
they provided for the rave camp.  And another thing, why did ppl show up
bitching and whining about the sound at 9am?  Wouldn't it have been a bit
wiser to head over at say 3 or so and ask that something be done?  As for
not sanctioning a rave camp next year...would it really be that hard to work
it out so that noise wouldn't be a problem?  Perhaps put the rave portion
downwind, a bit further away, and face the speakers totally away from the
main camp?  I think the rave community brought alot of diversity to the
event, and it would be a shame to see it go...

Jim 
 
  
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Everywhere is walking distance if you have the time.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

On Wed, 6 Sep 1995, Craig Lauxman wrote:

> >speakers were pointed away from the main camp, except for the far east fringes,
> >which might have caught some sound from the Wicked camp.

Just to set the record straight, the Rave camp was directly south of the
main camp on a vector of 180, the speakers for wicked were pointed
at a heading of 140 degrees so they were not pointed at the main camp
in any way, shape or form, the Purple Turbo Sound system is designed
to extrtemelyu efficient and the Subs are designed to radiate Bass,
IN ALL DIRECTIONS, Indeed you could hear the sound system from the
hot springs three miles away. You would have to move it about 7 miles away
or more to achieve complete isolation.

to making sure that people are safe and cared for.  I know of a couple of
people who tried not to pay and I don't have a lot of respect for them.

     After reading Grigsby's BM post and speaking w/a person who is 
     involved w/BM paraphanalia (who also has some connections w/the 
     organizers), it is true that there may not be a Burning Man next year. 
     
     Evidentally there were far more injuries and incidents this year than 
     the past...partly due to the larger number of attendees and the 
     attraction media gave the event.  The law enforcement presence did not 
     help either.
     
     I asked if the organizers might want to make a incident report on the 
     net so we can see what is influencing them to think about not hosting 
     the event next year.  For those who attended, I think we need to think 
     about what the intention of the Burning Man is not only for us but 
     from it's original conception.  I asked to be kept abreast on their 
     decision and I mentioned that I'd compile the pertinent sfrave posts 
     (or I'll just point her to the archives) so the organizers know what a 
     profound effect the event had on our lives.
     
     I'll probably post more about my observations later...but like Brian 
     McG (aka Dad) said, there's alot to process.
     
     Over and out,
     Diane
     
     P.S.  Did you visit the WBL's orange parachute...an oasis between 
     camps?  There were sfravers & netter en masse there.  Yours truly and 
     the RaVer's RV included.

On Wed, 6 Sep 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> Agreed.  There was noise *everywhere* at night, with a couple sound systems
> set up around the main camp as well, so to blame the rave camp for noise is

I was out on the south-eastern outskirts of camp. By Saturday and Sunday
nights, there was a continuous droning techno-track that played (probably)
all night and was still repeating by morning. Doesn't that assume a
meth-fueled exuberance that could just as easily have occurred anywhere? 

The exercises in drumming would have been more inspired had they 
functioned as communicative/situated/talking-poly-rhythms; there was 
little chance of this happening with concurrent, continuous, amplified
looped-broadcasts.

As it was, I had to smile at someone's sign which read: DRUM-FREE ZONE!

/b

Mime-Version: 1.0

From: Forrest Norvell <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	Even as a Burning Man newby, I have to say that I understand what Grigsby's 
saying. I had a wonderful time (in no small part because I was hanging out 
with the beautiful loons of Team WBL (either Weird Blinking Lights or Wobble, 
take your pick)), but I was sort of bugged by the amount of hedonism for its 
own sake that I witnessed. It's popular to pick on beer-swilling jocks, but I 
have to say that most of the crasser examples of stupidity that I saw _were_ 
indeed from the jock-types. Especially the morons who were talking about 
throwing chains around one of the Sani-Huts on the last morning and dragging 
it around.
	Also, even though raving is more or less my religion, I really didn't spend 
that much time in the rave camp. Why? It's pretty simple -- I can go see 
Wicked or the various members of the S.P.A.Z. soundsystems whenever I want in 
the city, but I very rarely get the chance to witness the level of oddity that 
was prevalent at Burning Man. It bugged me how insular the rave camp was; it 
was obvious that the only reason that some of the folks were there was to 
rave, which seemed very short-sighted to me when there was so much gut-busting 
bizarreness happening all around.
	The power of Burning Man is in its ambience; I get reminded of this every 
time I try to describe what it was like. I can't. It's just not possible for 
me to summarize what was essentially an ineffable experience. I feel like a 
wholly changed person but I lack the words to describe how. Treating it as 
just another big rave turns it into a much lesser experience. At least that's 
how I feel about it.
	With that said, I had a wonderful time. I got to meet and talk to Michael 
Clay, Franklin Minor, Peter Lasell, the Captain, Niels, Vince, and a whole 
host of sfravers who I had previously known only as user IDs on the net. I 
_want_ one of Vince's flamethrowers -- watching him run around hosing down the 
Man with flame is something that will stick with me for a while. Take from 
that what you will. I know I enjoyed dancing my ass off to Minor Minor's set, 
but I regarded it as only a small facet of a very large event, and that's 
really about all of the time I spent in the rave camp.

yrz,
ozy



ozymandias G desiderata
personal info : http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/
discographies : http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/discogs/
Missoula raves: http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/raves/

Precedence: bulk

This is not related at ALL to raving ... and it's kind of mean to guys ...
but I figure most of you are secure enough in yourselves to take it in the
spirit it's intended ... *EVIL GRIN*


DUMB MEN JOKES

1.  What is the thinnest book in the world?
   -  What men know about women.

2.  How many men does it take to screw in a light bulb?
   -  One ... men will screw anything.

3.  How does a man take a bubble bath?
   -  He eats beans for dinner.

4.  Why do women rub their eyes when they wake up?
   -  Because they don't have balls to scratch.

5.  What's a man's idea of foreplay?
   -  A half hour of begging.

6.  How can you tell if a man is sexually excited?
   -  If he's breathing.

7.  What's the difference between men and government bonds?
   -  Bonds mature.

8.  How do you save a man from drowning?
   -  Take your foot off his head.

9.  What do men and beer have in common?
   -  They're both empty from the neck up.

10. How can you tell if a man is happy?
   -  Who cares?

11. How many men does it take to change a roll of toilet paper?
   -  We don't know ... it never happens.

12. How are men and parking spots alike?
   -  The good ones are always taken and the ones left are handicapped.

13. What's a man's idea of helping with the housework?
   -  Lifting his feet so you can vacuum.

14. What's the difference between men and E.T.?
   -  E.T. phoned home.

15. What does a man consider a seven-course meal?
   -  A hot dog and a six pack.

16. Why does a man have a hole in his penis?
   -  So he can be open minded.


k

_________________________________________________________________________

         Ladies.  Gentlemen.  Shhh.  This is the way truth is.
           You've got to let those strange hands touch you.

_________________________________________________________________________

eidrah@wimsey.com  *  karen_hardie@mindlink.bc.ca  *  karen@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 18:21:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA27937; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 18:21:23 -0700

From: scarmike@tmn.com (Seth Carmichael)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Karen, Thanks for the jokes, they eased up what was otherwise getting to be
a bad vibe with all the talk about Burning Man problems.

As the individual that made the comment about next year being all
commercialized and different, I want to clarify that I meant that with some
humor, and also I followed it up with saying that you have got to go next
year. The experience was spectacular, yes there may have been a few
conflicts between camps, and some people were not on my wavelength, but it
was the nature of my experience to let that blow over me. The good
outweighed the bad soooooo much there was no bad to speak of and if done
right, next year could be just the same. The rave made the party for me,
that was the culture I was there to celebrate, others were there to trade
shop talk about ham radios, custom cars or fire eating. The beauty was
having fringe cultures of such diversity united there in one place. Some of
us mixed some of us didn't, but we were all there on that playa, all on the
same plane of existence. Those who were spectators? Well they can't really
be avoided, but they can get a look at a side of life they know nothing
about and learn from it. I bet they took away more then we expect.

I had never been to a burning man before, and who knows where I'll be this
time next year, but I will point to the past weekend as one of the turning
points in my life and that is more important right now then any of the us
vs. them stuff right now. Peace, gumby and flying saucers.

*Seth D. Carmichael(scarmike@tmn.com)*
*Global Business Network*
*PO Box 8395 Emeryville, CA 94662*
*510.547.6822 **510.547.8510 FAX*



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 18:26:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA28241; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 18:26:52 -0700

	id AA18073 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 6 Sep 95 18:26:42 -0700

	id AA25891; Wed, 6 Sep 95 18:27:58 PDT
Date: Wed, 6 Sep 95 18:27:58 PDT
From: hpcprod@lcc1.nsc.com (Craig Lauxman)
Message-Id: <9509070127.AA25891@lcc1.nsc.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Burning up reality
Cc: wiskers@netcom.com, glee@mailhost.hooked.net
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I had a great time and now am trying to get a grasp back on what normal
people (like the ones here at work) see as reality.

Friday I setup camp and my Burning Newt then got soused at Tiki Camp
till rumors of blended spam drinks scared me. Proceeded to do Twinkie
research by shooting them out of a spud gun, zapping them with one of the
backup transformers for the Mans neon lights (1500 volts and a great arc),
and torching them with flaming aerosol and rubbing alcohol. The Zen of twinkie
testing was discussed when one of the twinkies leaped out of the way of a hammer.
Then we headed for rave camp till sunrise. The dancing chills creeping up and 
down my spine as the playa grew light were incredible.

Saturday I got body painted then blown away naked by the white out dust storm.
I was in central camp and it was amazing to see what held up and what didn't.
Also cool to see people grabbing hold of the nearest thing around and holding it
down not even knowing who's it was. (Tiki kept the blenders whirring through out
the storm. Talk about pros.) Damn near lost my voice whooping and hollering as 
each storm came through. What a rush.

Polkacide was really cool. (I'd never slam danced naked before.) Then the next 
storm came which put a halt to the avenue of art. Oh well, the camel at sultan 
camp got burned with a really good drum circle and quit a few wild dancers. The 
sunrise at the man was really intense with a pink walking rain cloud to the east 
and dark clouds full of lighting to the west. (Almost matched the blue and red 
sides of the Man.)

Sunday was slow in main camp (Lots of people recovering.) I met Vince and Amy
and that was cool, (good to hook-up with a few sfravers.) Then the rains came,
signaled by a hugh thunder clap which rolled around and around the hills. Before
long, people are getting pulled behind vehicles on their butts making us laugh 
and then this guy started playing a trap set and people started throwing off their
clothes and dancing naked in the rain and the mud. I took some pictures then
decided it was perfect for a newt so I joined in. As more and more people had
trouble keeping their feet we collapsed into a big wiggling pile doing the naked
amphibian mud flop. It was the wildest inner child mixed with adult sexuality 
type of thing I've ever done. I had the Water Woman shower me to get cleaned off.
The stuff was up my nose, in my ears and pretty much every where else, but it was 
worth it. 

I got to tape a twinkie to the colon of the man to finish the twinkie research.

Then it was time for the Man. I went around the backside (southeast) so I could
get front row without being crushed. The jet car going by was really wild and
came about ten feet from me. Close enough to feel the heat from the side. Then
the fireworks. I happened to be right where some of them ended up hitting the 
ground. The first one landed about three feet from me and exploded into a ten foot
radius. Several peoples clothes got burned but no one was hurt. Boy did they 
listen when the guy with the flare told them to move back again. We, had several
more land in our midst but now that we were paying attention we made plenty of
room for them. Then the performance dancers and finally the man was lit. It was
great seeing Vince torch the parts that didn't catch due to the wind. The Dancing
Man was great when they pulled the guy wires to try to make him fall.

The Lingam burn was great (Amy gives a great description) with white blue flames
coming out the top at the end. The music had changed from the drum procession 
which played the whole time for the Man to Sharkbait warming up for the crushfest.

They tossed out hundreds of drum sticks and drug out parts of cars, metal tubes,
sheet metal, corrugated metal and lots of other stuff to pound on. It's a wonderful
thing to be making these wild pulsating beats with hundreds of others. The band
becomes incidental and the tribalness takes over. Bang it, jump on it, go crazy
making sounds getting into it with your whole body.

Finally, it was time to burn my newt. Had to carry it out to the middle of center
camp because of the high winds, but we got it torched up after the procession,
did some drumming, and poured the rest of the newts head stout. Vince showed up
with a laminate for me (thanks a ton, that was really great) then headed for rave
camp. I felt like drumming some more, but every time I headed for what I thought
was a drum circle it ended up being Wickeds bass bouncing off of something so I
went and danced for awhile then passed out from exhaustion and excitement.

Overall, the super weird became normal (weird was barely noticed) and the surreal
became the way of things. The storms couldn't have been better planned for their
entertainment value while their duration was short enough to be quite surviable. 
I again had one of the best times of my life. 

The Newt King

On Wed, 6 Sep 1995, Grigsbeast wrote:

> PS:  There is great antipathy amongst the organizers for the rave camps; 
> evidently a lot of people tried to get in without paying, claim that they
> were "setting up the sound system", etc. in much greater numbers than the
> rest of the populace.  $40 seems like a lot, but _each_ porta-potty is about
> $100 _a day_ (x 3 days, x at least 40 of them, you do the math), there are 
> BLM land use fees, *insurance*, and The Man (materials
> alone run several thousand).  BM has _never_ made money, and that's including
> the fact that no one is paid for their time constructing, planning, cleaning
> up, or anything else.  They have turned down many offers of corporate
> sponsorship (from Bud, etc.) in order to maintain integrity in the face
> of lack of cash.  It looks bad when people in an big and obviously rented
> vehicle claim they can't come up with money.  (Note: I don't know who
> this was, or care: I just know it happened.)

Unfortunately this seems to be true, it is hard to plead poor when you
show up in a delux RV, also if you were at laa prepared, you would know
that the $35 is a fraction of the cost of actually coming to burning man,
in my opinion EVERYONE should pay or volunteer services if you don't
pay, it's only fair that way.  I have to admit that I did feel a wee bit
embarrised by the "ravers" for all our talk of PLUR we didn't show much
unity or respect out ou the playa.




> 	The second problem they have stems from, yes, the noise.  Even being
> 2/3 of a mile away doesn't make much difference to the Purple People Pusher,
> and they feel that one small group having such a huge impact on the sound-
> scape of the festival, especially all night, is out of balance with the rest
> of the performances, installations, and other events.  There is serious talk
> about not sanctioning a rave camp at all next year, in which case I would 
> suggest Wicked/SPAZ/whoever do their own event out there.  It sounds like
> most people spent most of their time at the rave camp anyway, and it would
> certainly save $ for the attendees.
> 

I have to take exception here, while the Wicked sound system was loud
it was not any louder in the main camp then any of the other soundsystems
or acts, I think this complaint has more to do with the "repetative
beats" that these sound systems emit, either you love it or you hate it.
I think if you moved the camp out a little further that would help a lot,
many people were really turned on and I got positive words from a couple
of the young off duty rangers who came out to check us out.

					G

Well I had a great time, this my second year at BM.  I was quite bummed at
the anticlimatic burning of the man though.  I can't believe they made
everyone sit down and wouldn't let people dance while the man burned.  I
guess I can believe it from a safety standpoint, cuz someone would have
probably got pushed into the fire, but none-the-less I was really
disappointed at how the crowd couldn't participate as much.  (sorry to
dredge up the past, but...) Last year as soon as it was lit a huge dance
circle formed around the man and everyone went fucking crazy.  I remember
having to take most of my clothes off because the fire was so hot and I was
dancing so close to it.  It felt like we were watching a movie this time.
We ended up going over about 300 feet away and watching Ren and Stimpy on
the side of someones RV...and I despise TV.  I'm really glad that so many
people had as good a time this year as I did last year though.  

Then we found this guy laying on the ground being totally unresponsive.  We
tried to get him up but again he wouldn't respond.  We finally got some help
from some authority types and they called the medics.  After a while he
finally started responding and eventually got up.  He kept telling them he
was dead.  He kept saying "I died".  Everyone just kept telling him "nope,
your alive".  It was kinda funny actually.  Eventually one of the rangers
led him away to find a warm place for him to ride out his trip.  It was cool
that they didn't arrest him.

I'll probably post more later, but I'm hungry.  All in all I had a wonderful
time.  Later.

Rick

> Interesting. Notice the word "rave" instead of "party". 
> I did some thinking on the drive back about how people have switched to 
> calling them "parties" instead of "raves". 

I call 'em raves cause that's what I learned that they were.  The word 
"party" conjures up visions of kegs and rowdy drunken jerks.  A rave is 
just a rave...nothing can substitute what it means to *me*.  I call 
Friends and Family a rave, I call the Gathering a rave, I call Wicked a 
rave.  Now I call Cool World just plain madness.   I think people are 
getting a little anal when they get all worked up saying "no, that wasn't 
a *rave*, that was a *party*!!"   For crying out loud....the event/ rave/ 
party, whatever - just IS.  Words are stupid.

love,
Amy

This is reallly looong. I'm sorry! for those interested in the heart of 
the matter, skip to AfterBurn (pt.2) and scroll down to 
the burning man section.


Yowzaa! 

Gretchen, Christina, Alyssa and I arrived in Gerlach 
in our rental vehicle around 6pm on Thursday. We met up 
with Jeff and Kevin who took my car. Then we were off 
to the playa! I don't know what to say about the
expanse or the landscape in general, except that 
it is beautiful. Ok -I'll admit more than that- 
I felt that the Earth, the distant shapes of the hills, 
the (on Thursday night, anyway, before it just became dust) 
patterns of the cracked lake bed, the one mountain that looked like 
a resting nanook(sp?) truly were communicating- sending 
their own messages out into the cosmos. Ultimately, i 
guess I felt that despite all of the revelry, pagentry, ritual, 
noise and plain old living going on- the land and sky had 
more to say out there than we did. (though that's not to say that 
I didn't appreciate or enjoy the man-crafted wackiness.
 Man knows I did !)

We finally decided to pitch camp in a place we happened 
upon. We didn't really know the lay of the land or 
what shape the civilization would take at that point. We 
were one of the first 40 or 50 sites. I am incredibly 
grateful that we went early- and I would highly 
recommend it to anyone who is able to shed the skin of
daily life for a few extra days. We were about 1/4 or so mile 
due north of the central radio tower. (Yes, Virginia, there were two 
radio stations to choose from). We had a mellow evening-
setting up some of our camp, exploring a bit, taking in the million 
and one colors of purple at twilight. None of the sound systems 
had arrived yet, so we just put some Getz/Gilberto, Vince Guaraldi 
and Big Bang CD3 on the box and chatted on the tarp. Periodically
we'd walk away from camp and its lights to look at the 
stars, trying to identify various constellations. On this night,
the encampments had more of a quiet nomadic presence than 
the later carnival/festival presence. 

On Friday, we arose to a perfectly clear sky. The sun was so 
bright that it stung your eyes to look at the desert floor.
We were greeted early in the day by a show of inverted Blue Angels-
frightening and spectacular. 

We did some more exploring- discovered McSatan's- the 
general store of the playa. On that first day, everything 
was $1, $2 on the second day and $3 on the third- Robinson Carusoe
all over! We drove out to the camp toward the far north- it looked like 
a mirage from our camp. Each structure was doubled by a 
floating, waving reflection. When we returned to 
our camp, it was too hot to do much of anything but sit in 
the shade. we played a little soccer and frisbee, but only 
for a short time- then back to the shade, where we watched 
more and more people arrive. We rightly guessed that we would have 
several new neighbors by nightfall and many more in the morning.
We waved and shouted Hellos to people who passed us, welcoming them 
to our slice of suburbia. 
 
At dusk, christina and Alyssa set out for, well, for the outlands. 
I decided to join them after a while. Kevin had to point them out 
to me- 2 small black dots on the horizon. I decided to jog all 
the way- about a mile or so. I did stop occasionally to look at the 
desert floor. Patches of it were very smooth, but as you moved away from 
camp, it became more like curved, cracked clay; then in sections 
like broken glass. The mountains were shading parts of the playa by now,
but the sun still shone, too. Looking off to where the sun was shining
the playa looked like a golden field of wheat. When you looked 
closer to yourself so that the sun no longer reflected off of 
the floor, it turned this blue color. The contrast 
between the golden color and the long shadows generated by Alyssa, 
Christina and I made it appear as if there were halos around our 
oblong shadow heads. did I mention the purple? 

We returned to camp and were happy to see a large teepee being 
erected near our camp. Yea! a landmark. We hung around camp 
long enough to watch the bug van come rolling up to the teepee. 
The folks in the bug van t.p.ed the teepee! Those meta-expressionistic 
buggers!

Sometime later we women went to the rave camp- about 1&3/4 mile walk-
south and just left of the moon. I'm sure it was closer, but we 
could never quite manage a straight line. Along the way, we 
veered east to look at the neon sculptures- one was a little 
family of burning people, some neon palm trees, and some 
other neon shapes sprouting from the desert floor. 
The other looked like a series of 
straight neon lines from a distance, but really it was this 
enormous neon dancing person facing the desert sky. We passed the 
North Pole on the way- a full shanty shack with a glowing Santa 
on top!

Once we arrived at rave camp, we danced for a bit near the 
closer sound system (i.e. SPAZ)- I don't think 
Wicked was playing yet. We milled about a bit, danced some 
more- oh- and I introduced myself to the Capt'n- hiya! 

Meanwhile, Kevin and Jeff went downtown and watched 
a man push and pull skewers through his body.

Everyone but Alyssa left rave camp earlier than later-
at this point we were finally realizing that we should 
try to be nocturnal (though we didn't quite manage this either).

Alyssa returned to camp bearing gifts- she brought Phil to 
our camp to meet me! hi Phil! I was pretty tired by then
and not the best company- sorry about that. We shared some 
oranges fireside and listened to Sean(sp? DJ from Seattle)'s 
tape, which is really good, BTW.

Sat & Sun in AfterBurn pt2...
  

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 19:53:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA03395; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 19:53:38 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA03376; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 19:53:34 -0700
Received: from sr-tty23-ppp.well.com (sr-tty23-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.233]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id TAA26669 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 19:53:23 -0700

Date: Wed, 06 Sep 95 09:56:20 -1000

Precedence: bulk

Burning man report
==================

After last years very strange and exciting encounters at Burning Man 
festival,  I just HAD to do it again this year.   I think that no matter 
where I would ever be in the world,  I would ALWAYS somehow try and make 
it back to the Black Rock Desert in September.   WOW!!  What an 
incredible way to end a wonderful raving summer.

Preparation
-----------

It took some preparation for this trip,   mostly because of the fact 
that it's a dry desert,  and there are essential items one should take,  
such as plenty or water and material to make shade.

A fellow SFRaver Seth contacted me and was the only rider that responded 
to my posting on SFRaves.   There were others,  but nobody called me 
back,  so I assumed they got rides.

The Trip
--------

We left late Thursday evening,   drove through the evening,  thanx to 
Seth to arrive at Gerlach's Bruno's Bar,  where I was to hook up with 
one of the organizers to put up an Internet link out on the Playa.

So,  we pull into the ONLY gas station in this town,  look round and I 
find Travis (Another Raver dude).   We talk for a while I went into 
Bruno's to hook up with Stewart.   I went to his hotel room but couldn't 
find him,  so we went out to the Playa,   following our directions 
PRECISELY.   At this point,  it was about 8 am,  which was
a perfect time to arrive.   It was cool enough so that I could scout 
around on my dirt bike without roasting in the sun.

Setting up
----------

At this point,  things were still getting set up,   and markers laid
out in a more organized way with little red flags,  defining the various
areas used by the festival.   These well defined areas made it MUCH 
better to locate other camps.   For instance,  they had red flags 
radiating WEST out from main center,  YELLOW for North,   etc.    Then, 
one would locate a camp in a quadrant between the specific flags.

My first order of business was to contact Stewart to see what was being 
done to establish an Internet connection between the Playa and the rest 
of the world.   I was somewhat skeptical if it was possible to send a 
good enough quality of signal to pass data packets reliably,   but 
eventually,  Stewart finally got a group of people with the equipment,  
and things were getting set up.

I stayed out of the way and looked amazement as a radio station sorta
materialized out of the desert.   It's simple pre-fab construction was 
carefully prepared and in just a few hours,   was constructed and ready 
to be hooked up.

I started looking around for the Rave camp,   but very little activity 
was going on,  except a small filming group,  shooting a movie with 
"Burning man" in it.


The location and setting
------------------------

The location (A huge dried out lake bed) is probably the flattest place 
on earth.    Just for fun,  as I was riding my dirt bike out on the 
desert,   I tried closing my eyes to see how long I could ride without 
the temptation of opening them.   At first,   I could hold them close 
for a few minutes,   before "getting chicken" and opening them again.
As I tried,  I also noticed that for long durations I tended to veer off
to the left,  thus circling back.    I think I was veering about 15 
degrees/minute.   As I practiced,  my veer rate would diminish,  and 
eventually I could hold them closed or 10 minutes.   After all that
veering around,   I couldn't see the camp anymore,   so rode in the 
approximate direction,  using the stars as my guide.    Later on,   I 
could barely see the outline of the familiar hills that always served as 
a direction guide.    IE:  Rave camp always slightly to the right of 
that really tall peak (Near where the hot springs were).

So,   after blissfully pedaling all around the desert,   I eventually 
spot the laser shining BEHIND the horizon,  and learned that I had 
traveled approx. 7 to 8 miles from BOTH main and rave camp.   So I set 
my sites on the laser beam that unerringly guided me towards the rave.   
Eventually I could see it appear above the horizon,  and it just didn't 
appear to get any closer.    After about 20 minutes of steadily pedaling 
I eventually made it back to rave camp,  at which time I wasted no time 
in dancing.


The Environment
---------------

It rained several times,  and boy did it ever get muddy.   The mud 
smelled like dead fish,  sorta had a pungy fresh smell to it,   but 
completely eliminated the dust problem.   Now,  there was lots of sticky 
gooey mud that people wasted no time in getting it all over their 
bodies.   

On Sat afternoon,  a rally nasty rainstorm came through in the afternoon 
which really generated tons of mud.    I was caught in main camp where I 
was just about to get a grilled cheese sandwich.   But the rain changed 
all of our plans.    It came up so suddenly.

As it was raining,  I took the opportunity to borrow some soap and a 
towel and took a nice refreshing shower.  Others did the opposite by 
rolling in the mud.   I saw this really cool midget guy,  hanging onto 
the back of the bumper of a car,  sliding in the mud.    Then,  he 
would 
let go and spin around several times,  and would slide an incredible 50 
feet after letting go.    About 100 feet away from me,   I found a huge 
drum circle,  and people writhing in the mud crawling all over each 
other in some twisted body ritual....  I just squished around in the 
mud,  enjoying it squishing between my toes.   I dirt bike was utterly 
useless,  so I stashed it somewhere and hung out until it dried.   It 
dried in just 2 hours amazingly enough. 

Main Features
-------------

The main feature of course was the burning of the man,   but the 
afternoon,  was a fashion show,   which I thought was really unique.
After the fashion show,  I headed out to the hot springs once again and 
took a well deserved break from the heat.


The Burning of the man
----------------------

I head back to the main camp to take in the final songs from the live 
band (Shark Bait - I believe).   At about that time,   people were 
chanting "Burning man" and the long procession began as people started 
marching towards the burning man.    I quickly zipped ahead of the group 
and established a good vantage point before the main contingent arrived.

As usual,  there was lots of ritualistic happenings,  such as skits,  
and this rocket powered go-cart using a "pulse jet" engine.   This thing 
was amazingly LOUD,  and zipped around the circle wildly.   The exhaust 
pipe was glowing orange hot,  then it broke through the crowd and headed 
out onto the desert.

At that time,  people were chanting "Burn it!   Burn it!" as the 
organizers were trying to hold everyone back.    Eventually,  it got 
lit,   but didn't quite burn evenly,  but the fireworks were absolutely 
impressive as it exploded in a huge shower of sparks.   As it was 
burning,   people were pulling on he guy wires until it fell over,  
which was the queue for people to run towards it,   yelling and 
chanting.

Shortly after that,  people were gathering around this huge penis type 
chimney,  dancing around in strange dances and costumes.   Eventually,  
it was lit,   and as it started to burn,   you could actually see 
through it as the flames shot upwards like a rocket exhaust in purple, 
green and blue flames.   Again,  people were dancing around it,  some 
actually jumping directly over the flames.   


The Rave(s)
-----------

Eventually,  I headed back to rave camp,  and arrived just in time to 
Lucas's set.   Lucas,  eventually from the Netherlands was playing some 
of the most brilliant Acid Trance I've heard in a long time.   It didn't 
take me long before I had a total "out of body" experience as I bopping 
around the dance area like a raving maniac.   Sheesh,  this was my 3rd 
all-niter as the ONLY time I slept was on Thursday evening.   Amazingly 
enough,  I danced all night long until the next DJ went on just as the 
sun rose.    After that,  I chilled for a few hours and came back for 
one more dance binge until the sound stopped.   

The SPAZ dance area was so good that I didn't even bother to make it 
over to the Wicked arena.    I did actually go over to check it out,   
but found the trance more to my liking.

Leaving
-------

As it became towards the afternoon,  Seth had already packed up the tent 
and supplies in the car,   so we organized a large caravan of 5 (or 
more) cars to Pyramid Lake for a much deserved splooch in the cool lake 
before heading through Reno and back to the Bay Area.   Thanx go to Seth 
for doing all the driving as he managed to get some sleep,  as I was in 
NO condition to drive at all.    We eventually make it back around 11 
PM.

Crunchman




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 19:53:56 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA03422; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 19:53:56 -0700
Received: from hal.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id TAA03394; Wed, 6 Sep 1995 19:53:37 -0700
Received: from dre.hal.com by hal.com (4.1/SMI-4.1.1)
	id AA11414; Wed, 6 Sep 95 19:53:30 PDT
Received: by dre.hal.com (4.1/SMI-4.1.2)
	id AA08372; Wed, 6 Sep 95 19:53:28 PDT
Date: Wed, 6 Sep 95 19:53:28 PDT
From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)
Message-Id: <9509070253.AA08372@dre.hal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: AfterBurn (pt.2)
Cc: jocelyn@hal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sat & Sun...

Saturday morning everyone but Christina and I went to Gerlach.
I thought they might take showers, but instead they drank 
margaritas at one of the bars in town. 

christina and I waited for more of our crew to arrive- we were 
pretty worried about them being able to find us. Luckily
we spotted them driving around aimlessly in downtown 
playaville. We ran after them,
christina taking one corridor and I another- finally, 
we caught them and led them to the spot. Manny, Steve,
Daniel, Pete and Cara looked a little road-weary, but 
were equally awakened at what they'd seen so far.
The other group folk came back and we played a few rounds 
of soccer. Some people left for rave camp. 

Soon thereafter we watched the approaching, vertical sheet of clouds. 
We heard lots of people cheering it on its way and assumed 
that it was a rain storm. We put everything inside the tents,
except ourselves, as we were waiting for the rain. Once the 
dust storm hit, I couldn't see my hands, much less any of the 
tents or cars. Luckily, I was holding a tarp. I grabbed 
Gretchen and walked until we were standing on top of one of 
the tents that had deflated. I grabbed the tarp over my head 
and tried to get Gretchen under there with me. She was in 
pain and afraid of damaging her eyes permanently (she 
had her contacts in). Finally, she understood what I was 
motioning for her to do and she joined me under the tarp. 
Moments later we were joined by Christina and Kevin. After 
we had secured the tarp beneath us, we just hugged, held 
and petted each other-aware of our own delicacy. 

When the storm passed and we exited the tarp, we were 
pretty dazed and looked on each other with awe. What I 
remember most was that everyone's eyelashes and hair 
were white with playa dust. That and that only two of six tents 
were still afloat.  We didn't rebuild right away- we just 
walked around, estranged witnesses to the power that had passed. 
Then we saw the rainbow forming and watched as it stretched and 
arced- something between a yawn and a smile- until both ends 
touched the desert floor and the second reverse rainbow did
the same. Everywhere people were cheering the sky. This 
was one of the most magical moments to me. It was as if the sky 
had sent down tentacles of wind and dust to find out what we 
were all about, then colorfully displayed an acknowledgement 
of our presence- or perhaps it was recognition, or perhaps 
nothing at all but the usual late summer/early fall weather of 
the desert coming up from the Gulf of California or maybe 
from as far away as the Gulf of Mexico- our own little taste 
of hurricane Louise. 

Everyone who had been there Fryday was tired and stuck close to camp 
and downtown (except Alyssa). The newer arrivals took off for rave camp.
This was the only night I slept well. I understood the 
gravity of my mistake upon waking in the morning to the boom boom
wah wah boom boom coming across the desert from the rave camp.

Sunday morning we decided to drive to what we thought were the 
closest mountains. As we neared them, the playa began to 
look a little less dry. So, we parked some distance away.
During our approach, we began to hear loud noises echoing 
off of the mountain and we saw a long shining line of cars 
parked on a road cut into the hillside. From the noise, 
we guessed they were shooting. We were right. We walked 
up to the firing range just in time to catch some staged 
drive-by shootings. Most commonly, there were two shooters 
per truck bed. The trucks travelled about 5-15 mph and once 
they crossed into the firing range, the shooters took aim 
and fired at their targets. The targets consisted of many 
stuffed animals hung up on stakes- Barney included. &, no, 
I didn't see Ernie! One of the participants was this large naked man-
naked except for his hat, shoes, sunglasses, earplugs,
gun, gun holster, and a strategically placed ammo holster. 
I heard him introduce himself to one of the other drive-by patrons.
He said, "Hello, I'm Bob; or, if you will, Zeus!" Real 
Church of the Sub-genius material! No doubt graced by the Bob 
trinity. Just don't eat the children, Zeus!

But really folks- I didn't know how to feel about this event.
I'm pretty confused about gun control in general. I'm for it,
but I don't think it would work & I still respect the rights 
of folks like these to have a safe, organized bit of firing fun.
On the other hand, there were more than a few people standing 
around who I didn't want to be near & who made me edgy. It
was interesting to come across, but I wanted to leave 
almost immediately.  The scariest part of this event was the 
red-shirted fool who started his own personal firing range 
almost directly behind us! He was far enough away that we weren't 
in immediate danger, but none of us could walk out until 
he quit. 

We drove to rave camp and dropped a few folks off, then returned to our
camp. We picked up a bunch of walkers along the way- all very 
friendly and glad of our company as well as the transport!
alyssa, Christina, Cara and I tromped around for a bit from one camp 
to another. I think we walked about 4 miles altogether. Then we 
came back to camp. Manny took my car to rave camp for a bit.

I decided to try to nap. Just as I was about to put myself in a tent,
Manny came barreling up in my car with Markie. We introduced ourselves
while Manny fiddled with something or other. That's my Emanuel! 
Jason (Spun) also visited sometime before the storm, but I can't 
really say when- that napping business ya know ;) it distorts 
everything under the sun.

I was up and about when the rain and hail came! 
What a welcome relief! After it stopped hailing for the second time,
we started a game of grudge-match mud soccer in true slide tackle 
style! Many people from neighboring camps joined in & it was
a lot of fun! We were all pretty mud-soaked at game's end, which 
was all good and well until the mud started to dry and 
crack on our skin, but a couple of towels and some water 
took care of most of this. Ole'! Ole'! Ole'! Ole'! 
(Internatioal futbol chant).

___THE BURNING_OF_THE_MAN___________________________________

Soon, we began to hear an ever increasing din of drums coming 
from the central camp. I was very anxious to leave 
for the downtown, but others were content to wait a bit. So, 
I went by myself. I must say I felt a little lost amid the throng, 
but I found a place where I could easily view and focus on the man. 
Soon people started to chant and/or individually scream "Burn Him." I 
found myself having a really bizarre reaction to that. On the one hand, 
I was as ready as the next person for the fire- his fire. On the 
other hand, I had an overwhelming sense of sympathy for 
both the man (the symbol) & the structure (the art). I was honestly 
wishing that I could do something to save it. Now I can only 
wonder what that heroic act might have looked like and how 
completely pissed off everybody else would have been. Am I nuts?
Did anyone else feel this way? Also, another bizarre occurence-
a bit before the burning, a man walked up to me and said, "In 
the name of Jesus of Nazareth I place a white shield around you,"
raised his hand in front of me and walked off before I could respond.
I wasn't afraid, just surprised to be singled out for this:
Clearly he meant to protect me and keep me pure for Jesus- amen 
and hallelulu! 

Maybe I felt that sympathy because I only witnessed the razing and not 
the raising- I don't know.

After the burning, the whole place errupted in lunacy.
There were lunatics running around everywhere (i think I 
might have been one of them- but I may not be the best judge).
Real lunatics- moon gods and goddesses howling, shrieking, 
yelling, laughing, cavorting, ecstatic... For me the falling of the man 
mostly served as a marker for the start of the carnival- 
a real carnival- masked flesh gone mad! drummers and mummers everywhere-
every kind of fire and/or light glinting off the skin of naked 
men and women who were caked in the dried mud of the playa- their 
eyes and nostrils taking on a red/yellow quality next to the whitish 
playa paint. fireworks from every direction added to the acrid
smell of pitch and gasoline and sulfur in the air. parades of 
bizarre hand-made bicycles and costumes flashed past. 

i returned to camp to meet up with all of the folk- none of whom i
could find in the throng. soon, we decided to go to rave camp.

I remember the exact circumstance of becoming a part of the madness:
as we were walking to the rave camp, we passed a stage in the downtown
area where there was some man laughing into a microphone- but I 
couldn't see him for the crowd- I could only hear a wild voice 
coming out of the speakers with a background of noise music. 
What I did see was this- another man in the "audience" who was 
silently miming along to the laughter- rolling and shaking with it.
One guffaw a mimicry, another a mockery, the next a parody and 
so on... the disembodied voice had found a home in him & his body 
a home in that evil speaker laughter. I glanced away from the man
& noticed that maybe a hundred others were there & they were laughing
too- out loud, right along with the overlord speaker-laugher. 
I looked back to the silent man who was still shaking, and I began to 
laugh. At that moment my non-laughing self became afraid for my 
laughing self and the other laughers about me. My laughing 
self would not be persuaded to silence, but neither would my 
non-laughing self. So, a funny thing happened- my non-laughing
self began laughing at my laughing self; "as if you could ditch 
me with laughter- ha ha ha- look who's laughing now!"
And so I ended up with both feet in the madness pond.

But only very briefly. This all passed in a matter of seconds.
Then we were off again. As we neared the rave sites, we noticed 
a bunch of Nevada state trooper cars with their lights flashing.
Then those disappeared and in their place were a bunch of flares 
in three parallel lines. We passed this, but soon turned around to 
watch the medivac helicopter land. We didn't know what had happened
(though we found out on our walk back) & decided it was probably 
not the time to go hunting for info near the helicopter/accident 
site. 

A good sized group was already amassed at the 
Wicked site. I pretty much stayed along the perimeter. Then I 
went to the sani-hut by myself. Here I met three people-
Ranee(sp?), Niel and Jon- was that you? All really sweet! 
If you're out there- I had glasses on, some jeans and 
an oatmeal-colored sweater. Although Ranee and Niel invited me 
to come dance with them, I just wasn't sitting right with the 
emerging scene. I was glad of the opportunity for dancing 
to "house music all night long", but what I really wanted to do
was put my head on the desert floor, look up at the stars 
and let my mind be quiet. With that, Kevin, Daniel and I 
left to return to camp. 

On our way, a man told us that a woman had been riding atop 
a car and had fallen off. she was then hit by another car.
Does anyone have any information about her condition or 
can anyone verify if this is true?

When we got to camp, Kevin and Daniel played their guitars 
and I did what I wanted. I was really tired and soon left 
the stars for the cieling of the tent. I had a hard time 
falling asleep and mostly just thought about things while 
listening to the tent move in the wind. Suddenly, Daniel, Kevin 
and Jeff (who had returned by then, too) broke out into song-
Daniel started singing about the "Funky Dirt" (of which there was plenty)
at the top of his lungs and doing a remarkably well-matched drum solo 
to go with it. Cara, alyssa and I were in the tent. Alyssa didn't wake, 
but Cara and I rolled with laughter. 

soon Daniel stopped and we settled back down. For some reason 
I chose this time to think about Jon, who was my boyfriend 
of 2 & 1/2 years and who broke up with me the Saturday before 
Burning Man. I mourned and cried for a bit as quietly as I could-
something I had been meaning to do since I arrived, but kept forgetting.
Every once in a while, either Cara or I would remember 
and/or whisper "funky dirt" and then I would laugh again. So I 
spent my last night at black Rock with a bunch of maniacs 
while in a mania myself. I finally fell asleep, but before 
I did I heard Daniel say (and this was the last thing I heard 
that night), "My soul for a bottle of dirt" [of which there 
was plenty ;)     


Love to all! 

Jocelyn

> but I figure most of you are secure enough in yourselves to take it in the
> spirit it's intended ... *EVIL GRIN*
>

> DUMB MEN JOKES

okay, i gotta comment here...

yikes!  i thought i escaped this kind of stupid, genderbiased humor when 
i left the office ... sigh.  i really can't stand these kinds of jokes, 
cuz even tho they're making fun of specific behaviors that may be common 
to many (straight) men, i think they actually REINFORCE the idea that these 
are typical male behaviors (hence somewhat okay) and they reinforce 
gender-biases (i.e. men are always horny (as if women aren't!)  men can't 
clean...etc. etc.

some more comments:

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep  6 21:15:32 1995

On Tue, 5 Sep 1995, Tim McDonnell wrote:

> So let here all the great stories, Amy had some good stuff, I expected this to 
> be flooded with stories by now, or is everyone recouping. I wanted to go but 
> couldn't so all I (we) have is stories from the people that went.


Well, after finally recovering enough to post...

Rather than repeating things that have been described sooo well by Mizz 
Starkey and others, I decided to post some bad and some GREAT 
observations/things that happened: 
1) Good and bad:

The AWESOME forces of nature. Riding through the worst storm of my life 
on a motorcycle to get to the playa, with standing sheets of water on the 
road and hail the size of large peas really gives one a new found respect. 
The good thing about this is that I can probably laugh off fear of driving in 
the rain around the Bay Area.

Variations on a common theme: Dust, dirt, and MUD!!! It became insuated 
into your very being. Never had I imagined how cleansing jumping nekked 
into a muddy pool of water(hot springs) could feel.

Absolutely incredible lightning storms. I remember walking towards the 
man on the night of the burn, with him being silhouetted by a natural light 
show that nothing man made could come close to. Almost overwhelmingly 
powerful. 


Main Camp:

Good Things:

The sheer wackiness of it all. Things I would be hard pressed to come up 
with in a million years, like Mc Satans, and Celebrity crucifixion. There 
were some very imaginative, intelligent, creative people out there.

Bad Things:
(minor)
A few close minded people, which was rather perplexing. Lots o' trash.


The burn itself: 

Good things:

The wonderful people I went with.

The procession including the jet car with an unearthly rumble, fireworks, the 
vari-colored masked dancers, and of course Vince, in a bright orange jumpsuit 
with a flame thrower strapped to his back, helping the man to its firey demise. 

Bad things: 

The spectator quotient. Quite a few assholes standing around yelling "Just 
burn the fucking thing down," and similar epitaths, really detracted from the 
communal energy of those getting into it. It is my sincere hope that 
these folks will stay home and watch the Beach MTV re-runs in the future.

The pandering to the media. This is my single, biggest problem with this 
entire event. For a group that proclaimed that it didn't want the media 
interfering with the participants, it seemed they had no problem giving 
the media preferential access to space during the burn. Media should have 
been given the same access as the participants, if the organizers had 
really meant what they said. I guess they didn't...


The rave camp:

Bad things: 
The rumors of petty bitching between the two groups (S.P.A.Z./Gateway/F-8) 
and Wicked. Someone please correct me if I am wrong; from what I heard the 
people from one group were trying to get to get together with the other group 
to put forth one massive effort at one point, but the other group had a 
stick up their ass and wouldn't do it. To the group that think they are all 
rock 'n roll stars: Get off yourselves, this thing is supposed to be about 
togetherness,not hero-worship. Again, rumors are just that, so someone put me 
straight if I am wrong in this. I would like to be.

Distance, distance, distance! People were sooo spread out, it was hard to 
find anyone.

The SfRaver turn out: It was good to meet a few more of ya and to see 
those I already know and love. The bad thing was not meeting many,many 
more of ya that were there. I can fault myself for not being more gregarious.


Now on to the good thing...:

Camping with some wonderful people, Reagan(dunno if she counts cause I 
camp with her all the time ), Tony, Denise, Bill, Gaby, Mike, Jeff, Graham, 
and one or two others whose names escape me. 

The vibe level was really nice. People almost always had a hello and a 
smile. This went for the whole camp, not just the rave camp.

Dancing to some great sets for hours, which I haven't done in quite a while.

Being woken up at 6 in the morning by music and not being able to go back 
to sleep, not because it was too loud, but because it was was SO good and 
going off so HARD.


Misc:

The Police:
Good Things:

All I have to say is good things. I can't imagine myself saying that, but 
whenever I came into contact with them, they were always NICE, and 
generally looked like they were enjoying the event almost as much as we were.
I vote that we send all the California officers to Nevada for awhile to 
get a clue. 


My Motorcycle:
Bad Things:

I dropped my bike not once, but twice. The first time as I was first 
entering the playa which was soaked after a cloudburst, the guide said 
"Go in and fall down." I guess I was too obliging, and promptly did just 
that, losing my chain. 

The second time, riding towards the hot springs at about 30 MPH the playa 
shifted from hard dirt to mud without warning and down Reagan and I went, 
causing some swelling and road rash between the both of us. The bike 
ended up missing mirrors and with bent handlebars.

Good Things:

The first time I dropped my bike, through the kindness of 
strangers(fellow bikers,) I was lent the tools and given the knowledge to 
fix the problem.

The second time, I received an offer from Vince and Wayne to put my bike on 
Vinces' trailer and be given a drive back to the Bay Area, for which I am 
very much in their debt.  



Summary:

Well worth the time, expense, and effort.

I know that this post is *HUGE* and I ramble, but other than from a 
stream-of-conciousness perspective I can't explain it. It was, and is, 
and will always be, an experience that lives.

                                             Black Adder

On Wed, 6 Sep 1995, Amy R Starkey wrote:
> 
> I call 'em raves cause that's what I learned that they were.  The word 
> "party" conjures up visions of kegs and rowdy drunken jerks.  A rave is 
> just a rave...nothing can substitute what it means to *me*.  I call 
> Friends and Family a rave, I call the Gathering a rave, I call Wicked a 
> rave.  Now I call Cool World just plain madness.   I think people are 
> getting a little anal when they get all worked up saying "no, that wasn't 
> a *rave*, that was a *party*!!"   For crying out loud....the event/ rave/ 
> party, whatever - just IS.  Words are stupid.

I was trying to look at the changes in the vibe that have occurred over
time in relation to the way people envision the events, no matter *what* 
they call them. I was just trying to express how happy I was to discover 
that something I thought had died, something I hold *very* near and dear, is
still alive, well, and *thriving*. It had been four years since I attended
anything that was even in any way comparable to Wicked at Burning Man.
I live in Reno. Everything here is commercialized to the extremes, in one
way or another. It used to be that we would all caravan down to the bay
area as often as possible to enjoy the many sights and sounds. But lately,
it's been impossible to find out about the smaller events. It used to be
that people would freely offer the information to you, glad to include
you. Now it's like people are trying to preserve everything for just their
friends, and their scene, without regard to anyone else or regard to the
scene as a whole. 

Practically everyone in the bay area seems to take everything there for
granted. It makes me sad to hear people have a "oh, it was okay" attitude
about events I would have given a lot more than 10 hours of driving to go 
to. It's not about the price at all, it's about what you get out of the 
experience in it's entirity. There is no cash value than can be place on 
Burning Man, nor is there one that can be placed on your memories.
If someone offered you forty little green pieces of paper in exchange for 
all of your memories surrounding last weekend, would you trade???

In the words of Richard Bach:
"Anyone you want to keep in your life, _never_ take them for granted."

It applies not only to humans, but to everything. As soon as anything is 
taken for granted, it disappears. Kind of like the vibe. As soon as you 
assume that it's going to be there, it's gone. 
*That's* what I was trying to get at. 
So much for the concise, one page post. :)

I'm sorry this is so long, --but-- 
i've never been called "anal" before. :)  	lv, Alex



      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 00:59:35 1995

Subject: Burning man report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Burning man report
==================

After last years very strange and exciting encounters at Burning Man
festival,  I just HAD to do it again this year.   I think that no matter
where I would ever be in the world,  I would ALWAYS somehow try and make
it back to the Black Rock Desert in September.   WOW!!  What an
incredible way to end a wonderful raving summer.

Preparation
-----------

It took some preparation for this trip,   mostly because of the fact
that it's a dry desert,  and there are essential items one should take,
such as plenty or water and material to make shade.

A fellow SFRaver Seth contacted me and was the only rider that responded
to my posting on SFRaves.   There were others,  but nobody called me
back,  so I assumed they got rides.

The Trip
--------

We left late Thursday evening,   drove through the evening,  thanx to
Seth to arrive at Gerlach's Bruno's Bar,  where I was to hook up with
one of the organizers to put up an Internet link out on the Playa.

So,  we pull into the ONLY gas station in this town,  look round and I
find Travis (Another Raver dude).   We talk for a while I went into
Bruno's to hook up with Stewart.   I went to his hotel room but couldn't
find him,  so we went out to the Playa,   following our directions
PRECISELY.   At this point,  it was about 8 am,  which was
a perfect time to arrive.   It was cool enough so that I could scout
around on my dirt bike without roasting in the sun.

Setting up
----------

At this point,  things were still getting set up,   and markers laid
out in a more organized way with little red flags,  defining the various
areas used by the festival.   These well defined areas made it MUCH
better to locate other camps.   For instance,  they had red flags
radiating WEST out from main center,  YELLOW for North,   etc.    Then,
one would locate a camp in a quadrant between the specific flags.

My first order of business was to contact Stewart to see what was being
done to establish an Internet connection between the Playa and the rest
of the world.   I was somewhat skeptical if it was possible to send a
good enough quality of signal to pass data packets reliably,   but
eventually,  Stewart finally got a group of people with the equipment,
and things were getting set up.

I stayed out of the way and looked amazement as a radio station sorta
materialized out of the desert.   It's simple pre-fab construction was
carefully prepared and in just a few hours,   was constructed and ready
to be hooked up.

I started looking around for the Rave camp,   but very little activity
was going on,  except a small filming group,  shooting a movie with
"Burning man" in it.


The location and setting
------------------------

The location (A huge dried out lake bed) is probably the flattest place
on earth.    Just for fun,  as I was riding my dirt bike out on the
desert,   I tried closing my eyes to see how long I could ride without
the temptation of opening them.   At first,   I could hold them close
for a few minutes,   before "getting chicken" and opening them again.
As I tried,  I also noticed that for long durations I tended to veer off
to the left,  thus circling back.    I think I was veering about 15
degrees/minute.   As I practiced,  my veer rate would diminish,  and
eventually I could hold them closed or 10 minutes.   After all that
veering around,   I couldn't see the camp anymore,   so rode in the
approximate direction,  using the stars as my guide.    Later on,   I
could barely see the outline of the familiar hills that always served as
a direction guide.    IE:  Rave camp always slightly to the right of
that really tall peak (Near where the hot springs were).

So,   after blissfully pedaling all around the desert,   I eventually
spot the laser shining BEHIND the horizon,  and learned that I had
traveled approx. 7 to 8 miles from BOTH main and rave camp.   So I set
my sites on the laser beam that unerringly guided me towards the rave.
Eventually I could see it appear above the horizon,  and it just didn't
appear to get any closer.    After about 20 minutes of steadily pedaling
I eventually made it back to rave camp,  at which time I wasted no time
in dancing.


The Environment
---------------

It rained several times,  and boy did it ever get muddy.   The mud
smelled like dead fish,  sorta had a pungy fresh smell to it,   but
completely eliminated the dust problem.   Now,  there was lots of sticky
gooey mud that people wasted no time in getting it all over their
bodies.

On Sat afternoon,  a rally nasty rainstorm came through in the afternoon
which really generated tons of mud.    I was caught in main camp where I
was just about to get a grilled cheese sandwich.   But the rain changed
all of our plans.    It came up so suddenly.

As it was raining,  I took the opportunity to borrow some soap and a
towel and took a nice refreshing shower.  Others did the opposite by
rolling in the mud.   I saw this really cool midget guy,  hanging onto
the back of the bumper of a car,  sliding in the mud.    Then,  he would
let go and spin around several times,  and would slide an incredible 50
feet after letting go.    About 100 feet away from me,   I found a huge
drum circle,  and people writhing in the mud crawling all over each
other in some twisted body ritual....  I just squished around in the
mud,  enjoying it squishing between my toes.   I dirt bike was utterly
useless,  so I stashed it somewhere and hung out until it dried.   It
dried in just 2 hours amazingly enough.

Main Features
-------------

The main feature of course was the burning of the man,   but the
afternoon,  was a fashion show,   which I thought was really unique.
After the fashion show,  I headed out to the hot springs once again and
took a well deserved break from the heat.


The Burning of the man
----------------------

I head back to the main camp to take in the final songs from the live
band (Shark Bait - I believe).   At about that time,   people were
chanting "Burning man" and the long procession began as people started
marching towards the burning man.    I quickly zipped ahead of the group
and established a good vantage point before the main contingent arrived.

As usual,  there was lots of ritualistic happenings,  such as skits,
and this rocket powered go-cart using a "pulse jet" engine.   This thing
was amazingly LOUD,  and zipped around the circle wildly.   The exhaust
pipe was glowing orange hot,  then it broke through the crowd and headed
out onto the desert.

At that time,  people were chanting "Burn it!   Burn it!" as the
organizers were trying to hold everyone back.    Eventually,  it got
lit,   but didn't quite burn evenly,  but the fireworks were absolutely
impressive as it exploded in a huge shower of sparks.   As it was
burning,   people were pulling on he guy wires until it fell over,
which was the queue for people to run towards it,   yelling and
chanting.

Shortly after that,  people were gathering around this huge penis type
chimney,  dancing around in strange dances and costumes.   Eventually,
it was lit,   and as it started to burn,   you could actually see
through it as the flames shot upwards like a rocket exhaust in purple,
green and blue flames.   Again,  people were dancing around it,  some
actually jumping directly over the flames.


The Rave(s)
-----------

Eventually,  I headed back to rave camp,  and arrived just in time to
Lucas's set.   Lucas,  eventually from the Netherlands was playing some
of the most brilliant Acid Trance I've heard in a long time.   It didn't
take me long before I had a total "out of body" experience as I bopping
around the dance area like a raving maniac.   Sheesh,  this was my 3rd
all-niter as the ONLY time I slept was on Thursday evening.   Amazingly
enough,  I danced all night long until the next DJ went on just as the
sun rose.    After that,  I chilled for a few hours and came back for
one more dance binge until the sound stopped.

The SPAZ dance area was so good that I didn't even bother to make it
over to the Wicked arena.    I did actually go over to check it out,
but found the trance more to my liking.

Leaving
-------

As it became towards the afternoon,  Seth had already packed up the tent
and supplies in the car,   so we organized a large caravan of 5 (or
more) cars to Pyramid Lake for a much deserved splooch in the cool lake
before heading through Reno and back to the Bay Area.   Thanx go to Seth
for doing all the driving as he managed to get some sleep,  as I was in
NO condition to drive at all.    We eventually make it back around 11
PM.

Crunchman

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 11:06:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA28427; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 11:06:08 -0700
