From: Jonas Judd <jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: jjudd@taurus
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Still more energy stuff
Message-Id: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950907093806.6192A-100000@taurus>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Length: 3019
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey everyone,

I'm still coming down to Earth after my experience at Black Rock desert, 
but I wanted to post while I'm still "feeling it".

Let's just say that any expereince is what you make of it.

Yeah, there was a lot of media B.S.( I was dancing while the Man and 
the mud tower burned, and I  was greeted by many a video camera, with 
someone asking "so what do you think of all this?", and "on a scale of 1 
to 10 how do you rate this?" Damn people, let me dance!

Yeah, there were drunk, clueless individuals who staggared about with glazed 
eyes, crying out for the sake of impressing their friends and others.

Yeah, there seemed to be some tension among a few of the sound systems at 
the Rave Camp.

And yeah, I'm sure the ritual is not what it used to be. (I can imagine 
how beautiful it must have been for a few hundred people to be together 
to share in this experience).

But I chose not to focus on all this. Instead, I decided to reach 
back...way back, into the depths of my psyche and get in touch with 
something that we all have within us, but appears to be buried underneath 
a deluge of conditioning, programming, self-doubt, and fear.

A primal energy that defies my explanation. 

I've experienced this energy on the dance floor, but due to the influence 
of drugs, there was no connection to it's source, so after a while, the 
"feeling" was lost. At some outdoor parties, I could feel this energy 
much more, but due to the limited duration of the TAZ, the connection to 
this energy was not as significant.

Burning Man was a TAZ that allowed enough time for the natural 
progression from conditioned human to a timeless, sentient being.  

On Sunday, after wrything around for a couple hours in the mud in front 
of the SPAZ tower, I walked into main camp, covered head to toe in mud.

The mud clinging to my skin, I could feel each hair on my body pull 
tight with each step. I felt a sort of alien, a being from some distant 
world visiting these things called "humans". I began thinking...

I am not of this world. 

Wait. I AM of this world. I've just become so distant from what I TRULY AM
that I feel alien.

This primal energy. This is me. 



I was then reminded of a Tibetan proverb:

		"If it is here, it is everywhere.
		 If it is not here, it is nowhere."


Exactly.


If Burning Man happens next year, it'll probably be more of what it was 
this year, a media free for all, a place for the family to come and look 
at all the "crazy" or "weird" people, and a very fragmented ensemble of 
energy. Perhaps all the more reason for the promoters to take a break and 
rethink their strategy for maintaining the intimacy needed for this type 
of ritual.


Burning Man gave me the reasssurance that though we all might have our 
differences, we are all connected with this primal energy. 

Perhaps if we can begin to trust this energy, welcome it and nurture it, we can 
dissolve our conditioning, thus our differences, and live in a world of 
mutual respect and trust.



Jonas

Received: from ns0002.dnt.dialog.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA29576; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 11:21:24 -0700

	id LAA10936; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 11:21:18 -0700
Received: from ccMail by corp.dialog.com
  (IMA Internet Exchange 1.04b) id 04f38540; Thu, 7 Sep 95 11:22:12 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Date: Thu, 7 Sep 1995 11:16:48 -0700
Message-ID: <04f38540@corp.dialog.com>
From: Corey_Johnson@corp.dialog.com (Corey Johnson)
Subject: The desert (s)wiped my mind. 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Description: cc:Mail note part
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     --Nomads--
     
     Don't know about the rest of you, but I find the Black Rock has 
     permanently etched images of boundless moonlit expanses on the 
     palimpsest of my brain.  Even now -sitting here at work- that taught, 
     electrical sensation on the back of my neck makes it hard for me to 
     settle entirely in the moment.  My eyes burn brighter.
     
     I would be deeply disappointed if Burning Man did not occur next year. 
     Not specifically the event itself even, but the opportunity to 
     experience that stunning, otherworldy environment, with a community.  
     My question is this:  to those of you with connections to the 
     organizers, do you think it would still be feasible to plan an 
     intimate, unrelated gathering on the playa without so much paperwork 
     and legalistic entanglement?  I'm sure that at one time Burning Man 
     was more comparable in scale to a New Moon party, without the 
     helicopters and portable toilets and the Happiness Boys in their 
     patrol cars.  What would it take?  What might it cost?  
     
     Perhaps it's time to invent new rituals and reshape the character of 
     this desert pilgrimage.  It has been suggested that we may have 
     alienated some who did not share our passion for the music.  Fair 
     enough.  This rave community includes quite a diversity of backgrounds 
     and perspectives, but as we continue to demonstrate every weekend, we 
     know how to come together and take care of each other.  Who better to 
     converge and collaborate?  Even for just 2 days it would be worth it.  
     Am I being unrealistic?  Perhaps, but I feel quite certain the playa 
     will intersect my future before another year passes.  It simply won't 
     release me.
     
     Corey Francis

        OH MAN! that was lovely! i'm burning with jealousy right now that i
couldn't attend this event (for lack of a better word, but i'm sure i could
never describe it) and also for that feeling that you've felt that i REALLY
strive for but haven't experienced in a long time: that feeling of
"everything is in it's place" that contact with everything.  One of my
favorite quotes is "ecstasy is the contemplation of wholeness" and i think
you get what i'm saying. If you haven't already read the Archaic Revival,
read it! It totally talks about the same sore of experiences that you're
talking about.  That "primal energy" is what terence Mckenna would call the
"overmind" or the "oversoul" or the "gaian mind" and coming into contact
with that, that thing that is sooo deeply buried in all of us (and that
thing that many have tried to supress for the past couple thousand years)
that it DOES feel completely alien to us. He goes on to say that the rash
of UFO sightings and all the craziness with aliens and abductions (and this
is a TOTALLY observable cultural phenomenon currently) is a reflection of
the fact aht there are a lot of ppl (ravers and non-ravers alike) who are
beginning to percieve something outside of empircally substantiated
science.
        anyways, i just thought i'd pass this on to you but being that
you're into Hakim Bey and TAZ theory and whatevah i figured you'd be
interested if you haven't already read McKenna's stuff. It IS good to know
that there are ppl out there who are having similar experiences and
thoughts as me though :)
        take care,
                brad

In-Reply-To: <9508068104.AA810431680@beluga.adoc.xerox.com> from "Diane Tabellija" at Sep 6, 95 05:54:21 pm

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>      After reading Grigsby's BM post and speaking w/a person who is 
>      involved w/BM paraphanalia (who also has some connections w/the 
>      organizers), it is true that there may not be a Burning Man next year. 
>      
>      Evidentally there were far more injuries and incidents this year than 
>      the past...partly due to the larger number of attendees and the 
>      attraction media gave the event.  The law enforcement presence did not 
>      help either.

The main problem, I think, is that it's no longer fun for the organizers;
they're spending all their time trying to keep people from injuring themselves,
dealing with police/BLM officials, raising money, and other not-fun things --
and they're still losing money each year.  As someone put it, "The credit 
cards are all maxed out.  If we don't make money this year we're going to
have to pack it in."

My suggestion?  Let it rest for a year; let the feeding frenzy die down.
Let the organizers pay off their credit cards.
Let people realize how much it means to them, how much they miss
it, and if the playa experience means that much, go ahead and do one
themselves.
Then, start again, maybe even on a different date, with word of mouth.
Redesign the Man (which people were planning to do anyway), and don't
try to make a huge spectacle out of it.  No bands, no raves, nothing
up on a stage, nothing that needs a generator to run, just the Man
and what people bring to him.  Keep the costs down, keep the spectacle
down, and maybe all the people who came because it looks like just another
night South of Market except with some nekkid chicks will skip it because
there's nothing there to consume anymore.  Back to the basics.

It's a nice thought, anyway, but as Fugazi said, "You can't be what you were,
so you'd better start being what you are."  I don't know if it's possible
to find the magic again without people splitting off and burning their
own Man, but it's worth thinking about.

// g

My mailer says that Grigsbeast said:
> 
> Then, start again, maybe even on a different date, with word of mouth.
> Redesign the Man (which people were planning to do anyway), and don't
> try to make a huge spectacle out of it.  
> [...]
> I don't know if it's possible
> to find the magic again without people splitting off and burning their
> own Man, but it's worth thinking about.
> 
hmmm....i've been ignoring most of the Flaming Dude discussion, since i
didn't go, didn't want to go, and anticipated spectacle.  so, i come to
this discussion/thread ~very~ late, having only dipped into a few posts.

grigsbeast post, along with diane's, are quite suggestive of the many things
that went on, as well as capturing the ambience.  i am reminded of my own
experiences going from rave consumer to rave helper.  while the Flaming
Dude may indeed be a wonderful thing, is this Flaming Dude the one and
only flaming dude that *can* be in the world, or is it possible for there
to more than one?  i think so.

if there can be more than one full moon rave going at a time, each 
contributing to the collective full moon rave, with every participant
happy and joined together mystically, it seems entirely possible that
many people could put together their own, smaller Flaming Dudes, and
those who want to put on a Flaming Dude Massive can do their flaming
thing, and everybody's happier.
-- 
=== Bryce Ryan ===== AMBIANCE ========= e-dress: brycer@ultima.org =========
=== Internet services, education, and Toaster Net construction :-) =========

list have come from the San Francisco contingent of guys ....

Brian, I thought you knew me better than that.  I would never post anything
to this list that was intended to be deliberately inflammatory.  If offense
has been taken, I apologize, but I assumed that most guys on this list (and
girls too) would understand the spirit of fun in which it was intended.  I
receive my share of sexist and specifically redhead jokes here at work but
I am secure enough in myself to know that my co-workers aren't being
insulting to me personally.

the word "rave" has been used as slang for the last 30 years for: staying up all 
night and dancing. The only thing that has changed is that now we do it in 
the day sometimes too. I like the word, and I think if you are not comfortable 
with the worst thing someone can say about you... then its time to fire your 
Image Consultant!

If you don't like dancing then some of the other good things about raving 
may one day let you down. But as it is: rave culture has got the dance music 
thing goin' on... and you are allowed to dance in the most freakish manner 
one could imagine- someone might even hug you for it.
;.;.;.;.;....................................................;.;.;.;.;

Perhaps there are some ways to capitalize and recapitulate the growing
popularity of the Burning-Man. 

I thought the event would make an ideal proving ground for 
Performance-Art/Theater students. Actually, I will be teaching a Visual 
Arts course online this year, and am considering incorporating a 
'field-trip' to the BM Event. Architecture/sculpture students could be 
assigned the problem of erecting a sturdy structure based on a single 
blue-polypropylene tarp.

I'd appreciate hearing more on the evolving structure of the BM; I still 
think it's uncanny how similar this year's effigy is to Nevada power-line 
towers.

/b

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 14:35:10 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA13541; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 14:35:10 -0700
Received: from blizzard.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA13532; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 14:35:02 -0700
Received: by blizzard.berkeley.edu
	(5.65c/IDA-1.4.4.1-DomainOS) id AA01938; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 14:34:52 -0700
Date: Thu, 7 Sep 1995 14:34:52 -0700
From: Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199509072134.AA01938@blizzard.berkeley.edu>
To: ravers@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: thoughts on burning man
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, you see, I'd never even been to the desert before.  I sat in the backseat
of our cramped car as we motored through the Sierras, squinting at my U2 Joshua
Tree CD, trying to get an idea of what the terrain would be like.  Cactus?  
Sand?  Scorpions?  I really didn't know; we don't have any deserts back east,
and I'd never been to Nevada before.  
I had dramatic visions of myself crawling across the desert floor in 110 degree
midday heat, hallucinating waterfalls and such, so I made everyone in my group
buy gallons of water at the ShopKo in Reno.  Armed with food, drink, supplies,
and anticipation, we left Reno at around 5 pm on Saturday (we had left Berkeley
earlier that day), and arrived at Black Rock Desert near sundown.  
	As we steered our nervous little Nissan off the highway and pointed it
towards some lights twinkling in the distance, I felt like we'd landed on Mars.
The landscape was *so* brilliantly different from anywhere else I'd been, the
sky was so much bigger (since the horizon line, in every direction, was so 
faraway), and the colors had been switched.  Instead of greens, bright blues,
and whites, nature had chosen rich red clay, pink dust storms, neon yellow
lightning bolts, and an orange moon.  
	We drove around in the twilight, trying to figure out where the rave
camp was.  All around us were tents, scaffolding towers, blinking lights, dusty
motorbikes, off-road pick-up trucks, campfires, and a glowing, enormous, statue
of a man, the burning man, and he was outfitted in blue and red tubelights.
	The scene was awesome in the truest sense of the word.  I felt a bit out
of place at first, but I was excited about getting into character.  I wanted to
be dusty, too, and I wanted some boots, and a cigarette, and smoke through my 
detergent-scented clothes.  We found the rave camp, and I hopped out of the car
and ran over to what I would later discover was the Gateway setup.  The first 
person I spotted was Jon Carel, my favorite DJ, and I asked him where everything
was.  "This is it!" he shouted.  "The main camp's that way, and Wicked is over
there..."   We talked about how beautifully strange everything was, and how it
felt as if we were in some post-nuclear war renegade camp.  I felt like I shouldhave been dressed up as a ravesoldier, or a fighter pilot, or something... I was
in the middle of a movie and I wanted a copy of the script.
	So my friends and I parked the car, pitched our tents, and went looking
for others that we knew.  I saw my friends Dave and Ben, who were huddling by a
fire eating food from tin cans, I saw my friend Reza, who I had raved with all
summer long, saw Claire and the Gateway crew, Fiona and Jenna and Jesse and Rona
and a bunch of other Berkeley ravers.  And I couldn't get over how -cool- every-
one looked!  Standing around in the desert, making tent repairs, planning shuttle runs to main camp, fixing dinner, sharing water and talking excitedly.
	I ended up dancing ecstatically that night, crashing in my tent at 
around 4 a.m., dusty and sweaty and blissed out.  I woke up an hour later to 
eat tiny bits of paper with my friend Joe, and we got to see the sun come up over the red hills on the eatern lip of the desert.  The morning music was pounding
good and hard, it was bright, warm, and just 9a.m. when our shirts came off,
sweat-drenched and mud-caked.  We floated through the rest of the day, lying in
the hot sun, checking out the main camp, and preparing for the final night.
At around 1 pm, a thunderstorm hit, turning the ravecamp into a muddy Woodstock.
People splashed around in the muck, and the bravest ones got completely naked 
and covered themselves in green mud.  Lightning came crashing down in big pitch-forks, (thank God none of us were struck, actually), and when the storm finally
passed over, you could see a skyscraping mushroom cloud and a double rainbow off
in the distance, and if you looked one way, you'd see a hailstorm, the other,
clear blue sky.  Reza said to me, "well, you'd never been to Nevada before, and
I still don't think you've ever been."  The Bay Area seemed orbits away.
	They finally burned the man later that night, and I heard a rumor that
some protestors planned on disrupting the ceremony, and for that reason, 
supposedly, the organizers kept everyone at considerable distance. It was still
a good showing, however.  I know that some American Indian tribes have burning
rituals, where the burning of statues and belongings represents spiritual 
cleansing.  I'm not sure if this is what the organizers had in mind here, but I 
liked my interpretation so I thought about it as I watched the fire.  
They also torched the "Langin"(sp.?) statue that night, which was clearly a 
sexual representation.  It was a phallic tower that had female characteristics
to it, but was still overwhelmingly masculine.  That was another thing about 
Burning Man--the festival, to me, anyways, had a very male quality to it.  I 
missed the sexual equality that most raves have (I'm not talking about the 
number of men and women present, I'm talking about the general attitude), but itwas an experience to see this type of setup, too.
	The DJ's on the last night, the ones from UltraViolet (a Dutch troupe
that spins hard trance), kicked my head in.  The music was relentless, and the
people dancing were appreciative of the tempo, too.  You could tell how much the
fun the DJ's were having--pounding their fists in the air, heads bouncing around
like a Jack-in-the-box, and smiles stuck on their faces.  
	It was Monday morning now, and we ended up leaving around 8 o'clock. It
was sad to drive away, and Jesse and I had said the day before how we had just
started getting used to be dusty, scrappy, desert-rave urchins.  I didn't even
want to take a shower anymore, and the trail mix, as long as you don't mind
raisins, was pretty tasty.  But we had stuff to do back in Berkeley, so we said
bye-bye to Burning Man and started the long drive home.
	For those who didn't get to go, go next year.  And the year after that.
It's one of those experiences that swims around in your head for a week after-
wards.  Also, hi to Brian McGonigle, who I saw on his bike but didn't get to
stop and chat with (and get a hug from!) and all other SFRavers who I didn't 
manage to say hi too.  Well, that was Burning Man out of my eyes--hope everyone
else had a sandblast as well.
	Love and double rainbows to all
	Timothy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 15:29:53 1995

	id m0sqpSG-002qkbC; Thu, 7 Sep 95 15:29 PDT

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: GHB?; A New Recreational Drug(?), All Natural & Body Friendly(?), That Really Delivers/Kicks Butt(?); LONG
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950907142218.22099A-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	While I was at the most glorious of Sunset's of all, a friend 
asked me if I wanted to try a new drug called GHB. Having never heard the 
acronym before, I was curious and cautious for many reasons that will follow.

	They showed me what appeared to be a slightly mirky, but basically
transparent liquid. I asked him if it was just MDMA in a liquid form and
he assured me it was not. He said that the drug was a new SEX drug that
was all natural & made up of amino-acids that are produced in the human
body. 

	My immediate thought was OH, another Herbal(crap) E, or boy is
this going to be anti-climatic. Well, being the person that will try
almost anything once I purchased 3 capfuls for $10.00, which was ruffly
about a little more than a double shot. It tasted like watered down E, but
not as vomit provoking. I then went on my merry little raver way,
expecting not to feel anything except ripped off, or possibly sick to my
stomach. Cause we all know that every substance on the planet that is
worth it's weight as a mood altering substance has either been controled,
exterminated, horded, or sold by the Fed's; right? 

	NOT!!!, 15 minutes later WOW!!!!, I MEAN REALLY WOW!!!!!!, I 
cannot go into words that would describe the MANY wonderful feelings and 
sensations I experienced for over 3 - 4 hours. Keep in mind folks I'm the 
person who was interviewed by MTV, who got on camera saying to the Youth 
of the world, "Do the real thing", meaning Herbal E is hype, and do real 
MDMA. I don't like advocating the use of mood altering substances, but 
this one is worth some look at. Note, other freinds who took the drug 
experienced different feelings & sensations, which considering we are 
all wonderfully unique, is not surprising, however, everyone I spoke to 
said that it was fantastic. AFterword I didn't experience any type of 
hangover or aftereffects, it was like I didn't do anything at all. 
However some people did experience a very very deep sleep towards the end 
of the experience, how deep you ask, like we had to pick them up, and 
walk them around in order to wake them; that deep.

	If I had to describe what it was like I would use this analogy: 
MDMA is to GHB, as LSD or MUshrooms are to Mescaline. Different paths, that 
eventually take you to the same place. Nuff said.

	Cause this is a relativily new substance, and it's showing up on our
scene, which is one of the most connected(Internet) scenes in the world, I
would like to encourage people to share their positive & negative
experiences around this drug, with at least me, as this could both enhance 
life & save it.

	Precautions: Because it's a "SEX" drug, a very powerful one in my 
opinion, you should first try it around people you TRUST WITHOUT ANY 
DOUBT IN YOUR MIND. Start out with a small dose and work your way up, 
there will be many raves in the future for you to get really wild at. It 
comes in a liquid form, this should immediately tell you that this 
substance can end up in anything, like the soda that seemingly nice 
person just offered you. I say this cause one of our female friends took 
the drug, and ended up with someone she didn't want to or planned to be 
with. Both genders need to be careful around this drug, especially womyn 
who have been traditionally and almost exclusively the victums of rape, 
and non-consentting sex. 

	This is the most important, and most overlooked by people, new drug
precaution. Say you take GHB, and you have an allergic, excessive, or 
negative reaction, and you go to your local emergency room to get help. 
You tell the doctor I took GHB, and they look at you and say sorry I've 
never heard of the drug, we can't help you. THis can happen, cause is a 
new bootlegged drug. If it does make sure you take a healthy sample of 
the drug with you so that they can at least analyze it, cause once it's 
in your body, it's harder to do that, especially if they are just tring 
to keep you alive.

	GHB I feel will be around for awhile, if it doesn't kill anyone, 
and if the FED's don't get their hands on it. I however will try it 
again, until I either get tired of it, or have a bad experience, So enjoy 
yourself's and most of all USE YOU HEAD, DON'T LOSE IT.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Big squishy SFRaves hugs
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm not real sure how to begin on this one, or even what prompted it.  I
guess it was after reading all the burning man posts.  I got to thinking
that most people here don't think of SFRaves as a mailing list.  Think about
it.  How many of you get on your computer, check your mail, and go "oh, it's
another SFRaves message."  At least for me, I get on and read them and they
make me all warm and tingly.  Even those of you who I haven't met, I feel
like I already know.  Those of you I have met have been the greatest people.
I know that most lists are sort of an information exchange.  Here, it's more
than that.  It's like a family.  After being on the list for a while now, I
feel like not only do I know what all of you know about, but also your
personalities.  I know you all as people, not as some lifeless voice that
floats out of cyberspace.
        Something that made me realize this happened about a month ago.  If
you hadn't picked it up from my massive sig, my passion in life is the 4AD
recording label.  It's music that moves me incredibly.  I had always heard
that there was a 4AD listserve out there and had always wanted to join.
"Wow," I thought, "I'll finally have a chance to discuss this great music
with others who feel the same way about it as I do."  When I finally did
find it a few weeks back, imagine my disappointment when all most people
cared about was whining about the label going downhill and having petty
arguments back and forth.  That's when I realized what makes SFRaves so
different.  People are generally positive and friendly, and even if they
have anything critical to say, it is usually of the constructive variety.
        A lot has changed in my life in the last 6 months, a good amount of
that because of the scene and _especially_ you guys.  You all provide this
positive energy that I've never, _never_ found so strongly in a group of
people.  I remember a few weeks back when my friend Matt posted something
saying he'd had a bad day, and not only did he recieve tons of email, but
about 4 phone calls on top of that.  It's great to see people reaching out
like that to others.  We tend to forget, but most people can't do that so
unreservedly. 
        So I just wanted to send BIG hugs out to all of you, and hope I get
to meet you all at some point.  And to those of you I've met, Brian D.,
Black Adder, Reagan, Brian M., Amy, Karen and anyone else I forgot, thanks
for showing me that friends from cyberspace can be more than just that.  I
feel the same way about all of ya, and with any luck we'll all meet up
someday.  That would make Jake a very happy camper :)

Love,
Jake

have been working in the multimedia industry; most likely I will be working 
a lot at home.   Also, I have a cat--she is tidy and well behaved and has

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello fellow sfravers,

After being a silent listener for six months, I am finally making my first 
post to sfraves. 

Before I begin, I would like to thank everyone for their incredible 
contribution to this list. I still cannot get over the amount of 
positive energy that this list generates. I know that I can always turn
to sfraves to have a smile put back on my face.

I was born in Australia and lived there all my life until moving to
San Francisco three years ago. I have absolutely no doubt that San Francisco
is the best city in the world. I have never met such positive, open,
friendly people. Discovering the rave scene a year ago, and sfraves six
months later has made life in this city even more incredible. I didn't think
that was possible but it is. Thank you all!

Now why am I posting? Well I need your help. I would like to attend my first
FMR this Friday. (Please let it be Friday night!) I am arranging for seven
or eight of my friends to join me. I have heard so much about this party for
so long now, but have never been able to attend because of work. Well this
time I'm going to be there.

However I do not have the phone number! If anyone can help, please email me. 
You will make seven or eight people very happy.

Thanks in advance.

Keep on smiling,

Scott.

basfords@corp.hp.com

>I'm not real sure how to begin on this one, or even what prompted it.  I
>guess it was after reading all the burning man posts.  I got to thinking
>that most people here don't think of SFRaves as a mailing list.  Think about
>it.  How many of you get on your computer, check your mail, and go "oh, it's
>another SFRaves message."  At least for me, I get on and read them and they
>make me all warm and tingly.  Even those of you who I haven't met, I feel
>like I already know.  Those of you I have met have been the greatest people.
>I know that most lists are sort of an information exchange.  Here, it's more
>than that.  It's like a family.  After being on the list for a while now, I
>feel like not only do I know what all of you know about, but also your
>personalities.  I know you all as people, not as some lifeless voice that
>floats out of cyberspace.
>        Something that made me realize this happened about a month ago.  If
>you hadn't picked it up from my massive sig, my passion in life is the 4AD
>recording label.  It's music that moves me incredibly.  I had always heard
>that there was a 4AD listserve out there and had always wanted to join.
>"Wow," I thought, "I'll finally have a chance to discuss this great music
>with others who feel the same way about it as I do."  When I finally did
>find it a few weeks back, imagine my disappointment when all most people
>cared about was whining about the label going downhill and having petty
>arguments back and forth.  That's when I realized what makes SFRaves so
>different.  People are generally positive and friendly, and even if they
>have anything critical to say, it is usually of the constructive variety.
>        A lot has changed in my life in the last 6 months, a good amount of
>that because of the scene and _especially_ you guys.  You all provide this
>positive energy that I've never, _never_ found so strongly in a group of
>people.  I remember a few weeks back when my friend Matt posted something
>saying he'd had a bad day, and not only did he recieve tons of email, but
>about 4 phone calls on top of that.  It's great to see people reaching out
>like that to others.  We tend to forget, but most people can't do that so
>unreservedly. 
>        So I just wanted to send BIG hugs out to all of you, and hope I get
>to meet you all at some point.  And to those of you I've met, Brian D.,
>Black Adder, Reagan, Brian M., Amy, Karen and anyone else I forgot, thanks
>for showing me that friends from cyberspace can be more than just that.  I
>feel the same way about all of ya, and with any luck we'll all meet up
>someday.  That would make Jake a very happy camper :)
>
>Love,
>Jake

From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@collab.com>
Subject: This letter is dedicated to you
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is a letter I am writing the friends we've made in the SFR community.

wayne

--

I had an awesome time at Burning Man.

I just can't put into words the things that happend out there that would
even remotely approach what happened, but upon leaving, we all felt like
it's changed us in strange, spiritual ways. Since I cannot assemble words
do justice to those feelings, I will not betray them with a verbally flawed
account. All I can say is that it was the best weekend of my life and I
simply just cannot tell you why. It was each and every minute, each and
every hour, each and every day we were there. Individually and summarily,
the moments were magical. I'll leave the 'overall' Burning Man experience
description to that.

---

I wanted to tell you that we are giving the SFR laminates out to show how
much we care about the scene and how much we care about all of you. We
really wanted to give something back to each of you individually and at the
same time bring all of us together. I think it's working. If you don't have
one yet, have no fear, There will be one for each and every one of you.

---

There's a couple specific events that I want share with you. It's just a
couple short stream-of-consciousness conversations that happened that I
hope affect all of you out there the way that they did me.

My friend Rusty is out there with us Sunday night at Burning Man in the
Wicked area, and he's experiencing a ravE for the first time. (Can you
think of a better 'first rave?!) Like all of us, at this point he is
totally immersed in the desert, the music, the vibe and the people.

I was off wandering around for a while dancing with all of you, then I
stopped by to see how he was doing and to give him his 'first' hug. In this
blissful state he tells me, "Now I know why you have to share this so
badly."

-

Then a short time later he asks Vince, "How long does this feeling last?"

and Vince tells him,    *"The rest of your life!"*

-

It's already been a few days, but whenever I think about or tell someone
this story, the power of those words words create this rush of emotions and
I get tears in my eyes.

I really hope it does the same for you.

That's why we rave.

jon asks;
> 	Say, did Sunset happen last weekend while bunches of us were at 
> BM?  How did it go?

It was pretty great.  Galen, Solar, Dervish & John Howard did a tag team
thing, switching off every 15 minutes or so, spinning some of the best
music (IMO) that I've ever heard at a Sunset.  Too bad my DAT crapped 
out.  It was very well attended.  The only blemish occurred due to a
small group of very drunk passerbys who decided to join us.  The cretins
stumbled about, littered their bottles, and generally enjoyed themselves
causing little trouble until one decided to get into a fight with his
girlfriend(?) and ripped her dress.  Someone called the police who
came and I guess took care of things.

> 	Does anyone know about the Family party this weekend being thrown 
> by Pacific?

$15  benefit to help pay off Pacific's soundsystem and some of the 
tickets they've received.  Call the Pacific # for more info.  Or Gateway's,
I think they're throwing it.

Lee

Forwarded message:
From:	STUMANGRUM@aol.com
To:	burnman-list@well.com
Date: 95-09-07 14:58:39 EDT

Just got off the phone with Vanessa K. of the Black Rock Rangers, who
informed me that clean-up is still in progress and there's a lot of work
still to be done. Gerlach High students are helping with recycling, but other
than that it's down to three guys (Michael2, John L. and Chris D.) and they
say they'll be lucky if they're done by Sunday. There are still THOUSANDS of
cigarette butts, firecracker papers, etc. to be picked up. 

If you are within striking range of the site, and have a few hours to spare,
PLEASE jump in your car right now and head out to help with the clean-up.
Bring a rake, a shovel, a dustpan, and a roll or two of trash bags. Unless
the BLM blesses this clean-up, we will NOT be allowed back next year. If you
care about this event, and if you can possibly find the time in your
schedule, GO NOW! 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	STUMANGRUM@aol.com
To:	burnman-list@well.com
Date: 95-09-07 02:41:50 EDT

Hi everybody,

Finally got my Mac back together after dragging it out to the desert and back
(it was installed at the mysterious "Site 19" communications bunker deep
beneath the Playa), and finally got a chance to read all the great postmortem
commentary on this list. Allow me to chip in a few cents (a handful of
change, really) of my own.

1. COPS - The local authorities were on the Playa this year by invitation of
the Black Rock Rangers, and by all reports deported themselves in exemplary
fashion.  Did you see any drug busts, or for that matter any busts at all?
Did you ever see them hassling anyone? Questioning anyone? Searching anyone?
The "Mad Max" car and the dirt bikes should give you an idea what these guys
devote the bulk of their attention and resources to: search and rescue
operations. Luckily we didn't need them for anything else this year, but
think about it: if only one-tenth of one percent of a crowd of 5,000 is going
to consist of drunken, armed, irrational psychos, that's still 5 possible
murderers. Do you want to be the volunteer who gets to escort those 5 guys
off the Playa? Even if you've got a gun yourself and you know how to use it?
I didn't think so. Let's face it: at this size and scale, we need cops. Real
cops, with real badges. Luckily, the lawmen who came out this year had a
great time and want to come back. Danger Ranger invited them to join us in
the circle next year under the two conditions that they (1) decorate their
law enforcement "theme camp" in as outrageous a manner as possible and (2)
enter at least one participant in the fashion show. They readily agreed, so
if you're a serious cop-hater you might just want to stay home next time.

2. RANGERS - It's impossible to praise these folks enough. Working literally
around the clock, operating on a few or zero hours of sleep a night, a
handful of volunteers managed to handle just about every conceivable bad
situation with courage, style, and (usually) a sense of humor. Their motto,
by the way, is "Keeping the Playa Safe for Anarchy." They lived up to it, and
then some. Next time you see one of these heroes (and I don't use that word
lightly), you ought to get down on your knees and kiss his/her dusty boots.
Without their tireless efforts, this event would have been a disaster.

3. ATTENDANCE - We're still waiting for the BLM aerial photos for a better
head count, but the general consensus seems to be 5,000. Attendance didn't
double this year - it tripled. As far as making a profit, don't get too
excited. Yes, the BLM charges us for using the land, and it ain't cheap. Add
insurance, dozens of portajohns (emptied twice a day), printing, postage,
radios, construction, et al and there's not a whole lot left. And of course
not everyone paid - especially the late Sunday arrivals who left us nothing
but their empties and a lot of piss stains on the playa. As for the "Burning
Man tour bus with satellite dish," it's owned by Andy Pector, a successful
travelling salesman who lives in that bus most of the year and comes out to
the Playa for his annual vacation. The three main organizers - Larry, John,
and Michael - have two near-dead trucks between them. They've also worked on
this event full-time for most of the year, and maxed out all their credit
cards long ago supporting earlier desert sojourns that lost money hand over
fist. I sure as hell hope they made some money on this one. But even if they
didn't, you can bet they'll be back to do it again next year. The sickness is
deep in them, and there's no known cure.

4. WEATHER - For me, the squalls were the best part of the trip. How many
times in your life do you get to see a full double rainbow? Or a 50,000-foot
cloud structure shaped exactly like the mushroom cloud from a nuclear blast?
Mother Nature was most definitely in the house, and she treated us to some of
her most awesome entertainments. Next to that, any burning pile of lumber,
regardless of how charged it may be with symbolic portent and collective
expectation, is going to be a bore. Strap on as much "what it means" bullshit
as you like - at its heart, the BM festival is an extreme desert camping trip
in one of the West's most awesome wildernesses. Rain, dust, wind and mud are
integral parts of the package tour. 

5. MEDIA - Along with the general attendance numbers, media attendance
skyrocketed this year. And no, they weren't always cool. As Minister of
Propaganda (retired), I'll take part of the blame for that, but there's not
all that much blame to go around. For the most part, the 4th estate behaved
themselves, with nothing like the arrogance we witnessed two years ago with
that @#$%^& HBO crew. As far as the burn being staged for the media's
benefit, that's a lot of crap. This year's burn was more tightly managed for
safety and crowd control, period. But yeah, there were a lot of flash bulbs
popping. On the way home, in Bruno's, I talked with a couple of bow hunters
who watched the burn through spotting scopesfrom atop of the adjoining ridge
(did you see those pockets of snow up around 8,000 feet?), and they said the
thousands of blue flashes around the bonfire were really beautiful. Glad
somebody enjoyed them.   

6. RAVERS - The rave scene is nothing new to Burning Man, and vice-versa.
This year there was a much heavier presence for the Big Hat crowd, but any
notion that ravers are "corrupting" the event is just plain stupid. My only
complaints were that (1) too many ravers heard about the event through
non-standard channels and arrived unprepared for wilderness camping (Who
needs blankets? I've got X!), and (2) too many tried to crash the gate or
weasel their way in as "crew." On one shift at the gate, I had no fewer than
16 people claim to be "the main DJ" for Spazz. Next time, if we're going to
talk it up on the rave lists, let's make an effort to get the right
information out - that this is NOT just another rave event.  

7. GUNS - Who had an M-16? There were a lot of Chinese SKS's around, but I
never saw an M-16, or even an AR-15 for that matter. Too expensive for this
crowd. As far as the "survivalist" presence, I saw about 5,000 of them, some
better at it than others. Guns are a fact of life out in rural Nevada, and
the reason we pack so much heat at the gate is not to intimidate our fellow
campers, but to dissuade any two-legged coyotes from trying to make off with
our cashbox or dropping in to prey on all you visiting "hippies." Last year
there were bonafide pirates on the Playa - a gang in a 4x4 luring motorists
to their truck at night with a flashing light and then trying to shake them
down for cash. They didn't come back this year, and you can thank Big Joe and
his heavily armed friends for that.   

8. THE BURN - What's there to say? You either enjoyed it or you didn't. For
me, it represented nothing more or less than closure on another year's work.
I went back to my tent, enjoyed a little late-night supper with one of the
more arresting Black Rock Rangers (my wife Paizley Hayes, sporting a chamois
skirt and a fur-trimmed vest layered in keys and spent brass), and got my
first full night of sleep in weeks. And that, my friends, was a pleasure mere
words cannot describe.

I encourage all of you to keep using this list as a forum for critiquing and
discussing this year's event. Even if I don't have much chance to respond
directly, I assure you I will be lurking and listening, and that I will share
your comments and impressions with the core staff when they return from
policing up cigarette butts and firecracker papers. If you have comments or
suggestions specific to media/communications issues, contact me directly at
stumangrum@aol.com

One last thing - don't stress too hard about getting the dust off your car
and out of your stuff. It's impossible. Just think of it as carrying a little
of the Playa around with you wherever you go. Every time I open my trunk and
see that dust in the nooks and crannies, I'll think about Burning Man, and
about you. 

See you next year on the Playa,

Stuart Mangrum
Ex-Interim Minister of Propaganda (ret.)
Burning Man Project

"The future, however radiant, does not yet exist, and the present is a line
without thickness." - Anthony Burgess  




Forwarded message:
From:	STUMANGRUM@aol.com
To:	burnman-list@well.com
Date: 95-09-07 02:41:50 EDT

Hi everybody,

Finally got my Mac back together after dragging it out to the desert and back
(it was installed at the mysterious "Site 19" communications bunker deep
beneath the Playa), and finally got a chance to read all the great postmortem
commentary on this list. Allow me to chip in a few cents (a handful of
change, really) of my own.

1. COPS - The local authorities were on the Playa this year by invitation of
the Black Rock Rangers, and by all reports deported themselves in exemplary
fashion.  Did you see any drug busts, or for that matter any busts at all?
Did you ever see them hassling anyone? Questioning anyone? Searching anyone?
The "Mad Max" car and the dirt bikes should give you an idea what these guys
devote the bulk of their attention and resources to: search and rescue
operations. Luckily we didn't need them for anything else this year, but
think about it: if only one-tenth of one percent of a crowd of 5,000 is going
to consist of drunken, armed, irrational psychos, that's still 5 possible
murderers. Do you want to be the volunteer who gets to escort those 5 guys
off the Playa? Even if you've got a gun yourself and you know how to use it?
I didn't think so. Let's face it: at this size and scale, we need cops. Real
cops, with real badges. Luckily, the lawmen who came out this year had a
great time and want to come back. Danger Ranger invited them to join us in
the circle next year under the two conditions that they (1) decorate their
law enforcement "theme camp" in as outrageous a manner as possible and (2)
enter at least one participant in the fashion show. They readily agreed, so
if you're a serious cop-hater you might just want to stay home next time.

2. RANGERS - It's impossible to praise these folks enough. Working literally
around the clock, operating on a few or zero hours of sleep a night, a
handful of volunteers managed to handle just about every conceivable bad
situation with courage, style, and (usually) a sense of humor. Their motto,
by the way, is "Keeping the Playa Safe for Anarchy." They lived up to it, and
then some. Next time you see one of these heroes (and I don't use that word
lightly), you ought to get down on your knees and kiss his/her dusty boots.
Without their tireless efforts, this event would have been a disaster.

3. ATTENDANCE - We're still waiting for the BLM aerial photos for a better
head count, but the general consensus seems to be 5,000. Attendance didn't
double this year - it tripled. As far as making a profit, don't get too

       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9pm-midnight - Seth w/ambient-experimental,
       acid-trance-techno, industrial and trip-hop on KALX 90.7
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 18:33:04 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA01304; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 18:33:04 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA01293; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 18:33:00 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	 id SAA27489; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 18:32:34 -0700
Message-Id: <v02120d0bac7539141735@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-Priority: 1 (Highest)
Date: Thu, 7 Sep 1995 18:32:15 -0700
To: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@collab.com>
From: rhea@xinet.COM (Rhea Gossett)
Subject: Re: This letter is dedicated to you
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, sweet thing!

You just made me cry, too.

>Then a short time later he asks Vince, "How long does this feeling last?"
>
>and Vince tells him,    *"The rest of your life!"*
>
>-
>
>It's already been a few days, but whenever I think about or tell someone
>this story, the power of those words words create this rush of emotions and
>I get tears in my eyes.

What a beautiful response to such a hopeful, longing, human question -
a while ago, the morning after the first ravE of two of my friends, we
talked about how beautiful the night was, the music, dancing, such surges
of pleasure, the joy of being in a place where everyone was simply HUMAN
and it
was enough - simply lovely, to be together...

They asked my boyfriend and I a similar question to the one your
friend asked Vince - wondering if it would always feel so wonderful and
right.

I did not quite know what to tell them - I mean, to me the answer
first seemed to wobble between "yes" and "no." At my first ravE - I
felt such a stunning joyous shock of "rightness" - like all my deepest
dreams and most delicate hopes had come true, and that all the love I'd
felt inside me for my whole life should NOT be buried in my heart, or
crushed down, or forgotten--it was beautiful and soft, both odd and
familiar, and natural as color and light.

That intensity of my "first time" has not been matched to this day.
But even as I write this, I hesitate - "is that true" ??  It seems
true only when I imagine my own existence within *time* - where there
is an imagined end, and a vague beginning, and where mysterious benchmarks
exist that I can hold memories up against, and compare them to.

But during each experiencE - I *can* feel that same surge of
hope, love, joy!  Where it seems to ebb is when my mind balks, and
struggles to lay its well-known "space/time" framework over my experience -
trying to evaluate it in comparison with others in the past, or with the
experiences of people around me, to try (who knows why??) to come up with
some sort of "definite" way to judge/rank/postulate an order...it's
merciless.

So damn funny, when, for me (with and without E), that "definite" so often
fades and becomes irrelevant.

To generalize a bit, it would seem that we humans (or hell, at least ME -
bear with me, I must need to imagine some company for myself, here)
have a lot of problems when we try to formulate our existence within the
framework of TIME.  We see time either on a llllooooonnnggg scale, extending
through the universe: in which case, we never seem to have enough of it.
Or, within this position of "scarcity", we compare one "time" to another -
as if we ourselves stayed constant, and "time" was the only variable...
so we can LONG for things in the past, and REGRET things in the past, and
PLACE EXPECTATIONS on the future.  We are shaping our lives *outside* the
moment; so time, then, though we spend a lot of "time" imagining it, does
not really exist at all.

That's why I think Vince's response is perfect - so often I ask myself these
skewed questions, then hate myself when I can't come up with the answers.
It's not a question of "how long" - our "time" is our LIFE.

Enough of my endless speculations, here's a bit of me:

I went to Burning Man, but did not meet you.  My mind was blank, blank as
the desert, filling with whatever happened, taking everything in.
I felt no desire to connect, though I walked by that cool V-MAR
truck & the SFRaves encampment many many times - I just wanted to exist,
without "human" verification, and sprawl in puddles of water and wet clay,
and crouch for cover from the hail, and smile at the clouds & rainbows, and

relish the thunder and lightning (god, I love a STORM), and discover the
graciousness of shade, and fix my collapsed tent for the 67th time, and sit
and bake on that flat-to-perfection lake bed and let the music drift around
me till it became inseparable from thought.

I enjoyed my dusty self.  I am lonely for that desert.

But, your letter made me cry - and tears are NOT the opposite of joy,
that loving feeling.  My tears helped me find words to share my lonely,
dusty love.  :)  :) :)

I send you love, outside of time, for that chance to be! here! now!

Rhea

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA09147; Thu, 7 Sep 1995 20:31:52 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@collab.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: Re: GHB? etc.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sorry for being so terse today, but everyone on this list should know to
check the Hyperreal FAQ archives for any questions on d-r-u-g-s.  I'll tell
you whatever misinformation I know(I havent' tried it):  GHB is a substance
naturally found in the human body once legally used by some as a sleep aid
and body building aid.  Generally found in a liquid state, a dose about a
capful.  It became popular for its e-like effects a couple years ago in LA.
Overuse and combining with alcohol and other depressants can possibly cause
seizures or even coma.  It can put you to sleep, making it a dubious rave
drug although some have used it with stimulants to good effect.  During its
LA heyday, alleged users included one B.I. (name changed to protect the
famous) who had to be taken to the hospital a couple of times after using
it.  Now in a legal grey area.  Phoenix may have taken it the night he died
for all I know, as a "natural" substance it's hard to detect, but with all
the other stuff that showed up in his blood, it would certainly be unfair to
blame GHB.  

Take it with a grain of salt.

David

At 05:58 PM 9/7/95 -0700, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

Wow, 2nd letter of the day to make me want to cry from joy! ;)
I feel as you do, Jake.  To me, reading my sfraves e-mail is more than 
just "checking my messages".  It is getting in touch with real people.  
And not just *any* people - sfravers have *got* to be some of the most 
wonderful special people I have ever met in my life.  I never thought 
joining a rave mailing list could affect my life so profoundly!  I have 
made REAL FRIENDSHIPS as a result....something hard to find these days.
Someone (who shall remain anonymous) once told me I was making too much 
out of these internet contacts - I put too much of myself into it and I 
should back off a little.  That would have been the biggest mistake I 
could ever make.  You guys never let me or anyone down when we pour our 
heart and soul into our messages.  We treat each other with the respect 
we deserve and as a result, we can open up to one another without fear, 
and therefore get past the bullshit and go straight to the meat of the 
matter.  That is what *true* friendship is about.  Thank you for such a 
great post, Jake. I hope to see you again soon.

love,
Amy

On Thu, 7 Sep 1995, Rhea Gossett wrote:

> At my first ravE - I
> felt such a stunning joyous shock of "rightness" - like all my deepest
> dreams and most delicate hopes had come true, and that all the love I'd
> felt inside me for my whole life should NOT be buried in my heart, or
> crushed down, or forgotten--it was beautiful and soft, both odd and
> familiar, and natural as color and light.

No, it should not be buried again as the tingly sensations wear off and 
the e trip comes to an end.....those entities  (dreams, love, hopes and 
INSPIRATION) are *always* there.  The drug just made you more aware of 
their presence.  What Vince said is so true, once you see them again for 
the first time, you can experience them all the time without a drug.  I
take e to *enchance* what I already feel.  Now that you have been able to 
tap in to that energy, it doesn't just disappear like the e effects.

> That intensity of my "first time" has not been matched to this day.
> But even as I write this, I hesitate - "is that true" ??  It seems
> true only when I imagine my own existence within *time* - where there
> is an imagined end, and a vague beginning, and where mysterious benchmarks
> exist that I can hold memories up against, and compare them to.

Welll......time is actually circular......there is no beginning, no end.  
Just infinity.  Where do our lives *really* begin and end?  (that is a 
whole nuther talk show anyway!)....The best way to get the absolute MOST 
out of life is to live it IN THE PRESENT MOMENT.  Don't compare now with 
the past - it already happened, so what difference does it make?  Do 
something NOW.   Don't worry about the future - it hasn't happened yet 
and the energy being wasted worrying could be used for something NOW.  It 
takes practice, but ever since I learned to live in the PRESENT MOMENT, I 
have been able to savor life with a new gusto.  Now, Rhea, I'm certainly 
not telling you how you should think - or anyone for that matter, I'm 
just saying what has been written in countless books and what I have 
experienced myself.  Maybe it will enhance your growth.  It did for me, 
and it made me not worry about the "rave scene being corroded" or things 
liek that.  This list is proof that the right vibe is alive and thriving!!

Hope to meet you someday soon.  Sorry for posting more than my share 
today...just so much to say lately I guess.....

love,
Amy

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

It's not a sex drug, it was used by body builders to bulk up before being
take off the market. It affects people in different ways - I tried it once
and just felt really stoned.

*DO NOT MIX GHB AND ALOHOL*

It used to be big in LA until a few people were hospitalized because of
mixing GHB, alcohola, and other drugs. The main contraindicated mixture is
with alcohol, however.

Joe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep  7 23:06:54 1995

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep  8 00:28:50 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA25893; Fri, 8 Sep 1995 00:28:50 -0700
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA25888; Fri, 8 Sep 1995 00:28:47 -0700
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.10/SM-8.6.4)
	id AAA22905; Fri, 8 Sep 1995 00:30:49 -0700
Date: Fri, 8 Sep 1995 00:30:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
Subject:  What is to give Light, must undergo Burning pt.1
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.2.4.55.9509080013.B22863@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Yeah I  know this is late but, as many of you know, it takes a while to
integrate the experience, even now, my body has a cold or flu or
something which is a tell tale sign as I almost never get sick.  Some
say that these types of sicknesses are the personality's way of allowing
you to retreat from eveyday life so you can have time to integrate the
stuff that just happened to you.  Perhapse, or maybe it is the aftermath of
the alien abduction that happened on saturday night, or maybe it was
just having too much fun, or walking around barely clothed for three
days with temperatures ranging from 110 to 42 degrees, or maybe It's
just my time to catch a cold, I had one coming on about a week before
the Man burned.

After some confusion as to who was going where, I finally settled that I would
be going with my old buddy from back east Chris, his partner Rona, his sister
Mary Beth as well as Mona Love and Yashoda both of which are San Francisco Ravers.  The ETD was to be 1600 hours on friday.  I decided to take my car
(the beat-up CRX) in that it would be safer with me then anywhere else,
besides, it is on it's last legs and it has always served me well, It deserves
to attend the Burning Man before it is put out to pasture, I also decided that
it might be good to have some transportation out on the playa as it seemed
pretty certain that Chris and Rona (who can't stand rave music) would not want
to camp in the rame camp and Mona, Yashoda and myself couldn't be kept away :)

The contingent more or less left on time, I was late but did rendesvouz
with the van at the vista point on the far side of the GG bridge at 5 p.m.,
we took 101 north and cut over to 80 via 37, this allowed us to avoid almost
all of the rush hour traffic that was most certainly on the bay bridge.
The ride to Sacto was uneventful and eventually we pulled out and started the long ascent up the sierras, there was a minor panic near the summit when after
stopping for a while, my car started to overheat.  We stopped , I put more anti-freeze in and waited a bit for it to cool down, shit, I knew I shouldn't
have brought my car but OH Well, be here now... things cooled down but then I couldn't find the car keys, after about 15 minutes of searching , they
turned up in my fanny pack :). Boy a great start and I haven't ingested any drugs yet. The rest of the ride was smooth, I kept my eye on the temperature
gauge but it stayed within acceptable levels, we pulled into Reno and found
a gas station/ 7-11 store to tank up for the last 130 miles.
It must have been obvious from our dress, (and yashoda's piercings) that we
were from SF.  The young guys eyed Yashoda and Mona with part desire, part
awe, part fear, like the beautiful alien creatures that they are. I found this 
pretty amusing and I'm sure they both enjoyed the attention.  OK, we roll out
of reno with our gas tanks full ready for the last long haul. Driving through
the Nevada darkness, straight into the badlands, illuminated by half-moonlight,
the buttes and hills looked even more lonesome and erie. Finally, by around
3 a.m. we roll into Gerlatch (which is pretty dead) but I do run into my
friend melissa (who passes us as we stop to get our final berrings).  We head out to the darkness of the playa, after several miles  of travelling and
searching for the entrance we eventually find the "large white square"
which marks the turn off point, hang a left, go off road and are teleported
into a Seperate Reality...


	End of Part 1

Subject: Re: burnt.  The noise factor
In-Reply-To: <Pine.2.4.55.9509061725.A15532@nexsys.nexsys.net>

Precedence: bulk

In reply to all this talk about the rave camp being out of sink with the 
rest of the festival and the Purple People Pushers not being into it 
because of it upsetting the balance.  To which I say: fuck the Purple 
People Pushers.  They were a small group of people, about twenty in all, 
whereas there were over two hundred people camped at the rave camp and 
about a thousand people came and checked us out over the weekend.  We 
were invited to participate by the organizers themselves where as they 
merely came on their own steam.  If you don't like raves fair enough but 
then go and camp some where else that is not 2/3 from the Rave camp; 
bloody idiots!  They were just out to cause trouble and should have got a 
smacking for their troubles.  I was right their when they complained at 
the SPAZ system and they were aggressive anal mother-fuckers.  Why don't 
they ban them from next years event instead of the rave camp?
     As far as the event itself goes both the rave camp and the main one 
were really good.  The Whicked system sounded so clean and smooth that if 
if sound was a solid matter it  would be like a new mirror.  Best song in 
Garth's set was Gangsters by the Specials.  But the thing that impressed 
me the most was all the effort, both financial, spiritually, creativity 
and sheer slog that people put into the entire event.  Every single one 
of them deserves utter and total respect from now until the end of 
time.  To mention them all would take an entire database but the main 
highlights were, for me, as follows.  Getting cruisified with President 
Rosevelt.  The swing on acid at the NYC playground.  A band called 
Beyond Race who played a kind of mix of trance, feedback guitar  and the 
most ammazing bass player I have ever seen; I mean this guy was 
unfucking believably good; he played a kind of mix between funk/rock 
and feedback and the whole effect blew me away.  Check them out at the 
next available opportunity.  The whicked sound system.  Riding my bike 
tripping in the dark to the rave camp on Sunday night.  The thunder 
storm.  Playing on Friday night on the SPAZ system as it was getting dark 
watching all the Cyberlab 7 crew and others coming into the festival for 
the first time.  The enire energy and flow of the entire event.  Next 
year is going to be even better.

Also,, I am leaving for a while; at least four months maybe nine.  I am 
going to Amsterdam first then to India to see the eclipse and to go 
traveling and to go to Goa for a few parties.  If at all possible I will 
try to send mail from their, probably around Christmas time when I am in 
Goa.  Thanks for putting up with in in the last year.  See you in a while 
or a twinkling of an eye.
Love and respect to the original hardcore,
TRISTAN.

Someone mentioned that the attendance of the Burning-Man event is
estimated from aerial photographs; any chance of seeing these posted? I
arrived on Wednesday and was intrigued by the manner in which the camp
grew. It seemed to begin in a concentric fashion around the area
sketched-in by those wire-flags; from there the growth seemed increasingly
sporatic with informal avenues developing independent of any axis. I
thought that a bi-polar (two centers) design would have encouraged a more
dynamic (less centrally congested) organization. A series of aerial photos
mapping the growth of the camp would be interesting... 

/b
--
   { brad brace }  The 12hr-ISBN-JPEG Project  <bbrace@netcom.com>
   ftp://ftp.netcom.com/pub/bb/bbrace/bbrace.html  ~finger for pgp
       Usenet: alt.binaries.pictures.12hr / alt.culture.beaches
   -> lucinda folio    http://www.teleport.com/~bbrace/bbrace.html

>This is a letter I am writing the friends we've made in the SFR community.
>
>wayne
>
>--
>
>I had an awesome time at Burning Man.
>
>I just can't put into words the things that happend out there that would
>even remotely approach what happened, but upon leaving, we all felt like
>it's changed us in strange, spiritual ways. Since I cannot assemble words
>do justice to those feelings, I will not betray them with a verbally flawed
>account. All I can say is that it was the best weekend of my life and I
>simply just cannot tell you why. It was each and every minute, each and
>every hour, each and every day we were there. Individually and summarily,
>the moments were magical. I'll leave the 'overall' Burning Man experience
>description to that.
>
>---
>
>I wanted to tell you that we are giving the SFR laminates out to show how
>much we care about the scene and how much we care about all of you. We
>really wanted to give something back to each of you individually and at the
>same time bring all of us together. I think it's working. If you don't have
>one yet, have no fear, There will be one for each and every one of you.
>
>---
>
>There's a couple specific events that I want share with you. It's just a
>couple short stream-of-consciousness conversations that happened that I
>hope affect all of you out there the way that they did me.
>
>My friend Rusty is out there with us Sunday night at Burning Man in the
>Wicked area, and he's experiencing a ravE for the first time. (Can you
>think of a better 'first rave?!) Like all of us, at this point he is
>totally immersed in the desert, the music, the vibe and the people.
>
>I was off wandering around for a while dancing with all of you, then I
>stopped by to see how he was doing and to give him his 'first' hug. In this
>blissful state he tells me, "Now I know why you have to share this so
>badly."
>
>-
>
>Then a short time later he asks Vince, "How long does this feeling last?"
>
>and Vince tells him,    *"The rest of your life!"*
>
>-
>
>It's already been a few days, but whenever I think about or tell someone
>this story, the power of those words words create this rush of emotions and
>I get tears in my eyes.
>
>I really hope it does the same for you.
>
>That's why we rave.
>
>
>
>

Kevin, I've been reading things you post and replies you make for a 
couple years now, and have cut you tons of slack, but I am *over it*.

You never seem to have much positive to say -- but you appear to be a 
veritable wellspring of worthless negativity.

Seeing your shitrain descending on to one of my posts makes me ILL.
Certainly you ought to post whatever you like to sfraves -- but just 
don't attach it to a post of *mine*.

No, I didn't attend Burning Man. I have physical problems that make 
attending even a single night's event something I will have to pay for 
all the next week; I have also had to be hospitalized for heatstroke twice.
Not all of us CAN go to things like BM, you dumbass!

But considering the source... what should I expect from a guy who 
publically defended the "right" of some asshole buddy of his to keep my 
girlfriend's stolen video projector.

I think you need to sit down and do a little deep thinking of your own.

On Fri, 8 Sep 1995, Rob Jellinghaus wrote:

> My girlfriend says she tried it once and it made her sick, which 
> apparently is not an uncommon response to it.  It's not new, in fact 
> it has only been illegal for the last five years or so.
> Rob Jellinghaus     robj@unreal.com     http://www.best.com/~robj
> 

I tried GHB about 2 years ago at Boogie Buffet and hated it. I nearly 
passed out -- couldn't stand up, much less dance. Once this initial fun 
wore off, these electric current-like sensations started shooting from my 
shoulder down my arm. I completely lost control of my hand, which was 
spastically opening and closing on its own. I had had a beer before 
taking GHB, which probably exacerbated my reaction. A friend who also 
tried it passed out completely and had to be carried out of the club. My 
personal bottom line on this drug is *don't*. I really think it's 
dangerous.

My $.02 worth.

:)
Kathryn

My 2 cents on GHB:
	I have avoided this one because is seems to have a very sharp 
dosage response curve.  That is a little can be fine, but a little more 
can be dangerous or even fatal.  Considering that the strength/purity of 
any street drug is always questionable, it seems the wise thing to do with 
this one would be to avoid it all together.  
	As for weight lifters using it, I believe it is used in small 
dosages to offset the agressivness etc. that are common side effects of 
the other steroids they are using.

	
	Very glad to hear that there will be a Wicked this weekend... see 
ya there!

smiles,
Andrew

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep  8 14:38:23 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA24919; Fri, 8 Sep 1995 14:38:23 -0700

From: cuci-cuci <mike@organic.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: DUMB MEN JOKES
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950908101503.3235E-100000@crl.crl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950908142117.11977A-100000@eat.organic.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Count me as a woman who also finds these jokes objectionable. Bashing is 
> bashing, no matter which way it goes. I believe we owe men the same 
> dignity and respect we ask for ourselves.


i don't think 'bashing is bashing'. there is a difference between bashing
and humor. that difference is intent. there's being snide and insulting
and hurtful, and there's having a laugh with no malice intended.the line
is a fine one, but in this particular case it's apparent. karen obviously
did not intend to bash, or she wouldn't have posted those jokes to this
list. she intended to make you smile and laugh and give you a chuckle. 

the stereotypes in those jokes exist wether we like it or not, 
and while agree that it's the jokes like these that perpetuate the 
stereotpyes, it's those stereotypes which makes these jokes funny. can't 
you look past the stereotypes? sure, we all know some men who have one or 
more of the qualities that those jokes made fun of, but there is noone 
who is completely tailored after them. am i making sense? i laughed at 
these jokes (even though i had heard them before). i'm not ashamed for 
laughing at them. who cares? am i an asshole for laughing at them? i 
don't think so. considering me an asshole is just another stereotype 
isn't it? people who laugh at insulting jokes like that *must* be 
assholes because those jokes aren't funny. it's all pretty ridiculous. 

hmm. this has gotten messy. i always end up babbling. 

my point is (i suppose, in a roundabout way), if you can't laugh at 
yourself, why bother laughing?

mikebee

you got to be startin' somethin') i present to you, this:

              T H E   L E A R N I N G   A N N E X
S U M M E R   C L A S S E S   F O R   M E N   A N D   W O M E N

All male classes are prepared and presented by females only and
all female classes are prepared and presented by males.
_________________________________________________________________

SEMINARS FOR MALES

1.  Combating Stupidity
2.  You, too, can do housework
3.  PMS -- Learn when to keep your mouth shut.
4.  How to fill an ice tray
5.  We do not want sleazy underthings for Christmas -- Give us money
6.  Understanding the female response to your coming in drunk at 4:00am
7.  Wonderful laundry techniques (formerly titled "Don't wash my silks")
8.  Parenting -- No, it doesn't end with conception
9.  Get a life -- learn to cook
10. How not to act like an asshole when you're obviously wrong
11. Spelling -- Even you can get it right
12. Understanding your financial incompetence
13. You -- The Weaker Sex
14. Reasons to give flowers
15. How to stay awake after sex
16. Why it is unacceptable to relieve yourself anywhere but the bathroom
17. Garbage -- Getting it to the curb
18. You can fall asleep without "it" if you really try
19. The morning dilemma if "It's" awake.  Take a shower
20. I'll wear it if I damn well please
21. How to put the toilet lid down (formerly "No, it's not a bidet")
22. "The weekend" and "sports" are not synonyms
23. Give me a break!  Why we know your excuses are bullshit
24. How to go shopping with your mate and not get lost
25. The remote control -- Overcoming your dependency
26. Romanticism - Ideas other than sex
27. Helpful postural hints for couch potatoes
28. Mother-in-laws -- They are people, too
29. Male bonding -- Leaving your friends at home
30. You too can be a designated driver
31. Seeing the true you (formerly "No, you don't look like Mel Gibson,
    especially when naked!")
32. Changing your underwear -- It really works
33. The Attainable Goal -- Omitting "TITS" from your vocabulary
34. Fluffing the blankets after flatulenting is NOT necessary
35. Techniques for calling home
_________________________________________________________________

Now, for the females.... (seminar will be given by men only)

SEMINARS FOR WOMEN

1.  "Are you ready to leave?" -- Definition of the word "yes"
2.  Appropriate rhetorical questions (Formerly "Honey, do I look fat?")
3.  Elementary Map Reading
4.  Crying and law enforcement
5.  Advanced Math Seminar -- Program your VCR
6.  You can go shopping for less then 4 hours
7.  Gaining five pounds v. the end of the world: a study in contrast
8.  The Seven-Outfit Week
9.  PMS -- It's YOUR Problem, Not Mine (was: It's Happened Monthly
    Since Puberty -- Deal With It)
10. Driving I: Getting past automatic transmission
11. Driving II: The meaning of blinking red lights
12. Driving III: Approximating a constant speed
13. Driving IV: Makeup and Driving--It's As Simple As Oil and Water
14. The Super Bowl: Not a Game--A Sacrament
15. Telephone Translations (was: "Me too" equals "I Love You")
16. How to Earn Your Own Money
17. Giftgiving Fundamentals (was: Fabric Bad, Electronics Good)
18. Putting the Seat Down By Yourself: Potential Energy is on Your Side
19. Know When to Say When: The Limits of Makeup
20. Beyond "Clean and Dirty": The Nuances of Wearable Laundry
21. We forget birthdays, you forget sports stats: LET'S LET IT DROP
22. MYOB: Proper response to other couple's public arguments
23. Yes, You Can Buy Condoms (was: WE learned to deal with the
embarrassment)
24. Joys of the Remote Control: Reaping the Benefits of 50+ Channels
25. What Goes Around Comes Around--Why His Credit Card is Not a Toy
26. The Penis: His Best Friend Can Be Yours
27. His Poker Games: Deal Yourself Out
28. Committment Schmittment (was: Wedlock Schmedlock)
29. "To Honor and Obey:" Remembering the small print above "I Do"
30. Why Your Mother Is Unwelcome In The House
31. Your Mate: Selfish Bastard, or Victimized Sensitive Man-child Healing
    his Father Wound by Expressing the Latent Wild Man Within?

Please sign up early.  Seats are very limited!!!
