> This comment shows complete ignorance of the history of the sexes and a
> predisposition toward sound-bite logic. For how many thousands of years have
> women been the targets of oppression? That 30 years of "male-bashing" have
> somehow given (white) men a perspective and understanding of this history is
> the height of revisionist ahistoricism. 

feeling a bit overly PC are we?

lets take a look at china and the chinese, shall we?
how long has there civilization lasted? about 7000 years or so, with 
things staying the same. women have always been "oppressed," yet things 
just seem to have worked for them. now you tell me why in the past 30 
years this country has gone down hill and is on the brink of a civil war?
but take a look at china. things are the same as they were 7000 years 
ago. (except for the communist dynasty.)  now why is that so? when the 
women in china are "oppressed" and have no "freedom" but they [chinese] have 
maintained a very high statis in the world. how long have we been a 
country? about 200 years, yet what we are doing is telling everyone that its 
ok to pick and bash on men, and everything will just be peachy king?
in the past 30 years, what has changed with this country, and why is it 
falling apart? i do agree that both sexes should be equal, but telling 
women that its ok to pick on men (which is what you have done) because us 
big bad white men are just horrible people and we just dont understand a 
thing, and the only way we'll understand is if women pick and bash on us, 
and then everything will be just fine. i think not. 

i dont care if everyone on this mailing list hates my guts because i just 
dont understand things in the world like everyone else that is so 
enlightened, but i do feel that i can express my opinions, and if 
everyone is going to get on my case about wht i have to say (this is the 
second time now) then this country is turning into a liberal totalitarian 
sociaty.

i thought the jokes were fairly benign.  things are fine in china ?  
hmmmmm.

but where did male bashing originate ?  probably from the explosion  
of social and economic freedom that women now have that they did not have
a few decades back; its the backlash from their liberation from male 
oppression in general.  it's understandable.  it's inevitable.  it will
pass.  what's the big deal ? 

does it mean we cannot stand back and laugh at male stereotypes ?
i can laugh, cause anyone that treats me in a stereotypical fashion 
i do not take seriously anyway.  in a like manner, i dont take the
jokes seriously, or personally.  i am comfortable enough with myself 
such that i can poke fun at myself. i can recognize the grain of truth
in the joke that is an exageration.

doug

I don't know anything about China, so I have no response for all that. I do
think aspects of China are lame, though, however well their system is doing.

Because I talk straight, you assume much. I didn't say "picking and bashing"
was the only way for "big bad" white men to understand. I didn't even say
abuse or aggression was a possible way for anyone to understand anything.
But if you can't take a little ribbing without falling all over yourself,
then you've got an even longer way to go before you have any idea of what
these people have been through.

Your reasoning is typical of those who would mistake a simple change of
heart for the harsh realities of society. You are a man,  and (y)our kind
has done some pretty odious things to women over the years. You are born
into history whether you like it or not, and sweeping that history under the
rug, saying that "It wasn't me, man," and "well I'M not prejudiced," ignores
these facts, these political and economic facts, and that because you've
come to this conclusion, nothing more needs to be done. Sorry to have to be
the heavy for ya, but these are the forces that produce lists of man jokes
that everyone here is up in arms about. If you ask me, as a middle class
white man, we deserve the abuse. It might be nice to think that because my
tiny little world in my head holds no hatred or stereotypes, that I'm "a
righteous being," that the world only has to do the same before these
problems are eliminated. But it's an all too romantic notion that is easily
swept away walking into any bar or strolling aroung sixth and Market in SF.
Hey, I'd like to believe it too, but that isn't the way it is out there, you
know, in the real world.

eh

Hey gang,

      GHB is not new it has been use by bodybuilders to promote muscle
developement and fat burn.  It has also been used as a sleep aid (which is why
those people were so sleepy).   Anyway,  GHB raises the level of some  happy
little chemicals in your brain that  are produce naturaly.   There was a
article on GHB that was posted to the list last year or so that can probly be
found in the SFR archieves.

      It is very fun and has pretty much no hangover.  The most important
thing to remember if you plan on experimenting  DO NOT USE GHB WITH ALCOHOL AT
ALL NOT EVEN ONE STINKING BEER!!!!!!!!!!

    

    Hope this helps...          BE SAFE


Tamotsu

Subject: Re: DUMB MEN JOKES 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 08 Sep 95 18:41:37 PDT."
             <199509090141.SAA08652@shell1.best.com> 
Date: Fri, 08 Sep 95 20:09:20 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Your reasoning is typical of those who would mistake a simple change of
> heart for the harsh realities of society. You are a man,  and (y)our kind
> has done some pretty odious things to women over the years. You are born
> into history whether you like it or not, and sweeping that history under the
> rug, saying that "It wasn't me, man," and "well I'M not prejudiced," ignores
> these facts, these political and economic facts, and that because you've
> come to this conclusion, nothing more needs to be done.
> [...]
> If you ask me, as a middle class
> white man, we deserve the abuse. 

Oh spare me the guilt! That's a tired, feeble and nonresponsive
attitude, unless of course your purpose is to get laid by a feminist
... :-) In which case, go for it dude! (Hi five! Wink Wink, Nudge Nudge
Say No More!! :-) :-))

Guilt never got no-one nowhere (trust me on this, I'm jewish :-) :-)).
More importantly the self-flagellation that you are proposing
diminishes the greatness of being male, and makes all male attributes
undesireable, when only some are. Effectively by denying any good in
maleness, you are casting out the baby with the bathwater.
 
Men have evolved long and hard (ahem...) to attain some of these "male"
attributes (that of the hunter, the farmer, warrior, builder, and the
travoltaesque disco machine) and these are genetic lessons that must
not be lost. We can teach these lessons, and be taught the female ones
(the nurturer, the moral/decision core of the family [in many cultures
at least], the arbitrator, the peacemaker, and the get-me-on-the-
guest-list-queen). And be proud of all of them, relishing masculinity,
relishing femininity, and loving the diversity and the differences.

Finally, you shouldn't confuse "maleness" as a gender from the 
social/moral/economic forces that force males and females into awkward
positions in western dominator-oriented industrial culture. This
culture is noticeably dysfunctional from a number of perspectives, not
only just gender -- so why not put the guilt/blame/shame on the source
of the problem?? Certainly the role of males and females is more fair
(not equal, just fair) in agrarian, tribal cultures that have not been
touched by industry, christianity, money, property, 9-5 workdays, etc.

It's stupid to harp on equality. The species will continue, children
will be born, and women will continue to bear children. That right
there is a root of inequality that you have to come to grips with. And
it means totally different roles for men and women.

A western-culture progressive male needs cast away shame of the past
and think towards the future. Think about what's right and wrong, fair
and unfair, and attempt to do the right thing for the *SPECIES* and the
*PLANET* as a whole. Once you take on a gaian attitude of the whole, it
makes the "right" direction much easier to perceive and act on,
independent of the past, and looking towards only the present and the
future. 

> It might be nice to think that because my
> tiny little world in my head holds no hatred or stereotypes, that I'm "a
> righteous being," that the world only has to do the same before these
> problems are eliminated.

No way baby! Crucify me now for all those past sins. For I am white and
male and wracked with guilt, a feeble worm of immense pathos. Grind me
on the asphalt with your stilleto heel, pour salt on my wounds, and let
me writhe in agony! Oh yes, do me, yes yes yes!

Wake up and smell the tofu! It's the future already!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

On Fri, 8 Sep 1995, Andrew B. Lawson wrote:

> My 2 cents on GHB:
> 	I have avoided this one because is seems to have a very sharp 
> dosage response curve.  That is a little can be fine, but a little more 
> can be dangerous or even fatal.  Considering that the strength/purity of 
> any street drug is always questionable, it seems the wise thing to do with 
> this one would be to avoid it all together.  


I tried a quarter hit onse and found it interesting and maybe even fun.  
The people who gave it to me confirmed the problems with dosage.  I don't 
think(from what I read on hyperreal) that fatality is a big concern, but 
it seems that a slight overdose often knocks out the imber for a few 
hours.  definately not what you want to have happen at a rave.

as with all drugs(especially one as poorly documented as this one)  be 
careful.

Patrick

>Someone mentioned that the attendance of the Burning-Man event is
>estimated from aerial photographs; any chance of seeing these posted? I
>arrived on Wednesday and was intrigued by the manner in which the camp

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep  9 13:45:25 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA06874; Sat, 9 Sep 1995 13:45:25 -0700

From: Foustus@aol.com
Received: by mail06.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id QAA10473 for SFraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 9 Sep 1995 16:44:46 -0400
Date: Sat, 9 Sep 1995 16:44:46 -0400
Message-ID: <950909164445_15021474@mail06.mail.aol.com>
To: SFraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Cabbage Patch ("touched" extended review..)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well,

Id have to say that this event hath inspried me in two or three ways...

One: Hold nothing sacred....  When I brought my items to 
Lett uS Dance (ie shoes, water, and lotsa smiles) I knew well that the H2O
would become the communal drinking jug.. (the shoes?? well, I reclaimed them
later on that night...) which was fine, since there were sooo many of Us
dancing in the frenzied state that we were in... 
Just dancing with soo many of  US, thoses in the scene, kept my belief that
we, as a community could do nothing but Grow.. accepting the next generation
of Dancers, Dj's and music...

Two: Although feeling ever so happy and trippy and dizzy et. al.
There was one thing that I did notice amongst the crowd and the place...
 This was the seemingly  noticeable through the change of "sets" that  the
DJ's from other 'camps' would throw up a little addititue here and there
(although it coulda been me too, I did go thru a bit of a paranoid stage
during the event myself).  However, if this was the case, Please people,
leave the 'fronting'  at home (ie. Yourpad@home.org).  All that frowns and
stern looks do is instigate fights and police, I know i've seen many
happen....
About the Place: I think it couldn't of been at a better local (since Ive
adapted my dancing style to sand and beachrocks...).  But, as day broke I
noticed all of these beat, worn down cardboards, which was no real problem
 since it is pyro-consumeable.  However, the plastic bottles I saw strewn
everywhere was indeed a sad sight to behold...  I know I can't lay blame
since I'v'e been culprit for many years too.  But to atone for my sins
against mother earth I've decied to take this oath:
        I (My Name)___  Do solemly sewar that wherever I happen to end up
finger snappin', Rump shakin', leg stompin', rug cuttin',  and spinning
around generally in madness, That amongst the other Neccesities that I may
bring to any Undergrounds (Ie flashlight, Battries, map et. al.). There WILL
be an empty plastic 10 (or 5) gal. trash bag to pickup such needless litter
that was so needful when water or other chemically derived compounds was
occupied in it.  And futhermore understand that Although I may get really,
really strange looks from others as I put a bag of useless trash in my car,I
will be content. Knowing I have Done my duty to respect the ground I dance on
& ravers I dance with...

Despite these lil' pratfalls the event was a smashing success. I recieved
plenty 'O' names (Again, all escape me now...)  A specal "Hiya" to thoses
campfire dudes from San Mateo, tha guy sining the CHiPs theme to his feamle
siginficant other, that Cute asian gal by the speaker, thoses two other gals
I think I talked to & Mars for a good set (and Tom too I believe...)...

Smile O meter Ratings:

Vibe:  Trippy trancy Madness 
 9Smiles....

Dance space: funny to see that people are brining thier own "dance floor"
 (ie. cardboard boxes) but, I perfer contact w/the earth I dance on 
8.5Smiles

Lights/visuals:  after getting accustomed to everyone looking like radiation
victims it wasnt too bad 
8Smiles

Location:  As the saying goes... "Getting there is an adventure in itself"
 Directions were Pretty Crazy 
 7Smiles...

Frienship Potental: I believe this rating in itself depends on the person(s)
initiating it... Although I did see guys chasin' E-babies and doing what they
knowingly or unknowingly do.
On the other coin I also saw pleasent conversation and general acceptence
with strangers-turn-freinds just ploping down and chatting.
8Smiles

Overall:  8.1 smiles

In closing (about time, eh?),
I'd like to believe this, the scene, is all about communicating w/each other
and becoming closer because of it.  A common thread that unites us all
(almost like this post)...  And although I know that This message is
probabaly being read by less than 10% of the actuall people in attenence I
feel if I touched any of you then all this scatterbrain-bandwith-consuming
Eline then something has been achieved.....

-Dancing, weaving, catching a hug in between. Still free.-
Adam 

P.S. 
BTW, I was the one in the Blue shirt, torn grey pants, and an X cap....
If you see me next time, yank me from the dance floor and say howdy....
 C-ya @ the Sunset Benefit...

Oh come on, I think you're exaggerating a little, I saw maybe a couple of "jocks" at the most.  I thought it was cool that there were so many diverse types of people there - even people I normally wouldn't have a lot in common with.

Date: 9/6/95 3:01 PM
To: Bart Cheever
From: Grigsbeast
 It is still a TAZ of tremendous
magnitude, but the burning is almost anticlimactic, just another
spectacle amidst the crowds of Bud-swilling jocks who don't understand
why people who aren't 300 pounds and carrying a nightstick get to tell
them to move out of the way or they'll get killed by an M-100.
  Most of all, I miss that sense
of unity and purpose, where the Man burns for all of us and not just as
another distraction for the beer-swillers wandering around looking
for "nekkid chicks".  It was beautiful, and I miss it.  I'm not even sure
I'll go next year.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 10 02:53:28 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA18556; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 02:53:28 -0700
Received: from nova.unix.portal.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA18548; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 02:53:25 -0700
Received: from jobe.shell.portal.com (jobe.shell.portal.com [156.151.3.4]) by nova.unix.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA29222 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 02:52:23 -0700
Received: (grigsby@localhost) by jobe.shell.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) id CAA26183 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 02:52:20 -0700
From: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>
Message-Id: <199509100952.CAA26183@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: BM nostalgia: why.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 10 Sep 1995 02:52:20 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <n1401453280.36452@digipix.com> from "Bart Cheever" at Sep 9, 95 05:52:45 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 4181      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Oh come on, I think you're exaggerating a little, I saw maybe a
> couple of "jocks" at the most.  I thought it was cool that there
> were so many diverse types of people there - even people I normally
> wouldn't have a lot in common with.  Why don't we just put a velvet
> rope at the entrance to the Playa, and only people you approve of
> can get in ...

Please.  I specifically noted that you can't do that, and that things
change, and move on, and such is the way of life.  This was, however,
the first year that I saw *any* people walking around with beer during
The Burn, and several were giving me serious attitude as I attempted to
move back as per the wishes of the rangers.

Let me tell a short story:

Rewind to two years ago.  There are about 800
people on the playa, roughly 1/6 as many as this year.  It is the night of
the burn, and we are all painted, costumed, and readied as usual.  The sky
is growing cloudy and ominous as the sun sinks beneath the mountains.

We begin the procession to the Man, drummers (including me) in a loose cloud
of rhythm near the center.  We reach the Man, and the beat picks up as we
circle around him, and we can feel the pressure dropping as our energy
increases.  The drums pound louder, the massive booming heartbeat of the
Man, of us all, arms upraised towards the electric sky, ready to die.  

Lightning flickers and arcs in the clouds above.

Someone with a torch lights the Man's legs on fire.  The rhythm grows hotter, 
faster, as we feel the exquisite pain of the flame licking upwards, over
the legs, up the torso, up the arms.  No fireworks, just the zap of neon
tubes popping in unison with the electrical storm overhead.  I cannot
take my eyes off the Man, and neither can anyone else in our group of
demon drummers; we are a fragile vessel of energy, discharging its potential
in our frenzy lest it build up in our limbs and organs and set us aflame
along with the Man.

Electric snakes snap and coil across the sky, sometimes touching earth in their
convulsions.

Just when I think I must break from the tension, the Man, weakened,
succumbs to the fire, and falls.  We rush in as one to come as near as we can,
to catch the energy from his burning body, screaming in triumph and shock that
we are still alive --

and the storm opens its black heart to us.  The dust hits in a choking wave
of dry grit, wind blowing so hard it seems to be driven through my body.  The
rain comes in hard cold spatters, almost painful in its velocity, but I cannot
feel it.  We have not stopped drumming, and we have not stopped dancing, and
we welcome Nature to the ritual, booming electric snakes and all.

This image will remain in my mind forever: drumming next to the fallen corpse
of the Man, lightning striking around us, the dust and rain blowing so hard
that all I can see is leaping silhouettes dancing around, over, and through
the wind-whipped flames.  To some people, this is a classic conception of
Hell.  I laugh manically, and keep drumming until the storm dies down and
the Man is an unrecognizable pile of embers and slag.

===

Now do you see why I might permit myself a little nostalgia?  Conspicuously
absent from this event were:
-crowd control measures (beyond showing people where the Man would fall; no
 lines of people with flares and event T-shirts)
-non-participants, defined as "people holding beers/cigarettes instead 
 of dancing"
-so many people that many had to sit down so you could see what was happening
-many competing groups of drummers, none of which were together with each
 other, or often even themselves
-the feeling of watching something from a distance (necessitated by the
 sheer numbers of people) instead of being a participant
-those wimpy 10-minute storms that were over before anyone could really
 start panicking >;^)

As I said before, the Burning Man means something different now: a gathering
of the tribes, a three-day TAZ in a beautiful place, a freakfest of amazing
scale and diversity.  The ritual that was key to my experience can't be the
same anymore, though, which is the cause of my wistfulness.

Oh well -- guess I'll have to build my own someday or something.

// g

Although this was my first year, and I think that alcohol gets a bad rap 
because of the stupidity of some imbibers, I definetely agree with this 
observation. I saw A LOT of people with attitudes, yelling things like 
"just burn the fucking thing,", grabbing asses, etc. which really detracted 
from what was trying to happen. I too am all for diversity, and was glad to 
see people from so many walks-of-life that helped add to the experience. 
However I don't think the cretins interfering with everyone elses' 
experience added anything positive to it. As I said before to these folks, 
there's always Beach MTV reruns, and it's a lot cheaper too.... ;)

                                               Black Adder

heart right now. I can feel it and it has a smile on it a mile long. As I'm
dubbing some tapes a DJ friend gave me (BioJeff) I caught myself getting
goose bumps and beginning to dance in my living room. I have the people
across the way staring at me through there window( the whole family it looks
like) the music is sorta loud, is probally why there looking but I'm just
dancing away as they look at me with there mouth open. and all the while I
have a big smile as well as my whole body. And I LOVE it. His sets have a
great impact on me that you could not believe. The Day my wholE lifE changed
and at thE moment it did, I was listening...back up I should say FEELING the
music he was spinning, now when ever I hear his sets I just break down. I
feel he it really great at the turn table and I'm glad I know him...

From: Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE

Subject: Meet Me!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know this is not supposed to be a personal ads forum, but I'd like to 
introduce myself.  My name is Rikki and I used to go to raves a few years ago 
but got out of the habit for awhile.  I started going again this summer and 
can't remember when I've had such a blast!  I've been reading over the postings 
and feel absolutely elated and overjoyed that there are so many people out 
there digging the scene.  It truly warms my heart that I have found these raves 
and an open minded forum where people share their experiences and feelings.   
It makes me ache to meet some long-lasting friends who enjoy the same things I 
do.

Anyway, I love raving but I have a hard time finding people to go with because 
I just started going recently and haven't made tons of connections, and because 
my friends say they can't keep up with the energy so they don't like to go as 
often.   Also, even though I can dig hangin' out with youngins', I'm 28 (not 
that that's old, just a different space) and, although I find it easy to meet 
people in general, I find it hard meeting dependable people a little closer to 
my age, interests, mind set,  etc., (not that I don't party down and dance 
non-stop like the rest of 'em).   I believe in having friends of all ages 
(respecting who they are as a person, not how old)  but I'm looking for 
something a little more substantial and long lasting than what I've had with 
the "younger crowd" in general.  

Unfortunately, I've had a few experiences meeting people at raves where there 
seemed to be a real connection but it all turned out to be superficial and 
disappointing because, beyond the scene, we didn't have much in common.  It 
made me feel that it was due to an age gap or the drugs talking, but I'd hate 
to think that was the case.  I'm really hoping that's not just the nature of 
these people and parties.  Don't get me wrong, it's mostly positive and I've 
had some great times meeting awesome people and that's what keeps me going and 
interested.   So,  I have nothing but respect and love for these raves and the 
people, and I'm not dismissing younger folks, just looking for people with 
similar or complimentary lifestyles, experiences, ideas, maturity, etc.

Love ta hear from ya!

Peace, love, friendship and dancing!

Rikki :-)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 10 15:01:34 1995

After two years of searching, I *finally* landed a copy of "Love & Energy"
(Zeony Lee Experience) which I'm sure many of you remember from the
Connection II tapes!  It was in the "recently received used" bins at
Exotique Records in Seattle (just to give credit where it's due).
I also got a sealed copy of "Phuture" there (I guess Trax has been
reissuing or at least releasing a bunch of their old stuff lately),
so if you ever happen to be in town check it out, it's at 3rd and
Battery.  DJ Masa who also has a new release out is one of the people
who works there.

I can't tell you how hard I looked for Love & Energy.  I actually came
within five minutes of landing it at Ameba, just after someone had
put it in their "buy pile" a few months ago :)  It was a popular track
and I'm sure I could have ordered it from one of the distributors, but
that kinda takes the fun out of it (although I will admit I finally
broke down and put an order in for Wink's "Meditation Will Manifest"
which somehow I lost a while back, though I still have the sleeve).

So . . . . yay!!!

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 10 16:41:17 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA28479; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 16:41:17 -0700
Received: from pogonip.scs.unr.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA28474; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 16:41:14 -0700
Received: (from alex_c@localhost) by pogonip.scs.unr.edu (8.6.10/8.6.9) id QAA01965; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 16:09:06 -0700
Date: Sun, 10 Sep 1995 16:09:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: Alexandra Crocket <alex_c@scs.unr.edu>
To: Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE <Rikki.Kiefer@sybase.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Meet Me!
In-Reply-To: <9509102115.AA05009@notesgw2.sybase.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSF.3.91.950910142459.6818A-100000@pogonip.scs.unr.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It is completely ironic that I was just thinking about this exact same
subject when your message popped on my screen. The "scene" where I live is
practically dead. It is so hard to meet people in this area who are even
remotely interested in enduring 10 hours of driving to go to a single
event. I wanted so badly to go to Liquid Groove in Sacramento on friday,
but not *one person* here in Reno was interested in going. (Just for the
record, I *really* wanted to drive to SF for Schwa is Happening, but Sac
is 2 1/2 hrs closer.) Now, as I wade through my mail, I find out that not
only were many sfravers planning on going, a few I met at Burning Man even
offered me a place to sleep! 
The people here in Reno are only interested in going to the large venue,
vibeless, unpersonable events. I am completely the opposite.  I couldn't
even talk any of the ravers here into going to Burning Man, if that says
anything. About 15 of them, though, drove out on Sunday night for the
final night of Wicked after they heard how good it was.  They missed the
entire *experience* of Burning Man. When I tried to explain this to them,
they thought I was crazy. If you went to Burning Man or read sfraves last
week, you probably know what I mean by this. 

Anyway. My whole reason for explaining all of this is so that you can see 
that I understand exactly where you are coming from. 
True friends are very rare and far between. 
Especially friends who rave, too. :)
Raving is more to me than just going out and dancing-- it's a way of life.
A way of living. Perhaps even a religion, if I were dare to use the R word.
It's not something I take lightly, and it pains me to see others taking 
everything for granted. Especially when they go around treating each 
other so badly and continue to spout rave spiritual idealisms without 
giving them any thought. I truly believe that PLUR and the energy 
experience are a big part of it all; whereas the people here think it's 
about who has the groovest shoes, who can do the most drugs, and who 
knows the most DJs. AHHHHHH! 

There seems to be a growing lack of respect not only for each other, but
for the kind spirituality and enlightenment that raving originly brought
about. No one can make the determination if someone is a raver or not, 
(or even determine what the definition is!) but I think this change of
focus has been having a big effect on what's been happening in the scene
as a whole lately. 

I'm sorry to go off like this, and I hope that no one considers it wasting
bandwidth, but it's something I've really spent a lot of time thinking
about over the past two weeks. 

You're definitely in the right place for meeting some really special people.
Sfraves is very unique, and I think everyone holds it very near to their 
hearts. I *never* thought I'd be if for this or make as many good, true 
friends and I have over the past two years.  

If you ever want to go out and have a blast, I'm up for it if you are!!
It's just a matter of finding someone here to drive down with me, and for 
us Renoites finding somewhere to stay for the weekend.

I may take a lot of this stuff extremely seriously, but above all it's
about the people and about having FUN!!!! :) :) :)
Hope your day is wonderful!!! 			
						lv, Alex



      Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
      alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
	         -------PLUR-------

> 
> Anyway, I love raving but I have a hard time finding people to go with because 
> I just started going recently and haven't made tons of connections, and because 
> my friends say they can't keep up with the energy so they don't like to go as 
> often.   Also, even though I can dig hangin' out with youngins', I'm 28 (not 
> that that's old, just a different space) and, although I find it easy to meet 
> people in general, I find it hard meeting dependable people a little closer to 
> my age, interests, mind set,  etc., (not that I don't party down and dance 
> non-stop like the rest of 'em).   I believe in having friends of all ages 
> (respecting who they are as a person, not how old)  but I'm looking for 
> something a little more substantial and long lasting than what I've had with 
> the "younger crowd" in general.  
> 
> Unfortunately, I've had a few experiences meeting people at raves where there 
> seemed to be a real connection but it all turned out to be superficial and 
> disappointing because, beyond the scene, we didn't have much in common.  It 
> made me feel that it was due to an age gap or the drugs talking, but I'd hate 
> to think that was the case.  I'm really hoping that's not just the nature of 
> these people and parties.  Don't get me wrong, it's mostly positive and I've 
> had some great times meeting awesome people and that's what keeps me going and 
> interested.   So,  I have nothing but respect and love for these raves and the 
> people, and I'm not dismissing younger folks, just looking for people with 
> similar or complimentary lifestyles, experiences, ideas, maturity, etc.
> 
> Love ta hear from ya!
> 
> Peace, love, friendship and dancing!
> 
> Rikki :-)
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 10 18:30:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA04245; Sun, 10 Sep 1995 18:30:01 -0700

Message-Id: <n1401364559.74028@digipix.com>
Date: 10 Sep 1995 18:30:37 U
From: "Bart Cheever" <bcheever@digipix.com>
Subject: Re: BM nostalgia- why.

Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   RE>BM nostalgia: why.

Alright, I apologize if that post was a little negative.  It's just that Burning Man was so incredible this year.  Hearing people (a few people, not just you) focus on how good it "used to be" instead of just appreciating how beautiful it was was starting to get me down.

'93 sounds like it was pretty amazing, wish I had been there too ... 

--------------------------------------
Date: 9/10/95 3:02 AM
To: Bart Cheever
From: Grigsbeast

> Oh come on, I think you're exaggerating a little, I saw maybe a
> couple of "jocks" at the most.  I thought it was cool that there
> were so many diverse types of people there - even people I normally
> wouldn't have a lot in common with.  Why don't we just put a velvet
> rope at the entrance to the Playa, and only people you approve of
> can get in ...

Please.  I specifically noted that you can't do that, and that things
change, and move on, and such is the way of life.  This was, however,
the first year that I saw *any* people walking around with beer during
The Burn, and several were giving me serious attitude as I attempted to
move back as per the wishes of the rangers.

Let me tell a short story:

Rewind to two years ago.  There are about 800
people on the playa, roughly 1/6 as many as this year.  It is the night of
the burn, and we are all painted, costumed, and readied as usual.  The sky
is growing cloudy and ominous as the sun sinks beneath the mountains.

We begin the procession to the Man, drummers (including me) in a loose cloud
of rhythm near the center.  We reach the Man, and the beat picks up as we
circle around him, and we can feel the pressure dropping as our energy
increases.  The drums pound louder, the massive booming heartbeat of the
Man, of us all, arms upraised towards the electric sky, ready to die.  

Lightning flickers and arcs in the clouds above.

Someone with a torch lights the Man's legs on fire.  The rhythm grows hotter, 
faster, as we feel the exquisite pain of the flame licking upwards, over
the legs, up the torso, up the arms.  No fireworks, just the zap of neon
tubes popping in unison with the electrical storm overhead.  I cannot
take my eyes off the Man, and neither can anyone else in our group of
demon drummers; we are a fragile vessel of energy, discharging its potential
in our frenzy lest it build up in our limbs and organs and set us aflame
along with the Man.

Electric snakes snap and coil across the sky, sometimes touching earth in their
convulsions.

Just when I think I must break from the tension, the Man, weakened,
succumbs to the fire, and falls.  We rush in as one to come as near as we can,
to catch the energy from his burning body, screaming in triumph and shock that
we are still alive --

and the storm opens its black heart to us.  The dust hits in a choking wave
of dry grit, wind blowing so hard it seems to be driven through my body.  The
rain comes in hard cold spatters, almost painful in its velocity, but I cannot
feel it.  We have not stopped drumming, and we have not stopped dancing, and
we welcome Nature to the ritual, booming electric snakes and all.

This image will remain in my mind forever: drumming next to the fallen corpse
of the Man, lightning striking around us, the dust and rain blowing so hard
that all I can see is leaping silhouettes dancing around, over, and through
the wind-whipped flames.  To some people, this is a classic conception of
Hell.  I laugh manically, and keep drumming until the storm dies down and
the Man is an unrecognizable pile of embers and slag.

===

Now do you see why I might permit myself a little nostalgia?  Conspicuously
absent from this event were:
-crowd control measures (beyond showing people where the Man would fall; no
 lines of people with flares and event T-shirts)
-non-participants, defined as "people holding beers/cigarettes instead 
 of dancing"
-so many people that many had to sit down so you could see what was happening
-many competing groups of drummers, none of which were together with each
 other, or often even themselves
-the feeling of watching something from a distance (necessitated by the
 sheer numbers of people) instead of being a participant
-those wimpy 10-minute storms that were over before anyone could really
 start panicking >;^)

As I said before, the Burning Man means something different now: a gathering
of the tribes, a three-day TAZ in a beautiful place, a freakfest of amazing
scale and diversity.  The ritual that was key to my experience can't be the
same anymore, though, which is the cause of my wistfulness.

Oh well -- guess I'll have to build my own someday or something.

// g

Charged GBH got their name from a UK general-purpose statute often used
by the police to suppress and arrest people in the punk scene in the
early days.  GBH = "Grevious Bodily Harm"

phred

On Sun, 10 Sep 1995, Alexandra Crocket wrote:

> It is completely ironic that I was just thinking about this exact same
> subject when your message popped on my screen. The "scene" where I live is
> practically dead. It is so hard to meet people in this area who are even
> remotely interested in enduring 10 hours of driving to go to a single
> event. I wanted so badly to go to Liquid Groove in Sacramento on friday,
> but not *one person* here in Reno was interested in going. (Just for the
> record, I *really* wanted to drive to SF for Schwa is Happening, but Sac
> is 2 1/2 hrs closer.) Now, as I wade through my mail, I find out that not
> only were many sfravers planning on going, a few I met at Burning Man even
> offered me a place to sleep! 
> The people here in Reno are only interested in going to the large venue,
> vibeless, unpersonable events. I am completely the opposite.  I couldn't
> even talk any of the ravers here into going to Burning Man, if that says
> anything. About 15 of them, though, drove out on Sunday night for the
> final night of Wicked after they heard how good it was.  They missed the
> entire *experience* of Burning Man. When I tried to explain this to them,
> they thought I was crazy. If you went to Burning Man or read sfraves last
> week, you probably know what I mean by this. 
> 
> Anyway. My whole reason for explaining all of this is so that you can see 
> that I understand exactly where you are coming from. 
> True friends are very rare and far between. 
> Especially friends who rave, too. :)
> Raving is more to me than just going out and dancing-- it's a way of life.
> A way of living. Perhaps even a religion, if I were dare to use the R word.
> It's not something I take lightly, and it pains me to see others taking 
> everything for granted. Especially when they go around treating each 
> other so badly and continue to spout rave spiritual idealisms without 
> giving them any thought. I truly believe that PLUR and the energy 
> experience are a big part of it all; whereas the people here think it's 
> about who has the groovest shoes, who can do the most drugs, and who 
> knows the most DJs. AHHHHHH! 
> 
> There seems to be a growing lack of respect not only for each other, but
> for the kind spirituality and enlightenment that raving originly brought
> about. No one can make the determination if someone is a raver or not, 
> (or even determine what the definition is!) but I think this change of
> focus has been having a big effect on what's been happening in the scene
> as a whole lately. 
> 
> I'm sorry to go off like this, and I hope that no one considers it wasting
> bandwidth, but it's something I've really spent a lot of time thinking
> about over the past two weeks. 
> 
> You're definitely in the right place for meeting some really special people.
> Sfraves is very unique, and I think everyone holds it very near to their 
> hearts. I *never* thought I'd be if for this or make as many good, true 
> friends and I have over the past two years.  
> 
> If you ever want to go out and have a blast, I'm up for it if you are!!
> It's just a matter of finding someone here to drive down with me, and for 
> us Renoites finding somewhere to stay for the weekend.
> 
> I may take a lot of this stuff extremely seriously, but above all it's
> about the people and about having FUN!!!! :) :) :)
> Hope your day is wonderful!!! 			
> 						lv, Alex
> 
> 
> 
>       Alexandra Crocket   |  "Reality is anything 
>       alex_c@scs.unr.edu  |    you can get away with" 
> 	         -------PLUR-------
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On 10 Sep 1995, Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE wrote:
> 
> > I know this is not supposed to be a personal ads forum, but I'd like to 
> > introduce myself.  My name is Rikki and I used to go to raves a few years ago 
> > but got out of the habit for awhile.  I started going again this summer and 
> > can't remember when I've had such a blast!  I've been reading over the postings 
> > and feel absolutely elated and overjoyed that there are so many people out 
> > there digging the scene.  It truly warms my heart that I have found these raves 
> > and an open minded forum where people share their experiences and feelings.   
> > It makes me ache to meet some long-lasting friends who enjoy the same things I 
> > do.
> > 
> > Anyway, I love raving but I have a hard time finding people to go with because 
> > I just started going recently and haven't made tons of connections, and because 
> > my friends say they can't keep up with the energy so they don't like to go as 
> > often.   Also, even though I can dig hangin' out with youngins', I'm 28 (not 
> > that that's old, just a different space) and, although I find it easy to meet 
> > people in general, I find it hard meeting dependable people a little closer to 
> > my age, interests, mind set,  etc., (not that I don't party down and dance 
> > non-stop like the rest of 'em).   I believe in having friends of all ages 
> > (respecting who they are as a person, not how old)  but I'm looking for 
> > something a little more substantial and long lasting than what I've had with 
> > the "younger crowd" in general.  
> > 
> > Unfortunately, I've had a few experiences meeting people at raves where there 
> > seemed to be a real connection but it all turned out to be superficial and 
> > disappointing because, beyond the scene, we didn't have much in common.  It 
> > made me feel that it was due to an age gap or the drugs talking, but I'd hate 
> > to think that was the case.  I'm really hoping that's not just the nature of 
> > these people and parties.  Don't get me wrong, it's mostly positive and I've 
> > had some great times meeting awesome people and that's what keeps me going and 
> > interested.   So,  I have nothing but respect and love for these raves and the 
> > people, and I'm not dismissing younger folks, just looking for people with 
> > similar or complimentary lifestyles, experiences, ideas, maturity, etc.
> > 
> > Love ta hear from ya!
> > 
> > Peace, love, friendship and dancing!
> > 
> > Rikki :-)

Subject: full moon party

From: buvac-lists@cs.Stanford.EDU

Precedence: bulk

Lettuce Dance and Cloud Factory organized a beautiful party under the
full moon this Friday.  It was a small gathering (peaking at maybe
150-200 people) with an excellent vibe.  DJ Cloud started, got
everyone moving, and let some heavy trance DJs take over the night.  I
can't remember much from this period.  (Unfortunately this includes
DJ's names.)  But I do remember the morning.  It was warm, misty with
lots of birds flying over us.  We were calm, relaxing around the
campfires as DJ Stony from MESS was closing things down.  I feel
refreshed after this party;  will carry lots of positive energy
wherever I go (including work tomorrow morning :).

This was one of the best full moon parties I attended.  A big thank
you to everyone who was there and especially the organizers.

  v
SASA

On Saturday Niels wrote:

>Guilt never got no-one nowhere (trust me on this, I'm jewish :-) :-)).
>More importantly the self-flagellation that you are proposing
>diminishes the greatness of being male, and makes all male attributes
>undesireable, when only some are. Effectively by denying any good in
>maleness, you are casting out the baby with the bathwater.
> 
>Men have evolved long and hard (ahem...) to attain some of these "male"
>attributes (that of the hunter, the farmer, warrior, builder, and the
>travoltaesque disco machine) and these are genetic lessons that must
>not be lost. We can teach these lessons, and be taught the female ones
>(the nurturer, the moral/decision core of the family [in many cultures
>at least], the arbitrator, the peacemaker, and the get-me-on-the-
>guest-list-queen). And be proud of all of them, relishing masculinity,
>relishing femininity, and loving the diversity and the differences.



I appreciate his argument against self-flagellating guilt---eloquent
and well-reasoned, as always...however, I don't think that respect for
men or maleness does not have to be associated with traditional "male"
attributes or a sense of genetic destiny.  I get a little uncomfortable
when I hear such cut-and-dry definitions of what is masculine and what
is feminine; I happen to be one of those people who sees a more blurred
line inbetween, or at least that is the way I wish things were out 
there in the world--this has a lot to do with the way I was raised, by 
a very self-reliant, feminist mother, and a very nurturing father.
And unfortunately, such a viewpoint can be something of a curse in 
this society we live in, which if anything is sliding backwards into
old tried-and-true assumptions about males & females.  I have had many
bad experiences where a female friend or lover has misread me or 
projected typical "male" attitudes onto me that just weren't there...
I'm not about to go into all the gory details of my personal life, I 
just wanted to make the point that it is very easy to feel alienated
and misunderstood when you have an unconventional take on being "male."
I cringe at just about anything that encourages women to look at men
in a stereotyped or generalized way, rather than as diverse and 
varied INDIVIDUALS.

And how do I feel about "DUMB MEN JOKES"?  I chuckled at them; 
a few were pretty clever... but at the same time, I wish they hadn't 
shown up on this list.  First of all, because it instantly reminded
me of something I would have seen pinned up in office cubicles next to
old yellowed "Garfield" and "Kathy" comic strips in one of the shitty
corporate temp jobs I used to work in Sacramento.  Not an environment
I want to be taken back to...  Secondly, it poured cold water on one
of the warmest feelings I have had about raves since getting into 
them a year ago, which is my appreciation of how raves, good ones 
anyway, have much less of the tension, mistrust, and general 
guardedness that exist elsewhere between males & females.  The 
atmosphere of mutual respect and openness I have found in this 
scene has kept me sane through some crazy times; I hate to see 
anything cloud the air, even if it is supposed to be humorous.  
Besides, there are plenty of other things to joke about, no?

-Brian

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Tuesday, depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

                                Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Tuesday
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ...
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road
  Southbound: Past University Avenue

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)

* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 11 10:57:09 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA05378; Mon, 11 Sep 1995 10:57:09 -0700

X-Sender: ekjazz@netcom.com (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v01510100ac79b37cc167@[199.35.142.161]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ekjazz@netcom.com (Eric Kalabacos)
Subject: Here goes! (1st post to SFR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

After lurking for the suggested initial 2 weeks, I'm finally ready to
introduce myself to y'all and tell you how much I'm enjoying getting to
know you via the list.

First, the basics:

My name is Eric Kalabacos (friends call me E K). I'm 30 years old,
originally from NYC, in SF since 1/1/90, a Buddhist, a big-time Mac-head
(graphics, multimedia), and absolutely, positively, desperately, madly in
love with music. I live in downtown SF (2nd & Mission) with my wonderful,
beautiful girlfriend Veronika.

The first rave I ever went to was a Full Moon at Bonny Doon in the summer
of '92. My guides were Ammon Haggerty (my employee at the time and still a
dear friend) and Gary Henderson & Martha Harkey (of Yang Snowboard Clothing
- my customers at the time and also still close friends). I'll never forget
that night - arriving at 4am after a foggy, moonlit drive down Highway 1 -
peering over the cliff at the magical spectacle of 2-3000 people dancing
wildly under the stars - I simply couldn't believe it. This was an
experience I felt I had been waiting for my whole life. We danced until
noon. I loved watching the sun rise and seeing everyone's faces as the
light increased...

Needless to say, I've been to a couple (or a couple hundred ;-) ) parties
since that time. I've had all kinds of experiences - some great - some not
so great - but all very worthwile from the perspective of learning about
myself and my relationship to others. Raving has been (and still is) a
shamanic experience for me in the truest sense of the word. It is a
crucible into which I pour my whole being - my dreams, my fears, my
inspiration, my desire, my wisdom, my confusion. Raving has also given me
the chance to meet dozens and dozens of fascinating people, people like
yourselves...  =)

And, oh yes, the music. Let's not forget the music. The primal heartbeat of
the universe, the heartbeat of humanity. That feeling when you close your
eyes and feel it reverberating throughout your whole being, dissolving
fixation on self, teasing and tickling pleasure centers you didn't know
existed. And then the moment when you open your eyes and catch someone
else's glance and you both know. You both feel it together and there is a
flood of warmth and compassion for each other and for all beings. This is
why I rave.

As I said before, I've been lurking on the list for about 2 weeks now. I've
been aware of its existence for quite a while, but was dubious about
joining because of the anticipated flood of mail. I've made good use of the
calendar in the past (for which I thank Derek and Brian and anyone else
involved), but I'm so glad that I finally took the plunge and joined the
list. It is definitely an effort to wade through so much mail every day.
but worth it. I spend alot of time on-line (in fact, the company I work for
is developing games for net), and I've always been fascinated by the
potential of using the net for community-building. SFR is the finest
example of net-community I've experienced.

Speaking of shamanic experiences, Veronika and I went to Burning Man with
our friend Marcel last weekend. It was wonderful to follow the BMan-related
threads on the list. I could feel the excitement grow as the event
approached. I particularly loved the final day or two as people began to
post descriptions of themselves so that it would be easier to find each
other. I've also followed the post-Bman threads with great interest. It
feels like quite a privilage to learn from other people's experiences at
the event. When I get a chance I'll describe some of my own experiences
there...

Anyway, I have to get back to work now, but I just want to thank you all
once again for sharing yourselves in such an intimate, personal way on this
list. I look forward to meeting you in person (I'm sure I've met many of
you already and we don't even know it).

Peace & love,
ek  =)

barnoc@presage.com (Brian Salter):
>I appreciate his argument against self-flagellating guilt---eloquent
>and well-reasoned, as always...however, I don't think that respect for
>men or maleness does not have to be associated with traditional "male"
>attributes or a sense of genetic destiny.  I get a little uncomfortable
>when I hear such cut-and-dry definitions of what is masculine and what

>a very self-reliant, feminist mother, and a very nurturing father.

I think there are things that are generically associated with maleness
and femaleness. That's not to say that the male should not ignore the
feminine in himself, nor the female ignore the masculine in herself. 
By blurring the lines, recognizing or taking on aspects of either, one
is actually strenghthening the cut-and-dry definitions, simply by
recognizing them and taking them into oneself. If one is acting out
"opposites" one is doing nothing more than acknowledging the fact that
the opposite force exists. By doing the opposite, one is precisely
defining what maleness or femaleness is all about, even if it's a woman
acting "butch" or a man acting "feminine"...

However, the crux of my argument is that femininism has caused many a
male to feel shame for the masculine, and that both diminishes
masculinity and femininity (it's again that thing about opposites
really being part of the same entity). So while I mostly support
feminism (except for separatist, male-bashing oriented feminism), I
also more strongly support the mens movement. I see fighting for men's
rights to be necessary because, unfortunately, the role of men have
been largely forgotten in the social movement that has happened in the
last 30-80 years. 

I see lots of problems coming out of this:
	* Many of children raised without a male role model (aka father)
	  don't have a good/positive view of maleness. Many male children
	  are thus finding "the male" in degenerate forms -- e.g. gangs.
	  And you get a vicious cycle of males redefining maleness as  violent,
	  uncaring, unnurturing, and sociopathic, which further causes
	  people to dismiss maleness as some kind of evil.	  
	* Lack of positive male role models in the media. The only positive
	  one I can think of is Bill Cosby; but there's lots of negative
	  portrayals of men as bumbling fools, from Al Bundy (Married with
	  Children), Homer Simpson (The Simpsons), etc. Meanwhile, there
	  are (IMHO) more positive portrayals of women (e.g. Murphy Brown).
	* Lack of positive-oriented mens groups in college. There's a general
	  feminist rubric that women can fit into in college, and if a man
	  wants to be "cool" (without being a jock/fratboy) he has to fit into
	  this rubric as well. This means that the non-jock/non-frat male 
	  tends to be further socialized in only a women-oriented way. The 
	  closest men get to "male socialization" is the (typically) 
	  degenerate/separatist form of socialization found in the fraternity.
	* Men are getting the short end of the stick. Women are getting
	  their equality more and more. Yet, if women are equal, capable
	  of supporting themselves, etc, why are so many divorced men
	  paying alimony and child support? If we're going to go forward
	  with liberation of the sexes, we have to stop looking at women as
	  dependent and men as breadwinners, and stop the sexism
	  implicit in the marriage laws. When a marriage ends it ends, and
	  the liberated man/women should be able to go separate ways without
	  court mandated laws about either party maintaining the
	  same standard of living after the marriage.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

On Mon, 11 Sep 1995, Eric Kalabacos wrote:

> Hello everyone,
> 
> After lurking for the suggested initial 2 weeks, I'm finally ready to
> introduce myself to y'all and tell you how much I'm enjoying getting to
> know you via the list.
> 
> First, the basics:
> 
> My name is Eric Kalabacos (friends call me E K). I'm 30 years old,
> originally from NYC, in SF since 1/1/90, a Buddhist, a big-time Mac-head
> (graphics, multimedia), and absolutely, positively, desperately, madly in
> love with music. I live in downtown SF (2nd & Mission) with my wonderful,
> beautiful girlfriend Veronika.
> 
> The first rave I ever went to was a Full Moon at Bonny Doon in the summer
> of '92. My guides were Ammon Haggerty (my employee at the time and still a
> dear friend) and Gary Henderson & Martha Harkey (of Yang Snowboard Clothing
> - my customers at the time and also still close friends). I'll never forget
> that night - arriving at 4am after a foggy, moonlit drive down Highway 1 -
> peering over the cliff at the magical spectacle of 2-3000 people dancing
> wildly under the stars - I simply couldn't believe it. This was an
> experience I felt I had been waiting for my whole life. We danced until
> noon. I loved watching the sun rise and seeing everyone's faces as the
> light increased...
> 
> Needless to say, I've been to a couple (or a couple hundred ;-) ) parties
> since that time. I've had all kinds of experiences - some great - some not
> so great - but all very worthwile from the perspective of learning about
> myself and my relationship to others. Raving has been (and still is) a
> shamanic experience for me in the truest sense of the word. It is a
> crucible into which I pour my whole being - my dreams, my fears, my
> inspiration, my desire, my wisdom, my confusion. Raving has also given me
> the chance to meet dozens and dozens of fascinating people, people like
> yourselves...  =)
> 
> And, oh yes, the music. Let's not forget the music. The primal heartbeat of
> the universe, the heartbeat of humanity. That feeling when you close your
> eyes and feel it reverberating throughout your whole being, dissolving
> fixation on self, teasing and tickling pleasure centers you didn't know
> existed. And then the moment when you open your eyes and catch someone
> else's glance and you both know. You both feel it together and there is a
> flood of warmth and compassion for each other and for all beings. This is
> why I rave.
> 
> As I said before, I've been lurking on the list for about 2 weeks now. I've
> been aware of its existence for quite a while, but was dubious about
> joining because of the anticipated flood of mail. I've made good use of the
> calendar in the past (for which I thank Derek and Brian and anyone else
> involved), but I'm so glad that I finally took the plunge and joined the
> list. It is definitely an effort to wade through so much mail every day.
> but worth it. I spend alot of time on-line (in fact, the company I work for
> is developing games for net), and I've always been fascinated by the
> potential of using the net for community-building. SFR is the finest
> example of net-community I've experienced.
> 
> Speaking of shamanic experiences, Veronika and I went to Burning Man with
> our friend Marcel last weekend. It was wonderful to follow the BMan-related
> threads on the list. I could feel the excitement grow as the event
> approached. I particularly loved the final day or two as people began to
> post descriptions of themselves so that it would be easier to find each
> other. I've also followed the post-Bman threads with great interest. It
> feels like quite a privilage to learn from other people's experiences at
> the event. When I get a chance I'll describe some of my own experiences
> there...
> 
> Anyway, I have to get back to work now, but I just want to thank you all
> once again for sharing yourselves in such an intimate, personal way on this
> list. I look forward to meeting you in person (I'm sure I've met many of
> you already and we don't even know it).
> 
> Peace & love,
> ek  =)
> 
> 
>

The subject line might be a bit misleading.  This is to confirm that
Richie Hawtin will not be at the Desert Move.  He has been waiting on 
the US Customs or Immigration offices to decide on allowing him entry
to the US without a court hearing.  He was refused entry several
months ago and not allowed to return pending a court hearing.  He
now has his work visa, and is waiting for the Customs/Immigration
office to recognise that without the court hearing.

John Acquaviva and Matthew Hawtin will both be there, though!

Hi Vince!

I'm sooo pleased ta meet ya!

I know this is a loooooong post, but I feel like a lost nomad searching for my 
tribe, so please bear with me.

I've gotten some great impressions from the sfraves list of folks.  Everyone 
seems really open, sincere and willing to make an effort to reach out.  
Although I've only been checking out the listings for a couple days (I broke 
the rule of lurking for two weeks, but I just couldn't wait to meet all the 
cool people =o) ) I have already met some real genuine folks who I can't wait 
to hook up with in person.  

I am just thrilled that there are so many people out there who have responded 
and want to make a connection.  It warms my heart! 

I've heard a million awesome things about the BMan gathering.  It sounds like 
an experience that practically transcends description even though what I've 
heard is glorious.  It almost sounds like it was a holy pilgrimage where people 
went to offer love, worship and thanks to their fellow brothers and sisters, 
the music, the earth.  It makes me giddy but sad to hear all the reports 
because I FEEL what you and these other folks are talking about and I totally 
relate, but it makes me sad that I wasn't there and that I haven't been having 
so many of "those experiences" lately in the scene.

**If others are reading these next couple of paragraphs,  do you feel the same 
way?**

Usually, when I go to a rave, I consider it to be an absolute success when 
(aside from awesome music and non-federally regulated substances) I get that 
feeling of love, trust, respect, and harmony with my fellow humans that lasts 
far beyond the music and the drugs.  That feeling goes down into the very 
depths of my soul, grabs my heart and my emotions and makes me want to dance 
and cry with joy.  At times everything seems so right.  I actually have 
epiphanies where I suddenly see what it's all about.  It has become my holy 
sacrament, a way to celebrate music and dance, expend positive energy, offer 
peace and friendship, and honor my fellow human beings and the incredible earth 
on which we live.  Unfortunately some of these encounters have shown me the 
world can be a very dark and hostile place too (but that's another tangent).  
For the most part I see the world as a place to learn, teach, nurture healthy 
relationships, have fun and dance, dance, dance!   

When I do encounter that feeling of peace and one-ness with the cosmic 
consciousness and my brothers and sisters, it's incredibly satisfying, 
uplifting, exhilarating, but a little meloncholy because I'm so afraid that 
feeling will go away and the experience will be just a sweet dream.  I'll wake 
up and find those wonderful people have floated away along with the fading, 
hypnotic beat.  There have been a couple times where it was such an amazing 
experience, but ultimately beyond a clear mental picture, that I wondered if I 
hallucinated the whole encounter or if it really happened.  Many times, after 
raves, I go home by myself and listen to more tunes (of course!).  I put my 
walkman on and kick it while winding down.  I have a smile on my face but at 
the same time I feel like crying (I'm sure this is partly from exhaustion) 
because the experience was so beautiful and rewarding...yet very etherial.  
It's frustrating not to be able to reach out and embrace the core of the 
experience and the people and have only the essence left to tease you.  It's 
exactly like trying to hold water in your hands...you saw the water, it was in 
your hands, your hands are wet, but there is no more water and you're STILL 
thirsty!!!.

*Whew!*  Alright, I'll stop hoggin' up all the band-width and give someone else 
a chance to flap!  I hope no-one objects to my ravings, I felt I needed to get 
it out there though  ;-)

Peace, love, friendships, dance

Rikki

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: weekend revelation
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9509111718.A19307-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


First off, welcome Eric and Rikki. You have discovered a great bunch of 
people.  :) 

Something happened to me at Family that nearly just bowled me over.  I 
met someone new at Family and his name is Hy....I introduced him to some 
of you if you recall. Well, he had never heard of sfraves or Burning Man 
and as I started explaining it all to him, I realized what a tight knit 
group we all are. I stayed with Wayne this weekend (thanks again, Wayne) 
and Hy looked at me in amazement that I stay with people that I don't 
really know - only through cyberspace. He also looked on in amazement as 
I introduced fellow sfravers who hadn't met before (that is SO much fun 
to do!) and they talk like old friends. 

I discovered that night that we are all TRUELY a family.  I very nearly 
cried and at the same time, I could see some disadvantages:  I have met 
in the last 6 months or so, sfravers and their friends,& not many others 
outside the "internet circle".  I get so used to talking about computers, 
what topics are being discussed that week, etc.  that it can get easy to 
forget all those great ravers that are not connected through cyberspace. 
I felt that again as I talked about Burning Man with people from sfraves 
and non-sfravers alike.  I said to Hy that "you just had to have been 
there to TRUELY understand."   Maybe I'm reading too much into it, but at 
Family Saturday night I really DID feel like a member of a very special 
sfraves family.  BTW, keep a look out for Hy on the interet.  He has an 
e-mail account at UCSC and I think that after meeting lots of sfravers 
himself, he will want to join our family, too.  Stay beautiful... I LOVE 
YOU ALL!

love,                     ps: a sidenote on Sunset...great party, I just
Amy                       felt so guilty about leaving when there was 
                          so much garbage on the ground....they guys from
                          Pacific were probably dead tired after
                          throwing Family the night before.  Why do 
                          people litter like that?  I'm bring my OWN 
                          garbage bag next time....

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 11 17:40:11 1995

	id AA26618; Mon, 11 Sep 1995 17:38:54 -0700

Okay, my server said it was unable to deliver my mail to 'sfraves'.  I'm trying 
to send again.  If people get this message twice, I sincerely apologize for the 
inconvenience.  Perhaps someone could let me know if they got it?

Hi Vince!

I'm sooo pleased ta meet ya!

exactly like trying to hold water in your hands...you saw the water, it was in 
your hands, your hands are wet, but there is no more water and you're STILL 
thirsty!!!.

*Whew!*  Alright, I'll stop hoggin' up all the band-width and give someone else 
a chance to flap!  I hope no-one objects to my ravings, I felt I needed to get 
it out there though  ;-)

Peace, love, friendships, dance

Rikki

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 11 17:52:57 1995

From: Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE
  <Rikki.Kiefer@sybase.com>

Subject: You Gettin' This?
Mime-Version: 1.0

My server told me that sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com is unable to deliver my 
message, even though I got a copy of it...hmm...not sure what this means.  So, 
I'm sending it again.  If you've already gotten it, I sincerely apologize for 
clogging up your mail!  Could somebody let me know if they've seen this post 
though?   Thanks so much. =o)

Hi Vince!

I'm sooo pleased ta meet ya!

I know this is a loooooong post, but I feel like a lost nomad searching for my 
tribe, so please bear with me.

I've gotten some great impressions from the sfraves list of folks.  Everyone 
seems really open, sincere and willing to make an effort to reach out.  
Although I've only been checking out the listings for a couple days (I broke 
the rule of lurking for two weeks, but I just couldn't wait to meet all the 
cool people =o) ) I have already met some real genuine folks who I can't wait 
to hook up with in person.  

I am just thrilled that there are so many people out there who have responded 
and want to make a connection.  It warms my heart! 

I've heard a million awesome things about the BMan gathering.  It sounds like 
an experience that practically transcends description even though what I've 
heard is glorious.  It almost sounds like it was a holy pilgrimage where people 
went to offer love, worship and thanks to their fellow brothers and sisters, 
the music, the earth.  It makes me giddy but sad to hear all the reports 
because I FEEL what you and these other folks are talking about and I totally 
relate, but it makes me sad that I wasn't there and that I haven't been having 
so many of "those experiences" lately in the scene.

**If others are reading these next couple of paragraphs,  do you feel the same 
way?**

Usually, when I go to a rave, I consider it to be an absolute success when 
(aside from awesome music and non-federally regulated substances) I get that 
feeling of love, trust, respect, and harmony with my fellow humans that lasts 
far beyond the music and the drugs.  That feeling goes down into the very 
depths of my soul, grabs my heart and my emotions and makes me want to dance 
and cry with joy.  At times everything seems so right.  I actually have 
epiphanies where I suddenly see what it's all about.  It has become my holy 
sacrament, a way to celebrate music and dance, expend positive energy, offer 
peace and friendship, and honor my fellow human beings and the incredible earth 
on which we live.  Unfortunately some of these encounters have shown me the 
world can be a very dark and hostile place too (but that's another tangent).  
For the most part I see the world as a place to learn, teach, nurture healthy 
relationships, have fun and dance, dance, dance!   

When I do encounter that feeling of peace and one-ness with the cosmic 
consciousness and my brothers and sisters, it's incredibly satisfying, 
uplifting, exhilarating, but a little meloncholy because I'm so afraid that 
feeling will go away and the experience will be just a sweet dream.  I'll wake 
up and find those wonderful people have floated away along with the fading, 
hypnotic beat.  There have been a couple times where it was such an amazing 
experience, but ultimately beyond a clear mental picture, that I wondered if I 
hallucinated the whole encounter or if it really happened.  Many times, after 
raves, I go home by myself and listen to more tunes (of course!).  I put my 
walkman on and kick it while winding down.  I have a smile on my face but at 
the same time I feel like crying (I'm sure this is partly from exhaustion) 
because the experience was so beautiful and rewarding...yet very etherial.  
It's frustrating not to be able to reach out and embrace the core of the 
experience and the people and have only the essence left to tease you.  It's 
exactly like trying to hold water in your hands...you saw the water, it was in 
your hands, your hands are wet, but there is no more water and you're STILL 
thirsty!!!.

*Whew!*  Alright, I'll stop hoggin' up all the band-width and give someone else 
a chance to flap!  I hope no-one objects to my ravings, I felt I needed to get 
it out there though  ;-)

Peace, love, friendships, dance

Rikki

I believe this didn't post.  If it did, sorry for the repeat.

Well,

Id have to say that this event hath inspried me in two or three ways...

One: Hold nothing sacred....  When I brought my items to 
Lett uS Dance (ie shoes, water, and lotsa smiles) I knew well that the H2O
would become the communal drinking jug.. (the shoes?? well, I reclaimed them
later on that night...) which was fine, since there were sooo many of Us
dancing in the frenzied state that we were in... 
Just dancing with soo many of  US, thoses in the scene, kept my belief that
we, as a community could do nothing but Grow.. accepting the next generation
of Dancers, Dj's and music...

Two: Although feeling ever so happy and trippy and dizzy et. al.
There was one thing that I did notice amongst the crowd and the place...
 This was the seemingly  noticeable through the change of "sets" that  the
DJ's from other 'camps' would throw up a little addititue here and there
(although it coulda been me too, I did go thru a bit of a paranoid stage
during the event myself).  However, if this was the case, Please people,
leave the 'fronting'  at home (ie. Yourpad@home.org).  All that frowns and
stern looks do is instigate fights and police, I know i've seen many
happen....
About the Place: I think it couldn't of been at a better local (since Ive
adapted my dancing style to sand and beachrocks...).  But, as day broke I
noticed all of these beat, worn down cardboards, which was no real problem
 since it is pyro-consumeable.  However, the plastic bottles I saw strewn
everywhere was indeed a sad sight to behold...  I know I can't lay blame
since I'v'e been culprit for many years too.  But to atone for my sins
against mother earth I've decied to take this oath:
        I (My Name)___  Do solemly sewar that wherever I happen to end up
finger snappin', Rump shakin', leg stompin', rug cuttin',  and spinning
around generally in madness, That amongst the other Neccesities that I may
bring to any Undergrounds (Ie flashlight, Battries, map et. al.). There WILL
be an empty plastic 10 (or 5) gal. trash bag to pickup such needless litter
that was so needful when water or other chemically derived compounds was
occupied in it.  And futhermore understand that Although I may get really,
really strange looks from others as I put a bag of useless trash in my car,I
will be content. Knowing I have Done my duty to respect the ground I dance on
& ravers I dance with...

Despite these lil' pratfalls the event was a smashing success. I recieved
plenty 'O' names (Again, all escape me now...)  A specal "Hiya" to thoses
campfire dudes from San Mateo, tha guy sining the CHiPs theme to his feamle
siginficant other, that Cute asian gal by the speaker, thoses two other gals
I think I talked to & Mars for a good set (and Tom too I believe...)...

Smile O meter Ratings:

Vibe:  Trippy trancy Madness 
 9Smiles....

Dance space: funny to see that people are brining thier own "dance floor"
 (ie. cardboard boxes) but, I perfer contact w/the earth I dance on 
8.5Smiles

Lights/visuals:  after getting accustomed to everyone looking like radiation
victims it wasnt too bad 
8Smiles

Location:  As the saying goes... "Getting there is an adventure in itself"
 Directions were Pretty Crazy 
 7Smiles...

Frienship Potental: I believe this rating in itself depends on the person(s)
initiating it... Although I did see guys chasin' E-babies and doing what they
knowingly or unknowingly do.
On the other coin I also saw pleasent conversation and general acceptence
with strangers-turn-freinds just ploping down and chatting.
8Smiles

Overall:  8.1 smiles

In closing (about time, eh?),
I'd like to believe this, the scene, is all about communicating w/each other
and becoming closer because of it.  A common thread that unites us all
(almost like this post)...  And although I know that This message is
probabaly being read by less than 10% of the actuall people in attenence I
feel if I touched any of you then all this scatterbrain-bandwith-consuming
Eline then something has been achieved.....

-Dancing, weaving, catching a hug in between. Still free.-
Adam 

P.S. 
BTW, I was the one in the Blue shirt, torn grey pants, and an X cap....
If you see me next time, yank me from the dance floor and say howdy....

Hi Adam,
	In your last post, you mentioned that you felt some of the "DJs from
other camps would throw up a little attitude here and there".  I can anly
speak for myself when I say, "I still get queazy when i step up to spin"
(i almost passed out during my set at F&F =)  ) so sometimes I forget to
smile or even look up during my set!  So, during my (and DJ Swoops) set, I
prolly didn't look like the happiest person in the world; but believe me,
spinning makes my soul glow and my heart smile (on the inside).  
	With this being said, I would like to ask a favor of all you beautiful
people out there.  If you ever see me spinning (or anywhere else!) without
a smile or happy radience, walk up and say, "SMILE!" and I promise to respond
with a big chee-Z smile and/or a big hug!!!
Luv,
Sabin Cloud
