Subject: the gardening club(Bsp) invite to sfr
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To sfravers. $2 admission tonight if you mention sfraves. Free vegetarian
food at 11:30ish.The founding idea  of  the gardening club is to ask Dj's
to bring down music they would play to their friends on a hazy Sunday
morning after a mad night, they are requested not to play anything that is
in their sets at that time insuring different and diverse music each week.
All monnies taken on the door is evenly distributed amongst everyone who
works at TGC. Thanks for use of sfraves as a communication mediam.

Plus here is a question I would like to throw into the ring:
         technology has began to bring us the chance as independents to
produce and distribute music and interactive products cheaply. With things
like direct digital delivery, Virtual banking and the real time  audio
technologies, anabling you to broadcast live via the web. Do you think the
ties that have chained us as artists to corporate companies due to their
control of all the steps in the wheel of making, producing, distributing
and marketing of product, and even the control of the format you  listen to
the music from,will be broken when consumers will be able to contact
artists directly and download and pay for things from the source? Will
technology bring back the days when punk music ruled the airwaves and
independents ran the music industry(80's in Britain)?
       will  Majors become holding companies that will only have control
over back stock releases and will be there to do things like publicity and
marketing for the artist?
        This could be a possibility in the electronic and dance music
industries if the technology is utilized by the many small independents
that are starting up all over America. The major problem holding us back is
lack of airplay on commercial radio pushing the industry to rely on mixed
tapes to bring awareness of labels & artists.   You can guarantee that the
direct distribution network is already being cornered by the corporate
companies, just look at the politics and buyouts going on with the future
of home entertainment with things like the telecommunications bill, video
on demand, 100 of squillians of crap cable channels through fiber optics
and the new hybrid CD's that hold 2.5 hours of video. Plus After the
cancellation of the project between IBM and blockbusters to produce one of
cds in their stores allowing consumers to pick and choose their own
compilations through direct delivery. Which was blocked by the majors after
IBM and Blockbuster announced the idea causing much embarrassment?
          This is a bit of research for an article I may do in Xlr8r, so
thought sfraves would be a good place to start. So this is for a question
forArtists and consumers.
        Darkhorse

http//:www.manmad.com

...................FYI....................

THE GARDENING CLUB
An Electronic Hydroponic Environment
San Francisco

Sept 11th  Jonah(spacetime continuum), Bonehead(Dallas)

Sept 18th   Girlie night: Dj Emma(Diy,Uk), Dani(Sf),

Residing DJ's Darkhorse & Charles Uzzel Edwards

55 natoma(Between 1st &2nd)      For a good time call 415 207 LEAF

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 11 21:36:06 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA22353; Mon, 11 Sep 1995 21:36:06 -0700

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: My First FMR
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950911194541.20603A-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	This Cancer(Moonchild), had the pleasure of attending my first
ever FMR. It took me a year of raving in the Bay Area to get there. The
night started out with me posting to SFR, that I was in search of that
special person who would offer me a ride, down south. Well it was getting
late, bout 11:30pm, and I was thinking that once again I wouldn't make it.

	I went to log back on for the last time when I saw a post from
Kathleen Evans, offering me a ride down to FMR. Well my moon
goddess/mother must have been looking out for me cause a half hour later
Doug Faircloud called offering me yet another ride. Karma's a funny thing
ya know. Well, it promised to be a truely interesting, beautiful, and
charming night of music, environment, & company. I told Doug that I
already had a ride and the he should meet us down there, anyway. I then
met for the first time a very sweet Kathleen Evans, and we both headed off
down 880 south to the FMR. 

	From 880 I usually take 92 over the San M bridge to get to 1 and 
the coast. I am truely envious of all the Californian's that have had 
such a beautiful coast to share and enjoy there entire lives, while us 
east coast transplants had "the shore"; (sigh). Cali's coast is beautiful 
even in the dark, and even after a year I'm still awed and breathless. 
There's a 7-11 at the end of 92 where I usually stop for raver supplies. 
We pulled into the parking lot and ran into Doug doing the same. So we 
talked & hugged for a few minutes and decided to caravan down to FMR.

	So we drove down the coast until we saw a line of cars on the side
of the road signaling that we had reached our destination. We jumped out
of the car & over the first dune to behold the party location. A beautiful
& huge cove/beach cut out of the surrounding hill sides, protected all all
sides except for the water, erieially lit by an invisible full moon's
light, and about 50 - 100 down. This sacred place, could easially hold a
thousand or so ravers. The beach consisted of a few scattered fires,
tents, ravers(awake & asleep), and a silent sound system. The sight
reminded me of a track on my GAIA 1&2 CD, called a Tribute To Goa, by
S.M.I.L.E, of Berlin. The track opens with the echoing/reverbing vocals
"beach, sound, water, palms, stars, space, juice, Goa", I smiled and
headed down the hill with my compainions. As I was walking down the dune,
I imaged what a surprise it would be to some unaware campers from say
Kenny-Bunk-Port Maine, or similar local, to think they've found a really
cool camp sight, only to be awakened by house music, and 200 lovin,
freakin, dancin, children of the moon, at 3 o 'clock in da 
morning.        = >!!!!!!!!!! 

	After about 15 minutes or so, I heard the generator turn over and
knew the music was soon to follow. If was 3:00am or there abouts, when the
house music started to spin. I'm sorry but I can't tell ya who was
spinning, but they did a really, really, great couple of sets. The beat
picked up as the night went along, seeming to reach an exstascy filled
climax sometime near dawn, with almost everyone up dancing.

	In the day light I could clearly see about a hundred or so of us
"freaks"; and I thought to myself; god it doesn't get much better than
this. Da house music spun til bout 10am, including one more "crazy freaky
jam", by request :) 

	In a nutshell, and in my opinion, the three best kept secrets in 
the bay area as far as raves go are; the Full Moon Rave, New Moon Rave, 
and my personal favorite cause I LOVE TRANCE!!!, is Frequency 8. See ya 
this Friday.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET
		 CT Active Voice & Fax (510)-530-6452
	      CT Active Pager & Voice Mail (800)-590-4993

	Internet(Liberty BBS Account):	brianv@liberty.com
        Internet(LINUX Shell Account):	brianvan@liberty.liberty.com

		   GivE mE LibErty or GivE mE DEath
		  BewarE thE Tyranny of thE Majority
		      It's not a CrimE to DancE
		       (MEssagEs for the 90's)

On Mon, 11 Sep 1995, Amy R Starkey wrote:

> 
> First off, welcome Eric and Rikki. You have discovered a great bunch of 
> people.  :) 
> 
> Something happened to me at Family that nearly just bowled me over.  I 
> met someone new at Family and his name is Hy....I introduced him to some 
> of you if you recall. Well, he had never heard of sfraves or Burning Man 
> and as I started explaining it all to him, I realized what a tight knit 
> group we all are. I stayed with Wayne this weekend (thanks again, Wayne) 
> and Hy looked at me in amazement that I stay with people that I don't 
> really know - only through cyberspace. He also looked on in amazement as 
> I introduced fellow sfravers who hadn't met before (that is SO much fun 
> to do!) and they talk like old friends. 
> 
> I discovered that night that we are all TRUELY a family.  I very nearly 
> cried and at the same time, I could see some disadvantages:  I have met 
> in the last 6 months or so, sfravers and their friends,& not many others 
> outside the "internet circle".  I get so used to talking about computers, 
> what topics are being discussed that week, etc.  that it can get easy to 
> forget all those great ravers that are not connected through cyberspace. 
> I felt that again as I talked about Burning Man with people from sfraves 
> and non-sfravers alike.  I said to Hy that "you just had to have been 
> there to TRUELY understand."   Maybe I'm reading too much into it, but at 
> Family Saturday night I really DID feel like a member of a very special 
> sfraves family.  BTW, keep a look out for Hy on the interet.  He has an 
> e-mail account at UCSC and I think that after meeting lots of sfravers 
> himself, he will want to join our family, too.  Stay beautiful... I LOVE 
> YOU ALL!
>

>                           so much garbage on the ground....they guys from
>                           Pacific were probably dead tired after
>                           throwing Family the night before.  Why do

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 11 23:02:47 1995

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: My First FMR
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950911230231.15340E-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Dear All;

	This Cancer(Moonchild), had the pleasure of attending my first
ever FMR. It took me a year of raving in the Bay Area to get there. The
night started out with me posting to SFR, that I was in search of that
special person who would offer me a ride, down south. Well it was getting
late, bout 11:30pm, and I was thinking that once again I wouldn't make it.

	I went to log back on for the last time when I saw a post from
Kathleen Evans, offering me a ride down to FMR. Well my moon
goddess/mother must have been looking out for me cause a half hour later
Doug Faircloud called offering me yet another ride. Karma's a funny thing
ya know. Well, it promised to be a truely interesting, beautiful, and
charming night of music, environment, & company. I told Doug that I
already had a ride and the he should meet us down there, anyway. I then
met for the first time a very sweet Kathleen Evans, and we both headed off
down 880 south to the FMR. 

	From 880 I usually take 92 over the San M bridge to get to 1 and 
the coast. I am truely envious of all the Californian's that have had 
such a beautiful coast to share and enjoy there entire lives, while us 
east coast transplants had "the shore"; (sigh). Cali's coast is beautiful 
even in the dark, and even after a year I'm still awed and breathless. 
There's a 7-11 at the end of 92 where I usually stop for raver supplies. 
We pulled into the parking lot and ran into Doug doing the same. So we 
talked & hugged for a few minutes and decided to caravan down to FMR.

	So we drove down the coast until we saw a line of cars on the side
of the road signaling that we had reached our destination. We jumped out
of the car & over the first dune to behold the party location. A beautiful
& huge cove/beach cut out of the surrounding hill sides, protected all all
sides except for the water, erieially lit by an invisible full moon's
light, and about 50 - 100 down. This sacred place, could easially hold a
thousand or so ravers. The beach consisted of a few scattered fires,
tents, ravers(awake & asleep), and a silent sound system. The sight
reminded me of a track on my GAIA 1&2 CD, called a Tribute To Goa, by
S.M.I.L.E, of Berlin. The track opens with the echoing/reverbing vocals
"beach, sound, water, palms, stars, space, juice, Goa", I smiled and
headed down the hill with my compainions. As I was walking down the dune,
I imaged what a surprise it would be to some unaware campers from say
Kenny-Bunk-Port Maine, or similar local, to think they've found a really
cool camp sight, only to be awakened by house music, and 200 lovin,
freakin, dancin, children of the moon, at 3 o 'clock in da 
morning.        = >!!!!!!!!!! 

	After about 15 minutes or so, I heard the generator turn over and
knew the music was soon to follow. If was 3:00am or there abouts, when the
house music started to spin. I'm sorry but I can't tell ya who was
spinning, but they did a really, really, great couple of sets. The beat
picked up as the night went along, seeming to reach an exstascy filled
climax sometime near dawn, with almost everyone up dancing.

	In the day light I could clearly see about a hundred or so of us
"freaks"; and I thought to myself; god it doesn't get much better than
this. Da house music spun til bout 10am, including one more "crazy freaky
jam", by request :) 

	In a nutshell, and in my opinion, the three best kept secrets in 
the bay area as far as raves go are; the Full Moon Rave, New Moon Rave, 
and my personal favorite cause I LOVE TRANCE!!!, is Frequency 8. See ya 
this Friday.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET
		 CT Active Voice & Fax (510)-530-6452
	      CT Active Pager & Voice Mail (800)-590-4993

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep 12 01:57:09 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA09062; Tue, 12 Sep 1995 01:57:09 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA09054; Tue, 12 Sep 1995 01:57:06 -0700
Date: Tue, 12 Sep 1995 01:57:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: SFRaves List Party/Pre-Wedding Bash This Saturday
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950912011632.24228M-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


As many of you probably know, this Sunday, September 17th, I am getting
married to a very special woman, Laura La Gassa.  You probably know her
from her writings on PLUR way back when or her work with vrave and occasional
posts to sfraves and such.  We had to limit the size of our ceremony on
Sunday due to our budget, and since we had *many* friends we didn't have 
room to invite, we decided it would be great to throw an informal, 
open-invite beach party the day before.  Realizing now that it would 
probably be a rather large party, and since spirits on the SFRaves list 
are running at a nearly all-time high, we figured now would be a great 
time for a big SFRaves list get-together as well.

So, the details:

Place:   Bonny Doon beach, Santa Cruz (directions below)
Time:    Saturday, September 16th, 1pm to 8:30pm
   EVERYONE IS INVITED

Bonny Doon is a beach about 12 miles north of Santa Cruz along the 1 - as
those who have followed the list for awhile know, Bonny Doon is a very
important beach in SFRaves herstory - the first Connection was held there
back in August of 1992.  It also has a huge place in my heart.  The beach is
*very* big, is free and open to the public, and a daytime party will have no
trouble with music.  The curfew on the beach is 10pm, so we'll end right
after sunset, around 8:30, so we have time to pack up and move out without
causing problems. 

Ethan Miller of FnF fame has graciously donated SoundVision for the event -
what would a party be without music? - and he, Joe Rice, and a friend of ours
from New York, Will-E, are the DJ's on the schedule so far. If you would like
to spin, send me mail - I want to give at least 1 1/2 hours/DJ so there's
really only 2 spots left, reserved for SFRaves list people of course :)

So, here's the call out for help:  *WE NEED VOLUNTEERS!*  If you want to 
get together and *sweat* with your fellow listgeeks like me here's your 
chance :)

1) Bonny Doon is not an easy to get a sound system to, so we need a set up
crew and a tear down crew of roughly 15-20 each.  This involves some 
amount of heavy lifting.  With that many people the whole system could be 
moved in one trip between the parking lot and the beach.  

2) Someone is needed to pick up and return a 5Kw generator from Big 4 in 
the city (or wherever the person would like to rent from)

3) A tarp/canopy is needed to shield the DJ area from sun/heat - a simple 
blue plastic tarp with poles to support it would work, or even two patio 
umbrellas.  

If you can volunteer for any of these positions, send me mail here at 
brian@hyperreal.com so I can know what to expect.  If you are in the 
setup crew, be in the parking lot by 1 - if you are in the tear-down crew 
expect to stay to 9:30.

The aim is for a feel similar to Sunset parties - nothing fancy, no strobe
lights, just being outside with great music and lots of friends.  Of course
one should consider bringing food, sunblock, trashbags, fruit, things to play
on the beach with, your good spirits, and yes, even your massage table if so
inclined.  Feel free to bring friends too.  If you'd like to plan 
something monumentally interesting let me know... 

---

Directions from San Francisco/San Mateo/points east:

  Take the 92 west, past the 280, over the pass to the coast and highway 1
  Turn left (south) at the 1, go about 40 miles.  (see below)

Directions from San Jose and Santa Cruz:

  Take 17 south to the 1 north, go about 10 miles past the last 7-11

Just south of Davenport, you'll see Bonny Doon Road come from inland and 
interesect at a dirt parking lot.  Park in that lot, or nearby (observing 
all parking laws of course - they *will* ticket and smoetimes tow, but 
there is enough space for everyone) and head over the hill across the train 
tracks, and there you are.  

Again, if you can volunteer, send me mail so we can have some semblance 
of coordination :)  

See you all there!

	Brian

Hi SFRaves -

 Well , I posted the attached text back in Oct. 1992 - and I guess it 
mostly still stands. Some things are dated - I put in some comments
that are denoted by {} . I hope it introduces me adequately to the 
folks I haven't talked to yet!

                      Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 --------------------------------------------------------------------

My Testimonial: Why I Go To Raves
 
 I guess I should start with me and dancing. From what I remember about
my childhood attempts at dancing, I was a hyperactive stepper. I would
do what would be described now as pogoing, with a reve'd up version of
twisting ( showing my age there!). { I was 37 when I originally wrote
this } . I knew when to stop dancing, when my
nose started bleeding.
 
 So, from my earliest years, I valued sensation over style in dancing.
When I entered my teenage years, the sexuality & sensuality that I
became capable of added some spice to the equation, but it was still
mostly an adrenaline/trance thing. This was at odds with social dancing,
especially in the shy, conservative environment of 1970's teen Hawaii.
And, since I didn't like drinking all that much, rock concerts were the
only way I could dance the way I wanted to. ( At that time, rock
concerts in Hawaii were almost totally attended by white audiences ).
 
 The sensuality and trance components of my dancing increased after I
encountered marijuana and acid; and my accessiblity to these aspects of
dance has remained with me, in a mellower fashion, after I reduced my
level of consumption. { Despite all the odds , I still haven't done
E yet! Just never have been the right combination of mood , desire ,
and availability . I don't miss what I haven't had... }
 
 I screwed up my back a few years ago, so a lot of my dancing now is
done with my upper body, as opposed to doing fancy dance moves with my
feet.
{ My back is much better now ... I usually say that just before I
  screw it up again!}
 I do a lot of dancfloor roaming, as walking/jogging/running is
easier for my legs to do than in-place dancing. I don't usually like
compact crowds and uneven dancefloors at raves, because they both
interfere with my zooming around.
 
--------
 
 The main reason I like raves is that I can dance the way I've always
wanted to.
 
 
 Other reasons are:
 
- Meeting people who are kind and patient.
  At one big warehouse rave in Hayward, I accidently stepped on
someone's hand, but he was graciously forgiving. And, of course, I've
met all you good SFRavers! Good people are hard to find.
 
- Not so much macho "I/we can booze/do drugs/dance/fight better than you
and your gang can" attitude. ( Although the recent posts about WICKED
may indicate that a person should be aware of potential trouble ).
{ I can't remember what the Wicked reference was about - but there's
  been recent non-Wicked problems that make the warnign just as 
  relevant }.
 
- Crowd participation - can you imagine a seated audience "appreciating"
a DJ , like a classical string quartet? 
{ Well , nowdays if the DJ is doing ambient or acid jazz or ... actually
  listening in a classical music audience sense is not so far fetched.
  And I have stopped dancing at least once so I could just get deeper
  into some elaborate acid trance that DJ Theta Blip was spinning }

 What really annoys me at the
huge Grateful Dead shows are the "butt-parkers" who seem to be there to
watch the clowns (ie Deadheads) and be sports-style fans, as opposed to
using their minds and bodies to join with the music.
{ Recent example - Burning Man ? }
 
- (Bad reason coming here ->) Rave is "leading edge", as opposed to
"cool" or "fashionable" .
I'll be honest, part of my interest in raves comes from the novelty of
them. I've always been a Curious George about pop avant culture, and
these millenium (end)times have been very, very interesting! Also, I
still feel an air of impermanence to raves. I don't want to miss this
before it disappears, the way I was too late for the 60's.
{ Rave still seems to be around , like some high-quality airwick. I don't
  care if it's "leading-edge" or not anymore }
 
{ My old .sig follows ... "Dance Like A Flower" was the first semi-techno
  vinyl purchase ...}  
 *-------------------------------------------------------------------------*
 | "Listen carefully to the music, and dance like a flower"                |
 |  ---> Body Of Light:"Dance Like A Flower"                               |
 | "I AM THE GENIE OF THE TOOTHPASTE!"                  larryc@netcom.com  |
 |  ---> The Darwin Chamber:"Genie Of The Toothpaste"                      |
 *-------------------------------------------------------------------------*

Frequency 8 returns this Friday evening with an evening of trance, hard
trance, goa and related muziks which we like to call "Cybertrance"

It will be outdoors in Western Marin county approximately 45 minutes
(driving time) north of San Francisco.  Music will start at 11:30 and go to
shortly after dawn.

DJs will be Cyr, MysterE and MARS.

We are asking for $5. to help cover expenses and highly recommend that you
bring a FLASHLIGHT, wear sensible shoes and dress for the possibility of
fog.  The fire gods would also appreciate wooden contributions to the
bonfire!

Call 415-541-5019 for map point information!

Beautiful post Rikki!
"I get that feeling of love, trust, respect, and harmony with my fellow
humans" = DA VIBE -- its always been there and you can almost always find at
least a small pocket of it at any party.
Its wonderful to have new people come into the scene and see it again for the
first time through their eyes. I've made friends with a couple of "newbies"
recently and their enthusiasm is so contagious that it just lifts me up no
matter what mood I'm in.  

Its true that you can reach higher states of consciousness that aren't really
accesible to the normal waking consciousness even via memory.  And I'm always
working on bringing the vibe back into my everyday life.  It sounds like you
might be missing that key component to happiness and that's giving back.  For
the longest time I would feel that I was still unfulfilled that I couldn't
"embrace the core" as you say until I tried giving back even if its just
giving people water, candy,hugs, energy, whatever. When you give back you
complete the loop and thus fulfill the vibe within yourself and it just goes
higher. Try it. 
Oh yeah, dump the walkman, get a boombox and invite some people back home
with you when the parties over.
Keep it goin' y'all,
phuture

> would it be too much trouble for ya'all to send out a brief
> hello/bio for us new people?  mine shall come soon.  i think it would be a
> great way for this community to say hello, since we don't come face to face
> as often as i'd like.

Okay, here's mine:

Name:  Amy Rainier Starkey
Occupation:  Fulltime student @ CSUS major - graphic design.  Works part 
             time at Pottery Barn in Arden Fair Mall. 
Personal stats:  5'6" with long straight hair - two hair wraps behind my 
                 left ear, brown eyes, always smiling! :):) 
Rave history:  First rave was Liquid Palace here in Sac in 92.  But my 
             first ExpEriEncE was at the Gathering New Year's Eve party 
             92/93 at the Vallejo Fairgrounds.   I consider that my "real"
             first rave. My first year as a raver as mostly spent at 
             larger venues - ususally Basics or Gatherings - I never 
             missed 'em.  Now I prefer the smaller parties and getting 
             a chance to hear lesser known dj's.
Music pref:  Acid trance!!!!  I loved that harder faster stuff played at 
             Friends & Family.  Still my alltime favorite dj ever has got 
             to be Tony.  He never lets me down!!  

Okay, that's enough about me......

Just to let you know, the sfraves family extends all the way up to the
Northwest!  There are lot's of nw-ravers lurking on sfraves and we consider
ourselves part of the sfraves family.  We planned our first FMR 3 years ago
based on concepts and ideas we derived from sfraves.

Please don't consider your move to Seattle as going away from your family,
but merely visiting another branch of the family.  Welcome!  =)

Please feel free to contact me and I'll introduce ya around to your
Northwest cuzzins!

Date: Tue, 12 Sep 1995 22:52:42 GMT

Reply-To: fuzzy@crl.com

X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99b.112
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My personal view as an artist, technophile, and consumer:

While technology is going to make it easier and easier for the
connected few (as consumers) to make direct connection with the
artists this is in no way going to change the patterns of airplay
until the station music directors take advantage of the new digitally
connected delivery and search channels available thru the web and
other networked sources.  As a result the general public will still
not have a clue as to what is available from the independent
artist/producer, let alone know of how to find it.  It will still be
the adventurous quirky few that will know where to find the edge and
experience it.

The additional consumer issue here is of storage media.  The digitally
connected user is currently limited to either having a HUGE hard disk
or learning how to connect a cassette deck to their soundcard outputs
and piece together a string of soundfiles of varying quality and level
manually.  Until a truely affordable CD burner (with an internal swap
space equivilant to a full CD's capacity) complete with CD authoring
software that can roughly compensate for level and other discrepancies
in a playlist of files, convert from any and all soundfile formats to
red book audio, and, here is the key, do all this with minimal to no
input from the user, this will never be a mainstream distribution
system.

Fuzzy
-=-=-=-=-

On Mon, 11 Sep 95 20:00:50 -0700,
  object --> natural@SIRIUS.COM (Natural) <-- fabricated:

>Plus here is a question I would like to throw into the ring:
>         technology has began to bring us the chance as independents to
>produce and distribute music and interactive products cheaply. With things
>like direct digital delivery, Virtual banking and the real time  audio
>technologies, anabling you to broadcast live via the web. Do you think the
>ties that have chained us as artists to corporate companies due to their
>control of all the steps in the wheel of making, producing, distributing
>and marketing of product, and even the control of the format you  listen to
>the music from,will be broken when consumers will be able to contact
>artists directly and download and pay for things from the source?

> Will
>technology bring back the days when punk music ruled the airwaves and
>independents ran the music industry(80's in Britain)?

>       will  Majors become holding companies that will only have control
>over back stock releases and will be there to do things like publicity and
>marketing for the artist?

>        This could be a possibility in the electronic and dance music
>industries if the technology is utilized by the many small independents
>that are starting up all over America. The major problem holding us back is
>lack of airplay on commercial radio pushing the industry to rely on mixed
>tapes to bring awareness of labels & artists.   You can guarantee that the
>direct distribution network is already being cornered by the corporate
>companies, just look at the politics and buyouts going on with the future
>of home entertainment with things like the telecommunications bill, video
>on demand, 100 of squillians of crap cable channels through fiber optics
>and the new hybrid CD's that hold 2.5 hours of video. Plus After the
>cancellation of the project between IBM and blockbusters to produce one of
>cds in their stores allowing consumers to pick and choose their own
>compilations through direct delivery. Which was blocked by the majors after
>IBM and Blockbuster announced the idea causing much embarrassment?

>          This is a bit of research for an article I may do in Xlr8r, so
>thought sfraves would be a good place to start. So this is for a question
>forArtists and consumers.
>        Darkhorse
>
>http//:www.manmad.com

Attention!
Music Critics, Publishers, Music Producers, and Music Lovers

I would like to take the opportunity to invite you to visit our recently 
opened techno record shop.  This unique store contains the rare and hard 
to find records and CDs from Germany, Benelux, and U.K., many of which 
are distributed exclusively by Tranceatlantic in Canada.  Our mission is 
to bring the atmosphere of electronic musical creation which is very 
strong in Europe to Canada.

We are open from 1-9pm every day but Sunday, and would be very pleased if 
you would pay us a visit during these times.  Our music is currently 
being played on the Dr. Trance Show on Energy 108 on Saturdays from 
7-9pm.  Thank you for your time.

Paul Van Toss
Director, Tranceatlantic Music Canada

426 Adelaide St. W.
Toronto, Ontario
M5V 1S7

Tel: (416)703-4081
Fax: (416)703-4073

trance@ikon.tlug.reptiles.org

Attention!
Music Critics, Publishers, Music Producers, and Music Lovers

I would like to take the opportunity to invite you to visit our recently 
opened techno record shop.  This unique store contains the rare and hard 
to find records and CDs from Germany, Benelux, and U.K., many of which 
are distributed exclusively by Tranceatlantic in Canada.  Our mission is 
to bring the atmosphere of electronic musical creation which is very 
strong in Europe to Canada.

We are open from 1-9pm every day but Sunday, and would be very pleased if 
you would pay us a visit during these times.  Our music is currently 
being played on the Dr. Trance Show on Energy 108 on Saturdays from 
7-9pm.  Thank you for your time.

Paul Van Toss
Director, Tranceatlantic Music 

426 Adelaide St. W.
Toronto, Ontario
M5V 1S7

Tel: (416)703-4081
Fax: (416)703-4073

trance@ikon.tlug.reptiles.org

Ok here's mine too

Name: Sean Clare

Occupation: I drive a big yellow tow truck and part time candy flipper
Personal stats: 5'10" 155lbs  short brown hair, baby blue eyes usually
dilated at
parties. Got a few tattoos including this hot looking raver girl on my arm.

Rave history: First was a Toon Town back in '92. Been to too many more since
then  to even fathom a guess. My favorites have been FMR at Bonnie Doon
Beach, Wicked, Come Unity, The Orb in 93, and Pure Space. Allways guaranteed
to  be a slammin party. I live with my best friend who also happens to be  a
pretty good DJ and owns a fat sound system so I allways get to  hear all the
newest and raddest records. Lots ofother  perks come with having him for a
friend and roommate.

Music Preference: HOUSE MUSIC! Anything with soul (Garth and Thomas and my
favorite DJs) I also like funky, break-beat style and really trippy sounds.
Not too much into techno or trance. I prefer the BPMs in the 120-140 range.
I also listen to hip hop, reggae, modern dance, Patsy Cline, AC/DC, you name it!

What else.... I grew up in San Francisco, I've lived in San Jose, Santa Cruz
and San Rafael. I just moved back here a few months ago from my second time
living in Santa Cruz (too boring there) and my girlfriend just recently
brokw up with me.

And thats that!

If you want to know anything alse just ask!

  



-Sean
 F R E A K   Z O N E !
 Renegade Sound System
 (415) 679-3113
 "House Music All Night Long"

Subject: In/Equality
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950912220144.8281C-100000@netcom12>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


So it is apparently the opinion of Mr. Mayer that, because we have 
anatomical differences, men and women are inherently inequal, and 
therefore should not even bother to discuss issues of gender equality at all.

Well, as far as anatomical goes -- men are not incapable of physically 
nursing a child, given proper hormonal therapy, and the evidence shows 
that men would even be able to carry out most of the functions of gestation,
with similar tweaking. { Caesarian birth, guys... we're not talking about 
cutting anything off, here ;) }

I'm not saying that the above is anything we need to be doing, at least not 
in the name of "equal rights", but it does emphasize my point -- we're not as 
different as some would have you think. For example, the Religious Right 
would LOVE for us all to think as Mr. Mayer does -- "this is the way it 
is/always has been/always will be so there is no point in discussing it". 

Sorry, but that kind of smug crap just doesn't reflect reality. Biology 
is not Destiny.

What about those of us who are different in other ways? Those of us who 
are queer! Those of us who are disabled! Those of us who have darker skin 
and eyes that aren't blue!

Are we doomed to a life on the lower rungs of Society's Ladder because of 
our differences? 

NO!!! 

These are issues we address over and over, louder and louder, because there 
are still some folks who just don't get it -- 

**that there is nothing inherently inequal about difference**.


Maui


ps: we all start out female, don't forget...



AND WE ALL START OUT FEMALE.

OH well, Where do I begin?

My name's Geoff, I'm 6' 5" >250# :) African American Male I'm sorta a rave
"elder" as I will be 39 this January. Hmm, I can't remember my first
"rave" party exactly, I remember my first exposure to SF night life which
was a Do not sit (on the furniture) party back in 88.  I think the first
actual "rave party that I went to was a Toon Town at Big Heart City this
must have been sometime in '91 but I didn't really become a "raver" until
I went to two particular parties, my first full moon rave at
Grey Whale Cove in March of '92 and the Whoopie Ball of that same month.
When I saw all of those people on the beach having fun and dancing in the
moon light and thc cops up top couldn't do a fucking thing to stop it,
I KNEW THIS WAS FOR ME :).  I also had the most incredible experience 
of community and spirituality at the Whoopie ball that it just blew me
away.  I went out to as many parties as i could after that.  I pretty
much prefer HOUSE music in all it's forms but since my major occupation
in the scene is to generate the Vibe, this is possible with any and all
types of music, from HOUSE TO Trance to Hardcore, I do remember seeing
God in the Bass Bins during hardcore techno sets during the Toon Town days
so It's al good.  These days I don't get to go out as much as i used to
having numerous full-time and part time jobs in and out of The Scene.
Some of you have most recently seen me as the "door diva" :) at Wicked.
But I do manage to get out about 4 times a month which is way lower
then 4 times a week which was the the norm in '92 :) Anyways you will
still find me at Wicked, Sunset and Friends & Family, as well as the
FMR and the smaller parties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow

		--PGP Public key available upon request--
     "If I can't trance, I don't want to be part of your revolution"

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950912220144.8281C-100000@netcom12>; from "Maui-YSH" at Sep 12, 95 10:29 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Maui:
> [...] and the evidence shows 
> that men would even be able to carry out most of the functions of gestation,
> with similar tweaking.
> [...]
>  Biology is not Destiny.

And of course genetic engineering might someday allow human biology
to be configuarable.  Sexuality seems to be a relatively flexible
trait.  There are invertebrates (at least one species of fish) that
will change gender under certain naturally occuring conditions.

I've always felt that the only chance for the continued survival of
the human race will be through an evolution that transcends our
biological origins (yes, there is a paradox here).  Though I usually
think about this in terms of spirituality or psychology, it  will
probably have to occur physically as well.  Supplementing our brains
with chemicals or computer interfaces are a couple of near term
examples.

I think raving already points us in this direction. There isn't a
single human who can keep time like a drum machine, yet for some
reason, that perfect beat feels so right.  Sure, we still like to have
our emotions triggered by a vocal sample or some irregularity in
the rhythm, but a large part of the rave experience (for me) is to
reach a state that takes us beyond our human limitations.

Lee
______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> would it be too much trouble for ya'all to send out a brief
> hello/bio for us new people?  mine shall come soon.  i think it would be a
> great way for this community to say hello, since we don't come face to 
face
> as often as i'd like.

Another brief bio:

Name:  Ivan Lamont

Occupation:  Computer Programmer and Loud Guitar Player

Personal stats:  5'10" brown eyes brown hair, born in Dublin Ireland some 26 
years ago, moved to USA last summer, often seen raving with a Atlanta Braves 
cap on my head, maniac grin on my face and a rust covered blue 71 Cadillac 
Coup de Ville somewhere in the background.

Nickname:  Speedy (not sure why, exactly  ;)  )

Rave history:  First rave was in London in 1989.  Watched and participated 
in the Explosion of the ravE scene in Dublin until 1994, first US rave was 
Moonlight about 3 months ago where I met so many incredible people that my 
mind melted.  :)))   I used to think there was a really good techno/dance 
music scene in Europe but the DJs in northern Cali leave no room for 
argument!  This is the BEST scene I have ever experienced.  And the 
locations here simply defy description!

Music preference:  DJ Dan (sorry Galen, you made 2nd) and preferably 
outdoors on _solid_ ground!!

The only other note I can add is that I have a lot of friends visiting me 
now and over the next few weeks from Ireland, and I'll be bringing them to 
as many parties as I can - this has to be seen and experienced to be 
believed!

Peace!

Ivan   :)   <ilamont@visa.com>  <ilamont@msn.com>

nights, whatever. If you're into the scene I want to hear from you.

every other day, not just every other month.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I've always felt that the only chance for the continued survival of
>the human race will be through an evolution that transcends our
>biological origins (yes, there is a paradox here).  Though I usually
>think about this in terms of spirituality or psychology, it  will
>probably have to occur physically as well.  Supplementing our brains
>with chemicals or computer interfaces are a couple of near term
>examples.

As long as we're on the topic of future stuff, I just wanted to bring up
stuff I've read about and thought about for a while.  It's great that all of
us can talk in this fashion over the Internet, but what about the people who
can't?  I mean, usage of the Internet has shot up _exponentially_ since I
started using it two and a half years ago, much faster than anyone would
have expected.  Does this mean society will be divided into the have's and
have-nots, the hooked up ones and the people who are computerless?  It seems
like in the information age this could cause a deadly schizm in society.  I
know that at least one senator (can't remember who) suggested making
terminals publicly available to prevent this from happening... right now a
lot of people view email and web-browsing as a high-class toy, but how many
of us rely on it a lot?  I know that I do.  When my mail server goes down,
it's more detrimental to my work than if the postman got lost.  And in the
next couple of years, it will only be true more so.  Just a thought...

Jake

Received: from peseta.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA01897; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:29:42 -0700
Received: from  by peseta.ucdavis.edu (8.6.12/UCD3.4)
	id LAA26043; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:29:39 -0700
Date: Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:29:39 -0700
Message-Id: <199509131829.LAA26043@peseta.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: ok, my bio
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'll try to be brief: (uh, maybe not)

I'm 25, 5'8", shoulder length brown hair usually pulled back in a pony tail
with a multi colored schrunchy.  I currently have a go tee (I have no idea
how to spell that)  Facial hair is what I mean.  I have hazel eyes.

Let's see, I'm really into sound.  I play various hand drums.  I write
music, some dubby, some techno, some trance, some breakbeat along with live
drumming. I dj ambient, and have been seen spinning at alot of Sacramento
parties.  I made it to several Sunset parties this summer and met a few of
ya's, but I'd like to meet more.  I gotta get one of those laminates.  I was
also at Burning Man, but mostly did my own thing.  I totally love what this
list has represented for me.  My attitude toward raving/PLUR has changed
quite a bit since I joined.  I used to think of raving as a place to party
and do chemical substances, but now I strive to feel VIBE and attain higher
states of consciousness on my own....and boy-o-boy when it works do I feel
good.  I really attribute development of VIBE as a reality for me to this
list and all of you amazing people.  Thank you sooooooo much.

I work for the UC Davis Medical Center in Sacramento and that's the whole
reason any of you have heard from me.  My account is at work.  I'm working
as I write this.  I'm also listening to my Secret Life of Trance cd in my
office right now.

I'm really into my spirituality, which is all wrapped up and interweaved
with my music, dj'ing and drumming and every other aspect of my life.

I have a wonderful girlfriend Phelps, whom I share many of my life
experience with and who loves to rave.  Every once in a while when we are
dancing together we get into this groove and completely let go and bug out
all over the place.  The feeling of being able to let go and be totally in
your own moment, fully connected with the Universe, then to look over and
see someone you love soooo much buggin and boppin and flailing just as much
as you are, is incridble.  I wouldn't trade those moments for anything.

I like plants.

I love you.

Rick



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 11:40:10 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA02934; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:40:10 -0700
Received: from mercury.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA02929; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:39:50 -0700
Received: from taurus. (taurus.sfsu.edu) by mercury.sfsu.edu (5.0/SMI-SVR4)
	id AA09025; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:39:48 -0700
Received: from @taurus.sfsu.edu (taurus.sfsu.edu) by taurus. (5.0/SMI-SVR4)
	id AA17350; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:39:05 -0700
Date: Wed, 13 Sep 1995 11:39:03 -0700
Message-Id: <9509131839.AA17350@taurus.>
X-Sender: jjudd@taurus.sfsu.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.com
From: jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu (Jonas Judd)
Subject: Response from BM founder and director
Content-Length: 6940
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I found this to answer some of the BM "unknowns".

I especially like the part of creating your own intimate environment should
you not care for the masses. Something, I think, we can all relate to.

>Return-Path: <burnman@well.com>
>Date: Tue, 12 Sep 1995 23:12:05 -0700 (PDT)
>From: Larry Harvey - The Burning Man <burnman@well.com>
>Subject: Response from BM founder and director
>To: Burnman-list@well.com
>Content-Length: 6400
>
>Dear Burning Man participants:
>
>A double rainbow, a huge lubricious field of mud, and an atomic cloud... 
>What is Nature trying to tell us?   On behalf of all the organizers I 
>want to thank everyone who came to Burning Man this year.  You heeded our 
>message and you made it a success.  IUve read most of the e-mail and here 
>are some responses:
>
>1) Cops.  We, in fact, invited  the police to our event.  As Struart 
>Mangram (ex-Minister of Propaganda) points out, our numbers on the playa 
>exceed the population of Pershing County where we stage the event.  
>Naturally, the authorities were nervous.  We made them our back-up 
>(thanks to the brilliant plans of Danger Ranger and John Law) in case of 
>any true instance of violent anti-social behavior.  They are trained to 
>deal with violent people, we are not.  In the event, they werenUt needed 
>(which came as no surprise to us) and they were immensely relieved.  They 
>relaxed and had a great time.  Local sheriffs arenUt the agents of 
>oppression.  TheyUre elected officials who represent the local community 
>and this community likes us.  This year all the proceeds from our ice 
>concession went to support the Empire Girls Basketball Team and local 
>merchants and their employees profited mightily (theyUre able, in fact, 
>to engage in the sort of commercial activity that our Project bars from 
>the playa itself).  ItUs an arrangement that benefits everyone.   
>Sheriffs and their deputies develop personal relationships with citizens 
>of the rural counties they serve, and this is precisely what is happening 
>at Burning Man.  Not only may they save you from the odd maniac who might 
>sometime appear, they also protect our Project from less amiable agencies 
>who might merely view us as social renegades.  They do not come here to 
>harass people for practicing alternative lifestyles.  TheyUre our bulwark 
>and friends.  Burning Man is radically  inclusive-- an immediate, 
>infectious, and ultimately revolutionary experience. Having seen us at 
>first hand, the police are being gently enfolded into our community.  At 
>our debriefing on Monday it was even suggested that they establish a 
>Theme Camp.  No other counter-cultural event  that IUm aware of has ever 
>done this.  And this topic brings me to a related theme...
>
>2) The Evil Other.   All of us at sometime have designated certain 
>dangerously general categories of people as evil.  From my point of view, 
>at the center of the Project, I hear tales of this Evil Other.  Ravers 
>are evil, IUm told. Or everything would be OK were it not for Rednecks 
>from Reno.  Gun folks are the agents of oppression  and hippies are 
>deadbeats.  The urge to demonize outsiders, it turns out, is inveterate 
>to human nature, but Burning Man, as I keep saying, is a radically 
>inclusive experience.  It invites you to judge people for what they 
>immediately are .    
>If you knew how comic these proscriptions seem to me-- observing things 
>from my  perspective-- you would laugh.  If youUre looking for the source 
>of evil start at home.  It grows up in the space dividing us from other 
>people.  It grows, moreover, in the dark space that divides us from 
>ourselves.  Evil is real, but the Other, I think, is a decoy.
>
>3)  Numbers will ruin Burning Man..  Numbers arenUt our enemy; mass 
>culture is.  Commerce is not the enemy;  mass consumption is.  We have, 
>collectively, grown so used to feeling like particles in a mass that it 
>is hard to judge things outside of this context.  The key to the problem, 
>I think, lies in the quality of inter-relatedness between people and in 
>their relation to something sensed to be truly greater than themselves.  
>In 1994, particularly on the night of the Burning, I felt we had reached 
>a critical mass.  I called it RThe Year of Dark EnergyS.  Caught within a 
>clotted throng at the foot of the Man, people jostled and yelled.  In the 
>crowded darkness they became anonymous and isolated.  These are the 
>conditions that produce a mob or mass reaction, and this experience 
>produced a plan.  1995 became the Year of the Circle.  We strengthened 
>the Central Camp circle, forming it as a continuous boulevard of Theme 
>Camps, and we turned itUs center into a true nucleus (in 1994 the 
>services we housed there resembled shattered fragments of DNA).  The 
>compass which this circle formed was reinforced by colored banners and 
>marked with symbols at the cardinal points.  It functioned as a very real 
>source of security.  Moreover, the Man was redesigned to be seen in the 
>round.  The great circle which we formed on Sunday night allowed more 
>than twice the number of people, compared with last year, to witness the 
>spectacle together.  Socially, these circles functioned as a primal 
>form.  Society itself may have commenced when our hominid ancestors 
>gathered around fire at night, and it reconvenes nightly, in like 
>fashion, around hundreds of campfires on the playa.  Everyone is witness 
>to the circle of their fellows while united by the mystery at itUs core.  
>This can be done on a large or small scale, but I donUt believe that 
>numbers enter into it.  It is the human form of things which counts.
>
>Furthermore, although our numbers this year have more than doubled, the 
>level of participation has increased at a far greater rate.  Starting 
>from one theme camp two years ago, we have produced more than two dozen 
>in 1995.  There is one problem, however, which I do take seriously.  
>People complain that we have lost the intimacy of the old days, that with 
>increasing numbers they feel lost within the greater scale of things.  My 
>answer is this: rather than pine for that vanished village, remember 
>where you are.  This is Burning Man and youUre empowered.  Imitate the 
>ProjectUs example.  If you want a more intimate setting there is nothing 
>to stop you from creating it.  Band together with your friends and make  
>a neighborhood.  Circle your campsites and convene a public space.  
>Commemorate it, if you wish, with ritual.  This is a creative challenge.  
>It is entirely up to you.
>
>4) Is Burning Man getting smaller?  Yes, he is.  Since 1992 we have been 
>reducing the height of the Man by an average of 5.5 feet every year.  At 
>his current rate of shrinkage we calculate that he will entirely 
>disappear by the year 2002.  Then everyone will have to band together and 
>reinvent him.
>
>Best Regards,  Larry Harvey   
>
>
>


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 11:54:55 1995

	id AA24112 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 13 Sep 95 11:53:43 -0700

	id AA29839; Wed, 13 Sep 95 11:55:02 PDT
Date: Wed, 13 Sep 95 11:55:02 PDT
From: hpcprod@lcc1.nsc.com (Craig Lauxman)
Message-Id: <9509131855.AA29839@lcc1.nsc.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Response from BM founder and director

Precedence: bulk

Thought you all might be interested in what Larry had to say about the
Burning Man 95.  I think theres alot here we can take into our every day
lives. Specially Number 2 about The Evil Other.

The Newt King


>Dear Burning Man participants:
>
>A double rainbow, a huge lubricious field of mud, and an atomic cloud... 
>What is Nature trying to tell us?   On behalf of all the organizers I 
>want to thank everyone who came to Burning Man this year.  You heeded our 
>message and you made it a success.  IUve read most of the e-mail and here 
>are some responses:
>
>1) Cops.  We, in fact, invited  the police to our event.  As Struart 
>Mangram (ex-Minister of Propaganda) points out, our numbers on the playa 
>exceed the population of Pershing County where we stage the event.  
>Naturally, the authorities were nervous.  We made them our back-up 
>(thanks to the brilliant plans of Danger Ranger and John Law) in case of 
>any true instance of violent anti-social behavior.  They are trained to 
>deal with violent people, we are not.  In the event, they werenUt needed 
>(which came as no surprise to us) and they were immensely relieved.  They 
>relaxed and had a great time.  Local sheriffs arenUt the agents of 
>oppression.  TheyUre elected officials who represent the local community 
>and this community likes us.  This year all the proceeds from our ice 
>concession went to support the Empire Girls Basketball Team and local 
>merchants and their employees profited mightily (theyUre able, in fact, 
>to engage in the sort of commercial activity that our Project bars from 
>the playa itself).  ItUs an arrangement that benefits everyone.   
>Sheriffs and their deputies develop personal relationships with citizens 
>of the rural counties they serve, and this is precisely what is happening 
>at Burning Man.  Not only may they save you from the odd maniac who might 
>sometime appear, they also protect our Project from less amiable agencies 
>who might merely view us as social renegades.  They do not come here to 
>harass people for practicing alternative lifestyles.  TheyUre our bulwark 
>and friends.  Burning Man is radically  inclusive-- an immediate, 
>infectious, and ultimately revolutionary experience. Having seen us at 
>first hand, the police are being gently enfolded into our community.  At 
>our debriefing on Monday it was even suggested that they establish a 
>Theme Camp.  No other counter-cultural event  that IUm aware of has ever 
>done this.  And this topic brings me to a related theme...
>
>2) The Evil Other.   All of us at sometime have designated certain 
>dangerously general categories of people as evil.  From my point of view, 
>at the center of the Project, I hear tales of this Evil Other.  Ravers 
>are evil, IUm told. Or everything would be OK were it not for Rednecks 
>from Reno.  Gun folks are the agents of oppression  and hippies are 
>deadbeats.  The urge to demonize outsiders, it turns out, is inveterate 
>to human nature, but Burning Man, as I keep saying, is a radically 
>inclusive experience.  It invites you to judge people for what they 
>immediately are .    
>If you knew how comic these proscriptions seem to me-- observing things 
>from my  perspective-- you would laugh.  If youUre looking for the source 
>of evil start at home.  It grows up in the space dividing us from other 
>people.  It grows, moreover, in the dark space that divides us from 
>ourselves.  Evil is real, but the Other, I think, is a decoy.
>
>3)  Numbers will ruin Burning Man..  Numbers arenUt our enemy; mass 
>culture is.  Commerce is not the enemy;  mass consumption is.  We have, 
>collectively, grown so used to feeling like particles in a mass that it 
>is hard to judge things outside of this context.  The key to the problem, 
>I think, lies in the quality of inter-relatedness between people and in 
>their relation to something sensed to be truly greater than themselves.  
>In 1994, particularly on the night of the Burning, I felt we had reached 
>a critical mass.  I called it RThe Year of Dark EnergyS.  Caught within a 
>clotted throng at the foot of the Man, people jostled and yelled.  In the 
>crowded darkness they became anonymous and isolated.  These are the 
>conditions that produce a mob or mass reaction, and this experience 
>produced a plan.  1995 became the Year of the Circle.  We strengthened 
>the Central Camp circle, forming it as a continuous boulevard of Theme 
>Camps, and we turned itUs center into a true nucleus (in 1994 the 
>services we housed there resembled shattered fragments of DNA).  The 
>compass which this circle formed was reinforced by colored banners and 
>marked with symbols at the cardinal points.  It functioned as a very real 
>source of security.  Moreover, the Man was redesigned to be seen in the 
>round.  The great circle which we formed on Sunday night allowed more 
>than twice the number of people, compared with last year, to witness the 
>spectacle together.  Socially, these circles functioned as a primal 
>form.  Society itself may have commenced when our hominid ancestors 
>gathered around fire at night, and it reconvenes nightly, in like 
>fashion, around hundreds of campfires on the playa.  Everyone is witness 
>to the circle of their fellows while united by the mystery at itUs core.  
>This can be done on a large or small scale, but I donUt believe that 
>numbers enter into it.  It is the human form of things which counts.
>
>Furthermore, although our numbers this year have more than doubled, the 
>level of participation has increased at a far greater rate.  Starting 
>from one theme camp two years ago, we have produced more than two dozen 
>in 1995.  There is one problem, however, which I do take seriously.  
>People complain that we have lost the intimacy of the old days, that with 
>increasing numbers they feel lost within the greater scale of things.  My 
>answer is this: rather than pine for that vanished village, remember 
>where you are.  This is Burning Man and youUre empowered.  Imitate the 
>ProjectUs example.  If you want a more intimate setting there is nothing 
>to stop you from creating it.  Band together with your friends and make  
>a neighborhood.  Circle your campsites and convene a public space.  
>Commemorate it, if you wish, with ritual.  This is a creative challenge.  
>It is entirely up to you.
>
>4) Is Burning Man getting smaller?  Yes, he is.  Since 1992 we have been 
>reducing the height of the Man by an average of 5.5 feet every year.  At 
>his current rate of shrinkage we calculate that he will entirely 
>disappear by the year 2002.  Then everyone will have to band together and 
>reinvent him.
>
>Best Regards,  Larry Harvey

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 12:22:13 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA06536; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 12:22:13 -0700

	by marlowe.wimsey.com with smtp 
	(Smail-3.1.29.1 #7) id m0ssxNh-000TwyC; Wed, 13 Sep 95 12:22 PDT
Message-Id: <v01510102ac7cea7c5ffa@[204.174.30.87]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Wed, 13 Sep 1995 12:22:12 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: eidrah@wimsey.com (Karen)
Subject: Re: bios!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, why not.  After all, I don't get down there very often from rainy ol'
Vancouver (gotta buy a plane!) and so don't get to meet half as many of you
as I'd like ...

I'm a 26 year old Canadian/Scottish lassie, 5'4" or so, long straight red
hair, green eyes, tattooes, body piercings, the whole shebang.  I live by
myself with three cats named Nineveh, Morphia and Drucilla, and a white rat
named Spoosh.

Currently I work as a graphic designer with a small print shop, also I'm
sort of a landlady as I lease the basement of my house out.  I do a lot of
work with the Northwest raves mailing list with photography and doing the
ID laminates.  If any of you Vrave, I'm Pounce!

Musicwise, I tend to be into trance & goa & ambient .... stuff with more
flowing melodies and sensual beats.  I like things that are sparse yet
intricately layered, if you know what I mean ... I write and record my own
music, playing keyboards, bass, flute, some guitar and I sing.  :)  I don't
like exclusively "rave" music though, having great fondness for Pink Floyd,
The Doors, Grateful Dead, disco, The Police, Soundgarden ..... and
Pachelbel!

I'm fascinated with people and language and communication ... I love to
talk to people ... especially I enjoy rounding up a bunch of folks after a
rave who I've never met before, and taking them home for tea and chillage!

Other shit I like includes cooking, massage, paleontology, entomology,
flying kites, doodling cartoons, bike riding, snowball fights, astronomy
...

Hope to meet more of you awesome sfravers next time I'm down your way ...


k

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 13:43:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA13875; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 13:43:18 -0700
Received: from halon.sybase.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA13865; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 13:43:12 -0700
Received: from sybase.com (sybgate.sybase.com) by halon.sybase.com (5.x/SMI-SVR4/SybFW4.0)
	id AA23568; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 13:41:20 -0700
Received: from notesgw2.sybase.com by sybase.com (4.1/SMI-4.1/SybH3.4)
	id AA19194; Wed, 13 Sep 95 13:43:26 PDT

	id AA02893; Wed, 13 Sep 95 13:43:21 PDT

  E7D4D196DB0C2A30882562360065E5C1; Wed, 13 Sep 95 20:43:21 
To: "Matthew D. P. K. Lanier" <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu>

From: Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE
  <Rikki.Kiefer@sybase.com>
Date: 13 Sep 95 13:46:58 EDT
Subject: Re: bios!!!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> > Would it be too much trouble for ya'all to send out a brief hello/bio for 
us new people?

HEllo!

As some of you may already know, my name is Rikki Kiefer, I live in Oakland 
near Rockridge and I'm an Administrator for Lead Generation Marketing @ Sybase, 
Inc.  I'm 28, 5'5", petite, dark red/burgundy hair, flashy green eyes, 
double-pierced nose, big warm grin and heart!

I just recently started working with Sybase and learning all about software and 
computers, and I'm absolutely nuts about it!  I hope to transfer into one of 
the engineering depts. where they'll train me to program and do product 
design.  I'm becoming somewhat of a technofile and am trying to find a way to 
integrate my computer/music/design interests.  

I used to go to raves back in the early 90's, stopped for awhile and just 
started again this summer.  I kicked it off with The Orb, which was great but 
not as good as the '93 show.  Nation was the most impressive rave I'd been to 
in a long time even though it was a bit larger than what I like.  I've been to 
a couple Wicked parties, Stompy Stomp, Tribal Funk, Sunset and Spundae...all 
pretty impressive, but I thought the Wicked parties had the best vibe.  Simply 
love all the music, but especially the hard thumpin' and pumpin'.

Even though it sounds like it's becoming a bit trendy, I too want to learn how 
to DJ more than anything.  

I'm a dancing fiend, but work, the toll massive partying takes on my body, and 
the expense doesn't afford me to go as often as I'd like.  Also, like I said in 
my post, 'Meet Me!', I don't find people that often to go with... so 
people...drag me out more often!!!

Like I said before, "I feel like a lost nomad searching for my tribe"... so I'd 
like to share my take on the rave scene with ya all.  I posted it in, "You 
Gettin' This?"  Love ta hear some ideas on the subject from you alls.  Thanks 
sooo much for Phuture's response...I really appreciate it.

 WHOA!  I *just* felt and earthquake over here in Emeryville...anyone else?  
Yikes!!!  1:38 PM.  9/13

Peace, Love, Friendship, Dance

Rikki


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 14:13:26 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA17025; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 14:13:26 -0700

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: PLATE TECHTONICS: Seth's new tape (BSP)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9509131326.A26460-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Precedence: bulk

Greetings!

I've just finished and begun mass-producing (12 copies so far!) a new mix 
tape which I would like to distribute FREE to any interested sfravers.  

The music is as follows:
     SIDE 1: 142bpm, mostly spacey, reverbed, acidic techno-
	     some of the more well-known labels represented are
	     Warp, Underground Resistance, +8, and TZ
     SIDE 2: 105bpm for the first half, percussive ambient which 
             slides into slamming, crunchy 160+bpm techno for
	     the remainder of the tape.

If this sounds like music you'd like to listen to, email me requesting a 
copy, and I'll send you one if I can, otherwise I'll arrange to meet 
you at a party or maybe somewhere in the Berkeley area if you're close by.

I'm not asking for any money for the tapes, but if you do anything 
creative- djing, making music, computer art, or whatever, I'd love to trade 
you for your tape (or whatever your product may be).  

For those of you who don't know me, here's a short bio:

I'm a student, radio dj, and amateur electronic musician, and have been 
on sfraves for about 3 years (including last year while I was in India and 
Nepal- in which time I racked up over 10MB of messages!).  I've dj'd at a 
couple of sfrave parties and have had a radio show at KALX for the past 
few years as well.  I used to go by the dj name of MESCALINA, but 
now I'm just plain old Seth again.

See you all sometime soon...
///////{{{{{{{[[[[[[[((((((((((acid232dica))))))))))]]]]]]]}}}}}}}\\\\\\\

Subject: NB Lunch report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi folks,

Well, Veronika and I went to South Park for the SFR lunch. There were lots
of folks there, but it was impossible to tell who was from SFR. We bought
our burritos and started walking around cluelessly. I turned to Veronika
and said, "I don't really feel like asking everyone in the park if they're
here for the rave lunch, let's just find a nice spot and eat." The guy
walking next us turns around and asks, "Did you say rave?" "Yes," I said.
"Im looking for the SFR crew as well but I don't know what they look like
either," he said.

The 3 of us sat down together and had a really nice time. Our new friend's
name is Martin. Turns out we have lots in common, especially a strong
interest in snowboarding (any other boarders out there?). We had all been
to BMan, and we discussed that for a while.

I imagine there were other SFRavers there as well. I guess "laminates at
lunch" might not be a bad idea...  =o)

ek

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 13 21:50:29 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA11588; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 21:50:29 -0700

Received: from netcom.netcom.com (flux@netcom.netcom.com [192.100.81.100]) by sierra.zyzzyva.com (8.6.12/8.6.11) with ESMTP id XAA15890 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 23:40:18 -0500
Received: by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id VAA01922; Wed, 13 Sep 1995 21:35:56 -0700
Date: Wed, 13 Sep 1995 21:35:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jonathan Wells <flux@netcom.com>
Reply-To: Jonathan Wells <flux@netcom.com>
Subject: My Bio
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9509132120.A18784-0100000@netcom>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm a 25 year-old Gemini. According to my driver's license, I'm 5'11", 
though I haven't checked recently. You can see my mug at: 
http://www.lowres.com/lowres/huh.html 
(you can also see the faces of SFRavers Bart Cheever and Cindy Kawakami here)

I'm an associate producer at an interactive movie/videogame company 
Digital Pictures in San Mateo. Look at: www.digikids.com to see the kids 
product, Kids on Site, I worked on last year. In my free time, I produce 
a music tv program and am co-producing a film + video festival 
(http://www.lowres.com/lowres/).

I live in a SOMA apartment with two roommates Scott Pease, fellow SFRaver 
- Bart Cheever, and Bart's cat, Trouble. You can see pictures and 
descriptions of Trouble and our apartment at: 
http://teleparc.infoweb.or.jp/en/junc/hitch/dry00724.htm
This (http://teleparc.infoweb.or.jp/en/junc/hitch/index.htm) is a site 
documenting the trip to California by two very wired Japanese guys. You 
will finds pictures and text about AREA 51 (the rave we took them to), 
Hyperreal, and many other Bay Area cyber spots.

I first got interested in dance music in the late-80's attending 
underground clubs and illegal warehouse parties in high school (Mountain 
View) in the Bay Area. Upon moving to San Diego to attend college, I got 
involved in the growing club and rave scene. At it's height I wrote and 
edited the San Diego underground club column for URB Magazine (my year 
end report for '92 - the year it blew up! was 3 full pages long), ran 
the Statik Line - a free underground club and rave hotline, and produce 
several events most notably the Orb record release party in San Diego and 
in SF at the Planetarium. 

While in San Diego, I created the country's first underground dance music 
video show, Flux, showcasing ambient, acid-jazz, house and techno music 
videos as well as interviews and footage of raves.

When I can get away I like to hike on Mt. Tam and in the Muir Woods, watch 
Indie and Foreign films and read Int'l magazines. My favorite rave of all 
time is the first Narnia in San Diego, though I liked the FMR at BD Oct '93 
VERY much. Mark E. Quark is the DJ that will consistently get my feet moving 
on the dance floor. I use a Macintosh.

I hope to meet many of you on Saturday at Bonny Dune.

	If anyone wants to carpool to F8 from the Marin area I'm the
	woman to call as I have room in the auto...

	I've been thinking about all the cool things ravers are lately
	(fun, loving, friendly, thoughtful, great taste in music...)
	and I was wondering if we've got many environmentalists, 
	especially VEGANS. I came to the decision to go "all the way"
	vegan as a result of a particularly educational night of 
	raving myself... Anyway, veganism is good for the soul but we
	need the support of each other so if youre out there let me

Since most of you are on the topic:


Name:  Andrew Paul Dressler
Birthdate: September 16 1972
Hieght: 5' 7 3/4"
Weight: 155
Hair: Brown
Eyes: Brown

I've lived in Sacramento all my life. I come from a big family.
(enough history now for the good stuff)

I'm a self employed sound engineer. I specialize in permanent club
installs but mostly I do live engineering, BIG MOBILE CLUB SYSTEMS, and
recording. Most of you who know me know me from doing sound at raves.
I also work part-time at K&K music here in sac selling equipment.

BSP mode: Yes I give discounts to SF-Ravers
end mode

I attended ARC here in sac and also CSUS

Likes:

Big smiles, big hugs, people who don't NEED drugs to have fun(note the
word NEED), honesty and straight fowardness, big fuzzy stuffed animals,
big kisses, monty python and the holy grail, pasta, food, eats, cooking,
beautiful female voices, self confidence, and most of all, friends!

Dis-likes:

Frowns, lame hugs, people who can only FEEL IT when high on drugs,
judgements, fish, alcohol,  Ishtar, smokers, and most of all
RUSH LIMBAUGH!(hehehehehehehehehehehehe)

Although I have been doing sound for raves for almost two years, the
first time I went to one to have fun (and do E) was about a year ago at
Wicked. I attend them regularly and in all actuality you will find me
sober most of the time.(E causes me to have really bad sinus infections)


Best talents:

Not being able to sing(hehehe), E journeys(if your high ask me for one),
hugging(first place in the all nationals tourney last may in SF)(hehe),
roller blading, messing around on computers.
ALWAYS BEING IN A GOOD OPTAMISTIC MOOD!

Love you all,

Soundgod@iccse.com

PS: I'm a serious workaholic. I never have any free time!

I'm assuming I'll see a bunch of you at Laura & Brian's gig on Saturday...

As for a bio for those that don't know me, here's a bit.  About a year
ago, I moved to Hollywood to work for Jim Cameron at Digital Domain.  
Before that, I grew up in Detroit, and have a lot of deep feelings for
that wretched hole.  I have worked with several record labels there,
getting them connected on the Internet and progressing them into the
modern technology of animation and visual effects.  I still am in
close contact with many people there, and am always preaching the
gospel of Detroit to the unwashed masses here in the West ;-)

Personal stats, I am an Irish male, 6', 280#, blue eyes, reddish
hair cut in a spikey flattop.  I have worked as a bartender, a bouncer,
a purchasing agent, an MIS developer, and currently as a Digital Effects
Coordinator (a lot like an air traffic controller, but with special effects).

-- 
fix.er \'fik-s*r\ n : one that fixes : as : one that intervenes to enable a
   person to circumvent the law or obtain a political favor : one that adjusts
   matters or disputes by negotiation

All,
Seeing that this weekend is going to be the SFR Massive Gatering  heres my
post:

For the many who don't personally know me Im gonna jump aboard this bandwith
for a bit and give introduction....

Hi!

Im Adam.  Adam is 5'6" 145lbs. Hispanic.  He is a Front End Manager @
CompUSA. He has been in the scene since 90. I can't even remmeber the first
rave I went to. Although I've been going on strong since then (at least once
a weekend).  I guess the main draw to undergrounds for me was my brother.  He
used to DJ under the guise of Luie Lou and I usually got free 'ins' at these
events... My bro left the scene in 92 or 93 (as the Hype died) and I ususally
DJ'ed @ small parties (X parties as we called em') under the name of Nextacy.
 I generally don't DJ anymore since I don't have 1200's (but I do have the
records still).  For me this is a way of life, I can no longer imagine my
exstance w/o raving...
Favorite cuts are jungle, hardcore and impossibly fast BPMs as well as the
old 909 beats. 
Dancing is my favorite hobby. I grew up around breakdancing and been
intergrating the breakdancing, tribal stompings, and ravedancing styles in to
my own madness =).
I can usually be caught buzzing around a speaker or dancing in front of the
turntables/ dj area for hours on end...

Non-raving hobbies include Martial Arts, reading, chatting in general,
japanese animation and appreciating other music / visual arts.

Fav saying: When we die we turn into frequencies.  Music is everything....

Peace, happiness and wait for 1/2hr after eating until you go into that
pool...

Adam

C-ya'll @ Cybertrance.....

From: ecto@citenet.net (ecto)
Subject: ecto bio
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Well i'll make this short as i know from going to Art School that
the thing that artists do best is talk, especially about themselves ;)
        My real name's brad finlay and, right now, i don't live anywhere
near San Fran. I'm in Montreal but i must be somewhat of a masochist to
inflict all of your beautiful postings on myself and not allow myself the
chance to meet you all :) OH well, i just got a job doing HTML programming
(for an online shopping catalogue :P) so i'm planning on a short vacation
(which would hopefully turn into a move at some point) to San Fran for the
early winter :)
        You don't want to know what montreal winters are like :P *brrr*
        I think i'm on this list out of curiosity about San Fran, and the
area being that i am planning a move soon, and also that, to be completely
honest, teh people who post on here and the topics covered blow me away.
It makes it all worth it for me to slog through BSPs for things i can't
attend and reviews that i've never been to :( just to read the intelligent,
mature, 'spiritual' (wish there was a more apt phrase) and open minded
writings of ppl on here. You all are really something, is there something
in the water there? ;)
        So, i graduated from Concordia U in MOntreal w/a Baccalaureate in
Fine Arts, i do graphic design/HTML programming to get by, iv'e got a web
site w/some of my flyers (including some of the progress ones from San
Fran) and the web site is completely self-indulgent so i'll leave it at
that. :) I love dancing, in fact i'm thinking it's a biological necessity
to get your energy flowing again and prevent getting yourself all backed
up...energy constipation ;) Thing that moves me the most: super hard
chicago acidy house a la Robert Armani, Mike Dearborn, Relief Records,
stuff like that. I also love Autechre, Aphex Twin, Global COmmunications,
The Higher intelligence agency and other 'intelligent' stuff..along with
Muchos Ambientos like Pete Namlook, SpaceTime Continuum, stuff like
that....
        I guess that's about it :)
                peace to all...
                                brad

I hope I don't make this post twice, I have been having serious problems 
with my mail server....

My name is Dana.  

Perasonal Info:21 years old, 5'7", weigh 125lbs., have short black hair, 
brown eyes, freckles on my nose and a few tats.....I work for a local 
telecommunications company.

I live in Baton Rouge, Louisiana..The reason I subscribe to SFRavers is 
because I am planning a trip and SF is the place I want to be...I would 
eventually like to live there, but I am going to take my vacation there 
first to check it out(I have never been before!)

I went to my first rave about 2 years ago and knew that it was for me!  
That was one of the best nights of my life...The problem is that there 
aren't many ravers in this part of the country and it takes us a while to 
raise the funds to have a memorable rave....Even so, I don't think our 
raves come close to ya'lls.  The raves you describe seem magical, almost 
impossible.  I am moved by every post I read.

Aside from working and raves(the few we have), I love eating good food, 
reading inspirational works, and being around good people...

I hope I can make plans with some of you during my trip, maybe you can 
give me the reasons I need to stay!!


peace and love

Dana
danak@advtel.net
