   well my life is far less advanced than most of yours, since I am probably
the youngest person on sfraves.  
         Um...  my name is Matt Brooker. I was born in San Diego, in 1977,
making me 18 years of age!!!!  I moved six times to get here to sacramento.
 finished high school in june, and am going to college in seattle, UW.  

      I have been involved with music my whole life, I have played the
Bassoon for 10 years, and music has always been my life.  I dicovered house
music through a friend many years ago, and have been raving off and on for
three years.  my first rave was a casper rave in 92.  I didn't really start
raving full time until a year ago.  
                     In my spare time(while not raving) I enjoy people,
books, music,and people.  I am really interested in people, the way they act,
the way they interact, etc.  I plan on majoring in psychology, and going to
med school to become a psychiatrist, and use that to do research.  And if
that dosn't work out I am also into the production of music, and may end up
doing something in the music field.  

   so now that I have either completly bored you, or stimulated you, I am
leaving for school on sunday, and will have the same address in seattle if
any of you feel like writing. I havnt decided whether or not to keep sfraves,
but if so, then you will all be blessed by my presence in the future. 
                My bro lives in sf and raves, so I am sure I will be down
raving in the future with my laminate.  

love you all,

matt

hmmm...let's see.  i grew up in milwaukee, WI where i graduated from high 
school this past june.  in july i moved to SF to work for my bro's 
company cyborganic bu mostly i just worked on my own site for my zine.  i 
do a zine called anonymous and it is online and all.  i call it the sassy 
of rave zines cuz it is a rave zine done by and for girls and stuff:)  i 
was pretty active in the midwest scene when i lived there...i have kinda 
cut back since i have moved to SF but i have been to some seriously 
groovy parties since i have been here.  so now i go to mills college in 
oakland and most of the time i am stuck here cuz i have no car so feel 
free to offer me rides places!:)  i like it at mills.  all the girls are 
really cool ( it is a women's college if ya didn't know) it is kinda too 
PC for me but its all good.  the highlights of my summer were a party in 
july in dayton,OH called fantastic voyage (i got to see all my mw-raver 
friends for the last time for a long time and it was an awesome party) 
and burning mnan which i am sure everyone is sick of hearing about:) i am 
18, really short, big smile, brown hair and stuff.  i gotta go to class 
now so thats all:)  hope to see you all soon if i ever get off this 
campus!  just kidding...i will be at TND tonight;)

have fun

ellen

I guess I'll jump in the fray -

Joe Rice, born 7/25/72 in Salem, Oregon - I'm 6'5, 210#, brown hair,
glasses sometimes. Started raving April 1992 at Circa '92 when I lived in
LA. Got sucked into it and haven't outgrown it yet. =) Started DJing about
a year later so I could play Chime and Papua New Guinea back and forth as
much as I wanted. =)

Threw a few parties in LA, which made me lose respect in promoters in
general, but then started working with the Justice League in Santa Barbara
and I regained that respect. *Contrary to popular belief I never lived in
Santa Barbara, however*

I moved up to SF in 9/94 and have enjoyed meeting numerous SFravers at the
wide variety of events up here. My life has also been greatly enhanced by
getting to work with the F&F crew.

Music wise, I like dubby ambient and Detroit style techno/deep techno with
forays into techno bass/electro and funky acid house stuff. With the
occasional gabber polka, of course. =)

Favorite DJ's: Tony, Monty, Markem, Mark E. Quark.

Joe

(:"I know! He puts them on and off and you never know! I've never seen      :)
(: anything like it!"                                                       :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 12:15:37 1995

From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: bios...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Continuing on the bio theme...

My name is John Darrow, I'm 23 years old, 6'2" and pretty lean.
I don't post too often, but I have been around sfraves for about
3 years, so most likely most of you have seen me somewhere, in 
the background, smiling.  I got my first exposure to acid house
in 1988, listening to Steve Masters play his 1 hour show of "trippin
tuesdays acid house" in the middle of the night on Live 105.  I
bought lots and lots of records and took them back to Mount Shasta
where I went to high school, where I danced maniacly in my own
lonely understanding of what was to come.  I have danced in and out
of madness ever since, finishing a degree in physics while I struggle
between universal coherrent order and ego.  My main interests lie
in sound and acoustics.  My thesis is on active noise control.  Right
now I'm making web pages for a living... (see the new www.ucsc.edu for
an example, rather administrative and dull) and I live in Santa Cruz
where I very much enjoy life.  I'm a very spiritual person and beleive
very strongly in my meaning and the spirit of the rave.  I try to
express this meaning in my music, dancing, and understanding.
(Like many of you I have a large stack of electronic boxes and
wires which tend to overheat and distort themselves into chaotic noise.)

I beleive in morphic resonance, and the importance of coincidence.
hence my advice, you must be very very patient, meaning will
come to find itself.  The anthropic principle on all levels.

and if you aren't quite sure what those theories are, they just mean
you gotta be yourself to make the world fall into place.

You can see pictures and more at
http://www.ucsc.edu/mb/people/Spring.95/john.darrow

I love you all.

be seeing you,
-john.

hey matt-
you have stimulated me, not bored me!!!  it's never boring to hear from a
fellow psych major. i'm a psych major at the univerity of san francisco.  i
love analyzing people, which drives them crazy, but hey, they'll live (he he
he!)
keep on sfraves.  i like anyone with my same name!

love, peace, and psychoanalysis

matt

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 12:52:39 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA14574; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:52:39 -0700
Received: from eat.organic.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA14566; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:52:36 -0700
Received: from eat.organic.com (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by eat.organic.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with ESMTP id MAA12947 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:54:05 -0700
Message-Id: <199509141954.MAA12947@eat.organic.com>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bio...
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>

Precedence: bulk


I wasn't going to post one of these things because I'm so used to 
lurking on this list. But now that I'm actually meeting some of you I 
figure it would only be fair to let you know who I am. First of all, 
check out:

http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/

There's more information on me there than most anybody wants to see.

Yes, I work at Organic Online with Cindy Kawakami, Brian Behlendorf, 
and Rocky Mullin (one third of Weird Blinking Lights), as well as a 
plethora of other cool people. I've lived in the Bay Area for less than 
a month but I've been lurking on SFRaves for two years now, and have 
known Brian (via the net) for a decent period of time.

I'm 6'2", have brown, long hair, have multiply pierced ears and a 
piercing in each nostril. I tend to shy away from pictures because I 
don't think of myself as being very photogenic, so that description 
will have to do until y'all get a chance to meet me. I have a fashion 
sense but I'm too cheap to actually go out and spend money on clothes, 
so I often look a bit threadbare.

I'm a software engineer here at Organic, which entails doing database 
programming and Java development. I enjoy my job lots (not too 
surprising, considering that it's the reason that I moved to San 
Francisco) but I think I spend a bit too much time at the office, like 
just about everyone here. 12-14 days are not uncommon here.

I'm also a DJ, although I haven't done any spinning out in the Bay Area 
yet. I'm actively looking for gigs and I have no problem with sending 
out demos to people, so if anyone could link me up, that would be 
great. I spin a fairly wide variety of styles, all of which fall under 
the overall heading of "techno". I like Detroit techno soul lots and I 
really dig cold, experimental techno a la Leo Anibaldi and Locust. 
Everything else falls into a matrix somewhere in between. I love 
trading tapes with people, and I also just enjoy giving away my tapes. 
Music and DJing are things that are made for sharing. If you want to 
hear what it is that I'm into drop me a line and we'll work something 
out.

I'm also a staff member at Hyperreal, but I've been under the gun at 
work recently (I feel guilty even taking the time to write this) so 
I've been neglecting my duties there somewhat. I'm working on a system 
that will completely revamp how people get at the musical information 
on Hyperreal, and will hopefully make the music archives much easier to 
use.

I have always admired San Francisco's rave scene and it is with some 
frustration I say that I haven't managed to go to a rave here yet 
(unless you count Burning Man). I played a role in starting Missoula, 
Montana's rave scene, and I tried very hard to pattern my organization 
(the Rebel Alliance -- watch for its emergence in San Francisco ;) 
after groups like Friends & Family and the Cloud Factory. Missoula now 
has an extremely healthy and vibe-oriented scene, so I guess it worked. 
:) Whether or not that has anything to do with my magnetic personality 
I don't know.

That's enough about me for now. I look forward to meeting those of you 
that I haven't yet. It's good to be here, and San Francisco is 
seriously rewriting my brain!

yrz,
ozymandias

ozymandias G desiderata    ogd@organic.com    Tomorrow's Web Sites Today
(415)284-6888          http://www.organic.com             Organic Online


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 12:58:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA14852; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:58:18 -0700
Received: from netcom18.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA14840; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:58:14 -0700
Received: by netcom18.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id MAA09168; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:55:06 -0700
Date: Thu, 14 Sep 1995 12:55:06 -0700
From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)
Message-Id: <199509141955.MAA09168@netcom18.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Hi, my name is Chris Beaumont, and I've been interested in raving and
computers for quite some time now.. I first became interested in the rave
scene around 1988 when my friend Tim Otis turned me on to some "acid
house" records he had gotten.. Although I'm straight, back then, the only
places in SF to go and hear acid were gay clubs like Gus Bean's many
efforts.. So, Tim and I started a club at the I Beam, "The Acid House"
that I think was the first venue in SF to play exclusively acid house
music. I did visual effects, liquid oil projections, and Tim was the main
DJ. Later on I worked at lots of other seminal SF rave venues including
Recess (the first "rave like" BIG club in SF) and Club X doing visual
effects.. Around 1990 I was approached by Dave Dean and Jim English and
asked to help with their new club Vivid. This was a big success, and later
on it metamorphosized to something called "Club Love". 
I did liquid oil and slide projections, and was in charge of the
space in the basement, which we named the "Ambient Lounge". This space 
was the seminal Ambient space in SF at the time, and many parties were
planned there.. (and in Tornado's incredible VIP lounge upstairs) 
Among these parties was a party called Toon Town. Dianna Jacobs, and 
Preston Lyttle were regulars in the club scene, (Dianna had been working
off and on as a Peachy Puff for quite a while) and they approached me
and asked me to help with a new club they were planning, which would
be, basically, an "electronic playground". I agreed to help, and initially
we planned to have the first event in the basement of Big Heart City.
Although the venue was small, it was a big success, and the stage was set 
for more ToonTown rave
parties. Plans were made for a second party, but unfortunately, we werent
able to have the second party at Big Heart City, since the manager of
Big Heart City, Jim English (now part-owner of Smart Products) disagreed
with a key part of our plans.. We wanted to have a non-alcoholic "smart" bar
selling energizing amino-acid drinks there, as an alternative to alcohol,
but Jim English felt that this would be illegal, and wouldn't let us do it.
(Later on, Toon Town was such a big success that it essentially killed 
Club Love, and then Jim English embraced the smartbar idea.. :)  )

So , we decided to have our first big party at a warehouse, and the stage
for the first big Toon Town was set..  This second party was a huge success,
and the stage for the SF rave scene was set.. Toon Town went on for
over two years.I continued doing visual effects until we had a permanent
venue for Toon Town, and then I was able to realize my plan to set up
a smartbar there.. I did Nutrient Cafe for about three years, until
quite recently, when I decided that, for the sake of stability in my 
life.. to get a real job..

Around the time that Toon Town was breaking up.. (there were a lot of 
personal problems between members of the team, and all of the original 
people, including myself, quit..) SFraves came on to the scene..
The Sfraves crew has performed a valuable function in improving the access
to technology that enjoyed by members of the rave scene...

Sfraves has done really well, and now is integrated with the rave scene..
(Initially, we were not very well known to the local rave community..)
It has served as a bridge in connecting a huge number of people together..
almost like a big family..It is probably the single biggest reason that 
the Internet has become a part of the rave scene..
 My only regret these 
days is that I don't have as much time as I used to to go to SFraves events..



Big hugs to everyone on what must be about SFraves 5th anniversary!
And congratulations to Brian and Laura! May you have many other happy 
anniversaries!

-Chris Beaumont
chris@ncafe.com

Hi everybody!  I'm really enjoying reading all of the bios - makes me

Well, I'm a 28-year old female recently hired by my internet access

German, I have kinda 
long curly brown hair, hazel eyes and skinny :-)  I'm a singer/songwriter 
and I've been into the Dead for a long time enjoying the scene and the 
music then I went to my first rave this summer and was just blown away by 
the vibe and now I'm hooked, not just on raves but the whole vibe and 
philosophies that I feel from the people I've met and the people on these 
lists.  I'm into Terrence McKenna and just got turned on to Alexander 
Shulgin, I'm in the middle of a really cool article on Shulgin in "The

From: stranger@speakeasy.org (Tigger)
Subject: Bios
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi all,

My name is Glenn and I'm also known as Tigger (a childhood nickname).
I stand at about 5'8", 160lbs, dark brown hair and eyes.

I moved to Seattle in '88 and didn't really start attending Seattle raves
until '92.  The old school rave scene here was controlled mostly by folks
who were more interested in the glam, sex, drug aspects of parties and it
showed.  I joined sfraves in '92 and saw there there was a lot more to
raves and realized at that point that any individual had the power to
impact their environment/scene in a positive way.

In '93 a group of nwravers from Seattle and Vancouver organized the first
FMR in the Northwest. It was done fully in the spirit of what we've learned
from sfraves and it was a great success.  You folks in SF have been and
continue to be an inspiration to us up here in the Northwest.  Thanks you!

In the past couple of years, I've been involved with organizing parties
here including the Choc-Lit Factory, Earthspace, Evolution, NW FMR's and
another group of free outdoor parties called FreeVibes.

More recently, I've been focusing on doing visuals and working with the
Seattle branch of the Ambient Temple of I Magi Nation with dj's Michael
Manahan and Dervish (whom you might have seen spin at a Sunset party two
weeks ago).  We're currently working on an ambient dub, trip hop
compilation which should be out early next year.

I'm a graphic artist/designer by trade and currently work as the MIS
manager for a Seattle local paper called the Stranger.  And yes, I've done
a few flyers for parties here in Seattle.

I like most dance/rave oriented music.  Current favorites are Eat Static,
Banco de Gaia, Goldie and Springheel Jack (I really like ambient jungle!).
I'm really into ambient dub, trip hop also.

I guess that's about it.  Please let me know if any of sfravers plan on
visiting Seattle any time.  I would be more than happy to show you around
and to introduce you to our family up here.

Peace y'all!

Tigger

From: "Aaron_Edsinger" <AEDSINGE@us.oracle.com>

well, i guess i might as well throw my hat in the ring too.   
	 
	i'm 23, 5'10, brown and blue hair, Mex-Am,  graduated from Stanford in 
Computer Systems,and live SOMA in SF in a cozy warehouse. i've been on sfr 
since day 1, whenever that was, i can't remember anymore. some of you may 
remember me from then, when i wasn't the lurker i am now, as 
rave@leland.stanford.edu. 
	 i started doing the club scene in Seattle in 87 and can remember the 
first time i heard about raves. it was in some brittish music mag special on 
the acid-house scene there (called 88: Summer of Love, i think). as soon as i 
read that artical that i knew ihad to find a rave, which was a much harder 
thing then.  
	i finally found my first rave in the summer of 91 in some small 
warehouse in LA, but it wasn't till the following fall when i discovered 
ToonTowns that i really *understood* what they could be. Woopie Ball of that 
year was definitely one of my most memorable and shaping experiences. since 
then i would include numerous FMR's, Boogie Buffets, and Burning Man. 
	for the first year of raving i lived and breathed raves, and even went 
so far to start a now defunct rave clothing/necklace Co. back when the only 
things around were Fresh Jive and DoNotEat.  
	after too many nights and days spent in dark clubs, i have to admit i 
grew cynical about the scene. now-a-days, i prefer to save myself for small 
house parties or the occaisional *special* event that you know will go off. 
i've learned to balance my raving time with things such as snowboarding, art, 
etc, etc. Currently my roomate and I are working on a series of large 
silkscreens to wheat-paste around town on billboards,etc, so if you see a 
strange image looming over the freeway, it could be us... 
 
<<peace and respect to all>> 
------->aaron  
 
aedsinge@us.oracle.com 
<<GOD,INC>>

Precedence: bulk


   I've been getting out a lot more, so now I can really comment on
   what's going on...

   Come-Unity - still amazes me to see so many people getting down on a
   Wednesday. So crowded it's hard to stay in one place and groove, though.
   Stompy - Chicago meets SF. The DJ after Dani spun really smooth and
   soulful stuff, a great consistent groove.
   Sunset - goin' strong in Berkeley last Sunday. It really does have a
   special vibe.
   the Gardening Club - nice transition into the week. good veggie food too.
   Simply Done - big sound and a big room. probably too large for the
   crowd last night, but lots of room to move yer thang.
   
   Finally, congratulations are in order to SFR's Laura and list-founder
   Brian, as they prepare for a little matrimonial event this weekend.
   The pre-party is Saturday afternoon at Bonny Doon. Come on down to
   celebrate!

                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, September 15th - Stereophonic
   House Music - the champion sound. Feel it. Share it. Live it. One
   Sound. One Mind. All Massive. It Starts with You. DJs Mystic Bill, Jon
   Williams, DRC, John Howard, Samuel. Ambient Sounds w/DJs Darkhorse &

   415.541.5004

   Jeno & Tracy. Aqua Ambience with Ameba Hi-Fi gurus Mark, Allen &
   Andrew. Tix $20 presale only, at Ameba on Haight. 415.406.2118

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

--- Forwarded mail from C Tiberius Hull  <nozefngr@apple.com>

From: C Tiberius Hull  <nozefngr@apple.com>
Subject: Burning Man After-Party!
Date: Thu, 14 Sep 95 14:04:34 PDT

---------------------------------------------------------------
                   Mark Your Calendars!!
                          for the
                Burning Man 1995 After-Party

             Friday, 22 September 1995 @ 0830 PM
      Apple Computer R&D Bldg. 4, the Town Hall Theatre
               4 Infinite Loop, Cupertino CA.
---------------------------------------------------------------

Elise and I have quit our jobs and are working nights,
weekends, and holidays to bring you the finest in home video
entertainment from Nevada's beautiful Black Rock desert.  We
are furiously editing stills and videos taken from CyberLab7,
WBL, Team Fun, SPAZ, various web pages, and of course my camcorder.

Whitens the amazing Shark Car as it pulls donuts on the
playa.  See couch surfers, and idiots (like me) parasail over
a hard, unforgiving desert floor (splat!)  RAVE RAVE RAVE
till dawn in the rain!  Witness the mindless destruction of
various computing devices which would have been valued at
millions of dollars only a couple of decades ago.  And
finally, see the burning of a beautiful 40 story? (well,
that's what it said on the web page) effigy of wood and neon.

Additionally, Weird Blinking Lights will perform
electronic/ambient/drone music utilizing vintage analogue
synthesizers as well as state of the art QuickTime music
sequencing software.

Seating? Don't worry there's plenty!:
  The Town Hall Theatre is a facility capable of conformably
  seating 298 primates.  It is the largest conference room at
  Apple.

Food and Drink:
  Oh La La, our on-site caffeine merchant is used to feeding
  hordes of hungry hackers and artists round the clock.  They
  will be on hand for this event.  I have also managed to
  procure a popcorn machine for those who are so inclined.

Directions.Local:
  Apple Computer is located on Saratoga - Sunnyvale Rd at 280
  and is quite visible from the freeway.  There are off ramps
  from both directions leading onto Saratoga.  Head toward the
  large building with green windows to the South-East of the
  point where the freeway and Saratoga intersect.  The entryway
  off of Saratoga will take you to the main entrance, R&D1.
  The theatre is in R&D4 around the back side of campus.  Once
  you have pulled into the main drive, turn left just in front
  of the main entrance.  Go around until you see an entrance
  with the number 4 in front of it.  There will be far too much
  parking so please bring an extra car or two. ;-)  The theatre
  is immediately to the right of the R&D4 entrance.

Directions.San Francisco:
  if (you take 280)
      See Directions.Local:
  else
      See Directions.East Bay:
  endif

Directions.East Bay:
  If you are coming across the Bay Bridge, simply drive down
  101 until you reach 85.  Take 85 to 280.  The first off ramp
  is Saratoga - Sunnyvale Rd.  See Directions.Local:
  If you intercept 101 from a point East of 85, take the
  Mathilda off ramp South and keep driving past El Camino till
  you reach 280.  Apple will be across the freeway and to your
  left.  See Directions.Local:

Directions.Los Angeles:
  Assuming you people don't fly (Reno Air would be best) , you can
  always drive like idiots up *the 5!  Take Diane's Lexus, she
  won't mind.:-)  I have recently discovered that speeds in excess
  of 110mph can be sustained without attracting the attention
  of law enforcement if done after dark (Maxima, the ultimate
  flying machine!).
  But seriously, please RSVP as I am providing crash space for
  the LA contingent.  Bring sleeping bags and such.  The house
  is quite empty and I have plenty of floor space as I have not
  yet purchased furniture.
  ( * You will be pegged as an Angelino if you say things like
  "*the* 5", or refer to 101 as "the Ventura freeway").

Volunteers, Apple Employees:
  I will need an Apple employee to man the main entry.
  Security will not allow us to prop this door open.  Please do
  not allow people beyond the R&D4 inner airlock as the immune
  systems of our friends are not accustom to the strange
  atmosphere within Main Campus.

Warning(s), PLEASE READ:
  Please clean up after yourselves.  It took weeks to clean up
  after that Jittlov thing last winter and I will not have a
  repeat of that.  We must leave the theatre as it was and I am
  not your mother!

  The theatre is *supposed to be* isolated from the rest of
  campus.  But if you *do* find a way, please don't go beyond
  the inner doors of the R&D4 building.  I have been warned on
  three separate occasions that if *any* non-Apple being is
  found lurking anywhere on the rest of campus unescorted I
  will never be allowed to hold an event like this again, so
  please...!

Communication:
  Please title all replies regarding this event with
  RSVP BMan: (foo)
  and send to nozefngr@apple.com
  Now watch, I'll get a whole bunch of "RSVP BMan: (foo)".

  RSVPs would be nice.  Oh La La would like to know how much
  caffeine and goodies to crank out.  They would like to know
  by about the middle of next week.

  If you need to contact me by phone:
  1 800 680 7351 (pager) or
  1 408 862 2931 (Apple voicemail, this will activate pager)

This will be an extremely fun event.  We who participated in
Burning Man will have a wonderful opportunity to share our
experience with our friends.

See y'all at the movies!!

-Chris

..........................................................
[n o z e]  imagination is more important than knowledge...
[f n g r]  Tomorrow's leaders are busy Tonight!

romantics
  move
mountains

Grew up in NY/LI/NJ areas.  Age 38.  Degree in Physics. 
Family: Wife Janie, brother Peter - both "ravers". Parents retired in
Las Vegas - both nonravers. 
Corporate job (working to bring you PacBell's version of the infosuperhwy).
Hobbies:
Writing - finishing a novel, philosophy manuscript, netstuff.
Web Site administrator for Spirit of Raving archives and Council on 
Spiritual Practices (CSP) on hyperreal.
Electronic musician - look for my cut on the upcoming IDM mailing list
"Threads" CD, and soundtracks for a variety of porno movies in the 80's.

I've been raving since the spring of '92, and am mainly into the
oneness-through-music aspect of the experience.  Raving for me is
the closest thing to a spiritual ritual that I have ever participated in.
It has also provide me with some of the most hedonistic fun that I have
ever had. :)

I've tried my hand in organizing parties with two successful sfraves-
sponsered events in GG Park a couple of years ago (Connection Earth, In 
The Light), and learned that it was not such a good role for a control freak
such as myself.  Still, it's an amazing feeling to be able to create an 
environment where people can transcend their differences and connect with 
each other and nature through music and dance.

Nowadays my time and energy is a bit stretched between a variety of
interests so I don't rave quite as much as I used to.  Janie and I are 
pretty much loners, but we are always happy to meet people with interesting
outlooks on life, the Universe, and everything.

Lee
______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

>Directions.Local:
>  Apple Computer is located on Saratoga - Sunnyvale Rd at 280
>  and is quite visible from the freeway.  There are off ramps
>  from both directions leading onto Saratoga.  Head toward the
>  large building with green windows to the South-East of the
>  point where the freeway and Saratoga intersect.  The entryway
>  off of Saratoga will take you to the main entrance, R&D1.
>  The theatre is in R&D4 around the back side of campus.  Once
>  you have pulled into the main drive, turn left just in front
>  of the main entrance.  Go around until you see an entrance
>  with the number 4 in front of it.  There will be far too much
>  parking so please bring an extra car or two. ;-)  The theatre
>  is immediately to the right of the R&D4 entrance.

>  Mathilda off ramp South and keep driving past El Camino till

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 16:40:06 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA29582; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 16:40:06 -0700

From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>
Subject: bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello =)

My name is Ethan Isaac Miller. I was born on 5.16.67 in Oakland. I live in
Berkeley now with my lovely wife Jenny, my 4 year old son Andrew, and my 1
year old daughter Shannon.

I spent years -- most of my teenagehood in fact -- as an absolutely
ferocious junkie, and later crackfiend. Boy am I glad I made it.

True love and hard raving saved my life =)

Started going to raves three years ago. First party was a HardKiss at the
Trocadero. Never been the same since. Raving turned me right on with a
hardcore burst of happiness, optimism, and most importantly: creativity.

Started throwing parties and DJing 2.5 years ago. Threw two parties, one
called "Home" and one called "Chez Groove" as well as helping out on "Fluid
Grooves" and many "Liquids" as well as two well known ones at the Third
Wave Dance House, the first of which was great the second of which crashed
and burned totally, but resulted in enough soul searching and public verbal
thrashing to ultimately give rise to the ideas behind and the existence of
Friends & Family, the first of which was on January 15, 1994 at the Blue
Cube in SF...

Friends and Family, sfraves, and the community that has arisen out of and
now surrounds both remain great joys in my life and are indeed what I would
consider my life's work.

It's nice to reflect on these things as we get ready to celebrate the
joining of two people without whom much of this might not now exist.

Congratulations Brian and Laura. Live long and prosper. =)

take it easy
ethan

Oh yeah, favortie DJs (in no particular order):

Minor Minor, Joe Rice, Alex Windsor, Bryce, Andrew Astral Matrix,
Allen Ameba



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 16:41:57 1995

Heya, here goes: 
	My name is Jon Logan.  I'm 6', have brown hair in a lame 
pony tail, glasses, and a generally lanky frame.  I'm 20, although my 21st is 
coming up in two weeks (Sept 28), so you'll certainly find me shaking my 
birthday booty all over the place that weekend.  I'm currently working for 
the Stanford University Medical Center's Networking Team,
MedNet, as an HTML authorer and general roustabout.  I really like my job, 
and I get to use a really cool, powerful computer that inflates my 
masculine aura.
	I'm about to start my junior year at Stanford, and have yet to 
declare a major.  My primary interests include computers (although I 
totally flopped at being a Comp Sci major), film (there is no film dept 
at Stanford), and studio art/design (the art dept at Stanford is quite 
small, and he's probably going to die very soon).  I've recently decided 
to major in Science, Technology, and Society (a cool interdepartmental 
major which lets me take classes in most of the fields that interest 
me).  So I'm pretty excited about that.
  	I'm originally from Green Bay, Wisconsin (where the feminine 
napkin was invented--hooray), and spent most of my life there until 
transplanting myself in San Francisco, the last bastion of resistance in a 
state that's wallowing in depravity and decay... er, something.
	My first rave was in the tiny town of Portage, WI, last June, and 
it was really great.  Ever since I've been hooked on the whole scene.  
	I luckily managed to acquire a car, and since my return to CA, I 
have been boppping all over at Sunsets, FnF, burning man, etc., meeting 
interesting and friendly new people.
	I prefer to dance to hard, acid trance, but thumpin house 
(especially with creamy helpings of fat, deep, bass synth) will get me 
going too.  I particularly enjoy dancing to breakbeats, too, but they 
don't seem too prevalent out here.  I heard a few breaks DJs in the 
midwest, and they kinked my spigot in a big way.  
	My cat, Harley, is my best friend in the world (and is presently 2000 
miles away).  My favorite musician/songwriter/artist/genius is Tom Waits, for 
whom I would give up all the music in the world if I could only listen to 
one person's work.

	Eeek, this is too long.  Thanks for the bandwidth/memories.


	See ya at Frequency 8! 

			jon-shub-chump

	Check out my web site at:  http://www-leland.stanford.edu/~gonzo

Precedence: bulk

I was born a poor black child...

Just joking!  OK here's important information about me and raving:

STATS

FON (Freak of Nature)
bleached hair, blue/blonde, 5'2" (yes, part of what makes me a FON),
stocky, ear rings, glasses, Italian but not in a crime boss sort of way.
28 but neither look it or feel it, excpet for Monday mornings.  Aries.

Originally from Buffalo NY, spent two years working in DC and moved to SF
three years ago.  When asked if I like it here, I often reply:  "I have
never felt so sure about anything in my life, than how I feel about living
in San Francisco."  Reside in Noe Valley.  Work for a very cool, small
software company in Berkeley.  Marketing/PR/Advertising.

HISTORY OF RAVING

Like many others, I stumbled into it.  Came home from a day at the nude
beach and a neighbor said his DJ friend Lee An was spinning at a small
house party right down the street from us.  Went with a big group of people
but only a few of us got really into it.  Walked into the Blue Cube, hot,
sticky, perfect.  Did my first hit of e with a woman I like and a couple
other friends. Saw religious figures, the light, the end of the tunnel, a
lot of smiling faces.  Friends & Family II  How's that for luck?

Didn't really rave for the next 6 months but rather dated the woman I went
to the FnF with.  We broke up and in searching for some new fun, I started
going out with Lee and his friend Brian.  Couple nights at 1015, but no e
and not a really strong vibe, but I knew it would happen soon enough.
Timing is so important.  Then in the late winter of this year Wicked threw
a free party that exploded, and I again saw the light.  Made many friends
that night, many of whom I hang out with now outside of raving (which is
important for us).  Coincidently met and am good friends with a guy who
moved into the Blue Cube; we had a lot to talk about that night.

Have subsequently met many, many wonderful people and had many great times.

NOTED QUOTE
Stood up in the ambient room of the Friends & Family party that got busted
and yelled:  "APPRECIATE THIS!  APPRECIATE THIS!"  Friends wouldn't let me
forget it for weeks.

AFFILIATIONS
Friends & Family
Hymns & Anthems

FAVORITE DJs
Don't pick favorites, who ever is playing good at the moment.  If you held
a gun to my head?  Ethan, Tracy, Billie Haste, BIOJeff, Jon Carel, Lee An,
Jon Williams, etc...

OTHER SHIT
Prefer outdoor parties, i.e. New Moon.
Love people who are open and honest upon first meeting.  Those people you
feel you've known for years after a five minute conversation.  That's what
I love about this scene.

Out!

Tony

__________________________
Actualize Your Potentional

Hi all,

I'm working on an SFR history web page.  If anyone knows the dates of
the following events, it would save me some digging through the archives:

-exact date of the start of sfraves
-start of vrave
-when SFR was moved to hyperreal
-the week SFR was shut down

I bet Brian knows this stuff, but he's probably a little busy now :).

Also, if anyone wants to volunteer to accumulate the bios into a web page,
I'd be able to integrate them to the existing SFR web pages.  If not, 
someone's at least accumulating them and I can handle it later when I have
more time.

Does anyone have a problem with the bios being publicly accessible?

-Derek

Precedence: bulk


is:

A Navy kid ((Navy kids don't really have homes)) but who went to high 
school in San Diego where I became exposed and involved in the local Chula 
Vista straight-edge scene. Although sXe has got to be one of the least creative 
art forms it's also perhaps one of the most unmolested by the mass media. 
One of the neat things about punk rock is that skill isn't 
necessarilly a prerequisite for the job. You can suck and get away with 
it. To prove that point, I spent a lot of time making flyers, putting on 
shows, video taping bands, and making fanzines untill I got tired of 
kicking my friends in the back of the head to testestorone music. San Diego 
is a nice place to grow up and an even better place to leave.

One of the truelly neat things about San Francisio, and the primary reason 
that I found myself going out 2-4 times a week last year, is the public 
transportation. I think people in general ((Buddist may be the exception)) 
are victims to whatever crowd they're associating with at that time. It's 
also really easy to suffocate yourself among a circle of friends that can 
be supportive but also equally restictive. Nobody really enjoys commiting 
social incest just like people usually don't really enjoy driving to a 
party alone, that's a Morisey song waiting to happen. The amazing thing 
about living in SF is that you can *walk* to a party whenever you feel like 
it, hoping onto a bus or two along the way, recogize familar faces, talk to 
friends, dancehowyoulike, and then leave whenever you feel you've nothing 
left to contribute. Walking is always OK. 

I wouldn't be so quick to say raving is my religion, although sometimes it 
does open a line of communication between me and my maker. It's more of a 
ritual that's pretty important to me today, may be my career next year, or 
just a fad after the year 2000. I don't really know the person I am now 
and can only guess who I'll be later. We're all shaped by our experiences 
and those experiences are always happening. 

For me, raving is about dealing with themes of self-esteem, respect, 
courage, sexuality, mob mentality, tolerance, fellowship, loniness, dynamic 
personalities, inspiration, acceptance, and developing meaningful drug 
relationships. It's about *creating* something ((or as much as you can)) 
where your happiness isn't dependant on some one/thing else rather than 
buying into that artifical life mentality. 

The people are also a weird lot. Some strangers will get you high and 
offer you into their homes for sushi. Others will preach about PLUR in one 
breath and crack cripple jokes in the next. Go figure.

Currentlly a (graduating?) Brodcasting major at the State who's wet dream 
is to intern with George Lucas next semester, my hobbies include collecting 
flyers, comics, and looking for anyone to trade Jeno, Mark E Quark, DJ 
Dan, and other cool tapes with. 

Over & Out-

Bolger.

Well why not,

	I'm Gary - Scary was an old nickname - Scottish by
	birth, I'll have been living in the Bay Area for a 
	year come the 28th of this month.

	My wife, Leigh Ann, grew up in this area - we met
	in London, lived in Britain for a while, then made
	the move back here. Altough its has its ups and 
	downs, I've never regretted it. 

	Strangely enough, I've been subscribed to this list 
        (on and off) for a good few years now - I remember 
        old rave reports - people talk about the past, and 
	even though I never experienced it, I can relate to 
	names and events. At that time, I rarely, if ever 
	posted. After all, I was several thousand miles 
	away, and had no idea I'd ever end up living in this
	part of the world. 	

	My first rave must have been about six years ago, 
	though for the couple of years before coming here,
	I rarely went out.
	
	Coming to the bay area has been a revelation of 
	sorts, or perhaps a rebirth. Altough I'm not quite
	the weekend warrior, I head out more often. The 
	scene here in the Bay Area is something very, very
	special.

	I've worked in the software industry for the last 
	six years, doing lots of things - I like computers
	and the things people do with them.

	Lookswise, I'm 6'2, blonde (though shaved), and talk
	in a manner that seems, from experience, very hard 	
	for people over here to understand.
	
	If you see me, say hello.	

	Love, 
	Gary

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Bliss Tribe Collective" <bliss@coyote.rain.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date:          Thu, 14 Sep 1995 18:26:04 +0000
Subject:       Re: bios!!

First of all let me just say what incredible vibes I've been getting 
off sfraves lately.  It's so great to see everyone so happy and full 
of positve energy.  Thanks to you all.

My name is Scott Rector, aka Scotty, aka DJ Bliss.  I'm 5'11" with 
short curly hair (usually burgundy, sometimes dark blond) I have 
blue-gray eyes, a goatee, and a warm smile that I love to share with 
other happy people.  I wear a floppy velvet hat most of the time, and 
allways when I'm raving.  It's like the ones you see at Ren-Fair only 
better because I make them by hand with great care (BSP).

I grew up in OC and I started raving in LA in 1989.  We didn't call 
them raves, they were Acid House parties, almost allway illegal 
break-in parties thrown in various abandoned warehouses off Alameda 
Blvd in LA.  I moved to SF in 1991 but it took me a while to find the 
scene there.  My first SF rave (and 1st time candy flipping) was 
Wacky Citrus in 92,  It was, and still is, one of the most incredible 
experiences of my life.  I've been to hundreds of parties since then 
but the ones that stick out most in my mind were the first Vision, 
and my first full moon at Bonny Doone in 92 (yes there could easily have been 2000 
people there - MASSIVE!!!).

The things I love most in life are my girlfriend, art, good cooking, 
computers, exploring my spirituality, sensuality, sexuality, 
inteligent interaction with positive, free-thinking, caring entities, 
and music of all shapes, sizes, and colors.  =)
  
The things I dislike are any close-minded, negative, non-thinking, 
non-caring entities. and music with no shape, size, or color.   :(  
  
I've been DJing for around three years, though I haven't had many 
chances to spin live.  I love all types of music but my favorite 
music to spin is trance, and progressive house.  I love percussion 
and I like to play stuff that has lots of interesting rythm, the kind 
of groove that gets into your bones and completely entrances you. 

I currently live in Santa Barbara with my beautiful girlfriend Leigh, 
a wonderful, inteligent, warm-hearted, free-spirited, goddess with 
whom I share an open, spiritual, and passionate love.  She has just 
finished her BA at UCSB, and we plan to move back to the city this 
coming spring.

We get up to the Bay Area around once a month to go raving.  
Hopefully we'll get to meet some more of our wonderful sfraves 
familly in the coming months.  

Well thanks to all who read this for letting me share a little bit of 
myself with you.

cheers,
    Bliss

From: fixer@d2.com (Robert Smith)

A Girl's Guide to Geek Guys - By Mikki Halpin and Victoria Maat

So, your crush on the bass player from Vibrating Sandbox has finally died
a whimpering death and you're wondering where to go from here.  All the
sinister dudes are either dating a series of interchangeable high-school
riot girls in baby doll dresses and an overdose of manic panic, or
permanently shacked up with some bitter old lady who pays all the bills.
Which will it be, a wifely prison or a humiliating one-night stand? Into
this void of potential mates comes a man you may not have considered
before, a man of substance, quietude and stability, a cerebral creature
with a culture all his own. In short ... a geek.

1.      Why Geek Dudes Rule

        They are generally available.
        Other women will tend not to steal them.
        They can fix things.
        Your parents will love them.
        They're smart.

2.      Where The Geek Dude Lurks

While they are often into alternative music, geek dudes tend not to go to
shows too often. Instead you'll find them hanging out with their friends,
discussing the latest hardware revolution or perfecting their Bill Gates
impressions. You know how some people wear t-shirts with their favorite
bands on them, thus showing that they went to certain shows? Well, geek
dudes wear t-shirts with the logos of different software companies on
them, thus showing that they are up on the latest ... um, uh ...
releases. A small, though convivial, rivalry may be detected here amongst
the geek dudes. Try wearing one yourself and see if he strikes up a
conversation.  Of course the best way to meet a geek dude is through the
Internet. All geeks harbor a secret fantasy about meeting some girl in
cyberspace, carrying on an e-mail romance in which he has the chance to
combine an activity he is comfortable with, computing, with one he is
very uncomfortable with, socializing. To many geek dudes, cyberdating is
just an advanced form of some kind of video game, but they are frustrated
by a lack of players. Their lack is your strength.

3.      Imprinting

You might notice that these men harbor some strange ideas about how the
world works and some particularly strange ideas about women. There is a
reason for this. Because they've had limited interpersonal experience,
geek dudes must look elsewhere for behavior models. Lacking a real world
social milieu, geeks often go through a transference stage with such
narratives, and try to model their interactions on them. Thus, certain
media images and themes come to have an overly cathected, metaphorized
reality to them, while the rest of us view such programming as mere
entertainment. Case in point, our next topic....

4.      The Trek Factor

If you're not up on your Star Trek, you can forget about getting or
keeping a geek dude. And I'm not just talking vintage-era Captain Kirk
and Spock either. You've got to be up on your The Next Generation, your
Deep Space Nine, your Babylon 5.  Armed with your own knowledge of
Federation policies, you can better gauge when and how to act. The sexual
politics of Star Trek are pretty blunt: the men run the technology and
the ship, and the women are caretakers (a doctor and a counselor). Note
the sexual tensions on the bridge of the Enterprise: the women, in skin
tight uniforms, and with luxuriant, flowing hair.  The men, often
balding, and sporting some sort of permanently attached computer
auxiliary. This world metaphorizes the fantasies of the geek dude, who
sees himself in those geeky-but-heroic male officers and who secretly
desires a sexy, smart Deanna or Bev to come along and deferentially
accept him for who he is.  If you are willing to accept that this is his
starting point for reality, you are ready for a geek relationship.

5.      Once You've Nabbed Him

Of course, catching that geek guy is only half the battle. Keeping him by
your side is another story altogether. I was privileged to speak with
Miss Victoria Maat, who not only got herself a geek guy but was also
clever enough to marry him just a few short months ago. She interrupted
her newlywed bliss to give us a few tips on the care and feeding of a
geek man:  "Geeks are sensitive and caring lovers and husbands. If you
can hang with the techno-lifestyle, they make the best mates. They are
the most attractive people, not flashy or hunky, but the kind who get
cuter and more alluring over time (I told you she was a newlywed).
Definitely give geeks a chance."

6.      Geek Cuisine

Geeks tend towards packaged, junk foods since they prefer to work and
think and aren't all that into cooking for themselves. Make sure that
your geek understands that you are not merely a replicator, and provide
him with home cooked food. A batch of chocolate chip cookies will let him
know that you love him. You do have to monitor your geek for weight gain;
however, remember that most of their days are spent sitting and staring
at a monitor.

7.      Geek Lifestyle

The geek dude has long work habits and tends to bring his work home with
him. He seems permanently connected to his hard disk. You must at least
appear interested in his work. Generally, a solid understanding of the
computer is a must; if you cannot master this, you should at least be
able to talk the talk. Remember most geeks are anal and they get stressed
about details which appear insignificant.  Be understanding, put on your
best Deanna Troi face (see above) and empathize.  To relax, geeks love to
play the latest computer games. Let him play Myst or Chuck Yeager's Air
Combat for hours if he wants to. Act concerned if he's stuck or has just
been ambushed by three MiGs. My geek loves to try to help people on the
Internet who say that they are stuck in Myst. He comes up with clever
riddles instead of directing them point blank. Geeks also like to go to
sci-fi and Japanese animated movies; again, a basically harmless vent for
your man.

8.      Geek Buddies

Many geeks extend their work friendships into what they jokingly refer to
as RL (Real Life, also known as "that big room with the ceiling that is
sometimes blue and sometimes black with little lights"). The greatest
thing about your geek's buddies is that you can feel secure in setting
them up with your girlfriends.  They may feel awkward around females at
first, so don't overwhelm them. In time they will come out of their shell
and realize that you are into the same things they are.

9.      Post-It Note

I thank Victoria for the above advice. I must say that when she read my
draft of the piece, before writing her section, she asked her husband
which one he thought she was more like, Deanna or Beverly. Howard, the
devil, immediately replied that he had always thought Victoria was
actually most like Ensign Ro Laren, a cute character with a slight
authority problem who is always in trouble (this is fairly apt). This
exchange is interesting for several reasons:

  Howard had already thought about who she was most like.
  He could summon up characters from seasons past with ease.
  Victoria actually knew who he meant.
  Folks, I think this marriage will last.

10.     One Last Thing

Because they have been so abused and ignored by society,many geeks have
gone underground. You may actually know some and just haven't noticed
them. They often feel resentful, and misunderstood, and it is important
to realize this as you grow closer to them. Don't ever try to force the
issue, or make crazy demands that he choose between his computer and you.
Remember, his computer has been there for him his whole life; you are a
new interloper he hasn't quite grasped yet.



-- 
fix.er \'fik-s*r\ n : one that fixes : as : one that intervenes to enable a
   person to circumvent the law or obtain a political favor : one that adjusts
   matters or disputes by negotiation

          O.K. I told myself that I wasn't going to post my own bio because
  I wasn't sure what to include, but all you lovely ravers have given me some
  good ideas of how to start, so here it goes:
 
           I am Reagan Louise Reid, 5'8" with short brown-auburn hair no 
tattoos and just a little ole' belly-piercing. Even though I was raised 
during the blissful ;( Reagan years, I wasn't named after de man. I was 
named after "the Exorcist"; my parents thought that Linda Blair's 
character was cute( before the possesion). I'm 1/4 Irish, 1/4 Italian, 
1/4 Czechoslovakian, 1/4 Yugoslavian.  
          I live in Concord with Black Adder, who is quite dedicated to 
helping with visuals at F&F. I go to DVC in Pleasant Hill and have about 
1-1/2 years left of gen. ed before transferring to the 4- year state 
college of my choice( dunno yet ). I am REALLY interested in Psychology 
and have declared it as my major. I think with all the bios I've been 
reading there should be some kind of online Psych. majors support group:).
        I moved to Suisun, C.A. about 2 years and 2 months ago then to 
Vacaville then  on to Concord. I came from A *REALLY* small 
redneck-tobacco-spitting- society called Stafford, Virginia. How I made 
it out alive; could not tell ya; but I did make it to C.A. 
        My first rave ever was Future in Maryland- May 1993. It was one 
the mainstream $20-$30 parties that i found myself at because I had no 
other outlet to get info. Needless to say I never saw the same person, 
except for those that went with me, twice :(. Now my first REAL rave was 
a FMR in Sacramento in June of 1994. Outside and right near the river.
I was wired 100% and stayed awke well into the following evening. I was 
like a little girl who had discovered Elmo( LOVE him) for the first time!
Since then I 've been raving my ass off. Oh I love ,LOve it ,LOve it. 
I've never been involved with such a scene that I can let go of any and 
all inhibtions( like the hot springs at BM) and fears  and hey be 
MYSELF ; what a concept !!!. I would say that my most liked DJs are: 
Ethan-I listen to that damn Technosis tape everyday-, Carlos and Galen. I 
know that there are MORE out there. A great DJ to me is one that no 
matter how tired I am I will pick myself up and dance. It's just that 
certain beat or just when the music is about to go off that drives me nuts.
I love ,I love It I lo_ Oh I already said that.
   Well there is alot more I can write but I could go on and on.......
   I consider myself a real and friendly person and will talk to anyone.
   See all of you on Saturday!!!! 
            Sending HUGS galoooreeee,
            Reagan


xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 20:50:30 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA16968; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 20:50:30 -0700

Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.32.19]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id UAA19024 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 14 Sep 1995 20:43:55 -0700

Message-Id: <199509150343.UAA19024@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4

From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Bios 'n all that schtuff
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Well, here's me.  My name is Jake Reichert, I'm 20, have long brown
hair on top, about shoulder length, and really short brown hair on the sides
and back, beard, moustache, about 5'9", 140 lbs., greenish/bluish/greyish
eyes (changes all the time), and long nails, usually metallic blue.  
        I grew up in Huntington Beach behind the Orange Curtain as the child
of two ex-hippies (which I'll tell you has made for an odd childhood), and
all of my friends there were, like myself, people who really didn't care for
Southern California all that much.  We basically hung out and did weird
things (still do, in fact) and drank a lot of coffee.  Unlike most people,
I've been lucky enough to keep my friendship with almost all of them even
after high school ended.  Because of my girlfriend at the time, I started
looking into going to College at USF; up until then I was set on going to
Boston.  Well, it turns out that coming up here was the best decision I ever
made.  I've enjoyed it up here ever since I came, and since I started going
to raves it's gotten even better.  
        I was technologically illiterate when I first got here, but I got
addicted to the Internet within the first couple months of school, sometimes
staying at the computer lab until 6 in the morning trying to figure things
out.  Since then my knowledge of computers has increased dramatically, I've
bought my own computer, gotten an office, and now answer insanely stupid
questions about dial-up internet access for the University (for which I am
reimbursed well :) ).  I'm studying math and physics, although my interests
lie basically everywhere.
        I went to my first rave in April with my friends (some of yours,
too), Sarvi and Jan.  It was Organic down on Army, and it was _great_.  I
was immediately hooked.  Since then, I've spent basically the whole summer
at raves when I wasn't driving to LA and back in Archibald the Wonder Honda.
I've had the most amazing experiences in that time, from the crazy weekend
of Organic in the Park/Freedom where I met mucho SFRavers to the strangest,
most spiritual/psychic event of my life (it's a really good story that'll
make you go "aaawwww...", but it's kinda long so if you want to hear it
email me).  Basically, it made me realize what society could be like if
everyone really tried.  Although I've been to good parties and bad parties,
I keep going because... well, you all already know 'cause I'm sure it's the
same reasons you all keep going too.
        Musically, I'm into techno and ambient.  I prefer the really
fast/really mellow stuff to music in between.  Also, anything on the 4AD
label (if that's not obvious by now).
        Interests: Reading sci-fi, travelling, skiing, writing, making music
on my computer, monkeys, Vaughan Oliver, Carl Jung, Postmodern theory,
Waldo, Computer Graphics, Swiss Chocolate, Hugs & smiles, cats, Duckman,
candles, 42, blue light bulbs, Woolite, Tira Misu, cyberculture, baby
animals, good coffee, Twin Peaks, Winona Ryder, SGI's, my Smith's baseball
cap, general weirdness
        Things I don't like: Michael Eisner, Nasa, politics, getting up
early, The FDA, mean drunks, jeans that are too tight in the crotch 
        Favorite Movies: Jacob's Ladder & True Romance
        Favorite quote (as in my sig): Lonely is as Lonely Does/
                                       Lonely is an Eyesore  (Throwing Muses)
        Weirdest night of the summer: driving two of my drunken friends
around in a limo that wasn't mine with two psycho girls in the backseat we
didn't know who liked cutting themselves up and eventually breaking into a
friend's house to make ourselves breakfast (I live in a sitcom, by the way)

        I could go on and on, and usually do, but that's about it for now.

Jake

P.S.  For those of you going on Saturday that have never written in my book
before, you must do so!!!

P.P.S.  Is anyone that's going bringing any SFRaves laminates?




 
Jake Reichert			|  I used to be indecisive/
reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu	|  But now I'm not so sure...

OK, I suppose I'm more of a lurker, but I'll post a bio nonetheless, I 
think this is a great idea BTW...

Name:		DJ Mr. Bill / Bill Tanksley

Occupation:	DJ of seven years, college student (UNC-Greensboro)

Description:	oh, about 5'6" tall. 135 pounds. very short brown hair, big
		blue eyes.

What I do: 	Well, North Carolina is a big college state, so that 
		explains why we have such a strong scene here (there's lots of
		people in the 18-25 age group). During the week I stay busy
		with school, I'm taking 18 semester hours this fall. On 
		Thursday nights I DJ at my resident spot, "Lift". It's more
		of an intimate club, not very big, but that's a nice contrast
		to the other NC clubs, where you're lucky to see the DJ's
		silouette 2 floors above you. On Fridays I either spin at
		Babylon (my other regular spot & our hottest club), or
		out-of-town. Saturdays are usually out-of-town gigs as well.
		In upcoming weeks I'll be in Tampa (Florida), Salt Lake City,
		Baltimore, Atlanta and here in N.C. Also, I'll be spinning a
		HUGE local party with Funky Techno Tribe on October 7th, and
		we're having the Wicked posse host a party here on October
		27th at Babylon.

Why am I on SFRaves?:
		Good question. I started subscribing to this list last summer.
		I came out there to do a few gigs, and wanted to get a 
		feel for the scene, which is very different in some ways 
		than on the east coast. Thus, after all these months, I'm 
		still on the list, as well as SE-RAVES, FL-RAVES (Florida),
		MW-RAVES & DC-RAVES.

Hobbies/Interests: 
		"Sightings" on Fox; Schlitz Malt Liquor in the new 20 oz.
		bottle; my girlfrind Devina; wasting time on the 'net; 
		getting my groove on; buying records until I'm broke;
		Jerry Springer; my cats Chelsea and Athena; cleaning my
		apartment (not really a hobby, but I'm a clean-freak); 
		shopping; playing good mix tapes in my car and taking the
		long way home; getting the DJ's together for a nice 
		meal out before a really good party; mailing out tapes 
		(it never ends!)

-----------------------------------------------------------------

                           --> I *HEART* Bios <--

I was born in the oscillating corona of a neutron star.  Composed from
the quantum state I traveled to the planet you call Earth.  There I found a
young boy on the verge of madness.  The boy was depressed and disspondant,
afraid of a world that held no permanence or consistancy.  I took that boy
for my own, and now he carries my name.  I am the fuzzy bit at the end of
precision, the magic that cannot be controled, the joy of living.

                             I am Purple Tiger

<g>

-- 
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@sophistem.com) | http://www.cybernetix.com/~ptiger >
< Sophistem = Sophisticated Software Systems >

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 14 23:46:59 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

i didnt know jack about raving or trance or ambiant or A until i started 
working at hotwiiiyed about 4 or 5 months ago.  i strikes me as fascinating
that you can wonder around for years completely oblivious to expressions of
yourself that all of a sudden, booom, by a quirk of random fate, you are 
turned onto.  it makes me feel humble.  and keeps my eyes open !

the first time i heard ambiant was when brianb would pop cd's on at hotwiyed.
i couldnt make any sense of it.  at all.  but then one particular sound on
a SeeFeel cd jerked me.  i borrowed it.  i put it in my car cd player, and
drove up to Tahoe.  As i drove out to Heavenly to shred, i put it on, and
then completely tranced out to it.  i didnt even realize it, but then, i
went to get out of the car and fell down in the street !  so soaked was i,
and the world looked strange like i was in a dream and i could not 
remember anything about the drive there.  shit.  

my first rave was an outdoor, Frequency 8 deep in the woods in Marin.  I 
took a hit of acid.  the glow of lights within the darkness bit me.  I 
danced and lost myself in it.  i would stop and wonder what i looked like
dancing.  i was quite afraid !  i looked for someone i knew but knew 
no one.  then someone hugged me, and my sense of self returned.  shit.

it's been a journey since then.  still is.  i am fascinated with dance and
loosing yourself in it.  it seems primal.  it's very real.  i have never 
known moments of tranquility and peace as when i am at a rave and everyone
is smiling and feeling the vibe.  i feel closer to people and special that
i can feel something like that with other people, and have that feeling 
translated and experienced with other poeple.  

doug

Due to overhwleming response on the part of those who wish to spin, and a 
suggestion that more DJ's means more variety, here's the lineup for the 
DJ's on Saturday:

1:30 - 2:30: Bryce
2:30 - 3:30: Will-E
3:30 - 4:30: Ozy
4:30 - 5:30: Sho Kuwamoto
5:30 - 6:30: Jon Drukman
6:30 - 7:30: Joe Rice
7:30 - 8:30: Ethan

I think this is the best mix/match of styles and times... if any DJ is 
unhappy let me know, we'll see what we can do.

Everything is go for the party!  The generator is being provided by 
Frequency 8, who will be bringing it down from their party the night 
before.  We still need able-bodied volunteers to help with setup - be 
down at the Bonny Doon parking lot at 1pm to meet the truck.  

Reminder to everyone: bring what you would bring to a day at the beach: 
something to sit on, sunscreen, food, frisbees, toys, anything.  

See you all on Saturday!  

	Brian

better than an upload, would be a cohesive set of pages maintained by
an individual.  sfravers could mail in .gifs, .html, or whatever to
someone in charge of maintaining the 'site'.  for people who have
home pages, there would be a simple link to their page.  i think
it would be a neat core thing to have.  i'd even volunteer to put
it up, but i am sure getting someone to do it is the easiest part.

doug

>area being that i am planning a move soon, and also that, to be completely
>honest, teh people who post on here and the topics covered blow me away.
>It makes it all worth it for me to slog through BSPs for things i can't
>attend and reviews that i've never been to :( just to read the intelligent,
>mature, 'spiritual' (wish there was a more apt phrase) and open minded
>writings of ppl on here. You all are really something, is there something
>in the water there? ;)
>        So, i graduated from Concordia U in MOntreal w/a Baccalaureate in
>Fine Arts, i do graphic design/HTML programming to get by, iv'e got a web
>site w/some of my flyers (including some of the progress ones from San
>Fran) and the web site is completely self-indulgent so i'll leave it at
>that. :) I love dancing, in fact i'm thinking it's a biological necessity
>to get your energy flowing again and prevent getting yourself all backed
>up...energy constipation ;) Thing that moves me the most: super hard
>chicago acidy house a la Robert Armani, Mike Dearborn, Relief Records,
>stuff like that. I also love Autechre, Aphex Twin, Global COmmunications,
>The Higher intelligence agency and other 'intelligent' stuff..along with
>Muchos Ambientos like Pete Namlook, SpaceTime Continuum, stuff like
>that....
>        I guess that's about it :)
>                peace to all...
>                                brad

                http://www.magnet.ca/ecto

hello all my family members-
it's rather late thursday might  or early friday morning.  i have been
sitting at my gateway to the world (hilda, my computer) and have been
reading sfraverfamilymember bios for the past hour.

WOW!  WOW!  WOW!  reading these is as intense as my first rave and
e-experience.  i have heard so many things about so many people, i'm speechless.

(but i will speak more, nonetheless)

when i first joined this list, i was cynical about a bunch of people
communicating by e-mail.  that has all changed in the past month that i've
been on.  i'm finding myself crying on my keyboard now(gets my keys kind of
sticky, though) as i ponder how raving and this list has changed my life.
don't mean to sound cheesey, but it has.  you all have opened me up to a new
world of open-mindedness, life, music, and friends that i know without
physically knowing yet.

WOW!  WOW!  WOW!

i love you all.  if this sounds cheesey or sappy to you, too bad.  you are
all wonderful people, and it's odd that it took a mailing list to realize that.

love, love, love, love, love, love, and just a little more love

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier

pager 1-800-862-8577

Subject: Re: Bios
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

An addition to the list of bios...

My name is martin. I'm 36 yrs 5'10" 145lbs very short brown hair (the grey
has not completely taken over yet).

I'm a self employed software developer living on Potrero Hill in SF. I've
lived here for about 15 yrs but originally from Eugene Oregon where I studied
Physics, Mathematics, and other nerd related stuff :).

Moved to the Bay area in the early 80's during one of the Silicon Valley
Booms (boy was work plentiful back then). Got heavily into Macintosh
computing and software development  for the data acquisition, process
control, and image acquisition and analysis markets.

Started out in the early 80's frequenting punk clubs like Mabuhay Gardens
(Fab Mab), Tivoli, On boradway... as well as the other end of the spectrum
for dancing like the old I-beam (anybody remember what it was like around
1982?) and some of the more underground wharehouse parties like Anon and oh
well I don't even remember the names anymore. Boy am i showing my age.
Annyway, in the mid-late 80's got burnt out, big time, from all the coke and
speed that was so prevalent wherever I went. I guess what really stopped me
from going out for years was the attitude thang that happened here in SF with
all the clubs and undergrounds. That attitude being the "Velvet Rope" thing.
VIP rooms etc. If you look "cool" enough you could get in. What a bunch of
BS. So anyway I took several years off from going out. (I also fell in love
and that may have had something to do with it :)

About two years ago I went to a YSH (Your Sisters House) party and was
totally blown away at the positive attitudes and acceptance of complete
strangers. I went a little reluctantly knowing only one other person that was
suppose to be there. It took all of about a minute before I was completley
comfortable and out tearing up the dance floor. Maybe it was the door diva
who greeted me with a big smile and a blow pop. (Thanks YSH :) I heard about
the SFRaves list that very same week som some hacker zine I picked up ( the
same zine had an article by Laura on how to start DJ'ing). I joined the list
and thats it.

Some of my favorite parties/events have been... F&F, SPAZ (last summer at
Kalesa I really miss it!), the Jungle, Black Diamond...

Spare time activities :SNOWBOARDING!, organic gardening in one of SF's many
community gardens, good food/cooking, hiking, and at least a month a year in
the islands (warm water snorkeling, waterfalls and rainbows)...

One of my main attractions to this list/group is the PLUR which is not only
preached but practiced...


peace,
martin

PS see you all on saturday...

whatever year it was stands out to me, but i've spent that
past week running around in underground tunnels staring at 
lights through fiber optic cables, so i'm not sure
i really understand the concept of months and years anymore

 ,
dana

"In a garden, there are seasons.  First there is Spring and Summer,
then Fall and Winter, and then Spring and Summer come again."

From: "Rob Jellinghaus" <robj@unreal.com>

rhythm?  Bio status?  Bio logy?  Bio graphy!  Auto bio graphy, 
actually.

My name's Rob Jellinghaus, and I'm a native Californian who was born 
and raised on the east coast (namely, Connecticut).  Great place to 
grow up and be a kid, but out here is the best place on earth to be 
an adult.  I'm 26, 6'4", 145 lbs. (skinnier people than me are hard 
to find).

My first rave was a New Moon gathering last summer at Goat Rock.  It 
was pretty much a religious experience all the way through--the vibe 
from that party soaked into me and is still present.  Sunrise on the 
beach, and frisbee all morning, with house music and crashing waves 
filling the air.  Times like that are precious, and it's been great 
to find a whole community of people devoted to making them happen.

I helped out with the April Friends & Family rave, which was 
transcendent (though hazardous) until the cops showed up, giving me 
my first experience of getting busted--lugging my futons out right in 
front of 'em while, er, flying high.  But it was cool.  I also helped 
out at the last F&F (in Oakland)--outrageous that one was!

Rave music just gets into me right at the base of the skull, and 
takes over the signals between my mind and my body.  It's great to 
dance for hours.  Humans have always known this, and ravers are 
keeping the faith.  Raving's gonna be part of my life for a long, 
long time to come.

I don't get out nearly as much as many of you do, but it's only 
because I've got a full and busy life--currently hacking 3D computer 
games (without explosions or blood in them!) for a San Francisco 
company, riding my mountain bike to work (aaahhhhh).  I've got a Web 
site where I do various writing and sex education projects, and 
there's just not enough time in the day for everything.  I think many 
of you know that feeling.  I live with a housemate in San Francisco 
near Dolores Park.  (Where is the NB lunch again?  Wednesdays at 
South Park near Bryant, is that right?)

I look forward to meeting more of y'all on Saturday!  I can't get 
down there by 1 (meeting a visiting Seattle friend at noon in Palo 
Alto), but I will bring a big smile and some frisbees.  Ain't got no 
laminate, but I'll be wearing a tie-dye which is turned up to 11.

Blessings and peace out to all of us!
Rob Jellinghaus     robj@unreal.com     http://www.best.com/~robj

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings Sfravers:

Born September 19, 1973 at Grace hospital in Detroit Michigan.  I am a
short Filipino guy with short black hair.  My Fiancee (Nancy Mitchell) and
I moved to San Francisco about a year ago from Ann Arbor (Treetown) MI.  I
came here to work as a Graphic Artist for Morphs Outpost on the Digital
Frontier and Blaster Magazines.  Right now I am working as the Art Director
for NetNoir Online which resides in full form on America OnLine.  You can
also point your browser to Http://www.netnoir.com.  I am also the Art
Director for 4080 HipHop magazine in Berkeley as well as a freelance
Graphic Artist.

In my spare time, I have been working on some trax of my own, I DJ, and I
skateboard (ugh.. I love the EMB, pier 7, the DMV, Fort Miley, and those
crazy SF city streets!).  I am also taking Night classes in hopes of
getting my BFA in Graphic Design at CCAC in a couple of years.

My first dance related experiences were in junior high school when we used
to breakdance on the Boblo Boat.  I was first introduced to techno and
house music watching 'The Scene' which was a local dance music television
show that played 110% Chicago and Detroit dope shit.  We also used to
listen to the 'Electrifying Mojo' and 'the Wizard (Jeff Mills)' on the
radio.  As I went through high school, I was heavily into Alternative,
Technopop and Industrial music.  THEN:  1n 1990 came Alan Oldham and his
show FAST FORWARD which to me, was a revolution.  For the first time, I
heard imported techno music as well as local music on a regular basis.  As
I got into the club scene, we would go listen to Blake Baxter at 'The
Majestic' and Richie Hawtin at a small bar in Windsor called 'Vertigo'.  I
got my first taste of pitch sliders and crossfaders at 96.3fm where
resident dj Claude Young showed me the concept of beatmixing.

>From there, I went on to club promotion and flyer design by working with
the VOOM crew (much respect) and other nightclubs in and around Detroit.
Soon After, I met Nancy Mitchell - the love of my life.  We went off and
threw a few parties under the production name 'Diversity'.

Here I am now in SF, where I feel like I have rediscovered myself and
music.  Although I am not really into the spiritual side of this scene, I
have learned alot about eastern philosiphy and I appreciate it more (thanks
Jody!).  I am happy to have met such great people.  Hyperreal.com is more
than just a domain name server to me :)

Thank you SFR for the continuing experience of 'the scene'.  It's inspirational.


-jon


*
DJ Influences:  Claude Young, Stacey Pullen, Billeebob, David Cooper,
Paris, DAT, Jeff Mills, Richie Hawtin, Mike Huckaby, and D. Wynn.

Design influences:  P. Scott Makela, Zuzana and Rudy, Vaughn Oliver, The
Designers Republic, Steven Reaume, Todd Sines, Bucky, and Geoff
Mecfetridge.

Music Influences:  Mike Banks, Claude Young, Shake, Gerald from Drexcya,
DopplerEffect, Rob Hood, Richie Hawtin, Jamie Hodge, Basic Channel, Dave
Clark, Collin McBean, Jeff Mills and Carl Craig.

Favorite Labels:  oh my... too many of them.  Of course, I love the Detroit
and Chicago sounds, no matter which label its on.
*
