Well here it goes...

My full name is Noah Jordan Ruiz.  I was born in San Jose on 12/22/70, and
I have lived in San Jose all my life except for 2yrs in Seattle,
Washington.  I'm Apache/Mex about 5'9'', shoulder length brown hair, brown
eyes, and 160lbs.  I signed on to SFRaves just after it started.  I don't
post much anymore, but you'll see an occasional response from me.  =)

My first rave?  Gosh, some where around 1991 and 1992.  I can't remember
the name of it though.  I must admit that I didn't enjoy my self at my
first rave.  It took the third one to really see the light.  It was in SF,
and as soon as I walked through that door I knew that it was where I
belonged.  I helped out with the Connection I
rave @ Bonny Dunes.  That was one of the best of all times.  (Thanks SFRaves)
I stopped going to raves quite some time ago, but I go out every now and
then to see what its developing into.  It's nothing like it used to be, but
it has developed into what it is now, and there will always be something
there!  =)

I've been writing music since I was 9yrs old, and I started writing
ambient/techno
etc. about 2 1/2yrs ago.  I'm not signed.  I just make music for friends
and such.  I just got a pair of 1200's and a mixer, and started mixing
records pretty easily.  I'm sure there is alot of tricks to learn.  I just
can't wait to spin at a party!!!  I love trance/ambient/house/acid all the
wonderful sounds that fill my eardrums.

I go to DeAnza college off and on for Systems Programming.  I'm not sure
thats what I want to do with my life, but I have been learning WEB pages,
and let me tell you its alot funner, and easier than writing "C" code.
Programming is fun, but you gotta like what your programming first.
Programming music is the BEST!!!  =)
And mixing vinyl is a dream come true.

I work at Cadence Design Systems as a lead in Shipping/Receiving.  Hey,
it's not at the top, but it pays the bills, and let me tell you I have
bills!!!  =)  Anybody can get ahold of me at noah@cadence.com  I have a WEB
page, but Cadence doesn't allow outside distribution.  =(

My fav things to do are:

Rock Climbing, Snowboarding, Programming Music, Mixing Records, Hanging out
with my girlfriend Heidi and her baby Ian, Rolling Phat Ones, Record
Shopping, Computers, Surfing NETSCAPE, Skimming, Hanging out with my
friends, Raving, Dancing, Experimenting, Relaxing, Did I say Mixing Records
=) =) =), and just over all living day by day, and smiling my life away.
Thats what its all about....

So if there are any people out there that like what I like drop me a line...

Take Care,

Noah Jordan (Ruiz)
noah@cadence.com

p.s. Congrats to Brian and Laura!  I wish you a wonderful strong
relationship that will last for many years.  And thank you Brian for being
a big part in merging technology and the scene together.

Noah Ruiz
noah@cadence.com
Shipping & Receiving Bldg.1
Cadence Design Systems, San Jose
(408) 944-8050 / (408) 944-7486

	For those who don't know me, I used to be pretty active at
sfraves-type events, but for the past year or so I've been a
hermit. I've decided to start living again, so this should be fun.

    sentence)

  my job at Hughes Aircraft (i do about 4 tasks here)

      coming out with some neat SGI midi software

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep 15 13:28:19 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA06218; Fri, 15 Sep 1995 13:28:19 -0700

Subject: Campsites near Bonny Doon?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 1995 12:55:25 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID:  <9509151255.aa06158@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	How about Red White and Blue? Private clothing-optional camping a couple 
miles south of Bonny Doon beach.  Look for the RW&B mailbox and sign nailed to 
the phone pole.  This place is sort of a bohemian camp; a lot of trailers and 
about 20 transient campsites.  It can be a bit dusty this time of year, but its 
definitely unique.  Coin-op showers.  Most people had some clothing on most of 
the time last time I was there.
	
	Or, check Big Basin State Park and Greyhound Rock County Park.  You'll 
have to hike in at Big Basin, and I'm not sure camping is allowed at Greyhound 
(but I hear it can be done).  I'm pretty sure there is no camping at Ano Nuevo.  
Farther south, theres Henry Cowell State Park above Santa Cruz, New Brighton 
County Park in Capitola, and a little private one off Golf Club Drive off 9 in 
SC itself.

	Think about making reservations.  I don't think RW&B takes them but they 
will tell you if they're full yet.

Andrew
	
> Does anyone know of a good place to camp near Bonny Doon? Veronika and I
> have been planning a camping trip for the weekend, but we also really want
> to come to the party. We thought that if we could find somewhere to camp in
> the area we could do both.
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com

Hi Brian,

This isn't exactly rave related but, it is significant to what type of
content we put on line (no not child pornography, silly =)  )  I'll leave
it to your discretion as far as disseminating the information to the
sfravers.

If providers start giving the feds information about the contents of what
their users talk about in private chat or private email, what next?  In
this case they were allegedly trying to crack down on child pornography
but, what's to stop them from providing information about a group of people
they might percieve to be supporting the drug market?  Please be careful.
It seems that Big Brother is alive and has been on-line for quite a while
now.

Tigger


>Forwarded message...
>
>: From: TELECOM Digest Editor <telecom@eecs.nwu.edu>
>: Subject: FBI Arrests Dozens of America OnLine Users
>: Date: Thu, 14 Sep 1995  10:00:00 GMT
>:
>:
>: The FBI made dozens of arrests and searched 120 homes and personal computers
>: on Wednesday as part of an investigation into child pornography on America
>: OnLine.
>:
>: Management of America OnLine has, over a two year period, supplied the FBI
>: with the names and addresses of users 'suspected' of 'being involved in'
>: child pornography and/or arranging sex with children. The raids on Wednesday
>: marked the first time federal agents were called upon by an online service
>: to investigate the behavior of their subscribers in private chat rooms.
>:
>: Attorney General Janet Reno spoke in support of the actions of America OnLine
>: and FBI agents, noting, "We are not going to permit exciting new technology
>: to be misused to exploit and injure children."
>:
>: The raids were conducted throughout the day Wednesday in 57 of the 94 FBI
>: districts in the United States. They were mostly concentrated on the east
>: coast, however arrests and confiscation of computer equipment took place
>: all over the country in such diverse cities as Miami, New York, Dallas and
>: Trenton, NJ. Carlos Fernandez, an FBI spokesperson in Washington, DC said
>: that 'quite a few more arrests are expected in the next several days' and
>: that the Bureau would wait until those arrests had been effected before
>: discussing the case in detail.
>:
>: Pam McGraw, a spokesperson for America OnLine, based in Viennna, VA admitted
>: that the company monitored email and private conversations seeking out
>: persons who use their network to transmit pornographic material. She said
>: they always provide the FBI with the names of users suspected of involvement
>: in child pornography.
>:
>: Ms. McGraw also discussed an online 'neighborhood watch' program in effect
>: on AOL where users are encouraged to oberve each other's activities and
>: report on them to management of the online service.
>:
>: Although child pornography certainly is not allowed in public areas of AOL,
>: according to Ms. McGraw it 'usually is transmitted in email between users,
>: or in private chat rooms'. She did not indicate how AOL's interception of
>: email for the purpose of examining it for 'pornography' or their monitoring
>: of private conversations between subscribers could be reconciled with
>: various privacy laws, apparently because it can't be.
>:
>: FBI spokesperson Fernandez said the federal investigation of AOL users
>: showed that child pornographers are turning to online networks 'more and
>: more' to lure curious children. He said, "the utilization of online services
>: and bulletin board systems is rapidly becoming one of most prevalent tech-
>: niques for individuals to create and share pornogrpahic pictures of children
>: as well as to identify and recruit children into sexually illicit relation-
>: ships."
>:
>: Raids and arrests of other AOL subscribers 'suspected of being involved
>: in child pornography' will continue over the next few days until all the
>: user-suspects have been located.
>:
>: I don't know about you, but I'm going to purge all the AOL sofware from
>: my computer today. Child porn does not interest me in the least, but
>: having AOL scanning my mail and checking up on my in private conversations
>: with other users there is of great concern. It is hard for me to imagine
>: how any online service could violate the trust of their users in this way,
>: by getting into their email and personal files, regardless of the intentions.
>:
>: We have known for some time that AOL was 'cooperating' with federal agents
>: in their investigation of child pornography, but until the massive raids
>: and arrests commenced on Wednesday followed by AOL's admission that the
>: 'evidence' was found in email and private chat, we did not know the extent
>: to which AOL was abusing their subscribers in the process of cooperating.
>:
>: PAT
>:
>: ------------------------------
>

From: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: who i am
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 1995 12:26:45 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID:  <9509151226.aa02216@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>

Precedence: bulk


	Well, it looks like full-fledged intro time, might as well delurk for a 
moment...  start at my start...


	I was born in Kentucky, but after 9 months I decided California
was the place to be so I dragged my folks to Sonoma (wine country), where
I stayed till I was 18.  Then I got a degree in Physics and worked in
Menlo Park for awhile, before moving to Santa Cruz in 1983.  I do
architecture and programming in systems and systems management, mostly
under UNIX.  Networking is my main interest...  I chose my first job
because it was on the Net (in 1980), and believe I've managed to make a
few contributions to the success of the Net since then.

	In my play time I like to be outdoors and around people as much
as possible.  I also read a lot (SF and classics), and have a Windows
box at home to play with things like photoshop, cakewalk (esp.  when I
get my AWE32 running), and various cdroms (delorme has a new set with
the US phone book connected to the US map, with the phone book
searchable by business type and displayable on the map).  And I listen
to music...  recent growth in my CD library has been almost exclusively
house/techno/ambient...

	Raves...  my first one was almost two years ago I guess, when
the Universe crew came through Santa Cruz.  It was a small one, but with
a great sound system, excellent visuals and interesting people...
incredibLe.  One of my ambitions is to run the first bar in space (give
me 25 years), and the timeless atmospere of a rave made me feeL like I
was there already (well, the UV lighting and Universe's costumes helped
too).

	I got on sfraves around the time the Zippies came through, in
fact I think it was to find out about the effect they were having (and
to post my own experiences).  Since then I've found it an interesting
and valuable waste of time :-)...  a window into a side of life which is
often difficult to see in the US.  That includes the music, the parties
and the people.  Thanks...

Andrew


-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

I was an anonymous disco person who whent dancing where ever I could,
taking Acid at gay discos usually. I went to an Acid House party at DV8 in 
87-88 which sucked. I would rather listen to pre-rave experimental electronics 
when I'm not dancing.  I started working at Ameba in '93 and since then 
have started to meet other ravers. I've never left the Bay Area except briefly.
This is by far the only social group I have ever been proud to feel part of.

From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)

Hiya! 

I've loved all of the bios; it makes me hope I have a chance to love 
each of you, too. 

whoami

My name is Jocelyn Cordell. I'm 24, 5'2" or 5'3"- I'm 
not sure, ~110lbs last I checked. I have brownish/straightish/longish 
hair and brown eyes. I often wear glasses, because I'm 
nearsighted and I like it- like being able to change 
everything into an impressionist painting just by taking 
them off, too. I was born in wartime in fiarfax county, va;
then moved to Austin, tx at age 5- where i spent my 
formative yrs listening to local bands and dating too many 
guitarists. then onto bryn mawr college, where i majored in 
english and minored in math. then i came here, where i've 
been for 3 yrs.

work

I am a dilettante in a world of specialists. I guess I prefer 
writing to most things, though. What I want to learn in the 
near future: industrial welding (I have a driving vision of making 
a real-scale Mayan temple out of old, working televisions; that, and 
obnoxious lawn sculptures), and how to use plot in writing. 
I am currently a tech-writer at HaL Computer systems, where 
I do enjoy my co-workers, but hate the actual work- which includes
ALL of the manual pages + 5 sys admin guides (UNIX). If everyone 
would print out a manpage and burn it as a vigil, it would brighten 
my day! (I forgot to take my printed sets to the BM).

raving:
i've been raving since i was 3 or 4. whenever my folks weren't around-
i'd hit the stereo and go mad all over the living room. BUT-
i went to my first rave in summer '92 at king st. a friend of mine 
was visiting- we got a fairly gritty hotel room up in the city 
for the weekend and asked the desk guy what we should do- 
thanks desk guy!  I kept coming back for many reasons, but initially
it mostly had to do with the fact that I didn't know _anyone_ 
when i first moved here. i felt safe going to raves by myself 
& it was realy fun, too- whatever i chose. My first great rave 
interaction was at Sharon's Devotion in a field somewhere near 
Stockton. I hadn't quite acclimated to the whole warm during the day,
potentially cold at night SFBA weather thing. I was ill prepared 
and I was freezing. A woman came up and hugged me, having mistaken me 
for one of her friends. I returned the hug- so she didn't know I was 
somebody else until after the hugging was done! We talked a bit 
once she recovered from the surprise. I mentioned I was cold and 
she literally gave me the shirt off of her back. We exchanged #'s 
so I could return the shirt and we've been fast friends ever since.

the list

i've been on for almost 2 yrs. i feel like the old school snuffulupagus of 
the list. i guess i'm a bit of a recluse. i'll be at bonny doon 
this saturday- earlier than later. my doggy girl ursula will be 
with me- she's a large, sweet, black doggie. she loves the people.
i will gladly share my water & oranges. she will gladly share 
sandy slobber, so be careful!

p.s. both ursula and i are fuzzy and squeezable! (and i try hard 
not to slobber even when the set is really good)

music- 
i like all kinds of stuff & i often wish that all kinds of stuff 
was really played at raves. if anybody out there is up to the 
challenge- i want to hear some flamenco guitar mixed in!
(find an old record that features los romeros)

Bio:
	Born 12.4.74 Stamford Ct.
	Moved to Libertyville, IL, 6/89
	Graduated high school 6/93
	Moved to Berkeley 8/93
	Started c2.org 6/94

	So let's see, I live in berkeley, have been on sfraves since a
little bit before I moved here -- prolly since early 93 or so. The
past year has been hell, so I haven't been out much to event and
such-- I'm hoping to revitalize the ability to have fun that I had
last year, which I seem to have lost lately.
	For my day job I work at SGI, with a lovely 45-60minute
commute everyday. (weeehaw.) I run Community ConneXion, a heavily
privacy oriented ISP in berkeley. (http://www.c2.org)
	I attended ucberkeley for two years or so, and plan to return
sometime soon.

	I live alone in berkeley, if you don't count my baby. (c2.org
;-)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep 15 16:17:52 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA16037; Fri, 15 Sep 1995 16:17:52 -0700
Received: from smtp.interramp.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA16032; Fri, 15 Sep 1995 16:17:47 -0700
Received: from smtp.interramp.com by  smtp.interramp.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1.3-PSI)
	id TAA21831; Fri, 15 Sep 1995 19:13:38 -0400
Date: Fri, 15 Sep 1995 19:13:38 -0400
Message-Id: <199509152313.TAA21831@ smtp.interramp.com>
X-Sender: pp000267@pop3.interramp.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: pp000267@pop3.interramp.com (Paul Richard)
Subject: Bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I just returned from two weeks in Europe to find this wealth of information
about my brothers and sisters on SFRaves.  What a treat!

I'm a member of the Over 40 Posse, having been born in Washington, DC in
1950.  Grew up, went to school, and generally worked on the East Coast until
1986, when I fulfilled a lifelong dream and moved to SF with my lover, and
worked for a large law firm that shall remain nameless to protect the guilty.

In March of 92, I went to the AIDS Dance-a-thon, so that my pledges would
get their $2,000 worth of shakin my booty.  (Yes, being a lawyer at a large
law firm has some benefits!)  The dance ended too early so I went to
whatever gay venue that was then occupying Townsend St, where I met Ken (aka
Songman), who asked me if I wanted to go to a smaller party with him.  (BTW,
anyone know what became of Songman after to Waterworld bust?)  Anyway, it
was my first rave, and my introduction to many of you.  Many memorable raves
from that summer - Vision, Let Freedom Rave, one out in Tracy - the dust
from that one is still in my car door jamb, and prolly still in my lungs,
raving at the Russian River with the Ameba gang, Come Unity on Election
Night, 1992, New Year's Eve, 1992-93 (and my almost divorce for staying at
the EndUp until 4 in the afternoon without calling!)

Having caught the political bug during the 92 campaign, I moved back to DC
in January 93 to work for the Administration.  I was in the White House for
2 years, where I got to take a few ravers around (hey, Susie!) and to have
my picture taken wearing an Ameba sweatshirt while standing at the podium in
the White House Press Briefing Room.  I also got to invite the Prez to
attend a rave that took place right down the hill from Camp David - he
didn't go, but was amused by the invitation.

I'm now working for one of the many government agencies (more on this if you
ask).  And as I read your bios, I realize how much I miss all of you.  I'll
be in SF over Columbus Day weekend for a wedding, and maybe will be able to
escape for a party.  I hope to see and meet you all very soon.

Paul
(Raver in the White House)

P.S.  Love, peace and prosperity to Brian and Laura as they begin their
(legal) lives together.  May you enjoy a lifetime of happiness together!  If
you feel the molecules around you at Bonny Doon tingling, it's just me
dancin with you.
Paul Richard
pp000267@interramp.com

Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita
mi ritrovai per una selva piu' bella,
che la diretta via era scoperta.

Subject: BIO
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Bret Lee, 28, SWM, 5'9", 150lbs, brown hair/eyes, usually have some form of
facial hair from a full beard to a lower lip triangle thang.

Started combining chemicals and dance music at clubs, illegal parties or
anything with a DJ, in the early 80's shortly after doing the punk thing(I
tripped hard at a Better Living Through Chemistry at the On Broadway when I
suddenly truly realized just where I was/ had been 12 years ago jumpin' off
the speaker cabinets -- it was briefly like existing at two places in time at
once.)  While still in high school I bought a keyboard, drum machine and a
Commodore 64 (and it wasn't paid for by my parents or a job, hmm....)
 Electronic music and computers stuck so I tried to get a degree in CompSci.
 Summer of 88 I went to London and of course wanted to go out, little did I
know it was the "Summner of Love."  Wound up at Trip at the Astoria which was
an absolutely MASSIVE acid house fuckin' RAVE -- I'd never been to anything
that big let alone with DA vibE -- blew my brain completely and permanently.
 Came back and tried to explain it, only managing to convince people I was
nuts until I discovered that it was here too just a leetle bit more
undaground. Still driving down from Sacramento where I was going to school at
this point.  Briefly moved to L.A. in 91 where I released a couple of records
with a friend rapidly plunging into junkie-dom -- bad business move.   Moved
back to SF and got a  job at a music software company, Passport Designs,
where I still work today.  I get to travel as part of my job to music trade
shows here and in Europe.  Meeting ravers(especially netravers) in other
places has had such a deep impact on me.  Really feeling first hand the
global nature of this culture fo ours is a wonderous thing.  If you ever
travel -- get in touch with people there via the big ol' Net (or walk into a
DJ record store) you will be amazed!  I've been on sfraves since I don't know
when(I used to be loophead@cyberden.sf.ca.us)   FMR, Wicked, Basics, that one
New Year's Eve Gathering, Floppys, ComeUnity, Parties in the Park, LiquidAir,
F&F, Sunset, and a hundred more.  Jeno, Garth, Markie, Thomas, Tony, Simon,
Josh, Buck, Alfie, Galen, Ethan, Solar, Dan, Carlos, DRC, and so many more I
know I just forgot.... 
I plan on releasing some new music I've been working on soon.  
Raving is as spiritual as I get and guess what? I'm getting more spiritual
everyday :-)
Forever seeking and trying to increase the vibe, Love this city, love you
all,
phuture

Okay, okay!  I know this is probably blatant misuse of sfraves (perhaps a 
little off the subject) but...since reading all the posts and realizing all the 
awesome people out there with whom I share many interests and similar 
lifestyles (therefore being rave related! =o), am I pathetically grasping?) I 
thought this would be an ideal place to post an ad. 

You see...it's the 15th of the month and I am beginning to amp out because I 
have this really cool pad I want to share with a kindred spirit, but haven't 
gotten any responses from my *3* ads!!!  This is alarming because it's a nice 
place in an awesome location and I *think* I'm a pretty great housemate. ;-)  I 
think I'm having trouble finding people who mesh with the eccentric lifestyle 
cause of the music, DJing, conga drums and party substances (very occasional) 
But other than that I'm just a quiet, demure, 9 - 5 computer geek and Satan 
Worshiper, so what the hell's the *&%$#!@ problem!?   If I don't find someone 
by the 1st, I will be solely responsible for rent (which basically means 
eviction due to the fact I cannot pay)  Ugh!  I feel sick :-(  

Okay, the specs:

Location: Killer area on Webster off 51st in North Oakland, across from 
Rockridge, conveniently close to College, Piedmont and Telegraph   Aves, Bart, 
AC Transit, great shops, awesome dining, quick drive to parks, anywhere in 
Berkeley, etc.  Easy access to the 80, 880,   580,  and 24 freeways (15-20 
min's to anywhere you'd *want* to be)

Place:  2 bedroom (good closets)1 bath upper flat in duplex.  

Features: Lots of sunlight and air, whole front of flat is over garage so we 
can play music plenty :-), modern, gas kitchen, dishwasher,    balcony, *free* 
cable w/HBO & Showtime (BFD!), almost empty 2 car garage (actually thinkin' 
bout throwin' a block rave party   out of  the garage), washer, storage, off 
street parking.  Pets negot. w/ landlord (I don't have any).  *Water & garbage 
included in   rent*.

Area:  Safer than most.  Great neighbors, nice looking houses, trees, etc.

Rent:   $422.50 each. (Guuuulp!) a little pricey, but it's worth it just for 
the location and the fact I have cool neighbors and landlord who   don't give a 
shit if I party and make small sacrificial killings (that's worth quite a bit 
to me!) =oP

Pleeeeeease respond if you or anybody you know might be interested.  I'm 
lookin' for open-minded, open-hearted folk who take their shit seriously, but, 
welllll...ya know!!!  Independence, respect, generosity, friendship, peace, 
rave!  =o>

My number at home: 510-450-0236, at work 510-922-5978

Peace and love to all.

Rikki

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ekjazz@netcom.com (Eric Kalabacos)
Subject: Bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm so gald that my introductory post helped touch off the bio-fever
currently sweeping SFR, but I realized that my post didn't really
constitute a full bio.

Soooo, here it is =)

I was born 30 years ago in The Rotten Apple (NYC). Went to high school in
the East Village during the height of the punk era (practically spitting
distance from CBGB). Got into clubbing with friends (being carded was
unheard of back then) but could never quite get with the VIP/guest list
vibe that so permeated the scene at the time. Turned instead to hiphop &
reggae and many, many big fat blunts. Went to some very early hiphop
"house" parties and caught my first glimpse of the possibilities of two
turntables and a mixer.

By the time I turned 17 I was thoroughly fed up with NY and the urban vibe.
I managed to get into a small college in Santa Fe, NM. I only lasted for a
semester and then moved on to Dr. Hoffman's class ;-) I think I managed to
give Terrence McKenna a run for his money terms of frequency and dosage
during that period. These were very profound times for me, but were rather
solitary in a way. I broke my neck in a freak accident during that time
(still hurts :-(  ) and managed to work myself into a pretty severe
depression about the state of the world. I bemoaned the loss of tribal
identity, humanity's flight from nature, and things like that.

As a way to save my sanity, I turned to music and began learning to drum.
This eventually led me to a school called The Naropa Institute in Boulder,
CO, where I got two degrees, one in World Music and one in Buddhist
Studies. This was an amazing place and an experience I will treasure for
many lives to come. I took Buddhist vows at that time and have been a
practitioner ever since. Buddhism has taught me to look into my own state
of mind for the source of happiness and not to blame external circumstances
for my problems. It has also taught me the importance of continually being
in the present moment - right NOW!!!

I bought my first computer, a Mac Plus, while I was a student at Naropa and
began doing a bit of DTP work for some extra bucks (it beat delivering
pizza for Dominoe's, which was my job at the time). Actually, that's not
true, my first computer was a Radio Shack TRS-80 my parents bought me when
I was 12. I had fun with it, but then decided that guys who were into
computers never got anywhere with girls  ;-)

After 4 years at Naropa, I felt it was time to move on. I wanted to move
somewhere bigger and more diverse than Boulder, but knew I didn't want to
go back to NY. San Francisco seemed like a good bet, so my girlfriend and I
packed our bags and headed here on 1/1/90. My girlfriend (later my wife -
later my ex-wife) didn't really want to come, but did anyway to be with me.
If any of you non SFers is considering moving, don't make this same
mistake.

I thought I was going to pursue music as a career once I got here, but I
needed bucks right away and got a job at a computer company and, well, one
thing led to another...

In 1991 I started a company called Colorscape Communications with some
friends in what would later come to be known as Multimedia Gulch (it was
just cheap rent at the time). We did lots of graphics (mostly Photoshop,
Illustrator, and Quark) for the advertising industry, and later got into
CD-ROM develpment (I produced a couple of corporate CDs in Director).

In '92 I hired a kid named Ammon Haggerty who had grown up in Marin and had
just moved back to SF after a copule of years as a snowboard bum in Tahoe
and Oregon. It was Ammon that introduced me to the rave scene (events
described in my previous post) and to another great love, snowboarding.

In July '93 I started Mushroom Jazz/Jazid up with Patty Ryan and Erik Ross,
but I was only officially involved with that party for the first six
months. Around that same time I met my girlfiend Veronika (who I currently
live with and adore with all my heart ;) ).

After Colorscape dissolved at the beginning of '94, I got a job with a
Denver-based Mac software company called Lumin. I had to move to Denver for
a year (I didn't want to leave SF, but the gig was to good to pass up). My
official title is Director of Marketing, but I really wear many hats since
it is a small company. We are currently developing a multi-player game for
the net that we hope to release by end of year. I'm currently working on
our Web site.

Luckily, I now have the best of both worlds. I still have the job, but I
work out of my home in SF. Lumin set me up with an amazing computer studio
that people say reminds them of the bridge on the Enterprise ;) The view
from my 11th floor window looks out over the Gulch and the Bay Bridge. I'm
definately a lucky, lucky guy...

As far as musical tastes go, mine are quite broad. I'm into acid jazz, deep
house, acid house, ambient, trip hop, some jungle, world music, classical
music and just about anything with a quality of genuineness to it.

I hope I haven't been too long winded here, but I am enjoying everyone
else's posts so much and usually find them too short. You're all such
fascinating people.

I hope to see many of you at Bonny Doon tomorrow!

Much, much love,
ek

     Thought I'd write a quick bio since it looks my son and I will make it 
     out to Brian and Laura's pre-wedding bash.  Looking forward to seeing 
     y'all tomorrow!
     
     STATS:
     5' 0", 110 lbs. (Fit but not thin!), Black Hair below the shoulders, 
     Dark Brown Eyes, Dark Complexion (Filipino & East Indian descent), 34 
     yrs old, divorced, one nine-year-old son...hmmm, anything else left 
     out, just ask!
     
     I'm into and trained in some of the following types of dance:  jazz, 
     tap, modern, ballroom, African, contact improvisation,  folk/ethnic, 
     Latin, authentic movement, etc. and have formed and belong to a few 
     Bay Area dance collectives.  I'm not trained in any particular body 
     therapy but have incorporated some Trager(tm) and Alexander(tm) 
     techniques into dance classes I've taught.  Among the many projects 
     I'm working is one where I'm exploring how to bring that schwa feeling 
     naturally through yoga, body centeredness, group mind, theatre and 
     movement improvisation, music, and dance.  This is in collaboration 
     with a couple of fellow ravers.
     
     I enjoy all types of music but have a jazz and funk influence.  I play 
     guitar and have had classical and jazz voice lessons but recently have 
     been goofing around w/keyboards, congas, synthesizers, and other small 
     hand percussion instruments at some all night jams.
     
     I started trancing when I was about 12 during an interpretive dance 
     class at a Catholic school.  Without knowing what I was doing, I 
     became hooked into dance as a release and a form of expression.
     
     Spiritually, I've explored lots of beliefs and have developed a few 
     gifts that I occassionally share at raves.  These interpretive, 
     calming qualities along with my mothering energies allow me to meet 
     quite a few wonderful people in the rave/party circuit.  I've got a 
     longer bio but I think this'll do for now.
     
     See ya soon!
     
     Diane

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep 15 20:09:58 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Eric <ehill@best.com>
Subject: Bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Reader,

I'm Eric Hill. I was born in Oakland on March 2nd (Lou Reed and Dr. Seuss),
1968. I have lived in the Bay Area my entire life and I am moving to San
Francisco in three weeks to engage the opportunities of  a major
metropolitan city. Right now I live in downtown San Jose as I have for the
last six years, doing PC tech support, HTML and graphic design/cgi to pay
the bills.

I was introduced to House music through my former housemate Nick Philip who
turned me on to a free show at the I beam in the summer of 1990 featuring
the Inspiral Carpets, a scallie band we both liked. Performing techno-house
artist Adamski opened for them and that sort of opened the gateway for my
affinity towards this style of music. We started going out regularly up to
San Francisco to events like Vivid, the Firehouse, Wiggle It, Wicked, the
Candlestick FMRs, 650 Howard, Big Heart City, One Step Beyond '92, Zanzibar.
These  are the seminal clubs in my raving experiences and New Year's eve
1991/92 at Toon Town was the definitive Rave (Jeno playing Billie Jean? come
on...).

Playing true to a raver stereotype in full effect, one August Monday in 1992
I woke up to guns and orders in my sleepy face. I was getting busted.
Flogging wafers and lotus sheets in a suburban neighborhood can have that
effect. This event and it's consequences completely changed the way I looked
at the rave scene, the legal system, drugs and drugs-based
(counter)cultures, reality, society, life, and most of all, how I perceive them.

I DJ techno and avant-chill music. Over the past year or so I've noticed
that most DJs that I see are much better at getting gigs than being
musicians. I think it is the DJs job to go out, wade through and find the
newest and raddest music out there and bring it to the people in the clubs.
If the crowd doesn't want to dance to it, that's their option - at least
they were given the chance to get into something new. I don't get into the
crowd control aspects of DJing that seem to me like a top/bottom power game.
I love my records and I love music, but I'm not a magician. I know this
ain't the dominant perspective.

I am currently learning about synthesizers and playing drum machine so I can
start putting out records. I played drums for 10 years before I got into
raving and I have a lot of ideas about rhythm that have been sitting in my
head for a long time. These will be the records I'm always shopping for, but
never come out. This music will render the 4/4 beat obsolete to all but the
most sentimental of dancers and music fans.

I am ~6' tall, 155lbs with glasses and blond hair. Sometimes I wear a
Madonna shirt, but lately I've been wearing my blue Jack Purcells and a cap
that says "PROJECT STARBURST."

Here goes

Willis Wong 

5' 11" bowl cut blond hair, glasses, 125lbs +/-
5lbs, depending on pasta intake.  

My first rave was the spring of '92 in Orange County called "Alice's 
adventures in Wonderland". It was like a whole new world.. being with 
several hundred people all being nice to each other.  Not to mention the 
whistles and glowing things - it was something else.  I found out about 
it from Dana Watanabe's postings to alt.rave. Thanks Dana!

I'm not much of a social being... mainly just dance until my feet reach 
China when that groove kicks into high gear.  SFRaves is a swell place to 
be.  I've only been on for a year or so but it's been stellar reading 
what everyone does and says and feels.

I sometimes wear a shirt that says "walrus" but people usually mistake me 
for a Beatles fan. Oh well.





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep 16 02:21:39 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA21323; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 02:21:39 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA21318; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 02:21:36 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id CAA20868 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 02:21:38 -0700
Date: Sat, 16 Sep 1995 02:21:38 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199509160921.CAA20868@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

at 7 am on the morning of June 1, 1993, me and M and P-ter were shuffling
through the mist out to the parking lot of the Sonoma County Fairgrounds
at the end of Get Down Get Down Get Down Get Wicked.  I'm sure I had this
dazed look on my face, because even after a year of seriously going out
to raves and other events I'd had my mind pretty well blown in the old
armory building with the nice neon sign above the entrance naming it as
the Grace Pavilion.  This was the night that I actually left the smaller
building where Doc Martin was just rockin' the joint with the biggest
phattest vibe factor I've ever seen on the dance floor (and doing it with
just one speaker stack as I believe Markie had blown the other one when
*he* went over the top in his set!), to go back into the Grace Pavilion.
I don't know for sure who the DJs were in there but I believe in retrospect
it was Buck and Barry Weaver.  Well, there was the biggest wall-o-sound
I've *ever* seen at an SF party, a huge set of screens hanging from the
ceiling in this old armory with really great projections, gigantic fog
machines and a wonderful Windows-controlled laser projection system that
I'll always remember as the very first Windows program I ever saw that
didn't have *any* icons.  There were maybe 150 people in this huge hall
with this huge sound and light show just exploding around me, and I danced
and sat right in the middle of the whole experience like the universe
swirling around me and got THAT kind of feeling that never happened even
at the very best Dead shows I've been too . . .

. . . and after it was over, we walked out in the morning misty rain and
P-ter said, mostly joking, "Well, did it change your life?"

And I looked at him and M and kind of grinned and said,

"Uh, YEAH!"


phred




When I asked him about it recently, Barry Weaver said he didn't really
remember all of this except that it was a really crazy party :)


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep 16 02:51:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id CAA22323; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 02:51:08 -0700

From: Sindar@aol.com
Received: by emout04.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id FAA03080 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 05:46:26 -0400
Date: Sat, 16 Sep 1995 05:46:26 -0400
Message-ID: <950916054625_20791045@emout04.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

All I can say is that the all of the Bios have been great to read!  Now we
are getting somewhere =o)  I feel like the SFRavers have been pulling
together lately more than they ever have and that is what it is all about...
well at least I think so ; )

Well my real name is Rob Johnson, I'm 6'2'', 170lbs, very long light brown
hair, brown eyes and I wear size 12 shoes =p
I was born in Berkeley but started moving around the country when I was 4.  I
lived in 9 different states and Saudi Arabia before coming back to the Bay
Area when I was 19 (I'm 24 now.)  I love to travel and hope to eventually
live bi-coastaly (new word :) 

My interests are nothing too unusual for this list...  I love music,
computers and people (most of the time.)  I started out young doin the "rock"
thing and it only took me 8 years to figure out there was more to life
musically...  in fact I found out there was EVERYTHING better to be found in
music...  I think I have come to a point in my life musically where I truly
can fall in love with all music and I am happy with that.  

I played guitar for 12 years (classical to heavy metal) and I am still
playing every now and then.  About 6-7 years ago I started doing electronic
music and have thrown myself into it completely.  If it is electronic I do
it.  I have a really deep love for analog synths and always try to keep 10 or
so on hand in case I need a fix.  I also love the world of digital sound.  I
am currently learning to use the Kyma system.  It is a real time DSP synth
that will pretty much do anything you tell it too.  It uses up to 8 DSPs in
parallel and it ROCKS!  All I can say is that the real time voice morphing
left me on the floor so I will be sure to try n get some more music with the
Kyma on the dance floor soon!  (so far it has seen most of it's action just
in Universities)

I also do some DJing when I have the time.  Most of my time is spent in my
studio either on the computer or writing music...  one of these days I'm
gonna do some more home work cause I also go to San Jose State U where I am
an Electro Acoustic Music Major.

My first experience with house music was in 88 while I was on the East Coast.
 I was in NY with my best friend and we hit up a few clubs.  Well I had never
danced nor been to a club before but I caught on pretty quick =o)  The whole
thing totally rocked my little rocker world ideas on music.  There was NO
band and NO stage...  this was more about _everyone_ in the crowd...  and I
loved it!  When I came back to CA I could not find that music any where...
 (just goes to show you how some times our social groups can hide us from the
rest of the world)  ...until I went to Floppy's (I think it was 91.)  Well it
was all over from there...  non stop raving for at least 2 years...  those
were to date some of the best years of my life.  I guess I have been a Raver
in waiting for the last year or so.  The scene for me has been kinda
disappointing so I have not been going out too much.  I figure the best thing
I can do to help the scene right now is to really work on my music and try to
take it to another level... to do this I need the time and money that going
out consumes so quickly.  I'm really glad that the scene is continuing to get
stronger in many ways...  I guess I'm gonna have to be going out more but to
do that Ill have to stop writing this really long story =o)

Much love to ya all,

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep 16 13:15:03 1995

Received: from [198.93.4.215] (sr-tty5-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.215]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA03087 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 16 Sep 1995 13:14:53 -0700

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: My Bio
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok,  Ok!!   I guess it's MY TURN...  I suppose I could just do a cop out
and ask everyone to read Hackers by Steve Levy and look inder the index
under John Draper,   but I won't do that...

As most of you all know my now,   my claim to fame was my discovery that
Cap'n Crunch Whistle could send a "Disconnect" signal at trunk level...

Then,  using a blue box tone generating device,  I would be able to dial
any number that operators could,   including internal trunk codes.   Thus
giving me "root" access to the phone company.   I had to serve time in
prison for my deeds,  and had phone hacking school in prison,  where I
went out of my way to teach every criminal I came in contact with on how
to do this.

Lately,  in 1992,   I went to the Toon Town and Cyber Spider raves
(pretty much old school).    I never danced though...   It wasn't until
I started doing my famious wackey exercies that I got strong enough to
dance without excructiating pain,  and dealing with everyone poking fun
at my strange exercises.   Anyways,  I met Geoff White (Raver Jeff) at
a Cypherpunks meeting who seemed to be really well connected with the
scene.   Then,   I learned of the SFRaves mailing list and promptly
joined.    At first,   I would lurk,  like anyone else.    Then I went
to Beltane in may and got my first taste of dancing,   after a long
talk with my personal trainer,   I learned very quickly what my body could
and could not do.   At first,  I would just "shuffle" with the beat,
then pretty soon,   my body just sort of "took over" and my dance style
started having more variaty.

I dropped Kandy flipped at Let Freedom rave on 4th on July (Remember the
hill fire?).   From then on,   my head just started saying over and over
"I have truly found paradise"!!   No other social event ever comes close
to providing me with Friendship,  brotherhood and love,  as well as getting
an awsome amount of exercise.   As I started going to more and more of these,
I started evolving into a much higher physical state...   Now,   as most
can testify,   I have limitless energy.   So,  thanx to those funny looking
exercises,  combined with dancing,   I've found utopia.   Thanx everyone
for accepting me in this awsome community.   I am honored to be a part
of it.

My web page is coming soon,  got some amazing stories I'm telling....

Cheers
Crunchman

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Alright, enough of that energy shit.   ;)

First, I'd like to thank everyone for such a wonderful day at the beach.
Beautiful views, wonderful music, but most of all, incredible people! I'm
continually reminded that though the music is what brings us all together,
it is us that creates the environment in which to enjoy that music. We all
add a little something to the overall atmosphere at a party, and it is that
which keeps me coming back.

Though I didn't connect with many of you Saturday, I still felt an
underlying unity with you all. Sort of a reassurance that we are all pretty
much like minded people, trying to live within a social framework who's
world might not be to our liking. Strenth in numbers, eh?

So hats off to you all. Even if you didn't make it, I feel you were still
there in spirit.

about me:

Just turned 28 last week. 5'10", sandy blond hair, usually pulled into a
pony tail, unless, of course, I'm dancing.  ;)

Local boy. Grew up in Walnut Creek, which was cool until I started to think,
then it got scary. Moved with my folks to Oregon, then Idaho, then finally
back to Walnut Creek (which is much better than Boise, Idaho - trust me). 

At 19, I did something really crazy, and joined the Army. Long story, but
let's just say I was really confused about a lot of things, and needed a
structured environment to get my shit together. Kinda extreme, I know, but I
guess it was needed.  Ended up going to the Gulf for that crazy political
tap dance that many people bought into. Found out some things about our
government that I wish I didn't know. As Goebbles (Hitler's propaganda
minister) once said, "A lie told often enough becomes the truth." Scary.

So now I'm home (1991), and a year later I hear about these things called
"Raves".  My first is Pajamarama, at the Concourse. Interesting, but not my
thing (I was sober for the event). A  month later I go to the Live 105
listener appreciation party, and find they have a "Rave Room". Bump into a
guy with a thick cockney accent who's got something for me to try.  ;)

Started dancing, and came in touch with an energy I never knew existed.
Damn, so this is what this is all about! My next party was Community, and
I've been hooked ever since.

Joined the list in January of this year. Lurked for a while, then felt
comfortable enough to post. 

I've grown by leaps and bounds through my experiences, but it's only because
I've wanted to. I find many people come into our community looking for
something, and when it isn't found, they get dissapointed and split. That's
too bad, but I don't think we're in a position to be blatantly spouting
values to anyone. It seems that if we, as a species, are ever going to
change our destructive behavior, we have to come to similar understandings
on many levels. Since these understandings have to come at one's own pace,
it might take a while, but I'm confident things'll work out. 

I'm pretty serious about my spirituality, which might be why I'm a withdrawn
sometimes. In order to have the experience I like, I need to be in my own
"space". 

Blah blah....

Thank you all for being who you are. You've made my world a better place.

later...

Jonas

Before I go into the event itself I'd like to say I saw one of the  most
beutiful sights between two people:

It was during Mars set when the event was winding down, everyone was by the
fire or faling asleep on their blankets, sleeping bags ect... and I was
sitting up on a rock viewing my lovely community when I caught sight of Mars
and his significant other.  Both were on the vibe of whatever song was
playing at the time and both were on the same wavelength.  It so intimate, so
private.  About a hundred of us on a beach, but thoses two were on their own
planet.  That was beuaty.

The event in itself was very nice: tiki torches, more lighting than usual.
 The music was not as upbeat than thier previous sets.  But the spirits of us
people were at an all time high..  I actually spent less time by the speaker
and took time to meet some of you (ie. purple tiger, vince, and some others
whom I cant, for the life of me, remember...)

Two high points were the suprise birthday cake for one of the F8 crew members
(got milk Jim?) and the seals who came by to appreciate the music (I guess
seals like techno too)...

Funny how no one wanted to burn the broken pallet till we realised it was for
burning and not abstract art...
 
Overall:

Vibe:  8Smiles (maybe the cold weater)
Friendship Factor:  9Smiles (hug patrol in full effect)
Danceability: 8Smiles (I see the cardboard more and more often)
Cleanup: 10Smiles (I came back 2 the place after all was gone and it still
looked pristine).

Overall: 8.5

Thanks for the SFR badge Vince and thanks for the Medical response to
everybody (brian et al.) for my Boo-boo....

See Ya at the Mari-na,
Adam

P.s. I really enjoied Bonnie doone as well.  But I tend to think that it was
like Sunset: any review would be an injustice.  Thoese kind of gatherings
need to be experienced to be understood.

From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: The weekend, an apology...
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk


	Briefly,

	Well, this was a full weekend for me - Friday night was spent
	at a disappointing Stereophonic down at Mission Rock. The music
	was, IMHO, rather scattered, never building up into a consistent
	groove. Then the music gets turned off around 4ish, earlier than
	expected. Not a great party.

	Saturday, I headed down to Bonny Doon. The Calafornia coastline
	in general is a spectacular stretch of land, Boony Doon is 	
particulary beautiful (my first time there). There was an 
	energy at the event, despite the small(ish) numbers, which was
	wonderful to experience. Unfortunately, sleep deprivation, a
	general lack of energy and, later, a foolish descsion to get 
	all physcadelic, kept me in a slightly spacey state.

	Still, thanks to all the people I talked to, met for the first
	time and the DJ's, all of whom played a great set of tunes.
	
	Lastly, the apology - on the way off the beach, at the fairly 
	steep descent down to the road, I ran into a few problems. 
	Insufficient footwear, no light, and the influence of a certain
	substance, all contributed to the problems I had getting my
	load down the rocky path. After almost falling a couple 
	times, I had to leave the polystyrene cooler I was carrying 
	at the top, then slowly go down the path.
	
	I wanted to get someone to come back up and help me down with
	it - but, my ride was ready to go - so it got left. I'm so
	sorry about this. Normally, I make sure and take all the crap
	I've generated away with me, having left garbage there makes
	me feel really bad.
	
	All for now,
	Gary

monica: (monicat)

hmm...let's see...born 9/17/70 in brooklyn, grew up in nj...went to 
rutgers college (with a brief time in england where i started raving :) 
), degrees in women's studies and history... did a lot of 
radical/political organizing there, too (pro-choice, anti-sexism, 
anti-intervention stuff, mainly)

discovered raving in 1992 in england, tho i guess technically i made my 
own rave sometime in '89 (?) by bringing a boom box with early acid house 
to a little park :) 

moved to sf in the summer of '93, ,met tomcat at a Your Sisters' House, 
and then started working with YSH til the end...now work with f&f 
frequently, tho a back injury has prevented me from doing as much as i 
want or going out that much...

i also do a lot of anti-police brutality organizing now (helped start 
ACtion for Police Accountability, email me for more info), ever since the 
SFPD raided my friend's Visual AID benefitNew Years Ball...

i like kitties.   i'm a pagan.  and an anarchist.  and pansexual.  
love acid hose, acid trance, pwog, richie hawtin...ambient, too , but 
that's such a broad category... favorite djs:  alex (ex-gaia mantra), joe 
rice, junior vasquez...and tomcat :)

from the 9/14/95 Examiner:

22 COPS ON THE CARPET AFTER RAID ON AIDS PARTY

Six could be fired for excessive force, other violations at fund-raiser

Six Sf police officers face possible suspension or firing by the Police 
Commission for allegedly using excessive force and violating other 
regulations in a New Years Day raid on an AIDS fundraiser, Chief Tony 
Ribera says.

Another 16 officers face lesser disciplinary action for alleged 
misconduct in the riad on the Harrison Street party early Jan 1, Ribera 
said Wednesday.

The six facing more serious charges include a captain and a lieutenant, 
Ribera said.  He would not identify them.  <Yalon and Haggett?>

"The commission will either sustain all, part or none of the complaints 
against them, " Ribera siad.  "Assuming that a charge is sustained by the 
commission, then discipline will be given for that charge after looking 
at how serious it is and what the officer's disciplinary background is."

Ribera told the commission Wed. that despite the alleged violations, the 
raid itself had been legal (lie!) and had not been targeted specifically 
at gays and lesbians.

"The initial enforcement action against the nightclub <lie!@ it was not a 
nightclub - it' was my frien'd home/warehouse and was a private party!> 
had no indications of bias or homophobia," Ribewra said.  "This took 
quite a bit of time planning and there were a lot of people involved."

The Office of Citizens Complaints last month sustained 52 allegations of 
wrongdoing agains 22 officers who took part in the riad on a warehouse at 
938 Harrison St., where a packed benefit was under way for the AIDS 
charity group ?Visual AID.

The charges sustained by the independent watchdog agency, which has bno 
power of enforcemtnt, included excessive police force, false arrests, 
police uses of anti-gay slurs, illegal searches and lying on police 
reports.  Eleven people were arrested during the raid, which involved 
nearly 100 officers.

Ribera would not comment on the specific allegations against the 
officers, some of whom had multiple hcarges sustained against them.  
Buthe said the allegations included excessive force, illegal searches, 
inapropriate languageand being evasive during investigations.

Police, in concert with agents from the state Alcoholic Beverage Control 
agency, raided the club to enforce safety violations, including unsafe 
wiring and poorly lit fire exits <which were actually ok!> In addition, 
police say, alcohol was being served without a permit. <LIE LIE LIE!!>

Ribera said the OCC had determined that the fund-raiser organizers had 
been selling alcohol illegally.  <another lie!>

Twelve officers will be disciplined at a chief's hearing, with possible 
punishment ranging from a reprimant to 10 days' suspensiom Ribera said.

The remaining four officers, Ribera said, face relatively minor charges 
and will most likely be admonished or informally disciplined because they 
have good disciplinary backgrounds.

"They had many altertions during the course of the evening <that they 
caused!>, Ribera said.  "it was a high stress period and I think that has 
to be considered."

end.

well, crappy article - he didn't even interview T (main organizer) or his 
lawyer or anyone from the OCC!!!  lots of inaccuracies, too.  but let's 
hope some piggies get at least more than a slap on the wrist.

look for ademonstration at a Police Commission hearing coming up soon.

monicat

At 8:02 PM 9/17/95, you wrote:

>Well i wish i could've gonr to bonny doon hope everybody had a great
>time!big congrats to brian and laura!!
>i have a request...has anybody heard  of a compliation called ther
>california prodject? it features djs from all over california and is
>collectivly contains something like 24 hours of music anybody w/ info on
>this please give a ring ?!
>
>
>muchas gracias!....

There's a mail-order place called Pure Acid that lists it as follows:

"_The California Project_: 8 DJs, 16 tapes for a total of 24 hours of
music.  The best of Hardcore Acid, Progressive, Funky, Tribal, Trance, and
ambient.  Two mixed tapes each from Ron D Core, Thee-O, Simply Jeff, DJ
Dan, Jon Bishop, DJ Trance, DRC, and Vitamin D.  $120  VERY LIMITED"

I can't guarantee the integrity of the place, but I did order a couple
tapes and I was very satisfied so it seems kewl =)

If you e-mail your snail mail address to them at cubofdoom@aol.com and ask
for a catalog they'll send one.  I haven't heard any of The CP, but it
sounds like a pretty groovy collection.  Hope this helps some - Good luck!
Peace and Love

Eh, a very good weekend on my end of the rope.  F8 was fun, fuzzy, and 
mellow, in the kyoolest location I've ever seen.  Sunset was, as 
usual, supervibey and great fun.  Sorry I didn't make it to Bonny Doon, tho.

F8, and Amy Starkey, a great grrrrl who I met at Sunset (thanks for noticing 
my sfraves badge!).

SFravers are certainly great conversationalists; talking to these two was 
loads more fun than dancing to a great set!

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Tuesday, depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

                                Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Tuesday
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ...
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road
  Southbound: Past University Avenue

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)

* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Precedence: bulk


As reported, the Bonny Doon gathering was intimate and beautiful.
I usually don't socialize much when the music is *that* good,
but I had a wonderful time meeting quite a few sfravers face to
face for the first or maybe the 2nd time.  Hello to all of you
whose names I've forgotten, as well as Sho, Ozmandias (sorry if
I butchered that), Will-E, Phil, Tim, and especially Jocelyn. 

I found the couple simulating sex in the dance area to be a minor
annoyance.  That kind of self-absorbed focus tends to draw energy
away from the group vibe.  Oh well, after a while it just became part 
of the scenery.

Sunset had to take a back seat to the wedding on Sunday.  It was
kinda fun seeing ravers in formal dress.  The event had a couple of
minor rave influences: Bryce provided some ambient tunes, and we showered
the departing couple with bubbles instead of throwing rice.  Being
there with a bunch of net-friends drove home just how *real* our virtual
community can be.  As more people are brought together through this
medium, the world surely becomes a better place.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 18 13:14:43 1995

From: Doug Zimmerman <doug@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Bio
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950918125820.16459A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Bio: Rave Style

grew up in Hartford CT, went to school American University in washington dc
for two years.  my freshman year i started going to parties a little 
underground in a parking garage and then Catastrophic Masquerave in Oct. 92
  but the first party i had the slamming time was Ultraworld 2: the Milkyrave
which introduced me.  went insane going to parties getting busted handing
out candy, blowing whistles, dancing on  a ski resort and 2nd/Bowery in New
York City on New Years.  helped start dcraves and throw a few parties on
campus along with some renegades called Mobile Grooves Possee.  
  eventually i got burned out on parties and didnt go as much. i visited
San Francisco a few times and liked the scene here and didnt like the school
i was going to so moved out to San Francisco last year and san fran scene
has become my home.  you guys are jus so friendly ;)

Bio: Personal

 live in CT grew up there.  suffered identity crisis and visited Kenya in 
1991.  changed my life came back went to school in DC loved it and meet cool
people but then moved put to SF and SF State to go to school.  
Photojournalism major, two more years of school.  i love to travel
so after school who knows where ill end up.

  thats a brief intro.  hope to see ya around.  peace

doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23beta2]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1562      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As always, there's never enough time to do everything you want to...

Friday night was the little party on the wharf.  Not great, not bad,
just okay.  It was good to hear my old friend Darcy again, as well as
meeting John Williams for the first time.  It was also nice to hear
Seawolf while in SF, but luckily, it was just a taste of things to come...

Saturday at Bonny Doon was great.  When I got there and started walking
down that sandy hill, what did I hear but some good Techno Bass, courtesy
of Ozy playing an Aux-88 track.  That set the tone for the day!  It was
weird hearing the music that was being played in that setting.  Weird for
me, at least, as we tend not to have too many parties on the beach back
in Detroit, and I tend not to hear much techno while on the West Coast.
I am really glad things are going the way they are!

The obligitory name dropping of new SF-Ravers I met:  Geoff White,
Jon Drukman, Ozy, Jonathon Wells, Chris Hilker, WillE (well, netraver
if not SFRaver ;)  And of course, best wishes and all that to Brian
& Laura!

Also, if things pan out, you might be seeing a lot more of me in the
future.  To that end, Niels Meyer, I don't have your email address handy.


--

        I know you guys might be getting bored of bios, but I probably
should post one to let you know that I'm here.

        I was born in 9/8/77(right, I turned 18 a few weeks ago)... I have
been going to raves for about 2 years, but I've only gone to a few major
ones. I am really into the scene, though. 

        Most of the major ones I've gone to were Bonny Dunes and Santa Cruz
stuff. I just started my freshman year here at UC Berkeley and I want to get
into the SF rave scene since it is alot bigger than Santa Cruz's. I'm not
sure to how illegal I can talk over this email so I'll kick back and see
what you guys do.

        But I really am into raves and have a lot of friends into it from
Santa Cruz and here at Berkeley. I hope you don't mind that I'm probably
younger than most of you.

        I am really, REALLY into music. I can play guitar, bass, trombone,
trumpet, tuba, and baritone horn. Music is my life. I am into all styles. I
will probably major in music. My main instrument is guitar. I am also into
quirky old synth stuff, and quirky old guitar effects which I collect. So if
any of you are into music, or need a guitar or bass player of any instrument
for something, just talk to me. 

        -Chris (lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu)

Hey people,

I'm thinking about coming down from Portland to take in some of your 
lovely city next weekend and I would love some tips.  In case you didn't 
read my bio, I'm a 28-year old female into acid jazz, soul music, the 
Dead, Deep Forest, house, ect....I'm not so much into big parties right 
now but rather smaller get-togethers, outdoors, (your beach parties sound 
wonderful).  I like seeing good blues and jazz and sipping cocktails and 
good conversation.  My main subjects of interest are metaphysics and 
spirituality, music and good food :-)
Are there any comfy clubs that play like acid jazz, ambient and  are 
there any events happening this weekend that are sure to please but not 
throught the roof?  I'm looking forward to meeting many of you and there 
will be more on this as I receive info...thanks in advance!

Love and kind thoughts,

bren aka shakti

    Singer/Songwriter, lover of sushi, in-line skating, skiing and Santana

done what you receive is the sum of what you took out of what you put in" 311

Subject: My Bio!

Precedence: bulk

Subject:My Bio!

Wow!  After a weeks vacation I come back to over 500 messages, A good portion
of them are bio's.  I havnt even scratched the surface reading them.  

Here's my Spec Sheet:

Im 24. Born in Paso Robles, CA on Nov 21,1970.  Moved to and grew up in San
Jose when I was around 2.  I now live in Santa Cruz and work in Scotts Valley
at E-mu Systems.  E-mu Systems is maker and manufaturer of Sampling
keyboards/modules and synthisizers and digital recorders and multi-media
stuff.  I'm in Tech Support which means I tell people how to use our stuff all
day long.  I also monitor Internet and E-mail questions.

I have short brown hair, glasses, 3 holes in my left ear and one in my belly. 
And a recently aquired cast on my right arm (broke my wrist last thursday). 
I've been raving for about 4 year.  My first party was the Gathering.  Must of
been in '91.  And I've been hooked ever since.  Fondest party memories were at
a warehouse in South San Jose off of.......shot, cant remember the name of the
street.  They used to have a lot of parties there.  There was this big Sail
Boat in the middle of the floor that everyone danced on.  I dont make it up to
SF as often as I used to but if there is a party in Santa Cruz, You'll find me
there.

I write ambient music under the name Astronout (its supposed to be spelled
with an 'o' as in -out, not -aut.  But people still call us Astronaut
anyways).    I also do some House and crazy Techno stuff.

Outside of dancing and raving and what not, I enjoy skate boarding (hence the
broken arm!)  walking on the beach, movies, all types of music 'cept country
and Queensryche or Rush. And I probably watch way too much TV. 

-M

Dear All;

	& Hello; latey it kinda seems like people have taken interest in my
personal life, life as raver ...etc. So what do ya want to know, better
yet, what don't ya want to know :). God knows I wouldn't want to torture
people like Dave Alves, with the "clueless" details of my life. = >
(sarcasum present)

	Things like this cause me a great deal of concern. I'm just not
the type of person you can say a few words about, it would just be a waist
of time, and bandwidth for me. There's so much I want to share with the
people I consider family.

	I don't chose to call myself Brian Darkness for not. Being
mysterious is kinda cool, but I'm about shedding light & awareness, even
though I do a good job at shedding darkness, better than a type IV Demon
for those D&Ders out there :). I'm a relativily visible raver on our scene
ta-boot, coming up on almost a year here on SFR, which sometimes I feel,
my silence around ?'s like what do you do, who are you Brian Darkness?
generate suspicion, rather than acceptance, yet the answer's amost always
generate more ?'s going deeper and deeper into my p-life. 

	Let it be known that I have nothing to hide, I not an ax murderer,
or escaped con, and the only people that want me are the Florida State DMV
for a traffic ticket or two I've negelected to pay. But I also warn ya be
careful for what you ask for, you may just get it :). So in the mean time
if curiousity gets the better of ya, go look at Hyperreal Vrave People
Thingee, I forget what its called Laura sorry; the public version's in
there, under ABC, briandarkness. 

	It's hard when things are so personal, I don't want to be mean and 
say that it's none of your bussiness, yet I don't want to lie either, 
cause truth is important to me, more so, being true to thy self is even more.

Subject: Evil People On Our Scene
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950918173550.11546E-100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	I'm very sorry to have to inform you all that there are four
individuals praying on our scene. These person/s lack any form of 
concern, compassion, or human consciousness; more simply put 100% pure 
sociopath. 

	While at Brian B. & Laura D. semi-private party Saturday we where
approached by person/s who were alledgedly offering what they claimed was
"pure MDA from Texas" in a 0 or 00 jell cap. The powder contained in these
jell caps varied in color consistency & gradulitity, and tasted sweet like
sweet tarts; which person/s claimed "it was cut with". They drove a
upscale clean(no dents) black 4 door with California plate # 3AAD600, the
car had Alien Workshop stickers on it, as well as Santa Cruz Sound
stickers. This could mean they are from the Santa Cruz Area. The person
selling the bunk E, was Caucasian, early 20's, 5'9", 170lbs, medium frame,
light brown wavey hair, and was wearing a New York Giants Teeshirt. His
compainion was black, mid 20's, 5'9", 200lbs, medium to large frame, and
had black short dreads. They're not very smart cause they let me get 
close to their car.
	
	They are not part of our scene, outsiders, possibly the reggae
scene, punk scene, and/or surfers, denoted by their appearence, music in
their car, and their two other compainions. These people think we are
fools, and as they drove away I'm sure they had a good chuckle. They 
travel the beach roads looking for parties, and are tring to get on SFR 
to obtain the calendar so they can use it against us, and our scene.

	If you see this car, please remember the license plate number it's
an easy one, Let your friends and other people know. Remember the MO,
taste any powdered E unless it's from an unquestionable source, especially
if it's in a large jell cap. If you see me, please tell me, I have a
special surprise for them, but nothing that would compromise, what WE are
about, or our scene. 

	Please be careful, these people do not share our values of PLUR
and could, if cornered possibly resort to violence, or even be armed. 
Cause there are about 4 of them, your could be dealing with the 2 and have
the other 2 behind you, and not even know it. 

	If anyone has pictures of that day, and you happen to get these 
individuals in your pictures please get them to hyperreal.com so we can 
digitize them and post them. A picture is worth a 1000 words, so please 
develop and look them over very carefully. thanks

Precedence: bulk

> Anyone been to Maui? Anyone gone dancing in Maui? Anyone have any suggestions
> of somewhere to party in Maui?

W/r/t partying, you can both party everywhere and nowhere on maui. the
only place where the mythical thing known as partying (usually alchohol
fueled checking out of tan-lines between sexes) happens is Lahaina, or
as I like to call it LaHiney. I think there's a cheezy disco in some
hotel nearby too, but I hear it sucks. Anyways, about the best you'll
see is the Hard Rock Cafe and various equally cheezy/plastiscene
tourist traps serving overpriced alchoholic beverages to clientele
desperately trying to have a good time. Somewhere overlooking the ocean
on Lahaina's main drag is a bar where bands play -- they occasionally
will have a jawaiian reggae band playing that may put the glide in your
stride and the dip in yer hip.

You come from SF-Bay area, and you've seen some of our finer events. It
just don't happen like that in Maui so don't bother looking because
you'll be disappointed. (Honolulu on the other hand, can and does have
a small "scene").

nAture is the thing to check out while in Maui ... -- I suggest you
pick out a letter at the beginning of the alphabet, and find out if you
can taste the color of a rainbow.  This is best done by getting up at a
ferociously early hour and driving to Hana -- don't spend too long "on
the road" (and do it on an off-tourism day -- tuesday for example), and
try to spend as much of the day tripping/swimming around the seven
pools area at the end of the drive. Plan to entertain yourself come
evening because there's not much around, other than a few very posh
hotels ($500/NIGHT). But hotels aren't the point because it's the
closest *REAL* rainforest you can reach on a relatively small budget,
travelling in complete american comfort/safety. Of course, if the giddy
feeling of swimming in the seven pools has worn of, you may attempt to
drive home (about 3 hrs of windy 1.5 lane -- for two directions --
roads) at night instead of  car camping or whatever. In fact I
recommend night-time driving because you can see oncoming headlights,
which makes knowing that which lurks behind the next hairpin turn less
angst-laden.

Another excellent trip is the haleakala crater... a very pretty
moonscape of painted rocks. 

You must go snorkeling. Go to the end of the highway past kihei and
wailea, before you get to the part where the road goes over the lava
flows (i.e. the place where there are still trees), stop and look for a
sheltered cove, often with lots of snorkeling/diving activity. Bring
your snorkel and fins (or rent 'em in kihei). Swim around -- bring some
frozen peas from the supermarket and let the fish eat them -- within a
few moments, you'll be surrounded by hundreds of gaudy colored tropical
fish flitting about you in a spectacular specular 3D light
extravaganza.

ANd of course, go to the beach. Be careful with the waves, since
they're far more powerful than waves in CA and they *can* and *will*
damage you if you don't know what you're doing. ANd the Sun in Hawaii
is much much stronger than in CA (stronger than the sun at burning
man), so go easy on the Sun, and heavy on the sunblock. A sunburn early
on the trip can make the rest of the vacation quite horrible.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

For the umpteenth time, there are better ways to do this...I wish people
would keep their "stuff" and personal problems off the list.  Esp
concerning the buying of illegal substances.

>Dear All;
>
>        I'm very sorry to have to inform you all that there are four
>individuals praying on our scene. These person/s lack any form of
>concern, compassion, or human consciousness; more simply put 100% pure
>sociopath.

I do not want to repeat the entire message.  Fact is someone, ADMITTED
PUBLICLY , the attempt to buy a Schedule 1 substance; felony.  Next they
gave the location of the purchase, a semi-private party on a very public
beach; not too smart.  Next they gave the names of the parties to which
this party "belongs" to, or was thrown in the name of; not too bright.
Next, a license number was given, once again in a public forum, accusing
someone or some people of selling illegal subtances; lack of judgement that
could have very dangerous reprocussions.

Next time, why not just call five-o, tell them your plight, let them know
where the offense occurred, and be sure to call them right away next time
so that they may SHUT DOWN THE F*CKING PARTY, and arrest the lot for
complicity!  That is after they have stripped searched everyone!

Next time one of you'se folx wants to buy drugs, can you please not
announce it to the world.  I, for one, really don't want to know about
deals going down.  Either good, or bad.  One of the main weapons the 'man'
has is this very thing.  The dealing or suspicion of dealing drugs at a
party location gives the 'man' plenty of "just cause" to fuck with people.
And all that has happened by mentioning this sorry episode in jonesing, is
bringing attention to whatever authority that, perhaps, their hunch was
right; yep parties == drugs.  NOT! NOT! F*CKING NOT!

I wish I could be more diplomatic about it.  But this crap has happened
before, and now is piss poor timing to mention anything illegal on this
list.  I have a sneaking suspicion that there is/are moles among us.
Especially with those who have had recent brushes with the law under the
same context.  Be very careful people.

Nuff said',
John

Subject: The Behlendorf-LaGassa ticket to fun
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The beach party on Saturday in celebration of Laura and Brian's wedding was
great - a mellow gathering of SF Ravers and friends enjoying some great
music. Ethan played the best set I've ever heard him play, and I was
pleased to hear great sets from Sho, Will-E, and Ozy, none of which I'd
heard play before. Hearing Jon Drukman play funky jams of the type that
used to define the "San Francisco sound" reminded me how I miss that style
sometimes.

All in all a great party. Thanks to everyone who stuck around to help us
carry stuff out at the end - I was amazed at how quickly everything made it
up the hill.

Joe

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA26208; Mon, 18 Sep 1995 21:50:15 -0700
