>        Reply to:   Slide 5
>
>** Tue 10/24 "the acid jazz experience" part of the SF jazz fest, with
>*New Legends, Kelly Huff, Better Daze, DJ Grey Boy, Slide 5 (anybody
>*heard of these guys?? Any good??). At Bimbo's...
>
>SLIDE 5 are awesome, I'd highly recommend seeing them if you're into soul
>n' jazz.  Also Greyboy is really cool and he hardly ever performs here.
>Do you know if it's just him DJing or the entire Greyboy Allstars?
>
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-



Veronika and I happen to be the folks putting on this show, so I thought
I'd tell y'all a bit more about it:

After about a year's worth of cajoling, we managed to pursuade the San
Francisco Jazz Festival to be the first major American jazz festival to
officially sponsor an acid jazz show. We did it to help promote the scene
in SF and to let the traditional jazz audience know that acid jazz is here
to stay.

All the acts in the show are on Ubiquity Records. Ubiquity is an excellent
local label owned by Mike and Jody McFaddin. They've put out a number of
excellent compilations (Home Cookin', Mo Cookin' Still Cookin',
Explorations I & II, Is that Jazz?) and are now putting out some full
length LP's (Greyboy, Spirit Level, and soon: Slide 5, New Legends, Better
Daze). They have also re-released dozens of 70's jazz funk records under
the name Luv N' Haight. We thought they'd be an excellent representation of
the local scene.

The lineup for the night is as follows:

Slide 5 (w/ special guest Ledisi) - a smokin' funk band featured on several
Ubiquity comps - these guys will be returning to SF after a year in NY and
the show will be their homecoming debut. Their first album should be
released around the time of the show.

DJ Greyboy - dope DJ/producer from San Diego - soon to be releasing his 2nd
lp - (Bart, he's just DJing)  ;)

New Legends - a hot new local band featured on the "Is That Jazz?"
compilation - I saw them at the Oddball and they fuckin' cooked!

Better Daze - a "double DJ" act with Paul Scriver and DJ Andrew from On The
One. Their first record will be released just before the show.

Kelly Huff - a world class scat singer featured on the Ping Pong cuts from
the Cookin' series.

Paul Scriver - saxman featured on the "Is That Jazz?" comp.

There will be a '60s-style psychedelic light show by Glenn McKay. Glenn
used to do lights for bands such as The Jefferson Airplane and is coming
out of retirement just for this show.

By the way, this aint gonna be a typical "sit in your chair and clap
politely" jazz festival show. The tables will be cleared and we expect the
dance floor to be bumpin'!

Tix are $18 (sorry, I know this is a bit steep, but there are alot of acts
and the Jazz Fest and Bimbo's take a hefty cut) and are available at the
Jazz Festival store next to Cyberlab @ Four Emarcadero Ctr. You can also
buy them @ Tower or the Wherehouse (with the BASS rip-off added) or at
Bimbo's the night of the show. We're also planning an afterparty (probably
@ 111 Minna if they get their licence in time) w/ Greyboy and Better Daze
freestylin' it.

I just sent the flyers to the printer today. If you want me to send you one
just e-mail your snail-mail address to me.

peace out,
ek  =o)

ps. we had a wonderful time @ Bonny Doon on Sat. the vibe was right on and
we enjoyed meeting new folks as well as reconnecting with friends we hadn't
seen in a while. i really hope we can all do it again soon...

Subject: What's the connection?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This made me think of something.  There's a book I bring with me to some of
the smaller raves called _The Second Earth_.  Basically, the idea behind it
is that there was this first earth that the original inhabitants destroyed
through their own ignorance of the environment and each other.  The
remaining population got into these gigantic spaceships and headed off in
search of a habitable planet, which they found thousands of years later,
namely, our earth.  In essence, they are our ancestors.  It's incredibly
well written (and frighteningly believable), and it is accompanied by
amazing illustrations.  At one private party, I think about 5 people asked
me to order them a copy :)  Anyways, I'll show it around the next time I see
all you crazy raver types.

Mr. Jake


Jake Reichert			|  I used to be indecisive/

Last seen on the Connection II tapes, btw.  I love that stereo pan on the
synth bass hit zipping back and forth; it always feels like it's inside
the back of your head.

Actually I always thought the SF sound to be a more straight-four type
of beat but with the same swing feel to it, like back when the Garth/Jeno
axis was all that.  Had there been more funky tracks like the above defining
the "sound" I would have gone to more massives back then...

I'm a sucka for the two-and-four, like Spun used to play before he went
totally housey.  I almost wish "Raise Your Hands" had never come out so
people didn't get sick of that style all at once.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep 19 01:07:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA15627; Tue, 19 Sep 1995 01:07:31 -0700
Received: from netcom21.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA15622; Tue, 19 Sep 1995 01:07:28 -0700

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199509190804.BAA19891@netcom21.netcom.com>
Subject: Balmy Bonny Doon
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 1995 01:04:18 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2131      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good Music and Good People at Bonny Doon ....
 
 Mary and I finally got the generator to Bonny Doon , about 45 minutes 
later than the planned 12:15PM . It seemed that a lot of other folks had 
gotten there a bit late too. Many thanks to all the folks that hauled that 
heavy generator up and down those rocks and the great sand slope!!!  
After my Friday food poisoning , I still wasn't feeling 100% physically . 
 
 After hauling the canopy and other stuff down the sand slope, I helped 
my wife Mary get down it. I didn't notice that she was wearing Birkenstocks 
when we left the house or else I would have recommended shoes - they turned 
out to be the wrong footwear for her at Bonny Doon. They kept on getting 
caught in the rocks and sand . 
 
 Bryce started the music with some hits from the 80s ! I remember "I'll Tumble 
4 Ya" by Culture Club , Devo , B-52s , and (maybe) Bow-Wow-Wow !  Flashback
time!  About this time Mary and I walked to the shoreline and let the waves
wash our feet. 
 
 Bonny Doon is such a nice beach , and it holds so much wonderful memories 
for me now. The big SFRaves Connection rave , an FMR or two. And now I'll 
have another wonderful Bonny Doon event to associate with it!
 
 Thanks to all the folks that stopped by and talked to me and Mary. She was 
somewhat worn out herself , and couldn't visit the folks on the other side 
of the dance area . She did get some nice drawings - at outdoor daytime 
raves, she sketches while I dance. 
 
 I did more resting than dancing , but not for lack of great music! I also 
loved Jon Drukman's set , and Ethan's closing set was great! And all the 
other DJs were good too.
 
 Thanks to all the folks that stayed to help haul all that heavy stuff back 
over the rise and down to the road! Especially , of course , the guys that 
brought the generator back down to my truck! 
 
 I wish Brian and Laura many happy decades together !
 
 
      Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
 
 PS - Special thanks to : Wayne for the SFR laminate , Willis Wong for the
      conversation , Susie for being Susie , and all you folks who had a 
      smile to give me!

It would be awfully hard to beat a weekend where I went to Bonny Doon and
listened to great music and talked with my friends old and new all day
long with the most beautiful pleasant weather, went down to Santa Cruz
and ate late dinner at the Saturn Cafe, got up in the morning, had lunch
in the shade on the back patio of Zare on Haight St., checked in with
Joe Rice and Monte and friends at All You Knead, spun a good long session
at Ameba (going acid house->progressive->jungle->?->techno->kickin' house),
went to an absolutely fantastic Sunset at the Marina, had beers and nachos
at the Triple Rock, ice cream at Mel's, and *still* got enough sleep to
get in a full day of work today without falling head-first onto my desk!

Thanks everyone . . . it was great :) :)

phred

>Brian Darkness

There have been plenty of busts on the scene.  From people taking a little
dose at a club, only to have two COPS escort them out, and arrest them.
There have been epople pulled over and searched, there have been people put
in prison.  Directly from "our" scene.

As for ownership of this scene, I for one do not consider it mine to covet.
Something that is mine becomes something that belongs to me.  When I
establish the concept of me, then it becomes easier to call somebody them,
or those who do not have ownership.  I hate this type of elitism.  There is
"A" or "The" scene.  It belongs to nobody and everyone.  But hey, if you
want sole possession, please enjoy.  Parties of one can be fun.

And to think I'm using restraint...

Pace all,
John

will do. by the way, if you're into AJazz here's a couple of other options
in SF:

Monday nights: Mushroom Jazz/JazidUp - a club I started a couple of years
ago, but am no longer involved in. Now at the Cat's Alley Grill on Folsom
bet. 7th & 8th. Music is always good. The crowd varies a bit. Sometimes the
vibe is great. Sometimes it pulls a slightly aggro crew of guys mainly out
to scam on the ladies.

Thurs. nights - Le Jazz Hot - Nickies bbq - 460 Haight - Thurs @ nickies is
ubiquity's night, hosted by DJ Andrew from On The One - its a blend of aj,
soul, and other funky wax

330 Ritch St. - this is a restaraunt/club in SOMA with an AJ vibe. it often
pulls kind of a yuppyish crowd - not the best place to dance, but ok for a
drink with a friend

 Bulletproof parties - Bulletproof is a clothing store on haight St. that
sponsors a Friday night party at Goldies in the 'loin. two floors, one with
aj and one usually w/ deep house. They also throw the awesome SF Boat party
one sunday each month. the next one is on Sep.24th. the boat cruises around
the bay for 4 hours and winds up at mission rock for an afterparty. on a
good day it is fully worth the $25 bucks.

-------------------

also, if your into ambient etc. check out the Gardening Club at the
Carribean zone behind DV8 on mondays. its super chill w/ an eclectc mix of
music. run by Darkhorse and my good buddy Charlie Edwards. a must...

when I finally make it to portland i'll be sure to ask you for advice,

peace & love,
ek  =o)

Whoa!  We just went through all this on the NW Raves list.  This is total
deja vu ....

Brian, I know that your intent was good and I do appreciate that you care
enough to risk posting to a public forum.  But what everyone else has been
saying here is true .... summed up,

DON'T SAY ANYTHING ON THE LIST THAT YOU WOULDN'T BE AFRAID TO YELL LOUDLY
IN THE MIDDLE OF THE ANNUAL POLICEMEN'S BALL.  :)

True, it may be hard for anyone to actually crack down and prove anything
concrete, but the fact is that ANY mention of ANY kind of drug activity
brings attention, be it "John Smith who lives at 1234 west 5th sold me some
wicked lysergic acid diethylamide and he has 100 more in his freezer" or
"someone said they saw some guy down at the beach rave who might have been
selling some gelcaps".  It's a sad fact of life in the rave community .. oh
well.

that's my $.02, anyways.

k

This is all very paranoid. First of all, "admitting" an attempt to commit a
felony is not a crime, and nothing can be done by the legal system without
evidence or even a complaint. No cop can go up to whatever car was given out
and say, "Come with me, I read on SFRaves that you've been selling fake
sweet tarts." 

Do you think the illegal activities of this scene are any mystery to anyone
anymore? Hoo wee, we'd better shut up a little bit before everyone (and
their close cop friends) finds out that ravers go to secluded spots, set up
large sound systems, take lots of drugs and dance all night. If you're clean
you have nothing to worry about when the shit goes down.

The original poster was engaging in a time tested mechanism for dealing with
these problems without going to the man. It's called street justice, which
doesn't necessarily involve pain or harsh penalties, but is a way of letting
those who might be similarly taken to be informed about the people they are
dealing with. See the new Spike Lee movie, "Clockers," which touches on this.

eh

onnow: Pretty Tony/ "It's Automatic" (Music Specialists)

At 0:26 9/19/95, Brian Darkness wrote:
>Dear Joe;
>
>        Good I hope so. No one had a problem with me doing this when I
>don't them I was Saturday, everyone said yeah go a head, we need to
>inform others about these people.
>
>        Joe, I was physically injuryed by these people who encouraged me
>to snort this stuff, my nose is still burning, why are you defending
>them, do you want them to do this to other people, or maybe they'll but
>battery acid in it next time to make it taste more chemical.
>

They injured you (attacked you, etc.) or you injured yourself by snorting
an unknown substance?

You missed my point. I'm not defending them, I'm concerned about the
ramifications of posting such detailed info about illegal activity on this
list.
Do we really need more evidence for the govt. to point to when they deride
raves as drug parties?

If you feel like they deserve to be arrested, call the cops.

Look, we've all been burned before - that's life. Would the revenge exacted
by getting these people arrested make your nose feel any better? Does that
seem like a fair trade?

In your reply to John you mentioned inadmissability of email. Uh, I doubt
some anti-drug zealot of a cop is going to ignore information that may be
legally inadmissable. He'll just look for something that is, or try and
find an outstanding warrant for instance. It would be foolish to think they
wouldn't utilize such info if presented to them.

Joe

> > I totally agree, I thought Jon's set was dope. It really got me movin. 
> > I hadn't heard that "Dance to the speaker till you hear it blow" 
> > (or words to that effect) cut in ages, but it always gets me goin. 

that track has just been repressed, so get 'em while they're still hot.
 
> Actually I always thought the SF sound to be a more straight-four type 
> of beat but with the same swing feel to it, like back when the Garth/
> Jeno axis was all that.

to be honest, i don't think there is any real "sf sound".  certainly there is 
no consensus among the music makers... but despite lack of coherency in the 
music-production scene, there is at least a resurgence of the funky break.  my 
Bass Kittens project is of course obsessed with the break, but there are also 
new discs from bassbin twins, electroliners, brain candy enterprises and 
others that are funky as hell!

there is also a lot of good stuff coming out of LA in a similar vein.  now we 
just have to figure out how to get some parties in SF where they play it!  
(i'm seriously considering starting a club night for devotees of The Funk...)

> Had there been more funky tracks like the 
> above defining the "sound" I would have gone to more massives back 
> then... 

maybe you should have gone to more massives back then... cos i used to hear 
tons of stuff like that.  where do you think i picked up such a predilection 
for it?  :)  there was a time where jeno, spun and garth were heavily into 
electro and breakbeats... check out the New Years Eve Vision Tape collection 
for evidence.

> I'm a sucka for the two-and-four, like Spun used to play before he 
> went totally housey.

oh man, what happened to Spun?  i heard him a few weeks ago at ethan's party 
and i was totally disappointed... he inspired me back in the day... now he's a 
pale shadow of his former self.  :(

-j-

I have decided I want to move to San Francisco.  Now, all that remains
is to find work.  I have a resume ready if anyone has any leads.  I am
looking for a position as a producer or coordinator of interactive or

At 15:52 9/19/95, blkadder@value.net wrote:

>This is silly. There is info about illEgal activitEs posted here on almost a
>daily basis. The government I am sure already has plenty of evidence to
>point to if they chose to do so. Hell, just go to any party. Somebody
>posts because there are people preying on members of the scene and they
>get blasted. Maybe, just maybe, the idea is to help prevent this
>happening from others. If one person sees these jerks around and isn't
>duped because they saw info here, that is one less person that got
>fucked. Oh, I forgot, no raver ever does the d word. What a bunch of
>bullshit.
>

Fine, tell your friends, don't post some person's license plate to 800
people. Who knows if the car belongs to those guys anyway?

Did these guys know they had bad E? Were they maliciously preying on the
scene, or were they just dealers who had to make their rent and got a bad
batch of e? Most dealers know much less about their product than they
purport to. Do we really know the situation and intentions here? All we
really know is Brian snorted something he bought from somebody and his nose
hurts. If there's some other evidence pointing to their malicious intent
I'll tend to believe it more than I do now - I still don't think Brian's
post was the best way to go about warning people - especially if the motive
is to prevent harm to the scene.

>> If you feel like they deserve to be arrested, call the cops.
>>
>> Look, we've all been burned before - that's life. Would the revenge exacted
>> by getting these people arrested make your nose feel any better? Does that
>> seem like a fair trade?
>
>Gee I dunno, you go around fucking generally trusting, caring people, and
>you get fucked back. Seems pretty fair to me.
>

Well damn, lets just get a mob together and string 'em up then. =/

>> In your reply to John you mentioned inadmissability of email. Uh, I doubt
>> some anti-drug zealot of a cop is going to ignore information that may be

>If this were true, then about a third of the posters here would be in prison.
>

There's a difference between "I had a grEat timE at the GathEring" and
"here's the plate number of some dealers and here's what they look like,
and here's where they were last seen."

Here's a credo that would've prevented all this in the first place:

Don't buy drugs from an unknown person, especially at parties.

Joe

Subject: The Harrassment continues
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Fuckness
--------

Now that I have talked with an attorney,  I can elaborate to some
extent on what happened to us.

For the last 3 months,  Craig,  Another friend,  and myself have occupied our
time hanging out in the Mill Valley Town Square.   This is where a number
of my clients are,  and it's nice to sit outdoors working on the computer.
We also travel with each other,  as our other friend has a reliable car.

So,  after dropping Austin at his home,  we are driving down Miller
(High pig infestation area) but fastest way home.

Craig was driving carefully,  not going too fast or breaking any traffic
laws.   Almost immediatly,  we got pulled over.   Without hesitation,  the
cop,  a mr S Luscombe,  having a thick British accent,  claimed to smell
POT in the car,  and insisted that we immediatly give him the pot.
We actually hadn't smoked anything in the car at all.  Luscombe then
went into a paranoa fit and started hassling My other friend for having a knife
in the car he used while working at Whole Foods.   Craig was Handcuffed
while the cop was going through his things.    I was in the front passenger
side,  and in the corner of my eyes,   I saw another cop staring at me.

They eventually got to me,   they demanded that I raise my hands while the
officer un-hooked my fanny pack, and dumped out the contents and said
"Whats that?",  "And That?".   Anyways,  I was charged for posession of
controlled
substances and went to court today.   The police report claimed I concented
to the search....   BULLSHIT!!

It is a high probability that we will get drug diversion.   If not,   I might
be able to hire a really good attorney.   I talked with Matt Wilson,  a friend
of Tony Serra (Famious drug lawyer).    As we talked,  he mentioned he saw me
at Burning man,  and was the one dancing with a funny hat.   Because the cops
searched US first before searching the car,    it is likely that he might get it
thrown out of court.   Police claim that the tail light plastic was cracked
and unlawful.   We took pictures of it today.   Also,  when my other friend
got his
car back from the towing yard,   the tail light fuse was blown,  and the
fuse panal looked like it had been tampered with.   I always get into the
habit of walking behind a car and saying "Blinkers left,  now right,   now
brakes".

Anyways,  they took us to Marin Co. Jail,  where Craig got put in the "Old jail"
and I got put into the New jail.   Craig and I were able to see each other ONLY
while waiting in the drunk tank or court holding areas.   On Monday,  we each
had $5000 bail.

On Tuesday,  we see judge again and got O. R.   EI:  Released with promise to
appear.

That evening,  after getting invited to watch a movie at Aaron's place,  I
walk down
the trail and steps behind my place,  through town to Aarons place on the other
side.   Just as I got to the parking lot,  a cop comes up and said "Lets
see some
ID!" and immediatly took my bum bag again and searched it.   He let me go,   but
the next day,  yet another cop did the same thing.

Then,  tonight,  on the way home,   I make a phone call,  and as me and
Craig were
at the payphone,   we got searched once again (for 4th time in less than a
week).

So,  Matt also says that it would cost $2500 to file a "Motion to suppress",
and he believes that because the police searched us first,  before searching the
car,   he thinks there is SOME chance.   I also think that this would be a very
good excuse to have a Crunch Defence fund party to raise that $2500,
because if
we win,  the police will back off.

I think that you raver folks might be in a position to really help me out.   I
propose that we try and hold a benefit rave to raise the $2500 I need for the
motion to supress the evidance,   because we think there was wrongdoing and
extra harrassment on the part of Mill Valley police,  and might be able to
convince the judge to drop the case if we get it supressed.   I'll be happy to
answer any additional questions provided that you send me your PGP key,  and
use my PGP key inclosed below when asking me questions about this,  so I've
included my PGP key and encourage anyone to please dust off your copy of PGP.
This is my encryption key,   please encrypt any Email to me, using this key.
Read docs (they explain it well).   So please add this key to your keyring.

-----BEGIN PGP PUBLIC KEY BLOCK-----
Version: 2.6.2

Crunchman

HEY PEOPLE!

Could we drop the currently running argument for just a moment and funnel
our positive energy out to those people/friends/companions who might need
it just about now.  I know that sounds all sappy and shit, and I can't go
into details at this time 'cause it ain't my place, but let me just say
that there are people who need our extra positive energy more than Brian
(and his nose) does at this moment in time.  (Sorry Brian, no offense.)

I know this is ambiguous, but do me a favor and think positive thoughts
tomorrow.

Thanks,

Tony R.

	id AA811555878; Tue, 19 Sep 95 17:12:10 PST
Date: Tue, 19 Sep 1995 18:12:10 PDT
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9508198115.AA811555878@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: Evil People On Our Scene
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
I was going to stay quiet and just follow this thread but this last message 
tweaked something inside of me.  Regardless of all the conjecture, the bottom 
line is would you incriminate a fellow raver?  I know this is carrying things a 
bit too far, in fact, Eric Hill stated that "This is all very paranoid.", but if
our e-mail was monitored and more government attention was given to the scene as
a result, what would happen to the cyberspace community that has given many of 
us joy in finding people who uphold many of the same values and interests in 
common?

Granted there are loopholes w/what's stated in e-mail and what actually happens,
but look what's happened with the AOL/child pornography case (w/r/t e-mail) or 
for that matter what's happened with the New Year's Eve AIDS fundraiser (w/r/t 
false arrests and illegal searches per Monicat's message yesterday).  

I don't know all the facts with either of the cases mentioned above, but I do 
know that not all humans are infallable and not everyone in any group is honest 
and law abiding...the government included.  I also know that we should show 
common sense and consideration of others.  (What's plur all about?)

We've learned as a group how to handle particular phone numbers and renegade 
spaces (e.g., Sunset & Full Moons) and we've seen what can happen if the scene 
grows too quickly w/o an understanding of what "raving" is all about (why don't 
_you_ go to massives anymore?).  After all, why is it that many of us don't 
subscribe to sfraves at work or that we use psuedonymns?  I don't think it's a 
far stretch for us to apply this same reasoning for personal recreations.  And 
as another brother said, "Caveat Emptor."  

So I know notifying the group was meant well by a general post, but instead of 
dragging others into a personal drama, perhaps it'd be better to spend your 
energy into building sources that won't let you down in whatever you do.

On a much brighter less preachy note, I hope y'all can make it to the Burning 
Man After-Party on Friday.  There's so much we can do as a group and this is 
just a taste of one small part of it :) 

>From one freak to another,
Diane

From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  bio from a lurker
X-Mailer: UGate [Ver. 1.94]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


You probably won't know me from parties since I haven't been out in a 
long, long time, but since I lurk and post to the list a bio may be 
appropriate:

I'm an artist. I make steel, clay, glass sculptures... big stuff. I 
also paint and draw and print. Current fascination is bookmaking and 
I've got a small rusty letterpress which I'm trying to get into working order.

For money I work as a DTP and Page Compositor for Sybex Computer 
Books, Inc. in Alameda. [I was a graphic artist and designer here 
until they did away with the Graphics department.]

Aside from making art what I like to do: hiking, spend days on the 
beach or in the woods with friends, my best frined is Evan, a 4 year 
old Boxer dog who goes almost everywhere with me. Listen to music and 
make art. LISTEN TO MUSIC AND MAKE ART! That's about it. Oh yeah, I 
like to cook fantastic meals and throw dinner parties for my friends. 
Herbal medicine & healing.Considering going to school to become a Traditional 
Chinese Medicine Doctor.
 
My Rave History: I went to an FMR a long time ago, maybe '91, at this 
swampy area somewhere south of San Francisco (I don't really remember 
where).Later that year there was a party in Bolinas near a trailhead. 
some guys with an old bus (Josh and CB...are you guys on this list 
maybe? I know a friend of yours!) threw it.
The outdoor parties I went to really influenced my life in a 
positive way. Even tho' i don't get to so many parties I still feel 
that I'm a raver at heart.I love to dance. I love trance.

Why don't I go to more parties? Basically I'm suffering a major 
depression (related to an ugly divorce) which makes me unable to snap 
out of it and get to a party (I really don't want to bring this 
downer vibe to a party!). Catch 22. A party might be the best 
medicine! And I'm really, really shy.

But whenever I *do* get to a party( I *almost* made it to F8 this 
weekend):
age:31, but look younger; Hair: Dark Brown with red/Auburn 
highlights, mid-back length; Eyes: Dark Blue; Complexion: Pale white; 
Height: 5'5"; Weight: I dunno! not skinny, not fat. Muscular 
(ex-gymnast)

My looks are kinda plain, I dress kinda plain. You wouldn't realize 
that I'm anything but a nerd until I start one of my giant, 
wide-mouth laughs and my tongue piercing catches the light, or until 
you talk to me and discover what a true freak I really am.

yikes! this should be enough!

alissa (a.k.a. A)

>Dear Joe; All;
>
>        We have credital information that SUGGESTS that these PERSON/S;
>ALLEGDELY pulled the Doc Martin/Dubtribe scam. Still want us to be quiet
>Joe, or next time you show up to spin at a event, and the people come
>looking to you for their money, only to find out that these PERSON/S, are
>no where to be found. Would you want them to be quiet about Narina to or
>is that different.
>

I'm sure Dubtribe would love that info if they don't have it already. I'm a
little lost by your second sentence there - why would anyone ask a DJ for
money, =)

Promoters throwing parties and screwing people is a little different than
drug dealers screwing people. Unfortunately both professions tend to
attract the unscrupulous. =) The difference is that in our society drug
dealing (and use) is particularly frowned upon and many will go out of
their way to stop it. Of course, it's also illegal, which could lead to
more far reaching ramifications for those accused.

Yeah, we should hear about promoters who screw people so we can avoid their
parties. As far a drug dealers screwing people? I think the potential harm
from a public post outweighs the public service of such a post. I believe
there's a lot more personal responsibility involved on the consumer's part
when buying something from an unknown dealer than when buying a ticket to a
party.

>        Everything I said hear I would shout in a policemans ball for that
>matter. You guys just don't get it, this is why despite the temenous
>edvidence against OJ he is still not been convicted yet.

Uh, he's not convicted yet because the trial's not over...=) But that's way
off-topic. =)

As far as that last post with all the personal comments, I'll let that lie
other than clarifying that my comment about 'stringing them up' was
straight up sarcasm. As a friend once pointed out, however, sarcasm doesn't
work in the dark.

Joe

Well, if this is the way it's gotta be then this is the way it's gotta be.
Turns out there are two Equinox parties happing this weekend, both in the
Sierra mountains.  They were both planned well in advance and didn't know of
each others existance til Burning Man.  You probably already heard about the
Light party that's happening, and there was a sincere attempt (I understand)
to combine the two parties into one big event.  But the promoters of the
parties couldn't come to an agreement because of some problems at BM so now
there are two camping parties happening in the Sierra's.  I'm sincerely
disappointed that some agreement could not be made, but I had nothing to do
with the negotiations.  So here's the lowdown.


ELEVATION

Saturday, Sept. 23 - Sunday, Sept. 24

Two days of dancing, drumming, camping, hiking, swimming, dreaming, living,
loving and listening.  So bring your tents and camping gear.

DJ's:  Gavin (Tweekin Records), Ted (Primal Records), Rig-a-Tony, Karizma,
Flash, Pez (Adrian), Chris Burkes, Chezbo (Marin), Phil,  Frog (performing
live).  Ambient morning: Rick 

(916) 974-8201.

$5


Hope I see you there.  And again, I'm bummed I can't go to the light party.
Why can't everyone just kiss and make up.  

Rick

> > He did play some sick breakbeat set's for the time, 
> > but two hours of sample based beats gets extremely boring and 
> > undanceable for many people. 

I can say the same thing about drumbox-based beats, which is 
unfortunately the norm.  Mixing them up is how you get people to
really go wild.  Crank the energy up, hit the breaks, then let
people down again with some smooth house.  Or, just drop
in an 8 or 16 bar break for the bridge.

I would absolutely throw a rod if Ethan (or anyone) suddenly mixed some
breaks or jungle in with their deep trance.  Hit one of those half-minute
builds, then WHAM!

Just you all wait until we get the sound studio built here at work.  If all
else fails, do it yourself >%^)

// g

> 	I trust that when all the evidence was presented I would be vindicated.

I don't.  I've seen several people slammed by it, and a couple people who
got through.  Do you feel lucky?

> I trust the system, having been through it, even if it took several appeals.

I take it that you either have a _lot_ of money to waste on lawyers or
_no_ money and don't mind rolling the dice for years of your freedom.
Either way you waste a lot of time dealing with the problem, time as
surely gone as if you had been to jail.  I'd rather spend my time living
my life and fighting the source of the problem (drug prohibition).

"There are a thousand people hacking at the branches of evil for every
one that is striking at the root" -Emerson, or maybe Thoreau

The problem I have with such an appeal to the list is basically thus:

	If you're going to "do something" about these guys, go and do it.
Don't appeal to the list and hope someone else will take the revenge that
you are afraid to take on these people.  Community justice is fine, but
what am _I_ supposed to do on your say-so?  Slash their tires?  Come on.

// g

Hi...  After talking to a number of people over the last week and kicking
ideas around,   many suggested they would support the idea of having a
benefit party to raise the funds for my legal fees.   I wouldn't think
it would be proper for me to organize it.    Is there anyone out there
with this kind of experience who could help with the organization?   Let
me know and we can take it OFF LINE and work it out.   Almost all of the
DJ's I talked to,  would be willing to spin for free.

My attorney says today,  that if I could come up with $1500,   he would
start the process of filing a motion to supress the evidence.   Today,
he advised me to fill out a citizens complaint against Steve Lucombe.
I filed it today.   I expect to get retalitory action from the police in
the form of continued harrassment,   but i'm NOT going to go away and hide.
Instead,   I'm going to be very visible in town,  as I go around selling
the idea of WEB pages for the local clientel.   Wish me luck...   Let me
know what you can do to help out with....

  * Sound system
  * DJ's
  * Venue
  * decor
  * flyers (promotion)

And anything else necessary to hold a party...   I think that we want to
shoot for $7 - $10 admission fee,   does that sound reasonable?

As we can see, trolling is ever present in this post.  All anyone was
trying to do is to let you know what damage you can do by running off at
the mouth.  Just because one has freedom of sppech does not mean that it
should be used in any fashion one wishes.  It should be used in a
responsible fashion IMO.

In any case, please feel free to do what you want, and others will feel
free to say whatever they wish back.  Consider it a consequence of having a
right such as free speech.  Please don't expect your words to go
unimpeached or unchallenged.

BTW, I still think you're quite wrong for posting your drug deal gone bad.
If it was so bad you shoulda called the cops, but you really can't do that
when you're trying to buy E and get ripped off, huh?  And if some guys are
asking about someone who put thier license plate up on the net, I'll be
sure to direct them to you.  That way you can clear up whatever
misunderstanding you have with them as it relates to dealing bad Schedule 1
drugs, ok?  Cool.

me to step out of said person's way.  I would be remiss by standing in the
way of ones scheduled fall into the pit.

To all who attended (or wanted to attend) last Friday's Frequency 8

Thank you all very much for coming (or sending your energy)
The fog never came in, the garbage was at an all-time minimum, the vibe was
TRULY excellent and a lot of sfravers really helped us keep it together -
Special thanks to Vince and Wayne for bring the laminates, and for helping
us solve our "technical" problems early in the evening.

We have been wondering if it might be a good idea to organize some sort of
event in San Francisco that would make our collective presence known to the
political "powers that be" or the current crop of wannabees in this election
year.  In my opinion, the Jordan years have not been too friendly towards
our community.  Do we think that a change of mayor could improve the current
situation, or make matters worse?  Do we think that benefits could be gained
by organizing some sort of "rave the vote" like the "rock the vote"
organizing?  Would we want to organize a benefit for a particular candidate,
or for the democratic party as a whole (since it seems more than likely that
our next mayor will be a democrat)?
Opinions?  Suggestions?

Jim Cyr

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Jim Cyr:
: We have been wondering if it might be a good idea to organize some sort of
: event in San Francisco that would make our collective presence known to the
: political "powers that be" or the current crop of wannabees in this election
: year.  In my opinion, the Jordan years have not been too friendly towards
: our community.  Do we think that a change of mayor could improve the current
: situation, or make matters worse?  Do we think that benefits could be gained
: by organizing some sort of "rave the vote" like the "rock the vote"
: organizing?  Would we want to organize a benefit for a particular candidate,
: or for the democratic party as a whole (since it seems more than likely that
: our next mayor will be a democrat)?
: Opinions?  Suggestions?

I would say, start by giving the new mayor the benefit of the doubt.
Don't immediately assume they're against you.  Write a letter summing up
some of the problems of the past, explain what we're really about, and
give some proposals for how situations can be made better.

Start a dialogue on good terms.  It's easier than waiting until it's
an "us vs them" mentality.

Dear All; 

	Opps almost forgot getting caught up in all this pissy shit. That 
Frequency 8 was last Friday. This event is what I would call a 
quintessental Northern California Rave. You can't beat the 
environment, put together by Mother Nature Herself, opps sorry Jim 
that's Father Nature. I had invited some people who where working at the 
Safeway where I shop, who had never been to rave before, and they said 
they would be back. 

	This was the largest event so far, excellent turn out, with a much
more commilcated lighting set, that had some minor problems, which I know
will be corrected next time. With a 5Kw generator you guys should have no
problems in the future, plus throw those ShitShack powerstrips into the
sea where they belong. 

	As you walked along the beach you where greeted by at least a 
dozen tee-kee torches, and some really cool lighting effects, plus some 
killer Goa Trance, that burned all night long, without fear of being 
busted, and that comes from the cops!!!!!!

	At about 3AM we were paid a visit by the Demon Raver who lives up 
in the cliffs, It came down from above with its burning green eyes to 
give us it's blessing as true children of the night.

	The best part I think is when the sun comes up and you can see 
everyone that you could really see all night long, and the smiling &
dancing faces, that's what does it for me. Plus the rocks are just too 
cool, especially if you using visiual enhancment substances.

	So when's the next one, Lynn at the diner was pissed she wasn't 
told about it Jim, but I've promised to keep her informed. See ya, and 
remember Frequency 8 For Trance.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET
		 CT Active Voice & Fax (510)-530-6452
	      CT Active Pager & Voice Mail (800)-590-4993

surfpunk @ well.com (Jim Cyr) @ smtp on 09/20/95 11:34:40 AM, writes:

"To all who attended (or wanted to attend) last Friday's Frequency 8

Thank you all very much for coming (or sending your energy)
The fog never came in, the garbage was at an all-time minimum, the vibe was
TRULY excellent and a lot of sfravers really helped us keep it together -
Special thanks to Vince and Wayne for bring the laminates, and for helping
us solve our "technical" problems early in the evening."

Jim Cyr
____________________________________________________________

*Thank You*!!!  

I had one of the best times I've ever had at a party.  I can't do it justice, 
but I thought the music was slammin', the people were way excellent vibey, and 
the scenery blew my mind.  

Just wanted to share...

When the sun came up, I was still jammin' away on my little piece of cardboard, 
fully flyin' and in a trance mode.   I realized  as I experienced the ocean, 
looking out at this blue, surreal site with it's pink foam and golden crests, 
living, breathing rocks jutting out in the sea (they certainly lived and 
breathed all night...I kept seeing them move around! ;-) ), the sun, ambiant 
sky, warmth of the vibe, and the completely peaceful feeling I experienced, 
that I had tears on my cheeks.  I held up my arms, outstretched and facing the 
world, embraced and gave thanks and praise to our Mother and Father and the 
people who make this scene so awesome.   I knew, in that moment, that I could 
die right there and I'd be totally happy, feeling only peace and love, because 
this is what *my* heaven is like.  I *know* it is.   

 It was a transcendental, truely enlightening, religious experience because 
it's changed my perception about life and death.  It left me exhausted but 
joyful, fulfilled, peaceful, full of love, and no longer fearful of what lies 
beyond.  I've heard of people having these experiences at raves...*Wow*!!!  

Way to go to all those beautiful people who made this party so special by 
showing up, picking the incredible spot, and spinning the awesome tunes.  More 
hugz to Wayne, Vince and Craig...y'all helped make it what it was...a great 
adventure and enlightening journey.

Love, Love, Love

Rikki

	id TAA10963; Wed, 20 Sep 1995 19:07:46 -0700
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 1995 19:07:46 -0700
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v0151010bac8613f83d2f@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Chiming in...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Now that that drama is over...I wanted to reflect.  Delete this now if
you're tired of John S. Lee's babble.

Warning aside, one of the things that irked me was some of the posts that
quickly suggested "...now let's move on...".  I know the diatribe and
fighting get old quickly, and everyone wants to be all lovey-dovey, and
full of good vibes and all that.  But face the grim facts.  Dealing with
humans has its good points and its bad points.  The good is that we can
share experiences.  The "bad" part is that your mileage may vary.  If in
fact this is a family, then the family must have its time to fight
occasionally.  The fighting should continue, IMO, until there is closure.
That's what being a family is all about IMO, sharing the really good times,
along with the really bad ones.  The real test is, can we still "meet" at
some point, and leave the past as a learning experience.  The long history
of SFRaves dictates, YES, we can.

Some of you want to end the fights as soon as they begin.  IMO this is
quite unnatural for humans.  We can certainly live amongst one another
without killing each other, but to deny argument, debate, strong
discussion, is to deny each of our humanity IMO.

If the family is really that strong it can survive more than a war of
opinion between its members.

So I guess I'm saying to the lot, who wanted to push this thing out into
the ether, and not be bothered with a debate amongst the siblings.  You do
have the right to close your ears, and walk away (bka the delete key), or
sit by and spectate (bka the choice of many), or become part of the debate
(bka the choice of the few).  IMO its all good.  But what seems to happen
of late is that the first group would rather not hear anything considered
confrontational by any means necessary, "...take it to e-mail!" is the cry.
I say for things that go on for a long time (like a week), maybe this is
necessary, but for short little spats like the one we witnessed, I feel
everyone can learn something from the experience.  Of course I am on the
other end of the spectrum, if I see a good fight, and beleive in the cause,
I'll jump in.  I think, that in time, we will all come to some agreement.
We have no other choice, if we truly are "family"

With that, I'm out,
Peace, Audi 5000, Quarterpounder w/ Cheese, Clocker, Docker, BootKnocker,
John

                        "Ain't nuthin' but the funk"
                                jsl@netcom.com
                          http://www.twenty-hz.com
                             the feeling of bass...

Date: Wed, 20 Sep 1995 19:48:25 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nvg8r <nvg8r@c2.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: On sunsets past...
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950920193319.3895A-100000@infinity.c2.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk




A detail latched me onto a specific memory. Years ago, during my first visit 
to the SF bay area, a local, on the corner of a street, told me the 
story, of how the bay was first discovered.
Sometimes a story has the power to create a full imaginal scenery.
This was one of them... or was I just thrown back into some distant memory?

It is not a complicated story, or a long one... rather it occupies the 
space of a single image: imagine... you and your crewmen have been 
searching, for days, maybe even weeks, for an entrance, a break in the 
coastline, one that would reveal the immense inside bay that early land 
expeditions had hinted at. Yet fog and rough seas have kept you errant, 
as if nature had decided to hide its secrets, as if 
the gateway were somehow protected. Yet you persist, endlessly. Then, 
one day, as the afternoon wears old, as the fog, which has
been your enemy, begins its relentless march and roll, you discern, vaguely at 
first, but then with increasing definition, the 
appearance of what you had been searching for. You and your crew eventually 
make it to the mythological opening, just as the sun is throwing its last 
beams over the fog wall which has kept a close pace behind the ship. And 
through the portal, during those last minutes of sunlight, is revealed 
an image, one of such beauty and meaning, that it will forever be 
imprinted on your soul: There, ahead, laid out like some medieval 
tapestry, along the horizon line where mountains meet water, burn 
hundreds of campfires, casting a peaceful glow on the surrounding mist.
Each fire indicates the presence of an indigenous family, each group of 
fires outlines the location of an indian village. And even before your 
mind has a chance to register the possibility of danger, you are stricken 
and overwhelmed by a sense of peace and wonder, beauty and harmony, as if 
the native people were displaying, one final time, the silent joy
that was their's.

That was the last sunset gathering in a long time... 

And sometimes, when we all turn around to face the west, when my hearing 
is inundated by ecstatic cheers and droning beats, sometime, just for 
the briefest of instants, I can swear that there is a tall ship
making its way through the golden gate... And I can only hope that, 
this time around, it's message is one of hope and happiness.

Hi All.  I wrote the following a little earlier this week:

> I've got news for you, the police already believe that drugs are sold at
> raves.  The only reason they don't decend in mass on a rave and bust
> everyone there is that they are too busy busting underclass blacks and
> latinos.  It's a dark truth.

It has since been politely pointed out to me that the above statement could
be misconstrued as a racist slur.  Since I am not a racist, I wish to
explain what I meant.

It has become clear to me of late that the War On Drugs has become a
mechanism to oppress the underclass, in particular the minority underclass.
This happens because the underclass is easier to bust, have no money for
defense (where's the young black man on drug charges benefit party?), and
are wrongly perceived as the cause of all our problems (rather than a
symptom).

We as ravers benifit indirectly from all this because in the eyes of the
police, we are not nearly as "bad".

I hope this makes better sense,

PT

-- 
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@sophistem.com) | http://www.cybernetix.com/~ptiger >
< Sophistem = Sophisticated Software Systems >
               Don't let a chromosome determine your gender.

From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: bio
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9509202218.A21294-0100000@netcom20>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I haven't posted in a while, due to alot of work related stuff, and 
difficulties with my computer.  Still pretty busy, but I just got a new 
computer and thought I would start posting again with a brief bio.

I'm 35 y.o., 5'7" usually about shoulder length hair.  

Grew up in N.Y. and moved to LA after getting my BA in psychology.  I now 
have an MS in counseling and been working in the psych field for 10+ years.
I currently work in a psychiatric hospitol

After going to my first rave in the bay area (freedom harvest), I started 
looking for a job near SF, and knew it was time for me to leave LA.
I've enjoyed dancing since a new wave club opened near my college in 
1980.  For me raving has taken dancing to many more levels.  Raving helps 
me get in TUNE with my mind body and spirit.  Raving has taught me alot 
about love, and the joys of sharing.  Not only is raving therapeautic for 
me, I find that it helps me in the work that I do.  Raving helps me 
relate to myself and the world around.  Actually I feel I can go on and 
on about raving.  I'll try and keep my raving about raving to a minimum 
and get back to my bio.
Been raving for about 3 years. Been on sfraves about 1 year.
Other interests include, hiking in nature, running, playing guitar, 
exploring, traveling.

I just want to add that I really appreciate everyones contribution to 
the "scene".  With alot of your help I've had some of best and incredibly 
amazing times of my life.  I used to feel sorry that I missed out on the 
sixties being a little to young to fully experience them.  I am so 
appreciative of these times. The connections that we share...I'm not sure 
how to finish this sentence as I got caught up some warm emotions.  It 
opens my heart, and not only does it help me appreciate the beat of my 
heart, it helps me appreciate the beat all our hearts make together, and 
the individual beats as well.
All this thinking about beats has given me the urge to get up and dance, 
so I'll talk to you all later.  Hope to see ya out on the dance floor.

;)
peter

On Tue, 19 Sep 1995, Brenda Brewer wrote:

> Hey groovesters -
> 
> One of my fellow Teleporters is moving to SF and looking for a similar 
> provider.  Teleport is in Portland, has 10,000 subscribers, is a very 
> grass roots orginization dedicated to hopefully bridging the gap between 
> the haves and the have-nots as far as the Internet is concerned, offering 
> discounts to non-profits adn stuff like that (boastfully beaming as a new 
> employee :-)
> 
> Any bites?
> 

	My provider costs only $40 a year and has everything except 
graphical WWW access (it uses Lynx instead) and shell accounts.  It is 
strictly dial-up access.  Email info@svpal.org or check out 
http://www.svpal.org

hope it helps!
Mike
mikeym@svpal.org

Hi Willis,

I keep getting bounced messages from your address (walrus@zoom.com). In any
case,  here's my reply:

At 1:08 AM 9/21/95, Willis Wong wrote:
>Hi Glenn, I read in your bio of your involvement with nw-raves. The bios
>are  one of the best things yet for SFRaves don't you think?

Hi Willis,  I agree about the bios, it's really given a multi-dimensional
aspect to the relationships we build on the list.  The people are more real
and closer.

>Anyways, I will be in Seattle from this Friday 9/22 through Sunday 10/1 and
>would like to check out a rave if there are any you recommend?  I'm more
>of a dancer than a talker at an event so if there's good funky groove
>I'll take it!

On the 22nd ATOI dj's Lux, Michael & Dervish will be at a party.  The info
line is: (206) 447-3432.  If you like a groove, then you should definitely
check this one out.  It will be small & intimate & vibey.

Not sure about what's going on on Saturday.  I'll check into it and let ya know.

>I notice you are on speakesy.org and I have just learned that the
>speakeasy cafe has copmuters with net access for $6 an hour or
>something?  Since I won't have a computer it would be nice to go in there
>to check mail or what... Is it very hard to get on a machine?

Definitely check out the Speakeasy.  I believe there's a membership fee
($10) and then it's $6 per hour but, I'm not sure.  Check out their page
at:   http://www.speakeasy.org/   it might have more info.  Really nice place to
hang out.  Great folks working there.  There are about a dozen text
terminals and an another 10 graphics terminals (Sun workstations).  It's
pretty easy to get on them.

Please call me when you get into town.  Perhaps we can have coffee and even
go out to the party on Friday. My number is 323-7101x3019 at work.

Peace!

Tigger
(Glenn)

Someone in sfraves sent me e-mail requesting the information below and 
unfortunately my system froze taking his post with it. :(  So rather than 
waiting...and waiting for MIS to track his e-mail address, I thought I'd just 
repost what was sent earlier.

Remember to RSVP if you come so we have a better headcount...and it'll end early
so there's still time for dancing elsewhere afterwards.

Hope to see some of you there!

Diane
     
--------------------------------------------------------------
Burning Man Afterparty
Friday, 22 September 1995 @0830pm
Apple Computer R&D Bldg. 4, the Town Hall Theatre
4 Infinite Loop, Cupertino, CA


Elise and I have quit our jobs and are working nights, 
weekends, and holidays to bring you the finest in home video 
entertainment from Nevada's beautiful Black Rock desert.  We 
are furiously editing stills and videos taken from CyberLab7, 
WBL, Team Fun, SPAZ, various web pages, and of course my camcorder.
     
Whitens the amazing Shark Car as it pulls donuts on the 
playa.  See couch surfers, and idiots (like me) parasail over 
a hard, unforgiving desert floor (splat!)  RAVE RAVE RAVE 
till dawn in the rain!  Witness the mindless destruction of 
various computing devices which would have been valued at 
millions of dollars only a couple of decades ago.  And 
finally, see the burning of a beautiful 40 story? (well, 
that's what it said on the web page) effigy of wood and neon.
     
Additionally, Weird Blinking Lights will perform 
electronic/ambient/drone music utilizing vintage analogue 
synthesizers as well as state of the art QuickTime music 
sequencing software.
     
Seating? Don't worry there's plenty!:
  The Town Hall Theatre is a facility capable of conformably 
  seating 298 primates.  It is the largest conference room at 
  Apple.
     
Food and Drink:
  Oh La La, our on-site caffeine merchant is used to feeding 
  hordes of hungry hackers and artists round the clock.  They 
  will be on hand for this event.  I have also managed to 
  procure a popcorn machine for those who are so inclined.
     
Directions.Local:
  Apple Computer is located on Saratoga - Sunnyvale Rd at 280 
  and is quite visible from the freeway.  There are off ramps 
  from both directions leading onto Saratoga.  Head toward the 
  large building with green windows to the South-East of the 
  point where the freeway and Saratoga intersect.  The entryway 
  off of Saratoga will take you to the main entrance, R&D1.  The 
  theatre is in R&D4 around the back side of campus.  Once you 
  have pulled into the main drive, turn left just in front of 
  the main entrance.  Go around until you see an entrance with 
  the number 4 in front of it.  There will be far too much 
  parking so please bring an extra car or two. ;-)  The theatre 
  is immediately to the right of the R&D4 entrance.
     
Directions.San Francisco:
  if (you take 280) 
      See Directions.Local:
  else
      See Directions.East Bay:
  endif
     
Directions.East Bay:
  If you are coming across the Bay Bridge, simply drive down 
  101 until you reach 85.  Take 85 to 280.  The first off ramp 
  is Saratoga - Sunnyvale Rd.  See Directions.Local:
  If you intercept 101 from a point East of 85, take the 
  Mathilda off ramp South and keep driving past El Camino till 
  you reach 280.  Apple will be across the freeway and to your 
  left.  See Directions.Local:
     
Directions.Los Angeles:
  Assuming you people don't fly (Reno Air would be best) , you can 
  always drive like idiots up *the 5!  Take Diane's Lexus, she 
  won't mind.:-)  I have recently discovered that speeds in excess 
  of 110mph can be sustained without attracting the attention 
  of law enforcement if done after dark (Maxima, the ultimate 
  flying machine!).  
  But seriously, please RSVP as I am providing crash space for 
  the LA contingent.  Bring sleeping bags and such.  The house 
  is quite empty and I have plenty of floor space as I have not 
  yet purchased furniture.
  ( * You will be pegged as an Angelino if you say things like 
  "*the* 5", or refer to 101 as "the Ventura freeway").
     
Volunteers, Apple Employees:
  I will need an Apple employee to man the main entry.  
  Security will not allow us to prop this door open.  Please do 
  not allow people beyond the R&D4 inner airlock as the immune 
  systems of our friends are not accustom to the strange 
  atmosphere within Main Campus.
     
Warning(s), PLEASE READ:
  Please clean up after yourselves.  It took weeks to clean up 
  after that Jittlov thing last winter and I will not have a 
  repeat of that.  We must leave the theatre as it was and I am 
  not your mother!
     
  The theatre is *supposed to be* isolated from the rest of 
  campus.  But if you *do* find a way, please don't go beyond 
  the inner doors of the R&D4 building.  I have been warned on 
  three separate occasions that if *any* non-Apple being is 
  found lurking anywhere on the rest of campus unescorted I 
  will never be allowed to hold an event like this again, so 
  please...!
     
Communication:
  Please title all replies regarding this event with 
  RSVP BMan: (foo)
  and send to nozefngr@apple.com
  Now watch, I'll get a whole bunch of "RSVP BMan: (foo)".
     
  RSVPs would be nice.  Oh La La would like to know how much 
  caffeine and goodies to crank out.  They would like to know 
  by about the middle of next week.
     
  If you need to contact me by phone:
  1 800 680 7351 (pager) or
  1 408 862 2931 (Apple voicemail, this will activate pager)
     
     
This will be an extremely fun event.  We who participated in  
Burning Man will have a wonderful opportunity to share our 
experience with our friends.
     
See y'all at the movies!!
     
-Chris
     
     
..........................................................

[f n g r]  Tomorrow's leaders are busy Tonight!
     
romantics
  move
mountains

If you don't have access to the calendar for some reason, or you want to
help me pick up info :), here are my personal top 10 places to pick up 
flyers for events (no particular order):
1. Come/Unity
2. Ameba
3. Housewares
4. Tweekin' Records
5. Bulletproof
6. BPM Record Factory
7. Behind the Post Office
8. X-Large
9. Simply Done
10. Groove Merchant

Most of them are near the Haight, which seems to be the most heavily
flyered and is also near where I live :).

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

 From A Special Person On Our List, To Me; To Special To Keep To Myself; 
So I Share It With You
	
	Poetry, To Often Unheard:

Peace and love - so hard to achieve, but still we try!  And the
more we try, the more we see that they're not held up high, out of
reach.  They're only distant if that's how we imagine them...and if
we imagine them too distant - it makes it so difficult to BELIEVE.

Sin;
Brian Darkness

	id CAA22912; Fri, 22 Sep 1995 02:42:07 -0700
Date: Fri, 22 Sep 1995 02:42:07 -0700
Message-Id: <199509220942.CAA22912@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reza@uclink.berkeley.edu (Gateway Systems)
Subject: Light Family Campout Directions 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This Friday Sept.22nd-24th is the Light Family Campout! We have a beautiful
location in the mountians about three and a half hours away from S.F.  Music 
will start Fri. night between 10-11pm and are encouraging everyone to try to
arrive before midnight.  Should you plan to attend you will need to bring
with you your own water supply for the weekend (there is no running water),
food, warm clothes for the night time, sunblock and shorts for the daytime.
The elevation is aroun 6600 ft. so star gazing should be quite spectacular.
The camp area itself lies on the peak area in what used to be one of the
main stagecoach roads durring the gold rush days.  We are encouraging the
ambient meditation    on Saturday evening for everyone with your guide
Darkhorse.  Please feel free to bring any type of creative exchange - books,
paints, beads, toys, games whatever!  This is an opportunity to make closer
friends and grow.  There will     be a locally guided hike to indian sacred
cliffs and to a creek for a swim! The final line up for Fri. night is Joe
Rice, Minor Minor, Phil Smart, James Dee, and Monte ambient morning with
Darkhorse.  Saturdays line up includes Ethan, John Carel, Ted, Rob Doten and
Ambient with Jason.  We will be asking for a seven dollar donation for the
weekend to cover the costs of transportation etc. Any extra profits will
benefit a local small (pop. 17) town called Forest that is working at
rebuilding their community in a ecologically safe manner! Directions are:
Take Hwy. 80 E (Reno) past Sacramento.  Just in Auburn EXIT HWY 49
Go LEFT on HWY 49. (there will be a bright orange arrow sign to guide you)
Go THRU Nevada City. Hwy 49 splits just past Nevada City so Make
a LEFT TURN to stay on 49. (there will also be a orange sign) From that turn
go up 49 for about 19 miles. You will make a RIGHT on RIDGE ROAD.      (look
for orange sign) Go up Ridge Road 18 miles. You will pass a fire station
then a school on your left. Yes, you are in the right place. You will be
making a left turn and an immediate right to stay on Ridge road. There are
signs so look for them !  From that little intersection go up four miles and
look for a left turn onto a dirt road.  There is a cattle shute on the
corner with signs!  Go Slowly down the dirt road for it creates lots of
dust!  There will be signs to guide you safely to camp and possibly someone
to greet you depending on when you arrive.  
 OK, that should get you there.  Please don't forget water, food , warm
clothes, your big smile, and a flashlight!!! See you soon! 
FEEL IT - LOVE      -Gateway Systems!

From CallWest@aol.com Tue Sep 19 05:23:49 1995

Hey Jon.  Obviously I lied about getting this to you over the weekend.  Why
does everything take longer than you plan?  Anyway here's a fairly lengthly
blurb about the picnic.  Would appreciate your passing it along to anyone you
think might be interested.  It's shaping up to be a pretty good show.  The
boys from Rebus say they will be showing some java on their pc's. Will look
forward to seeing you this weekend.  Lee

FOOD, FROLIC AND HI-TECH FUN
AT MARIN'S SECOND ANNUAL ELECTRONIC PICNIC

Novato CA, September 18, 1995 -- Showcasing the North Bay's hi-tech
superscene, Digital Village's upcoming Electronic Picnic will be an
exhilarating experience for kids, their parents and multimedia pros alike. 

Festivities kick-off Friday night, September 22, at 6:30 pm with a Blues
Bar-B-Q reception and concert at Digital Village, which is located at the
College of Marin's Indian Valley campus in Novato. To the world beat music of
the Bay Area's legendary Haunted by Waters, picnic goers will enjoy a hearty
spread followed by the presentation of industry achievement awards to
Autodesk for their pioneering work in creating internship opportunities for
young people, to MIDAS for launching Marin County's new community internet
connection, http://marin.org, and to Mickey Mantle of Broderbund Software for
his efforts towards bringing Marin into the digital world.  Michael Moon from
Gistics will be the digital impresario for the event.  More music will follow
the awards ceremony. Admission to the Blues Bar-B-Q is $10 with advance
reservations and $15 at the door.

The fun continues at the Village on Saturday, September 23 with a hi-tech
play day for adults and kids from 10 am to 5 pm.  Admission is free for
children under age 12 and $7 for everyone else.

Spanning the beautiful wooded campus, the displays and demonstrations offer
something for everyone.  At the Learning Pavilion in a large tent in the
center of the campus picnickers can play with the latest games and
edutainment CD ROMs from Broderbund, LucasArts, and other Bay Area developers
both large and small, and see demonstrations of multimedia tools. They can
also smoosh their faces at the "Rubber Faces" booth or disguise their voices
at the "Audio Funhouse," and enjoy a showcase of multimedia developed by
students ages 5 to 18.

On-line virtual worlds will beckon to picnic goers from inside the
Internet/VR center, where Autodesk's team of student interns will lead 3D
tours of Digital Village's proposed New Media Center. There will be stations
for surfing the Internet, shared online workspaces, and demonstrations of new
applications utilizing Sun's Hot Java and VRML.

Particularly mind-warping will be the premiere of a revolutionary technology
developed by Japan's NTT using graphics technology available from Sense 8
corporation in Mill Valley.  This cutting-edge technology creates a
multi-sensory, multi-participant environment which users can enter through a
video camera perched on their computers!

More games, exhibits, and displays can be found throughout the Miwok cluster,
where picnickers will also be able to attend a series of showcase
presentations and panel discussions with some of the industry's most
experienced players.  On-line consultant Hank Duderstadt will take visitors
on a guided tour of cyberspace, while innovators such as Michael Evans,
specialist in high-end graphics development at ActivEyes, and Sheila Walsh of
Sense 8, makers of the industry-standard World Tool Kit, will present videos
of virtual world magic.  

Executives from Mindscape, InSearch, LucasArts and Zen Systems will address
Careers in Multimedia.  Sherry Miller, creator of SherryArt.com, a WWW site
"where art and technology meet," will host a panel about women on-line,
including Women's Wire founder Nancy Rhine.  Elana Rosen from Just Think
Foundation will tackle the topic of Teaching Children Media Literacy.

The magic of 3D animation will be on display at an 11 am panel featuring the
work of four leading animators -- Trish Schutz from Industrial Light and
Magic ("Casper"), Hal Hickel and Colin Brady from Pixar ("Toy Story"), and
William Opdyke of Colossal Pictures, who will discuss their craft and the
latest developments in computer graphics/animation.  At 3pm Bob Hone from
Redhill Studios will make a special presentation of his award-winning kiosk
Seeing Time".

Picnickers are invited to bring a blanket, and take a break from the creative
storm with a picnic in the sunshine (food and drinks will be plentiful), and
enjoy more of that neo-pagan ethno-electro music from Haunted by Waters.

Sponsors for the event include Autodesk, Broderbund, Frank Howard Allen
Realtors, Bank of Marin, Bay Area Multimedia Partnership, North Bay
Multimedia Association, Softech, the Valis Group, Equilibriuim, Island
Graphics, Marin County Fair, Memory Chips, Marin County Office of Education,
New Media Learning Center, JAIMS, and All American Printing. 

Digital Village, established in 1994, offers classes in new media and is
developing a community of multimedia businesses, practitioners and students
who share creativity and resources. Profits from the Electronic Picnic will
go towards the development of a New Media Resource Center at Digital Village.

For more information or reservations contact Laurie Vermont or Lee Callister
at 415/883-0792 or epicnic@aol.com.  Info is also available on the Intenet at
http://www.nbn.com/digiville/picnic.

    ###

First of all, thanks for all the enthusiastic requests for my tape, 
coming from as far as San Diego, Reno, and Vancouver (isn't this *SF* 
raves? ;).  I've been busy copying them, one by one, and cutting and pasting 
the insert and labeling.  This has been quite a project!

Anyway, there are lots of people who requested the tape who live in the 
SF area, so rather than sending them all, I've decided to leave a bunch 
of them for people to pick up in SF, either at Soundworks on Valencia, or 
at a flower shop on Church St. where my girlfriend works.  I should have 
the final details sometime in the next few days.  Stay tuned!

Howzit all y'all lovely people?!

     Name's Jason Sneed, aka chameleon...usually wearing a baseball cap 
with a white swirly-thingy on it or a black & white checkered 20's-style 
cap. Six foot, 24, Libra, Pro-caffeine.
     I was born and raised in the Bay 
Area, but ended up travelling a lot as a youngster (Pops works for the 
airlines)...
     I stumbled upon my first rave in London, although it took me a few 
years to figure out (oh, that's what that was!) I've since found that 
there is no other celebration ritual that inspires the same ancient bliss 
as the raves...
     I graduated from UC Davis with a BA: International Relations, World 
Resources and Environment...and immediately began a job inspecting ship 
cargoes in Bay Area Ports, 24 hours on-call via pager.  This ended up as 
a great way to experience the SF after-hours scene; i bought a laptop and 
started freelance writing at Coit Tower, watching the ships' movement 
through the Bay and waiting for pages.
     After six months of this, my brother (optik) and i left on a 
cross-country trip to explore nature, art and rave culture...equipped 
with laptop, national pager, 35 mm, internet account and tiki 
torches.  
Our friend james (eyeq) forwarded 'net-researched leads as we travelled; we 
accessed our account through local servers in cities across the nation. 
The friendships and experiences we had were so incredible that we're 
planning a second voyage, this time N/S from Santa Barbara to Vancouver.
     For now i'll be stickin' around in beloved San Francisco, developing 
Constant Synthesis Project, a new media publishing network based on 
contributions from artists and friends made during these excursions.  I 
would love to meet all the funky people on sfraves...i don't get too 
"social" at parties, because i -don't-stop-dan-cing- *8)...call me up and 
we'll get a cup!

take it easy

jason (chameleon)
csp94@netcom.com
1.800.sky.page; 289.2010#
http://www.sanctuary.com/haven/consynpro
415.773.9126
41 sutter #1166 sf ca 94104
constant synthesis project

"nine yards, four corners"

        http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/

Of special interest is the Title 21 section "Food and Drugs"

contains a list of all the "Schedule I" through "Schedule 5" controlled
substances.

Seeing as I lived so close to the location of "Hijacked", I decided to take
a look at what was going there. It was located in San Francisco's China
Basic/Lower Potrero Hill at the end of 24th street, just past Illinois, at
a small park that looked at the bay. For those of you that are not
familiar, that neighborhood is very industrial, kinda scummy, and where
people live in their vans down by the water. (yes, I actually live about 4
blocks away at 20th Street.) There were a few of those 'vans down by the
water', and there were a bunch of young people hanging around, all sucking
on balloons full of nitrous. I think that they were waiting for the sound
system to show up. I stayed around for less then 5 minutes and left. The
'sound system' at that time was a boom box sitting on top of a pickup's
camper shell. This was around 2am, and I just figured that the real sound
system had not shown up yet. Around 4am, I figured that if there were a
party there, it would be in full swing. I hopped into my car and drove the
4 blocks back down there. Nothing left of a party but the people in their
vans and a pile of used balloons right where the pickup was parked that had
the nitrous tank.
