From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 25 11:16:59 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA06708; Mon, 25 Sep 1995 11:16:59 -0700
Received: from firewall.island.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA06696; Mon, 25 Sep 1995 11:16:55 -0700
Received: (from daemon@localhost) by firewall.island.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) id LAA02862 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 25 Sep 1995 11:21:57 -0700
Received: from island.island.com(199.4.85.1) by firewall via smap (V1.3mjr)
	id sma002857; Mon Sep 25 11:21:05 1995
Received: from hokkaido.island.com by island.com (5.0/SMI-SVR4)
	id AA03272; Mon, 25 Sep 1995 11:16:00 +0800
Received: by hokkaido.island.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA06517; Mon, 25 Sep 95 11:15:59 PDT
Date: Mon, 25 Sep 95 11:15:59 PDT
From: peter@island.com (Peter Jones)
Message-Id: <9509251815.AA06517@hokkaido.island.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ecstasy and Death
content-length: 8308
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

    My son, Morgan Jones, then a sophomore at UC Santa Cruz, died 
from the effects of Ecstasy (MDMA, MethyleneDioxyMethAmphethamine)
on April 1, 1995.  He had gone to a rave in San Francisco at which
he bought and ingested two Ecstasy tables (about half an hour apart), 
at about 4:30 a.m.  He began to feel sick at the rave, and then 
returned to the house of a friend in Marin County.  He lost
consciousness about 9:00 a.m. and was pronounced dead at Marin 
General Hospital at about 11:00 a.m.

    There are lessons to be learned from his death.

    You can die from a relatively low dose of Ecstasy.  There were 
two autopsies performed on Morgan, one by the Marin County Coroner, 
and one by a private pathologist.  The Marin County Coroner attributed 
Morgan's death to "cardiac dysrhythmia due to idiosyncratic drug 
reaction." The blood test commissioned by the Coroner found that 
there were 0.56 milligrams per liter of amphetamines in Morgan's blood, 
of which almost all (0.54 MG/L) was MDA and a very small amount 
(0.02 MG/L) was MDMA. The private pathologist attributed Morgan's 
death to "acute MDMA and alcohol intoxication." The blood test he 
commissioned found .58 MG/L of amphetamines, all judged to be MDMA, 
and .05 (units not given) of alcohol.  The blood test commissioned 
by the Coroner found no alcohol.

    There is a great deal of variation among individuals in the
level at which MDMA becomes toxic.  Steven B. Karch, in "The
Pathology of Drug Abuse," (CRC Press, 1993, p. 211) reports that 
"There appears to be tremendous overlap between recreational and 
toxic levels.  In seven patients who died of MDMA toxicity, blood 
levels ranged from from 110 ng/mL (.110 mg/L) to 1260 ng/mL (1.26 mg/L).
Levels in five patients who survived serious bouts of toxicity were
from 200 to 970 ng (from .200 to .970 mg/L), while levels in five
car-accident victims were from 50 to 340 ng/mL (.05 to .34 mg/L)." 
So one person's recreational dose can another's fatal dose.  There
is no way to find your own limit except to die.

    MDMA has adverse side effects short of death.  The full extent
of these is not yet known.  The San Jose Mercury News reported on
Sept. 5 that "U.S. researchers have found new evidence that the
rave-scene drug 'Ecstasy' could cause permanent brain damage 
leading to mood disturbances, a report in the New Scientist 
magazine said Thursday.  A team of scientists at Johns Hopkins
University in Baltimore, led by George Ricaurte, found that monkey
and rat cells damaged by Ecstasy regrow abnormally."

    You cannot and must not depend on biased information sites,
such as the Web site at hyperreal.com (http://hyperreal.com/
drugs/mdma/) for information about the risks of MDMA or of
other drugs.  The hyperreal.com site carries an incomplete
and unrepresentative set of scholarly (medical and pharmaceutical)
articles on MDMA and other drugs.  It does not carry, for 
example, Steven Karch's book cited above.  My son had had a 
prior bad experience with MDMA and was apparently worried
about it.  He sought information which from which he could
decide whether to continue to take MDMA. He read the articles 
at hyperreal.com and other Web sites (I have a record of the Web 
sites he logged in to) and from them got a false sense of security 
about his continued use of MDMA.  

    You should beware of immoderate or overly enthusiastic
claims for the benefits of drugs, and you should be particularly
skeptical of the claims of the MDMA promoters.  The most venal
of the latter, such as Fraser Clark, Bruce Eisner and Nicholas
Saunders seem to be keeping a low profile recently, but they or 
their ilk will return.  Ask what any proponent of MDMA stands 
to gain from his or her advocacy.

    You should try to be sophisticated and mature in looking
for the signs of addiction or dependence in yourselves and in
your friends.  One such sign, which I have seen far too much
of in the sfraves group, is an unwillingness to accept evidence 
about the risks of drugs.  Morgan subscribed to sfraves,
and when his mother and I went down to Santa Cruz to pick 
up his effects we found that there was waiting on his e-mail
account a truly nauseating collection of e-mails about his own 
death.  Their gist was either that the news was false, or that 
his death must have been an aberration due to some carelessness 
on his part.  It was neither.  He did die.  He was no more care-
less than tens of thousands of other young people who take MDMA
regularly.  He just died.  The drug killed him.

    Interest groups such as the rave group can become clannish
and self-congratulatory.  When that happens misinformation
is amplified and perpetuated.  Seek advice and guidance from 
people outside of your own group.  Get some feedback about what 
you are up to.  There are lots of old hippies around, many with 
their own interesting drug experiences from the 60s, who could tell 
you a thing or two.  Speak to your professor, physician or minister.  
Reach out and check things out.

    I am 51 years old.  I think that my generation has not done
well in teaching the next generation about drugs.  I think the
problem is that we are so worried about the dangers of drugs
that we speak untruthfully about the attractions of drugs.
We talk about drugs as if they were sinister, and as if whatever
attraction they had was inconsequential or flawed or unreal
or unimportant.  From my own personal experience with drugs
(alcohol, marijuana, nicotine, caffeine) it seems to me that the
truth is very different.  The appeal of drugs is not trivial,
sinister or insubstantial.  It is the exact opposite.  The
nicotine addict, for example, feels more centered, more true
to himself or herself, more like the real person, when smoking than
when not.  I am sure that this sort of feeling is true of many
other drugs:  you feel more spiritual with the drug than without;
you feel that you have found something about your deep inner
self that you previously did not know.

   The main message at the hyperreal MDMA site 
(http://hyperreal.com/drugs/mdma/), attributed to Brett 
(phase@grove.ufl.edu) describes this kind of attraction very well:

   "Ecstasy is not a 'happy drug'.  It by itself does not do anything.
    That 00 gelatin capsule you bought from this guy your good friend
    knows... with bitter crystalline power in the bottom of it... does
    not contain any warmth, joy, wisdom, or experience. It contains
    a salt of millions of rather simple organic molecules.  All
    identical.  The ecstasy and joy come from within YOU.  That is
    your natural, instinctive consciousness when you aren't
    poisoning yourself with fears, hangups, and stress.  It is a 
    glimpse of the true empathy, calm wisdom and energy you possess
    when you are living HERE, and NOW... not based on the past,
    future and fear.  MDMA is a chemical key to the paradise within
    each of us."

    I have not taken Ecstasy but from what I have read, including
a short story by Morgan, I don't doubt for a minute that Brett's
statement is accurate. 

    When young people discover for the first time this sort of
appeal in a recreational drug they feel that they have been tricked 
by their elders: the drug seems to have opened a door into a spiritual 
world, and no one told them this could be true!  Their elders are 
hypocritical to have hidden this.

    What I wish is that my generation could teach not how bad
drugs are but how GOOD they are; i.e., how deeply appealing they
are.  So that no young person would be surprised to find this out
for himself or herself from personal experience.  The truth will set 
you free.  And the truth about drugs is that they are to be avoided 
not because they are sinister, but because their attractions come 
with truly awful risks of death, injury, disability or other 
permanent suffering.

    I wish for each of you what is within your grasp: the chance 
for a long and productive and spiritually fulfilling life.  I hope 
that you will take some extra effort to be sure that you come to a 
well-informed, considerate and personal evaluation of just how (or 
whether) recreational drugs should fit into this life.

Peter R. Jones
138 Hawthorne Ave.
Larkspur, Ca. 94939
415-927-7647
peter@island.com

Sept. 25, 1995

Feeling a little too sick to be outdoors and it being a longer 
while since I've played with lasers, I decided to try Thunderground,
in all it's "ultimate rave experience" glory.  I was expecting 
commercialized inexperienced vibe and cheese and was ready for it,
and you know what, I had just a fabulous night.  The sound system was 
loud and not very good, but the visuals and the music were great.
There was some jungle and some fast trance.  The only person I saw there
that I recognized was Carlos who had relentless energy.  But it gave
Cathy and I a chance to see new faces, and watch some of these new young
kids who dance like a firestorm.  I don't think that I've danced quite
that hard and long since Freedom.  So, it was refreshing and wonderful.
It was a good reminder that there is the most awesome vibe at every single
party, you just have to let yourself be open enough to listen to it.  
It all begins and ends with you.

So, I wish everyone a week full of such a powerful vibe.

be seeing you,
-john.

In-Reply-To: <9509251815.AA06517@hokkaido.island.com>

Precedence: bulk




   Firstly, I would like to say that there are many things in this 
post that I agree with, most notably the emphasis on getting 
information/education outside of one's social circle.
   From experience, I have noticed that groups tend, naturally,
to develop their own views and value systems, that have varying
degrees of similitude to or variance from the perceived societal norms.
It seems that these systems of meaning can become locked and self-referential,
when the flow of new information into the group's collective gets
thwarted for the sole reason of superficially not fitting in.
   I honestly have no idea whether or not the rave community has become
fixed in this way, but this post does remind me that such a danger
exists, and that being conscious of it would be the first step towards
avoiding problems. A specific example would be to not rely on
hyperreal.com for the last word regarding drug toxicity, something which,
we are apparently *already* doing, if I correctly remember the thread on E
from a few weeks ago, where outside sources on research *were* quoted. So 
I think that it would be in order to _again_ encourage every individual 
to do their _own_ personal research, especially around subjects as serious
as drug use.

Secondly, I think that it is ludicrous to use the problems associated 
with X as a marker for the general state of affairs on the safety/danger of 
drugs. To plug in the concepts put forth by Terence McKenna, many "natural" 
substances, which have been taken by indigenous people for 
centuries/millenia, have long track records of use; and we can thus
be fairly certain as to the relatively safety of some of these plants, 
especially  when they are consumed within the limits implied by the 
traditions in question. Again, individual research is in order. 
As for the recently created synthetics, we are faced with the choice of
either waiting for a full bio-chemical understanding of their actions and
toxicity on the body, or of using them now, and slowly building our own
"track record", and in so doing, also understanding, and taking
responsibility for the fact, that such usage is possibly very dangerous.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 25 13:47:22 1995

From: "Lamont, Ivan" <ilamont@visa.com>
To: Peter Jones <peter@island.com>

Subject: Ecstacy and Alcohol and Death
Date: Mon, 25 Sep 95 13:45:00 PDT
Encoding: 91 TEXT
X-Mailer: Microsoft Mail V3.0

Precedence: bulk



Dear Mr Jones,

I think I speak for all of those on the SFRaves list when I say that we are 
truly sorry to hear of your sons death.  I was not part of the list at the 
time the incident occurred, nor was I part of the rave scene here at the 
time, so you will understand that this is new to me and probably many others 
on the list.

There are a few points which I feel should be made in response to your 
posting.  You gave as a subject line "Ecstacy and Death", and I think 
perhaps this is incomplete.  The details which you supplied show a slightly 
different side to the story - Ecstacy and alcohol are a lethal mixture which 
should be avoided at all costs.

I started going to raves in London, England and in Dublin, Ireland, where 
alcohol use and abuse are commonplace.  A considerable number of deaths 
occur each year there from alcohol poisoning and from driving under the 
influence of this drug, although little media coverage is given to this fact 
due to its legal status.  It is considered reckless behaviour to drink to 
excess, and society sees it as the responsibility of each individual to 
ensure that they do not harm themselves by using alcohol.

There have also in the last ten years been a number of deaths related to 
ecstacy in Britain and Ireland - unfortunately I have no statistics 
available on precise numbers.  However, I recall from all of the news 
stories I read about these incidents, that a very large proportion of the 
deaths involved the simoultaneous use of alcohol.  I am not saying that all 
ecstacy related deaths involve alcohol, but at least a large proportion of 
them appear to.  Being a newcomer to the Northern California rave scene, I 
do not know if there are or have been any similar cases here.  If there are, 
then you will probably know what I am talking about.

My next point I think is very close to what you said about drugs being too 
good to persuade people not to use them;

We, the people, ain't stupid.  We know drugs are dangerous.  We know it's 
possible to get very seriously injured or killed by taking drugs.  We want 
to educate ourselves as much as is possible before deciding whether or not 
to take certain substances.  We openly welcome postings such as yours;  you 
remind us that we are walking a very fine line, and that it is our 
responsibility to ensure that we don't fall down.  We must be contantly 
aware that it is possible to make false assumptions based on inaccurate or 
incomplete information.

Western society generally accepts that alcohol is a fairly safe drug.  In 
some places, it gets such good press that it isn't classified as a drug at 
all.  The fact remains however that it is a drug, that it is responsible for 
many many deaths and that it must be treated with care.  I know from 
personal experience that (at home in Ireland at least) there is a high level 
of awareness that ecstacy and alcohol should never ever ever be mixed.  I 
tried to buy an E in a club in Dublin, I had a pint of Guinness in my hand 
and the dealer wouldn't give it to me.  No way, he said, lethal coctail, 
doesn't matter how much I offer, forget it.  Blood alcohol level must be 
0.000 ppm or he wasn't parting with the stuff.  Now _that_ was a caring 
dealer and I think only ecstacy helps you care like that.

There may not be such a high level of coctail toxicity awareness here.  If 
there isn't there certainly should be;  what you point out about different 
toxicity levels for different people is very true.  Just because you see 
someone on ecstacy with a beer in their hand dancing around doesn't mean 
that if you do the same thing you'll be safe.  It does mean that what they 
are doing is dangerous, and that if you do it too you're taking your life in 
your hands.  That's not to say that ecstacy on its own won't kill you 
either.  It might.  I don't know directly of any such cases.  If anyone does 
please let me know.  I wanna educate myself and those I care about.

There may be some small political point here that I would like to touch 
upon:  I feel, as do many other SFRavers, that use of ecstacy should be 
legalised, controlled and monitored.  I don't like big drug companies, but 
they do have very high quality control standards.  And I object to 
governments telling me that I shouldn't alter my mood or state of 
conciousness, based on decisions made by people who are not involved with 
the use of these drugs.  We are exploring a realm of human function that our 
leaders choose to ignore.  There is nothing morally wrong with wanting to 
temporarily change the way your brain functions.

Right, that's all I wanted to say.  I hope that the tragedy that occurred to 
Morgan and to your family is never repeated, I hope that open and frank 
discussion of the dangers of drug abuse helps people be aware of what they 
are doing when they do it, and finally I hope that the pain of the loss of 
Morgan eases with our sharing of your grief.

Again, my sincerest condolences,

Ivan Lamont    <ilamont@msn.com>





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 25 13:49:34 1995

Subject: New Moon 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 25 Sep 1995 13:49:27 -0700 (PDT)

hi everybody!

sat night we had a new moon gathering out in bolinas at a beautiful house 
close to the ocean.  all night long you could hear the waves- even though 
the house was a ways from the shore.

J. and R. who live there were kind enough to extend their housewarming 
party into the night to allow those arriving late for the NM to spend 
some time in the company of friends and listen to some beautiful music.  
the house and surroundings are absolutely beautiful, and everyone that 
was there was affected by the grace and beauty J. and R. have created there.

all except for one person, a friend of mine, who went out of his head for 
a while and had to be comforted through the night.  

THIS IS A WARNING TO ALL OF YOU:  Some people REALLY DO have chemical 
imbalances in their brains and are even taking medicine for this.  If 
someone like that has a bad reaction to something, it's very possible 
that whatever that person gets when taken to an emergency room could make 
the problem worse, not better.  

My friend could have died.  The 
seriousness of what could have happened has completely transformed my 
feelings about recreational or instructional or spiritual use of 
you-know-what.

Anyway, I had thought I'd seen everything, and now I know that's not even 
close to being true.  

If someone "freaks out" on something YOU gave him...if that someone hurts 
himself- by smashing a window, stumbling around outdoors, etc.- then 
guess who that person's family and friends are going to come looking for 
after it's all over.  So please, please, please be careful and control 
what happens to what passes through your hands.

I wanted to share this with you in hopes it will avert some potential 
suffering.

Yours,

Anthrax

  <Rikki.Kiefer@sybase.com>

You have my deepest sympathies for the loss of your son.

Thank you for your message.   It was written in the spirit of caring, 
understanding human behavior, and wanting to share information instead of being 
self-righteous and preachy.   I think that approach is much more effective and 
I will heed your words.  

Unfortunately, the government needs to realize that there is this incredible 
appeal about drugs...they *feel* awesome and they're fun.  Cramming how bad 
they are down children's throats doesn't do a damn thing and, as you said, only 
makes them distrustful and angry they've been misinformed when they do try 
drugs.  Therefore...they rebel and sometimes engage in hazardous behavior.

I wish the government would just get over the fact that drugs are an inherent 
part of people's behavior used to enhance feelings, spiritual awareness, or 
used just for escape from the daily grind.  When will they wake up and stop 
denying that cultures, since the beginning of time, have used drugs as part of 
their religion, relaxation, medicinal, sexual practices, etc.  These drugs were 
regulated to the best of the culture's ability and they suffered very few, 
irresponsible deaths as a result.  *And*, because they were regulated and 
acceptable, it was socially *unacceptable* to abuse them or act in 
inappropriate ways when using them.  

However, as massive consumers of alcohol(for example), Americans have the worst 
fatality rate from alcohol related deaths due to disease, car accidents, 
domestic violence, gun wounds, beatings, stabbings, etc., than any other 
country; however, there are other countries that consume far more alcohol per 
capita than America, but...they don't have the alcohol related problems we do 
because, even though it is okay and even encouraged to drink, acting drunk or 
grossly irresponsible is simply *not* socially acceptable and as a result, 
penalties are very, very stiff and you become an outcast if you cross that 
line.  (This also brings up America's problem with community...we don't have 
one, so everybody acts autonomously and avoids judgement because they don't 
have a smaller social structure to govern their behavior)  In close knit 
communities and cultures, you didn't fuck up because *everybody* would find out 
and you'd be a complete outcast and banned from the group. 

Since when can they deny the use and pleasures of a drug such as MDMA (a drug 
that enhances feelings of love, peace and security *and* leaves most of your 
judgement entact) when they go on cranking out alcohol and tobacco!?, which are 
responsible for more horribly violent *and preventable* deaths than *any* other 
drug!!!  I think it's a travesty that even after *all* the proof that alcohol 
and cigarettes kill, it's still acceptable.  Alcohol, when abused, can often 
make people violent, angry, depressed and can lead to dangerous if not fatal 
behavior... yet the government doesn't want people on a drug that helps them 
feel happy, loving, peaceful, secure!?  Is it just me or does this logic seem 
incredibly flawed???   Granted, the ability to feel all those things resides in 
you already, but who cares if you have the ability to feel these things when 
the fact is, society is so hung up on *everything* that it would be virtually 
impossible to create and show those feelings au natural.  

My point is, if they would just educated and regulate, people could go on 
enjoying drugs (like they have since the beginning of time) *and* acting 
responsibly because the drugs would be safe and there would be support for 
using them appropriately.  Everything in moderation and under the right 
circumstances to foster positive drug use...because, let's face it folks, 
people are going to continue to use drugs *no matter what* so you might as well 
make them safe, educate about them and make sure that if abused, there will be 
serious repercussions.   I believe drugs are the vehicle not the destination, 
and when people lighten up, set some safe standards and establish what 
*exactly* these drugs do and how to take them safely, you will have more 
liberated minds, far less crime, a significantly reduced prison population, 
fewer unwanted babies, better medicine and a more socially responsible culture 
and a *whole* lot more money saved that the government can use towards 
education, health care, etc., etc.

I'm not talking about approval of all drugs...I don't approve of any drugs that 
cause proven, drastic negative behavioral changes with prolonged use, mainly, 
speed, coke, alcohol, also all being very physically or psychologically 
addictive.   It seems you can't make a blanket statement that some drugs should 
be approved and others not, however, they have done it with alcohol and 
cigarettes, not to mention the millions of prescription drugs they crank out by 
the truckloads...also some extremely addictive.  Where's the responsiblity and 
logic in that!!!???

Again, thank you for sharing.  If there is anything I can do, please let me 
know.

Peace, caring, responsiblity

Rikki

Certainly the exhortation to investigate and carefully consider how we tweak
the chemical soup that is our earthly manifestation is right-on!  Very good
idea to always be aware of how what we put inside alters the brew.  But to 
limit such consideration to those substances the FDA/DEA term "drugs" is a big
mistake; just as Peter suggests we consider the interests of the MDMA advocates,
we must consider the interests of the FDA/DEA, and the corporate/government
establishment in general.  The substances Peter mentions (nicotine, alcohol,
caffeine) seem to be far more likely to cause health problems than most
illegal substances.  In fact, many substances the FDA terms "foods" are more
dangerous than those they term "drugs".  So what is the difference between a
"food" and a "drug"?  I would suggest that public consumption of one better
serves the corporate/government agenda than consumption of the other.  Not an
original idea, of course, but one which bears repeating, IMO.

I must also say that I find the following excerpt particularly disturbing:

> you free.  And the truth about drugs is that they are to be avoided 
> not because they are sinister, but because their attractions come 
> with truly awful risks of death, injury, disability or other 
> permanent suffering.

Driving a car is FAR more likely to result in death, injury, disability or 
other permanent suffering than using almost any ingestible substance in a
careful, traditional way.  In fact, I have heard recently that car accidents
are the leading cause of death in the USA.  If we are to avoid things which 
subject us to these risks, doesn't it follow that we should all stop driving
cars?  Apparently we consider the benefits of driving a car to outweigh the
risks of gruesome death.  

Death is apparently a certainty.  As for me, I would much rather die in a state
of ecstasy than in a bloody mess at the side of the highway.

nEil

Cc: kyobri@SIRIUS.COM
content-length: 1710
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The risks of driving are managed by a government which sets
traffic laws, builds freeways, and employs police to manage
things.

When you drive, you have a pretty good idea of the tradeoffs
between the benefits of what you are getting and your risks.
You can regulate your speed; you can choose when to drive;
you can choose the route to take.

The risks from taking Ecstasy are unregulated and unmanaged
and uncontrolled.  The substance you buy could be anything.

You say:

   "Death is apparently a certainty.  As for me, I would 
    much rather die in a state of ecstasy than in a bloody 
    mess at the side of the highway."

This is a spurious choice.  You do not have to die either
way.  You can control your risks of dying on the highway,
and you can send your risks of dying "in a state of ecstasy" 
to zero by not ingesting the stuff.

You imply that there is a "careful and traditional way"
to take MDMA:

   "Driving a car is FAR more likely to result in death, 
    injury, disability or other permanent suffering than using 
    almost any ingestible substance in a careful, 
    traditional way."

The implications are similar to those of the people who 
responded initially to Morgan's death: that he must have
been somehow at fault for not being careful.

My point is that the truth is otherwise; that there is a
great deal of variation among individuals in the level at
which MDMA becomes toxic.  I would guess also that there is
a similar variation over time; the does which is okay for
you today may not be okay tomorrow.  There is no "careful
and traditioanl way" to take Ecstasy.

I imagine that you personally are very much at risk.  You 
use the arguments of an addict.

Peter Jones

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

Dear Ivan:

   Thank you for your thoughtful reply.

   I appreciate that any particular type of behavior which is
known to increase the risks of Ecstasy, such as mixing it with
alcohol, should be avoided, and I think your warnings about this 
are useful.

   My point of view is different from yours, however.

   Three of the points you make are that (1) Western Society is
hypocritical for accepting the use of one dangerous drug, alcohol, 
while banning drugs that are perhaps intrinsically less noxious,
such as, perhaps, MDMA, and (2) that "I object to governments telling 
me that I shouldn't alter my mood or state of conciousness, based on 
decisions made by people who are not involved with the use of these 
drugs," and that (3) "I feel, as do many other SFRavers, that use 
of ecstacy should be legalised, controlled and monitored."

    I agree with all three points; I just don't see that they are
in any way tied to any single person's decision about whether or
not to take Ecstasy.

    We live, here and now, in a particular world and a particular 
nation in which Ecstasy is illegal and its manufacture and sale are 
uncontrolled and it is very dangerous.  We can be as mad as we want 
at the government; we can do whatever we can to change the laws, 
but none of this in any way compels anyone to ingest Ecstasy.

    I think it quite advisable to not ingest it.

    Peter Jones

> My point is that the truth is otherwise; that there is a
> great deal of variation among individuals in the level at
> which MDMA becomes toxic.  I would guess also that there is
> a similar variation over time;


Peter, I don't think anyone will deny the fact the ingesting
MDMA, as well as other substances, involves some element of
risk.  I think you'd agree that it what be useful to those
concerned to have some idea of the degree of risk.  MDMA has
been around for a while now, and has probably been injested
by millions over the past 10 years.  I'd be curious to know
of any statistics on documented cases of deaths due to MDMA
toxicity.  I've heard numbers on other drugs like heroin,
tobacco, etc. but never on MDMA.  What happened to Morgan is
a tragedy, and should be taken as a wakeup call to casual users.
Are lot's of kids dying of this stuff?  Or just a handful of
isolated cases?  Any idea where such information might exist?

Lee

Dear Rikki:

   Thank you for your thoughtful reply.  I agree with most of
what you say.

   I think, however, that we are perhaps a little further on in
handling alcohol and tobacco use responsibly that you say.

   They are both still legal.  We have reached a state, however,
at which most smokers and many alcohol users are apologetic for
their use of the drugs.  Alcohol and tobacco use are no longer
seen as things that attractive and hip people do.  You sneak your
smoke out on the balcony, and you watch your drinks and apologize
for them. 

   I think this attitude is healthy.  It is a step along the path
to treating drug use responsibly.

   I wonder if MDMA users are as apologetic about their use of 
their drug as smokers are.  I don't know if they are, but from what
I have hear on sfraves I doubt that they are.

   I think they should be.

   Peter Jones

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lee Fogel said:

  "I'd be curious to know
   of any statistics on documented cases of deaths due to MDMA
   toxicity.  I've heard numbers on other drugs like heroin,
   tobacco, etc. but never on MDMA.  What happened to Morgan is
   a tragedy, and should be taken as a wakeup call to casual users.
   Are lot's of kids dying of this stuff?  Or just a handful of
   isolated cases?  Any idea where such information might exist?"

I don't know the answers, but I know a research strategy.
This is what I would do if I had the time.

I would start with two sources, "The Pathology of Drug Abuse,"
by Steven B. Karch, CRC Press, 1993, and the bibliography, by
Alexander Shulgin, to Nicholas Saunders' "E is for Ecstasy."
(The latter is on-line at hyperreal.com.) I would note which 
journals are cited frequently in these two bibliographies ("JAMA 
(Journal of the American Medical Association) is one; there are 
also citations of "Nature" and "Science") and I would then look 
at the 1994 and 1995 volumes of these journals, perhaps in the 
library of UCSF.

I looked over Shulgin's bibliography to Saunders' book this
morning.  It is extensive.  He (Shulgin) puts his own spin on
his comments to the references, however.  Whenever there is 
any uncertainty about whether Ecstasy or a second source of
some kind caused a death he tends to side with the second source.

Peter Jones

At 4:58 PM 9/25/95, Peter Jones wrote:
>The risks of driving are managed by a government which sets
>traffic laws, builds freeways, and employs police to manage
>things.

Are you suggesting we don't need to question the motives/agenda of the
government/police?

>When you drive, you have a pretty good idea of the tradeoffs
>between the benefits of what you are getting and your risks.
>You can regulate your speed; you can choose when to drive;
>you can choose the route to take.
>
>The risks from taking Ecstasy are unregulated and unmanaged
>and uncontrolled.  The substance you buy could be anything.

I think relying on authoritarian regulation and management for my own
safety is often more risky than making my own evaluation, largely because
the agenda of the authority is often inconsistent with my own.  The
"substance" one buys, whether at the pharmacy or a club, can always be
"anything", just as there can always be "anything" around the corner when
you're driving, regardless of the existence of police and traffic
legislation.

Taking the position that authority/regulation is the only valid source of
information is participating in your own disempowerment, as well as
undermining human community, which is how people must have decided what was
safe and worthwhile before the wonderful FDA existed.  We actually *can*
make good decisions collectively, because we are intelligent, because we
love each other, because we pay attention.

>You say:
>
>   "Death is apparently a certainty.  As for me, I would
>    much rather die in a state of ecstasy than in a bloody
>    mess at the side of the highway."
>
>This is a spurious choice.  You do not have to die either
>way.  You can control your risks of dying on the highway,
>and you can send your risks of dying "in a state of ecstasy"
>to zero by not ingesting the stuff.

My point is that you *do* have to die *some* way.  I have thought about
death a lot this past year, as my father caused his own death last October,
and I doubt that the best way to die is on life support, or on an expensive
pharmaceutical habit, although I'm sure the medical establishment would
like me to believe this.

>My point is that the truth is otherwise; that there is a
>great deal of variation among individuals in the level at
>which MDMA becomes toxic.  I would guess also that there is
>a similar variation over time; the does which is okay for
>you today may not be okay tomorrow.  There is no "careful
>and traditioanl way" to take Ecstasy.

This is no different from allergic reactions; some people fall down dead
the first time they eat peanut butter, some people who have eaten meat all
their lives unexpectedly eat a poisoned bit and expire.  I don't see how
Ecstasy is any different from eating or drinking or driving.  In fact,
there is a lot of literature explaining safe and productive ways to use all
sorts of substances, many of which, although currently illegal, have been
used traditionally and ritually for millennia, with very positive,
empowering, community-building, imagination-expanding effects.

>I imagine that you personally are very much at risk.  You
>use the arguments of an addict.

In what sense am I using the arguments of an addict?  I am not an addict,
but I am certainly very much at risk, and know this full well.  We are all
very much at risk all the time.  If I were to stay at home and take Ecstasy
while you take a drive in your car, I would be less likely to suffer harm
than you.  This is not speculation, this is based on statistics.  There are
some things which are good enough to risk harm, perhaps including driving a
car, perhaps including eating at a restaurant, perhaps including realizing
how absolutely wonderful people are, how fabulous community is, how easy it
is to love when the fear and inhibition is gone.

I am also very sorry for the loss of your son.  I know what this sort of
loss feels like.  But I hope you can sense how much we all care about each
other from reading this list, and I hope you come to one of our parties
sometime and feel it for yourself.  There is so much love here.

nEil



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep 26 00:19:46 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA03228; Tue, 26 Sep 1995 00:19:46 -0700
Received: from get.wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA03184; Tue, 26 Sep 1995 00:19:39 -0700

From: Doug Fairclough <kensey@wired.com>

Subject: Re: Ecstasy and Death

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i smoke, and i am not apolegetic about it.  but i also work out everyday,
and bike, and take care of my body.  who is better off, the one who does
not smoke and sits at a desk all day, or the one who smokes yet gets a
healthy dose of fresh air ?  it's wrong to say that people who smoke be
apologetic about it. it's a blanket statement.  it does not apply to me.

in a like vein, people who do X should not have to be apologetic either.
X is illegal, but for political reasons unrelated to its safety.  sure, 
if govt legalized it, and it was thus controlled, there would be a safer 
environment to consume it.  the govt spends millions on preventing drug
abuse, through stong arm tactics, when the number of poeple who have 
died from illegal drugs pales next to numbers (hundreds of thousands)
who die from legal drugs.  

so, should users of X and other illegal drugs stop because the govt
has made a decision as to what is 'ok' to do, and what is'not ok' ?

the responsible thing to do is to legalize it.  that is where concerted
effort should go.  until then, i accept the risk associated with illegal
use.

doug

The folks at the Solo Mio Festival and Climate Theater--
specifically, Joegh Bullock, charming proprietor of
the wonderful Icon Byte Bar & Grill--
offer a $3 discount on tix (which means $15/ticket) to 
"An Evening with Terence McKenna, Live & Online"
Friday, Sept. 29 and Saturday, Sept. 30
8 pm at the Cowell Theater at Fort Mason Center, SF.

**To take advantage of this offer, call the City Box Office
at 415-392-4400 and mention your VeRGe 'membership.'**

Terence McKenna is an ethnobotanist (who has probably taken more 
psychedelics than all of us combined), theoretician, explorer, 
writer, & lecturer who's been studying Shamanism and Ethnopharmacology 
for 25 years. The upcoming event is described as: "A computer-assisted 
walking tour of the temporal universe from the Big Bang to the Big
Surprise."
It's been said that "McKenna may be quite mad, or quite brilliant, or 
an alluring mix of the two, but he is definitely a spellbinding
storyteller."

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Re: Elevation
To: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199509260221.TAA26508@peseta.ucdavis.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9509260904.A5296-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



> Hopefully Amy S. will post a full review...she's good at that.  See ya.
> 
> Rick

Hey, thanks Rick!  Here I go!

Melanie and I got there rather early, but since this is a campout as well 
as a rave, we wanted to be there rather early, so we finally got there 
around 9.  It was so incredibly dark - no moon out, and thank goodness we 
had the sense to bring flashlights.  I didn't bring a tent because at 
Burning Man we danced til the sun rose and then just slept on a lounge 
chair in the sun. 

It got ***COLD***!!!  There were a couple of fires going, but not near 
the dance area, so it was pretty much deserted. Everyone was hanging out 
at the firepit. 

Carlos Campos was spinning when we got there.  He played some pretty good 
stuff, and then Rigatony came on.  He was good, played good stuff, but 
didn't really create a mood, he kept playing all different kinds of stuff 
and I was ready to be put into a mood... Then Flash came on and he played 
some really really trippy trance.  I didn't care how cold it was, I was 
transfixed by his entire set.  I was the only one dancing for the longest 
time - I don't know if it is cuz people don't like trippy weird trance 
like me or if it was too cold!  Then my friend Ted had the awesome idea 
of building a firepit in the middle of the dance area!  Duh, why didn't 
someone think of that before?!?  And we had a fire going around 3 am when 
my friend Jeff (aka Frog) came on with his drum machine.  He really got 
the crowd *together* when he played that song, "make love, listen to the 
music, you got to let yourself go go go go". It was so neat dancing 
around a big campfire.  Then Gavin went on.  Boy is he good!  Be sure to 
check him out if you ever get a chance to. People then started this 
squaredance like thing going - we were literally dancing with everybody!! 
It was great.  The vibe was just fantastic!  After Gavin was Steve who 
started bringing the energy down and more mellow - the sun was beginning 
to rise and people were going to bed.  I was exhausted, but still wide 
awake so I sat and watched the fire.  Then Rick came on and soon after he 
started, I really wanted to lie down.  So I went to my lounge chair and 
really tripped out on Rick's set.  It was awesome! I really like that 
kind of ambient....

Got to meet 2 new sfravers:  Jim Cyr and Mike (I forgot your last name, 
hon -I'm sorry!!)  Saw Purple Tiger and his friend, Fred.  I had such a 
wonderful time and we left around 4 pm.  Alot of people left on Sunday 
morning, so not that many people were there to experience the music on 
Sunday.  It was mostly mellow very relaxing kick back and socialize kind 
of day.  Couldn't have been better!

love,
Amy

Seeing I wasnt going to get to the mountains last Sat. night for either
Elevation or Light, I choose Days Between...  (I decided that instead of
stewing in my ouwn juices @ home Id rater do it somewhere else).

I guess my heart wasn't in it since most of my extended family  was havin a
fun ole time camping and dancing in the woods. So I believe any review of
Days would be an injustice.  The music was good, however, the dancing medium
was a wooden floor which would make the records skip if everyone jumped
around too much...
The venue initself was a fire marshalls nightmare.  Many a times I was
waiting for some movement b-4 I could get from one side of the dancefloor to
the other... 

But all-in-all I had an Okayish time....

C-ya'll Friday,

Adam

---------- Previous Message ----------
Rikki wrote:

>Since when can they deny the use and pleasures of a drug such as MDMA (a drug 
>that enhances feelings of love, peace and security *and* leaves most of your 
                                                          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
>judgement entact)
 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Neils wrote in response:

>Yeah right. I got two words  for you -- unsafe sex -- lots of it
>happening, lots of it fueled by ecstacy, which in terms of sexual
>inhibition removal is the new alchohol w/o the un-PC social stigma.

Where do you get this statistic?  Are you citing researchable facts or is this 
just your opinion or experience?  And how many people are doing X as compared 
to those drinking alcohol and how many of those people are acting unsafely 
compared to those acting unsafely on alcohol?  This is a guess, but without 
facts, I'd say a tiny fraction.  Perhaps they are both inhibition removers (I 
don't believe for a second that X impairs your judgement like alcohol or most 
other drugs for that matter)but alcohol is in a completely different class as 
far as consumption, availability, price, social acceptance (don't forget folks, 
we live in a very enlightened, liberal area.   Most people think alcohol is 
just dandy still and it's perfectly acceptable to get smashed.  Go to any 
college campus or anywhere in the south, mid-west or east coast.  In Texas, 
they still have drive thru mixed drink stands!) therefore, you can't compare 
the two at least as far as *numbers* go.   

>Not that sex is bad or evil (just the opposite), but i prefer falling
>in love the old fashioned way, thank you very much. Nothing stupider
>than "love" attained through an emotional hallucinogen, cuz sometimes
>you wake up the next day, or the next week, or whatever, and wonder
>what the hell you're doing  pretending to be in love with some person
>you fell in love with on X... (and i've done that a few times a few
>years ago back when i was still doing X).

>"we were all Xing like crazy and this chick we had just met was acting
>real horny so we both got on top of her and did her" 
>  -- words i heard an X dealer once say (w/ some pride).

I'd say this guy you mention is a major asshole but shouldn't represent the 
entire X culture.  With every thing that makes us feel good, there are going to 
be people who abuse it, whether it's drugs or not.  You might as well 
illegalize sex...it certainly is dangerous behavior.  All behavior is dangerous 
when we don't know how to practice it responsibly.

I can't say I've been naive enough to think I'm *in love* with someone just 
because I was on a drug that made me feel loving.  I believe that it opens the 
doors for relationships and friendships that you might not otherwise encounter 
*because* you are on X and you *do* open up.   I have met some incredibly 
awesome people that I wouldn't have met otherwise.  I do wake up thinking, 
"Wow, I'm so glad I met that person, I hope I see them again".   Of course, not 
every experience has been a positive one, but every time you do something you 
enjoy, does it always turn out positive?  Are you never let down?  But with 
anything, you should focus on the good.  There is lots of good that comes out 
of these experiences too.  If you're not having any positive experiences when 
everybody else is, maybe that's a problem with the person.  

I think that the people that are engaging in unsafe behavior would be as likely 
to engage in unsafe behavior no matter if or what kinds of drugs they were on, 
because they aren't educated and don't know the risks they are taking.   Are 
you saying we should keep it illegal, unsafe and unregulated because it can 
lead to unsafe sexual behavior?   Boy, I'd think they'd whip alcohol right off 
the shelves in that case.

Rikki

A regular gold mine of amusing stuff today!! :)

Overheard on the CBC radio morning show ... A man in England attempted to
rob a grocery store.  He ran up to the cashier with a gun, but before he
could get a word out, he was roundly scolded by the people in line for
budging and told to wait his turn.  He was so unnerved by this that he
wandered off and was arrested two blocks later.

>From "The Mother Tongue - English and How It Got That Way" ....

The Pentagon's Department of Food Procurement specifications for a
"regulation Type 2 sandwich cookie":  'The cookie shall consist of two
round cakes with a layer of filling between them.  The weight of the cookie
shall be not less than 21.5 grams and filling weight not less than 6.4
grams.  The base cakes shall be uniformly baked wil a colour ranging from
not lighter than chip 27885 or darker than chip 13711 ... the color
comparisons shall be made under north sky daylight with the objects held in
such a way as to avoid spectacular refractance.'

Computer rendering of "Out of sight, out of mind" - "blind insanity".

In a Russian/English phrasebook, this instruction for ordering in a
restaurant:  "Please give me curds, sower cream, fried chicks, pulled bread
and one jellyfish."

On a bag in Japan:  "Elephant family are happy with us.  Their humming
makes us feel happy."

On a sign in the Europa Hotel in Sarajevo:  "Guests should announce the
abandonment of theirs rooms before 12 o'clock, emptying the room at the
latest until 14 o'clock, for the use of the room before 5 at the arrival or
after the 16 o'clock at the departure, will be billed as one night more."

:)

k

I forwarded Peter Jones's posts to Nicholas Saunders (author of E is
for Ecstacy and Ecstacy and Dance Culture) because he was mentioned in
a post and because I thought he'd be interested anyway.  Here is the
reply:

>Dear David,
>
>Thanks for forwarding the report on the tragic death of Morgan Jones due to
>MDMA. My immediate reaction is to feel for his father Peter and awful that,
>as he says, I may have contributed to the death of his son by providing
>false security when he visited my site.
>
>However, I do stand by my conclusion about the relative safety of MDMA, and
>in researching my new book I have again looked at the the risks using wider
>data but reached similar conclusions: that everything you do is risky, but
>that taken sensibly and in moderation by healthy people, the risks of
>taking MDMA are no more than many other accepted forms of recreation, and
>are probably less than alcohol use.
>
>The point is that if MDMA were eliminated, potential users would not stay
>at home safely watching TV: they would be doing something else and that may
>well carry a similar risk. This may not apply to Morgan, so that his life
>may have been saved, and will be no consolation to Peter, his mother
>Katherine or anyone else connected with this or any other personal tragedy
>of those who have died through taking MDMA. It may be cold hearted, but
>statistical risk is more relevant to sensible decision making than
>closeness to a personal tragedy.
>
>In fact Morgan's death was one of the extremely rare cases of death due to
>MDMA which appaently did not involve overheating. The great majority of
>Ecstasy deaths here in Britain could have been avoided by drinking enough
>water and 'chilling out'. Some authorities such as Manchester accept that
>they have failed to prevent illicit drug use through education and police
>efforts, so they have diverted 50% of their resources towards preventing
>damage to those who use drugs in venues. To obtain licenses, venues must
>provide free drinking water, be adequately ventilated, have quiet cool
>rooms available and have staff trained to recognise symptoms of drug
>related problems who are able to give appropriate treatment.
>
>Nicholas Saunders
>
>
>

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
I want a world where my biggest worry is getting sand on my blow-pop.
WWW:  My URL is http://www.crl.com/~davidmin/

>"we were all Xing like crazy and this chick we had just met was acting
>real horny so we both got on top of her and did her" 
>  -- words i heard an X dealer once say (w/ some pride).

I'd say this guy you mention is a major asshole but shouldn't represent the
entire X culture.

Aside from the obvious in this quote, a reference such as 
 "x culture" sounds REALLY bad.  Perhaps it was an oversight.  But any
"group" whose identity is based upon a drug, really has it's priorities out
of whack, IMO.   It seems that lately, on this list, there's been an awful
lot of flag-waving and glorification of X.   If that's someone's prerogative,
so be it.   I wonder though, why there isn't more discussion about music,
which, one would think, would be the focus.  What all of this sounds like, to
me, is people missing a "certain something" in their lives, and embracing a
"culture" (drug) as the cure for what ails them.  It's really quite sad, how
"raving"  basically equates to "drugs" in the minds of so many people,
outside of, and especially within the scene.    

Put that in your pipe and smoke it.    Tom

Niels and Rikki were talking about unsafe sexual practices and falling in 
love on E.  I used to be totally ani-drug because of the fact that I am 
not "me" while under the influence.  So if anyone becomes very 
affectionate with me during his e trip, I take it with a major grain of 
salt and see if he acts the same way when I see that person sober. 
I'm always very careful about what I say and do while under the influence 
as well, because I still want to be true to myself and anyone who happens 
to be around me at the time.  To do otherwise is lying.  My 2 cents for 
the day....

love,
Amy

At 12:23 PM 9/26/95, Rikki Kiefer/SYBASE wrote:
>---------- Previous Message ----------
>Rikki wrote:
>
>>Since when can they deny the use and pleasures of a drug such as MDMA (a drug
>>that enhances feelings of love, peace and security *and* leaves most of your
>                                                          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
>>judgement entact)
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
>
>Neils wrote in response:
>>Not that sex is bad or evil (just the opposite), but i prefer falling
>>in love the old fashioned way, thank you very much. Nothing stupider
>>than "love" attained through an emotional hallucinogen, cuz sometimes
>>you wake up the next day, or the next week, or whatever, and wonder
>>what the hell you're doing  pretending to be in love with some person
>>you fell in love with on X... (and i've done that a few times a few
>>years ago back when i was still doing X).
>
>>"we were all Xing like crazy and this chick we had just met was acting
>>real horny so we both got on top of her and did her"
>>  -- words i heard an X dealer once say (w/ some pride).
>
>I'd say this guy you mention is a major asshole but shouldn't represent the
>entire X culture.  With every thing that makes us feel good, there are
>going to
>be people who abuse it, whether it's drugs or not.  You might as well
>illegalize sex...it certainly is dangerous behavior.  All behavior is
>dangerous
>when we don't know how to practice it responsibly.
>
>I can't say I've been naive enough to think I'm *in love* with someone just
>because I was on a drug that made me feel loving.  I believe that it opens the
>doors for relationships and friendships that you might not otherwise encounter
>*because* you are on X and you *do* open up.

        for me at least, the feelings of love that one has are as genuine
as anything else, being that everything is relative. I think that these
feelings of love well up in you as, simultaneously, you realize the real
joy of being ALIVE and not running around SURVIVING. There is a difference.
So when you are alive and in the moment of now-existance and you look into
someone else's eyes and you see yourself reflected and realize that nothing
is ever going to be the same again and that this person in front of you,
though you may not even know their first name, never mind their last, is a
part of you, on the quantum level and that the distance between your heart
and theirs is almost totally constructed by social conditioning and walls
that we all build up in a world that is full of pain and that distance
between your heart and their's is bridged just for a second, past the
arbitrary, constructed walls and we all realize that we are all one,
underneath everything...we're all just reflections of each other...facets
on the same jewel...seeing everyone's deep essential complex-beauty,
everyone has it, it's just some bury it a bit more than others...
        oops...that was a bit mushy, wasn't it? hee hee ;)
        what i'm trying to say is that these are my feelings, other people
filter their experiences according to their own personalities, and for some
that means sex with strangers (which i have no problem with if it's
consensual and safe and there are no power games) and for others it's a
brief drug-induced feeling that passes and then we go back to real life.  I
guess i, like rikki, see x as a small additional factor that is added to
the experiential equation that allows for things to manifest themselves
that were always there. MDMA is a drug that gives you feelings of a state
of mind called ecstasy, and ecstasy is the contemplation of wholeness.
Wholeness of self, and wholeness of the self's place in the world. This
state of mind is not necessarily acheived SOLELY through the use of MDMA,
too. :)

        peace,
                brad

i don't know...i guess what we're talking about here is what is that
ambiguous, flowing, inarticulable feeling that we have to stuff into the
little word-box named 'love' in order to be able to communicate that
feeling with others. I mean, what is 'love' anyways? the appreciation of
beauty? well, what does 'beauty' mean?

      The new film "THE HEMP REVOLUTION" will be playing at the
      locations listed below.


     *******************************************************************
                                 NOTICE
     *******************************************************************
     
     The most comprehensive and informative film about hemp ever
     produced has just debuted in America.  This 72-minute film
     titled "The Hemp Revolution" covers all aspects of hemp and
     cannabis--the enormous environmental and economic potential of
     hemp, the failed drug war, medical marijuana, the history
     of hemp, the reason marijuana was made illegal, and more.

     The potential of this film to attract media attention, inform
     the public, and generate pro-hemp activism is enormous.
     Currently, only 2 copies of this film are on tour.  In order
     to get this film played in theaters throughout the U.S. and
     Canada, approximately 10 more films need to be purchased at
     $1,000 per film.

     To raise money to purchase more copies of this film, the
     producer and director (Anthony Clarke) is seeking $100
     donations.  For a $100 donation you will receive your own VHS
     videotape copy of "The Hemp Revolution."  Not only will you
     get your own copy of this superb film, you will do more to
     educate the masses about cannabis/hemp (therefore building
     support for legalization) than anything else you could do
     for $100.

     Many of us think nothing of spending $100 for a bag of cannabis.
     Please consider redirecting that next hundred bucks to do
     something for the cannabis/hemp movement.
     
     Thanks for your time--end of sales pitch.
     SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY, contact: hemprev@aol.com

     *********************************************************************
     
     Please call theater to confirm times and dates...
     -------------------------------------------------

it is not socially acceptable to publicly post someone's private mail
to a public forum without asking.

amicably, apologies have been made and accepted, and enlightenment, not
stupid bitchy sniping has ensued.

the size of the stick you've got shoved up your ass.

with the ad-hominem attacks -- a sure sign that you've reached your
limits in terms of coming up with a cogent reply.

I'm getting to the part where I'm checking out all the rave related sites.
Thanx to those that want to be listed.   If I missed YOUR site,  it was
because you didn't respond to my initial query,  which I assumed you weren't
interested in getting a link.   I have many others which I've collected,
like John S. Lee's site,  and a few others.   So,  if you haven't responded,
please do so.    I haven't checked all of them out yet,   and won't put
them up until I've checked each one out.

So far,   I've got the following.   Please check the caption I've
written,  to make sure I've represented you correctly.

I'm getting an amazing number of hits to my site,  as indicated by the
counter,  and mostly coming from word of mouth from alt.rave,  alt.hackers,
and alt.2600 readers.   The databases have yet to add my site,   but I put
it up on all of them.

USA Rave related sites I'm planning to link to.
===============================================

updated every Thursday.

David Minuk,  a dedicated SFRaver.

parallel university.

http://www.siu.edu/departments/iotaphi/mxc.htm

http://gladstone.uoregon.edu/~drenalin
Cloud Factory,  a rave group down in the Monterey area

http://www.netnoir.com
<check out>

http://www.vossnet.co.uk/company/pronoia

http://www.ameba.com

http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/raves/

 The Saturday before the Halloween weekend will be
the date for the SFRaves Peninsula Picnic - Saturday, October 21st.
I will be there early to reserve a nice , tree shaded little
valley of a picnic site with three big tables and water and
a small barbecue pit. A nearby dry streambed should make
a great place for a drum circle!

 More details ( directions, etc. ) the week of the picnic.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com 

PS - Please email me so's I can get an idea of how many folks
will be showing up. It will be in a park about 1/2 hour drive time
south of S.F. No pets or dogs allowed , but children and horses
are allowed .

Well, Nu Energy is not what F8 plays, that's for sure.  It's more in the
JX/Blu Peter realm of things, really fast Eurohouse, fairly cheezee.
It's kind of a stupid name for a style, but people need handles for things
and I guess this is one.

I saw another new style name yesterday in an interesting story in the
Seattle Post-Intelligencer about a DJ who's playing "bhangle" -- that's
a new combination of bhangra and jungle which is popular in the Indian/
Pakistani cultural areas of London . . .

Labels, labels, labels . . .

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 27 12:56:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA02701; Wed, 27 Sep 1995 12:56:18 -0700

From: Phuture@aol.com
Received: by mail04.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id PAA11771; Wed, 27 Sep 1995 15:55:37 -0400
Date: Wed, 27 Sep 1995 15:55:37 -0400
Message-ID: <950927155537_30790947@mail04.mail.aol.com>
To: ecto@citenet.net
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: ecstatic love
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Rikki, Neils and Brad were saying:

"I believe that it opens the
>doors for relationships and friendships that you might not otherwise
encounter
>*because* you are on X and you *do* open up."

"the distance between your heart and theirs is almost totally constructed by
social conditioning and walls that we all build up in a world that is full of
pain and that distance between your heart and their's is bridged just for a
second, past the arbitrary, constructed walls and we all realize that we are
all one, underneath everything...we're all just reflections of each
other...facets on the same jewel...seeing everyone's deep essential
complex-beauty, everyone has it, it's just some bury it a bit more than
others..."

Both are true in my experience.  The problems usually occur later when the
social conditioning, ego and psychic walls come crashing back in.  You may
find that you are frighteningly un-compatilbe in normal reality.  Veterans
can extricate themselves gracefully and kindly to an appropriate intimacy
level.  I have known more than one couple though, that was dependent on the
ecstatic mind state to keep from killing each other.  Having said that, I
wouldn't trade some of my stranger shared intimacies for anything because of
the insight into the beauty and diversity of humanity they have given me that
I would have otherwise missed looking for something more familiar/compatible.
And the communication/feeling skills I've had to learn to step back from too
deep of one of those special ecstatic intimacies in a way that leaves
everyone happy and hopefully truly new friends have made me such a better
person in my "normal" life.

phuture

music', 'jungle' really really loud.

I'm getting to the part where I'm checking out all the rave related sites.
Thanx to those that want to be listed.   If I missed YOUR site,  it was
because you didn't respond to my initial query,  which I assumed you weren't
interested in getting a link.   I have many others which I've collected,
like John S. Lee's site,  and a few others.   So,  if you haven't responded,
please do so.    I haven't checked all of them out yet,   and won't put
them up until I've checked each one out.

So far,   I've got the following.   Please check the caption I've
written,  to make sure I've represented you correctly.

I'm getting an amazing number of hits to my site,  as indicated by the
counter,  and mostly coming from word of mouth from alt.rave,  alt.hackers,
and alt.2600 readers.   The databases have yet to add my site,   but I put
it up on all of them.

USA Rave related sites I'm planning to link to.
===============================================

updated every Thursday.

parallel university.

http://www.mbc.umt.edu/ogd/aaxz/raves/

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 27 17:10:40 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA21516; Wed, 27 Sep 1995 17:10:40 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA21509; Wed, 27 Sep 1995 17:10:36 -0700

From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199509280010.RAA29721@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re:  Ecstacy and Death
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 27 Sep 1995 17:10:26 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2440      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear everyone,

A recent experience with a friend who had an unusually strong and 
dangerous "trip" on just half a hit of LSD knocked a little sense into 
me.  I'm still reeling from it, by the way.

I was so cavalier.  I thought there were no surprises left where things 
like Ecstasy, LSD, etc., were concerned.  Now I see how ignorant I am.  
How ignorant most people are.

But I can _imagine_ how I would feel if I sold, gave or led someone  to 
something that made them sick, that made them crack up or made them die.

If you see me at a party, please don't ask me if I know where to get you 
whatever.  Because even if I do, I won't want to tell you.  That person- 
however amiable- who wants to sell you something just wants to make a 
buck.  If only just to pay for his own trip.  

I'm not going to risk my peace of mind so that you can get high for a 
night and so that so-and-so can pay off the  new paint job for his car.  
Fuck that.  

Because if something were to happen to you, I would _never_ forgive 
myself.  Maybe most of the people who read this list are young enough 
that they have never done anything they are deeply ashamed of.  But I'm 
not, I have, and -believe me- it's not fun.

My friend could have ended up in the emergency room.  The ER personnel 
might have given him something to calm him down that could have induced a 
"cardiac dysrhymthia due to idiosyncratic drug reaction" - like what 
happened to Peter Jones' son Morgan- in combination with the LSD and 
whatever other crap was in there with it.

"Idiosyncratic drug reaction."  There you have it.  It may be rare.  But 
it's there.  And we had better not let anyone on this list forget about it.

There are folks reading this right now who are just getting into 
"raving."  They like the music, they like to dance, they like the 
openness and the love, they feel at home.  We older "list people" MUST 
make it our responsibility to remind kids -and eachother- that 
recreational drugs are dangerous and that they can fuck you up.  And 
here's how.  Spell it out.  Tell us stories about what you've seen.  
Maybe they'll think we're just being tiresome...but at least we will have 
discharged our responsibility.

Think about it.  If you knew someone who was having unprotected sex, 
wouldn't you say something to them?  If you knew someone who was abusing 
drugs, shouldn't you say something then as well?  

On that note, I'll say "bye"

-Anthrax

>Hello Everybody!,
>    I was wondering who, (if anyone), was going to the Renn. Faire this
>weekend. Alot of us were planning to go up on Sunday. From what I have

To Greg and any others going to Faire.

YES, this is the last weekend, probably forever at the Novato location, it
is an incredibly beautiful spot and you owe it to yourselves to visit the
Faire at this location. Secondly, I will be working there both days, as I
have most weekends, except B-Man :)  So look for me (I will even have some
SFRaves laminates for those of you who haven't gotten one yet). My schedule
for the day starts at the front gate before opening, approx 9:30 for the
little dialog that gets everyone in the mood before the gate opens at
10:00. I will be running around with the Fools guild, you know the silly
ones with the funky hats !!!  After 10:30 or so, I head to the morgue to
put on my bones and then do 2 parades with the Danse Macabre. The first one
is at 11:00 and goes from the Center of the Universe, tword the front gate
(not quite all the way to the front though), and then return to the Center.
The 2nd parade is at 1:00 and goes from the Center of the Universe all the
way up the the end of the world and back. Then you can find me being silly
again as the fools lead the Queens Progress heading up to the Main Stage.
We dance and frolic up on stage for the Queens Show, this happens around
3:00. After 4:00 I may be at the Wild Soles shoe booth, or just out being
Silly. Oh yeah, when I'm dead, I'm also about 8' tall, as I do the parades
on stilts, I may be a tall fool also, but I'm not sure, sometime I do,
sometimes I don't, it depends on my legs. (ouch)

So hows that for a lenghty post....  I hope to see some of you SFRavers out
there, I know Annie Stansfield <amstansfield@ucdavis.edu> will be there on
Sat., A good bet if you want to find me is to ask them at the Wild Soles
shoe booth, as they know my schedule and can usually point you in the right
direction.

Big giant long legged hugs,

vince

The Happy Rasta Raver

> >Hello Everybody!,

> >is true or not, but we are planning to go anyways. Well, I hope to see

> To Greg and any others going to Faire.
> 
> YES, this is the last weekend, probably forever at the Novato location, it
> is an incredibly beautiful spot and you owe it to yourselves to visit the
> Faire at this location. Secondly, I will be working there both days, as I
> have most weekends, except B-Man :)  So look for me (I will even have some
> SFRaves laminates for those of you who haven't gotten one yet). My schedule
> for the day starts at the front gate before opening, approx 9:30 for the
> little dialog that gets everyone in the mood before the gate opens at
> 10:00. I will be running around with the Fools guild, you know the silly
> ones with the funky hats !!!  After 10:30 or so, I head to the morgue to
> put on my bones and then do 2 parades with the Danse Macabre. The first one
> is at 11:00 and goes from the Center of the Universe, tword the front gate
> (not quite all the way to the front though), and then return to the Center.
> The 2nd parade is at 1:00 and goes from the Center of the Universe all the
> way up the the end of the world and back. Then you can find me being silly
> again as the fools lead the Queens Progress heading up to the Main Stage.
> We dance and frolic up on stage for the Queens Show, this happens around
> 3:00. After 4:00 I may be at the Wild Soles shoe booth, or just out being
> Silly. Oh yeah, when I'm dead, I'm also about 8' tall, as I do the parades
> on stilts, I may be a tall fool also, but I'm not sure, sometime I do,
> sometimes I don't, it depends on my legs. (ouch)
> 
> So hows that for a lenghty post....  I hope to see some of you SFRavers out
> there, I know Annie Stansfield <amstansfield@ucdavis.edu> will be there on
> Sat., A good bet if you want to find me is to ask them at the Wild Soles
> shoe booth, as they know my schedule and can usually point you in the right
> direction.
> 
> Big giant long legged hugs,
> 
> vince

We think that this may well be our last opportunity for a beach party 
this year and we want to take advantage of the light of the Full Moon!

of Cybertrance with MARS, MysterE and Cyr.  Your mappoint host will
be Mike Lasmanis.  $5.00  Call (415) 541-5019 for directions.

wear sensible shoes and carry a flashlight

Subject: Non-rave related humor
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

DISCLAIMER:  To the prudes--don't read this one. 
 
 A friend of a guy in the Nutrition School at Tufts was one of the lucky 
 passengers onboard a Northwest Airlines flight to Boston during our 
 recent hurricane "Bob".  The captain did his best to skirt the edge of 
 the storm, but it was a pretty rough ride just the same - rough enough 
 that the flight attendants were ordered to strap themselves into their 
 seats for about half an hour, and many of the passengers were putting 
 the little plastic-lined bags in their seat pockets to good use.  When 
 the turbulence finally abated, the flight attendants unbuckled them- 
 selves, and the captain's voice came on over the intercom. 
 
 "Well, folks, that was quite some ride, wasn't it?  But we came 
 through it fine, just the way we always do, and I'm happy to report 
 that it looks like the remainder of our trip should be much calmer. 
 On behalf of myself and today's flight crew, I'd like to thank you 
 very much for your calmness and cooperation, and extend our best 
 wishes for a pleasant stay in Boston." 
 
 After a short pause and several clicks "Jesus Christ - whatta bitchin' 
 ride!  Boy - I sure could use a cup of good strong coffee and a blow 
 job right about now" 
 
 As a stricken stewardess dashed up the aisle to the cabin to inform 
 the captain that his intercom was still on, one of the passengers 
 called after her,  "Don't forget the coffee!" 
 

Hugs and giggles

Rikki

Subject: POP QUIZ (intermission...)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello all.  I was confronted the other day by some "ravers" who asked why I
was pumpin suck funky tunes outta my car, yet didn't fit the raver profile
(Ie funny hat, "phat clothes" et al.).This inspried me to make this lil quiz
so you can test yourself.  ARE YOU A TECHNOPHILE?????

Part I: Multiple Choice.  Selecet the best possible answer to the question.
 Time limit 15 Mins.

1. Which DJ DOSENT belong: a)Gailen b)Myster-E c)Steve Masters d)Ethan

2. When going to an event the best clothes to wear is: a)None b)Really cool
duds from Ameba or Housewares c)Whatever is on the floor this morning.
d)clothes? Hell Im still footing the gas bill for driving to and from events.

3)When on the dance floor and you see a fellow partygoer slip and fall on the
floor, you: a)Make sure you dont step on his/her fingers b) Stifle a giggle
and walk away c) walk up and ask if she/he is ok and needs assistance. d) Sit
on the floor also, and gain a new perspective on everything.

4) When meeting a fello raver you: a) Give em a hearty handshake. b) Sit on
thier lap and tell em your life story. c) give a nice hug and chat about
whatnot. d) Wave hello and go about your beeswax

5) Looking in a ravers car you will find: a) a gallon of water b) a
flashlight c) various maps of Califorina d) all of the above

6) If Ross Perot were a DJ his name would be: a) Ross b) DJ loads'o'cash c)
That lil funny guy with those big ears d) He wouldnt. Perot would hire
someone else to be his DJ.

7) Which name DOSENT belong: a) E b) X c) Fruitopia d) Mdma

8) When Dancing on the beach it's appropriate to: a)Scream and make a mad
dash for the ocean b) climb up ricdicously perncious cliffs and ledges c)
dance really REALLY close to speaker wires d) share your cardboard.

9) you know your at a bad event when: a)They charge $2 for cups b) dancing
nekked is not allowed c)everything is shut down by 4AM d) Everyone at the
party looks the same

10) Instead of busting raves, police could: a) Eat more doughnuts b) Dance @
raves c) Brush up on thier 911 response times d) Catch REAL crimminals.

Part II:  Choose the corresponding number to the correct definintion.  Time
limit 10 minutes.

1) Underground
2) Massive
3) Renagade
4) Gathering
5) Event

A) Illegal party due to no permits, on private property or amplifed sound
B) The usual name that has replaced the term Rave
C) Legal or illegal party that is known only in close circles
D) Similar to c), however may or may not involve amplified music.  Drum
circles used instead
E) Very large, usualy commercal party that "pulls" persons usually not into
the scene.

Part III  Bonus question: This is a toughie...
Which Label dosen't Belong:

a) Interal  b)Harthouse c)Chrysalis d)R&S

Answers will be posted later.

We now return you to your regularly programmed life.


Spins,
Adam

     Well, this review is alot more favorable than my last review for the 
     same gig.  As always, things change and perhaps it was my mood, the 
     guest dj (Garth!), the ever-changing people (where have all the 
     fun-loving freaks gone?), the overall vibe factor, _and_ the improved 
     sound system that made this party go off more than what I've 
     experienced recently.
     
     Though a bit too smokey for me, the overall vibe of this party was 
     alot better than what I experienced at Phat Frisco or 1015 last 
     Friday.  (Keep in mind that all of these parties did go off, it's just 
     that for me, an energy-riding gal, I felt more of natural vibe and 
     plur at Simply Done than at the other two I mentioned.  _Purely_MHO._) 
     So what I'm trying to say, is that Garth ripped some funky tunes 
     putting a few people inside out and it was great to see and feel all 
     of that wonderful loving energy.   
     
     It's funny how much things change when you don't go out for a few 
     weeks.  In my case, it's been ~four weeks and I observed or heard:
     
     - that since Burning Man and Back-to-School not as many people are 
        going out.  1015 and the End-Up were pretty empty w/ravers this
        weekend.  
     - for those who went to Burning Man, how can you top that 
        experience?  Anything else is a let down if you expect to capture
        that same vibe/experience.
     - the scene always evolves and changes...but I'm finding not as strong
        of a vibe out there and alot more kids going off.  (Perhaps I'm
        just feeling old and out of it :}
     
     And yep, I know that the onset of Fall and less daylight affect us all 
     and tend to make alot of us more introspective.  But I haven't heard 
     anyone from sfraves really mention any of this yet, so I thought I'd 
     bring it up.  Especially since I really started interacting w/sfraves 
     and became more involved w/the scene around this time last 
     year...what's it been like in the Fall for the past three years?  Any 
     patterns?
     
     Well, I'm rambling and gotta get back to work but I wanted y'all to 
     know that Simply Done was great and I just wanted zap you all with a 
     dose of loving energy that I felt from the brothers and sisters out 
     there.
     
     Warm embraces,
     Diane
