So here is my personal situation with the topics Diane brings up:
>      
>      - that since Burning Man and Back-to-School not as many people are 
>         going out.  1015 and the End-Up were pretty empty w/ravers this
>         weekend.  

I've been going out EVERY weekend since the last F&F!!!  *AND* I'm
going to school full time.  My studies have suffered, so I'm trying to 
begin a lower profile life now. I'm actally staying home this weekend 
until possibly the next F&F.  And I have Sunday off, too, which will make 
me ache inside knowing there might be a Sunset party in Berkeley or 
Richmond.  But, alas, tis time to take control of this rampant hedonism 
that is loose within me and get down to business.  Wouldn't we all just 
love to party every single weekend - some of you have it so lucky!!

>      - for those who went to Burning Man, how can you top that 
>         experience?  Anything else is a let down if you expect to capture
>         that same vibe/experience.

To me, BM was in a category all its own.  You *cannot* compare it to the 
likes of ANYTHING, for to do so will result in certain disappointment.  
I've had a BLAST at Family, the Bonnie Doon Party, both Sunset parties 
after those parties, and Elevation last weekend.  I simply choose not to 
compare, for dwelling on past experiences is a waste  of time.  I have a 
good time NOW and I'm never disappointed.  


>      - the scene always evolves and changes...but I'm finding not as strong
>         of a vibe out there and alot more kids going off.  (Perhaps I'm
>         just feeling old and out of it :}
>      

What do you mean by kids going off?  Hmmm, Diane girl, you must be going 
to the wrong parties.....the parties I mentioned above have had 
incredibly thick sweet vibes pulsing strong all night long!  Maybe your 
theory of it being a seasonal change is somewhat responsible for your 
observations...(?)  Who can say....  Welp, there's my 2 cents for this day.

love,
Amy

   Out-a-Sight and the free Gathering on Saturday look the most
   attractive this weekend. But if you can get there, Desert Move looks to
   have the largest collection of star DJs I've ever seen in this region.
   Cyberfest?  Ummm...

       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford

       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Why am I forwarding this? Because I just *had* to! - wdc :)

--- begin forwarded text

Subject: [HUMOR] Another MIT Hack

An MIT student spent an entire summer going to the Harvard football
field every day wearing a black and white striped shirt, walking up and
down the field for ten or fifteen minutes throwing birdseed all over
the field, blowing a whistle and then walking off the field.  At the
end of the summer, it came time for the first Harvard home football
game, the referee walked onto the field and blew the whistle, and the
game had to be delayed for a half hour to wait for the birds to get off
of the field.  The guy wrote his thesis on this, and graduated.

--- end forwarded text

I have two tickets to see Tricky & Laika tonight (9/28) at Slims. My friend
who I was supposed to go with is sick and can't make it. I've called and left
messages with four friends who might be interested in going. If none of them

time, this is a great chance to put a signal out to a community of wonderful
people. so for those of you who aren't looking for a place to live in
berkeley, please bear with me and skip this message.

i live in a friendly co-op in berkeley with two other men. i'm a writer and
visual artist. mike is a pre-school teacher and nature-lover. chris is an art
student at sf state. as you know, the first of the month is almost here, and
we're still looking for people to live with us on october 1st. in order to
keep a relative gender balance in the house, we're looking for two women. 

if you're a woman who's looking for a place - especially if you're looking
for a fun, friendly, artsy, veggie co-op in berkeley - or you know someone

RIGHT ON!!!
We really can do more to help each other.
1.  Watch each other....,if someone is sick, help!!! dont wait till they are
unconcious.
     get them out of the confussion get them to help.
2.  All parties should have a plan if someone is ill.  Ideally at least some
type of medical
     personnel,  for craps sake even a volly...
3.  Understand the side effects poissible adverse reactions etc.,, before you
take      anything including aspirin.  If you dont KNOW say NO!! it really is
everyones      responsibility to KNOW.. Find out dont hope for the best.  
4.  If you are new to the scene or some aspect of the scene find someone who
knows.
     and tell them you are new 99% of the time they will be glad to have a
new friend.

I apologize if I sound a bit bitchy but the scene is getting very messy....
1. Kids barfing alone in the bathroom every party. No friends? bullshit
2. No medical help, much less plans at most parties sorry I think for the $20
    there can be paramedics at the party .  Afraid of the attention? Ignoring
the problem
    will not help. Why not spend a few bucks on people instead of silly mega
flyers.
    Even small parties need some contingency plan. LIKE WHERE the nearest
    hospital is.
3. Dont mix unless you are experienced likewise if you're new to something
try half then 
    maybe,  with supervision take half in 1 or 2 hours..  Are people looking
for community
    or oblivion ask yourself and those around you what you expect to get from
the     Evening....,  do you want to barf, pass out , or share the experience
with your friends
    Are all those people against the wall really tired from dancing or just
messed.
4. If you do business at the party expect to get burnt.

RAMBLE RAMBLE..,,,
sorry I find new meaning in the aphex twin title "I CARE BECAUSE YOU DO"

GREGO.

the National Alliance (aka Aryan Nations, aka US Nazi party). THeir
lies are truly scary, and it's scary to think there are people out
there running around with these sick ideas in their heads.

| WORLD WIDE WEB: http://www.natvan.com (if unavailable, try our ftp site)
| FTP SITE: ftp.netcom.com, path /pub/NA/NA

I think they need to be fucked with, big time -- with their own medicine.
Take a look at their plans for spamming the online world in
	ftp://ftp.netcom.com/ftp/pub/NA/NA/ANA/USENET_Strategies

Perhaps we should start by e-mail bombing these shit heads -- you are
on their list, even if yer lilly white!.  On unix, for example, you can
severely annoy the perpertrators by doing something like

	cat /unix /vmunix | mail treborle@netcom.com
	cat /unix /vmunix | mail bf221@freenet.carleton.ca

(though since the unix kernel is copyrighted, perhaps you'd be
better off getting emacs to core dump and send them that instead)

Gee, it's just too bad that treborle@netcom.com will have to pay
$2.00/megabyte/month for any storeage above 5 megabytes on Netcom. And
the above drops a tidy 2 megs into the mail box each time. Vote early,
vote often!

-- Niels.

PS: you're on your own w/r/t the legality of the aforementioned 
retaliatory act.

Precedence: bulk

I do love surveys...

>Hello all.  I was confronted the other day by some "ravers" who asked why I
>was pumpin suck funky tunes outta my car, yet didn't fit the raver profile
>(Ie funny hat, "phat clothes" et al.).This inspried me to make this lil quiz
>so you can test yourself.  ARE YOU A TECHNOPHILE?????
>
>Part I: Multiple Choice.  Selecet the best possible answer to the question.
> Time limit 15 Mins.
>
>1. Which DJ DOSENT belong:
A:  The one that can't spin or mix.

>2. When going to an event the best clothes to wear is:
A;  First , it's "...clothes to wear are:".  Other than that, you want to
wear fresh, washed clothes.  Ones that don't offend the olfactories.

>3)When on the dance floor and you see a fellow partygoer slip and fall on the
>floor, you:
A:  Determine if they're drunk.  If so, ignore them.  If on psychedelics,
determine their present state of crackerjacking.  If critical, call 911, if
not, have a good hardy laugh.  Scenes like this don't happen too often, and
it's best to get as much mileage as possible.

>
>4) When meeting a fello raver you:
A:  Check the state of crustiness.  If offense to the olfactories have
taken place, offer your hand.  If much offense, offer a pat on the back,
and wash the patting hand immediately.  If they smell good, a hug will do.
Especially if they're female.

>
>5) Looking in a ravers car you will find:
A: Parking tickets, empty water bottles, and tons upon tons of flyers.

>6) If Ross Perot were a DJ his name would be:
A: DJ ImRossAndUrTheBoss

>
>7) Which name DOSENT belong:
A:  The one that can get you 5 years under minimum sentencing.  It's a life
sentence or bust!

>8) When Dancing on the beach it's appropriate to:
A:  Masturbate.  Remember the Full Moon some moons ago?!?  Hee, hee! ;)

>
>9) you know your at a bad event when:
A:
-People are dancing while holding cigarettes.
-People who have no rhythm "attempt" to dance.
-People do aerobics or stretches on the dance floor (worse than circle
dancing IMO).
-People smell like they've taken tons of X &/or speed, dance all night, hit
lotsa pot, smell really bad, and THEN wanna hug you.  Yeech!
-You hear two people talking "Hey, is that Jeno?!?", "No, it's Garth!",
when it's really John Howard or Mark Farina.
-When someone searching for a reason, or perhaps a clue, asks "Is this
where the 'rave' is?"; time to leave.
-Cops are everywhere.

>
>10) Instead of busting raves, police could:
A; Continue like they always have, collect graft from the promoters.

>
>Part II:  Choose the corresponding number to the correct definintion.  Time
>limit 10 minutes.
>
>1) Underground - A party nobody knows about.
>2) Massive - A party everyone knows about.
>3) Renagade - A Party people wish they threw.
>4) Gathering - After lunch in the men's bathroom.
>5) Event - An excuse for having a Renegade.  Usually used as an excuse to
>get cops off yer ass so that party isn't shut down.

>
>Part III  Bonus question: This is a toughie...
>Which Label dosen't Belong:
A:  The label that cannot produce good, deep ass, 303 house.

>Answers will be posted later.
No need, I already posted them for you.

>
>We now return you to your regularly programmed life.
>
>
>Spins,
>Adam

Peace & Humor...

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 23 Sep 1995 19:43:47 -0700
From: Jon Zimmerman <bigz@cyberE.creative.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: My Bio!

Greetings and Salutations!

My name is Jon Zimmerman and I live in San Francisco. Bored yet? This is a
long one I'm warning you...
I'm 24 and presently attend S.F. State fulltime (21 units this semester) as
a junior/Senior IAC Major (Interdisciplinary Arts). I joined SFraves
approximatly a year and a half ago (I think?), and I've enjoyed the "Rave"
scene since 1990. Although I can't remember the name of it my first rave
was in Los Angeles in 1990. Although at the time I was not really into the
scene or the music I do remember it being very attractive to me because of
the psycadelic nature of the music and the visuals. I remember it was in a
big hall with probably 2000 people. The illicit nature of the party was
very attractive as well. Anyways if you havn't seen my name before
(bigz@creative.net) it's because it was originally zimmermanj@aol.com (a
bunch of thieves!), I then moved to znet (bigz@znet.com (another bunch of
crooks!)), since then I have found a comfortable home at "creative.net".
Soon I will become an Island unto myself (bigz@bigz.com).
        At any rate let me give you a little B.C. (Before Current era)
about myself:
        I was born in Berkeley in 1971 and grew up in Oakland (Montclair).
For years I built plastic models, and expressed my self through many
artistic mediums. Then I discovered Jimi Hendrix when I was 10. At the time
I was playing really lame folk songs for some granola teacher, then one day
she ask me to listen to Jimi Hendrix's "Star-Spangled Banner"! After the
first 30 seconds I was in awe, here was someone painting and expressing
themselves with music through a guitar. No longer did I see it for playing
lame songs at the campfire, it became a paint brush. I goofed around for
the next 6 years on it, but not seriously. When I was 16 I got stoned for
the first time and for the first time really understood what the Jimi
Hendrix "Experience" was really about, and in extention all the other
psychadelic music of that period. Self-exploration. Simultaneously I was
reading every piece of Science Fiction I could lay my hands on. (funny how
I wind up creating with computers) Time warp through many years of playing
guitar, school, Los Angeles, and Rock and Roll. Somehow I ended up at
Mr.Floppy's Flop House in Oakland. Lots of groovy people and I was hooked,
this was what I'd been looking for, the whole time (I realized this two
years later). After playing in a "Grunge" band, I became creatively
stagnant (1993) and stopped playing guitar for the most part, other than to
score a CD-ROM. Last summer I started going to the Sunset parties (94') and
really wished I could play guitar with the DJs since I found the music
really enlightening.
I burned out on the Rock scene since I felt that many bands just complained
about problems in life, but gave little attention to how to change things.
And here was this music that Didn't bitch about life, but celebrated it.
Although it doesn't say verbally "let's change things" it seems to be
inherint in the nature of it alone, and seems to respect the listeners
intelligence. Since I have started listening to this music my world out
look as been for the most part positive and generally optomistic.
        I also found that rave music is the best thing (for myself) while
working at my computer. I somehow feel more "Intelligent".
        My next project ( within the next year) is to midi my guitar, find
a drummer with a midi kit and start doing live shows again. If anyone is
interested please get in contact with me. Something like if Yes, Pink
Floyd, Orbital and Amorphous Androgynous had a child.
        The last year I spent helping start-up a small multimedia company.
Info on it can be found @ (http://hooked.net:80/user/sireel/).

Anyways more on me can be found at (http://creative.net/~bigz/)


May you prosper and be succesful at whatever you care about...

Jon Zimmerman
bigz@creative.net

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep 29 11:18:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA10184; Fri, 29 Sep 1995 11:18:35 -0700

From: laural@inmark.com
Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id KAA01280 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 29 Sep 1995 10:49:49 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA812398326 Fri, 29 Sep 95 11:12:06 
Date: Fri, 29 Sep 95 11:12:06 
Message-Id: <9508298123.AA812398326@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: ...all married now!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     
     Hello,
     
     Since a couple of people asked, I thought I'd give a brief report of 
     Brian's and my adventures of the past two weeks.
     
     First, though, I want to thank everyone -- especially Ethan, Larry, 
     and the load in/out crew -- for the party at Bonny Doon that day.
     
     We left that party a little early to go out to dinner with our 
     parents, and then the wedding was the next day.  It went by so fast, 
     about the only things I remember was the way Brian said "I do" and the 
     way everyone snarfed down the wedding cake.  It was gone in less than 
     ten minutes, and I had ordered 100 servings for 80 people :-) :-)
     
     On Monday (the 18th) we left for Hawaii.  Our first stop was Maui for 
     four days.  Speaking for myself here, Maui was okay.  It was very arid 
     (except for the north/east side, going to Hana) and full of tourists 
     who drive too fast to view the scenery.  We played tourist and took a 
     helicopter ride around the island, and got a good close-up view of 
     some incredibly steep mountains on the west side of the island.  We 
     also went snorkeling and sailing, which was a lot of fun.  
     
     After that, we went to Hawaii (the Big Island, which is not where 
     Honolulu is, although many people seem to get that confused.  Honolulu 
     is on Oahu.  We didn't go there except to pass through the airport).  
     The Big Island is gorgeous.  The east side is all jungly, like a 
     rainforest (and I didn't have to drive three hours on tiny roads to 
     get to it, it's all right there).  We saw pretty waterfalls that 
     created rainbows as the water misted over the rocks below.
     
     From there, we drove up to the Volcanoes National Park.  We spent two 
     days up there, hiking around.  The main fire pit at the top of Kiluea 
     has been dormant for a while, but we hiked about a mile and a half 
     across some lava flows further down the mountain, and got a good view 
     of the current active vent.  The next day we drove down to sea level 
     and could see where the lava was flowing into the ocean, spewing up 
     huge clouds of steam.  We didn't actually see any red molten lava, the 
     park ranger said we'd have to be there after dark to do that and we 
     were just too tired to come back later.
     
     Then, we drove around to Kona on the west side of the island.  We 
     stayed in a house right on the water -- sometimes the surf would send 
     bits of spray up to our window!  We went snorkeling and saw more fish 
     than I can describe.  There's this shallow bay south of Kona, and from 
     the second we put our masks on we saw that we were surrounded by 
     schools of multi-colored fish.  Plus, it was spawning time for several 
     species of fish, so there was lots of mating/chasing/protecting 
     territory going on.  Unfortunately, a hurricane off the coast of Japan 
     was kicking up heavy surf all around the Pacific, so it kept getting 
     rougher and rougher.  We tried snorkeling at a second location, but 
     stopped after I got dumped on the rocks by a wave.
     
     Our last stop was Kauai, where we stayed for four days.  Although I 
     liked the Big Island the best, I thought Kauai was the prettiest.  It 
     rains there a lot so everything is lush and green, overgrown with 
     flowers and vines.  We went hiking in Waimea Canyon, did a little 
     swimming, and attempted to take a boat ride along the Na Pali cliffs 
     (2000 feet tall) but the sea was too rough so they canceled the trip.
     
     Laura

At 12:33 PM 9/29/95, Karen wrote:
>I saw a really interesting show last night on PBS all about the birth and
>evolution of techno & house etc., and the use of 'tables as instruments ...
>and I finally found out something I always kind of wondered about ... so
>here's my question - HOW MANY PEOPLE KNOW WHY HOUSE MUSIC IS CALLED HOUSE
>MUSIC?
>

House music was first played and popularized at a club called the
"WhereHouse" in Chicago (?) or Detroit.  Hence, when people referred to the
music, they said "house".  Short for WhereHouse!  =)

Tigger

this is what i have heard...
house music was coined to describe the unique blend of musics being 
combined by carter/may/saunderson/et. al. when they were spinning records 
at chicago/detroit/new york clubs. certain individual styles became 
identified with certain clubs and the resident dj at the time. the clubs 
were the house, the music played therein was the music of the house, or 
just house music... like a resident rock band is the *house* band, the 
style of music of the dj spinning there was the *house* music.

...just what i have read...

kevin

> >9) you know your at a bad event when:
> A:
> -People are dancing while holding cigarettes.

Depends on crowd density on this one.  Also, one can cup a cigarette
in one's hand so as not to burn.  Those who smoke outdoors:  the earth
is not your ashtray!!!

> -People who have no rhythm "attempt" to dance.

Actually, there's usually so much movement on the dancefloor that it
doesn't really matter if any one individual is off -- except if they're 
wielding a cigarette like a weapon, moshing like some 
crossover-tourist-newbie, etc.  I'm usually not doin' enough spectating to 
notice. Actually, I'm glad that these rhythmically-challenged people are 
out there, cuz' it's one of the few environs where they can lose the 
burdensome load of self-consciousness experienced in daily life and in other
dancefloor contexts.

> -People do aerobics or stretches on the dance floor (worse than circle
> dancing IMO).

Yes, things that disrupt dancefloor energy:  conversations, 
camp-outs, wandering looki-loos, etc.  

One sure indicator:  When some idiot in the crowd yelps "eweh-eweh", the 
crowd responds w/a resounding "eweh-eweh".  I love it when this this 
call-and-response is suppressed by no response (sign of a promising 
party =).  Dear fellow, I can suppress you're cigarettes by moving away, 
but I can't close my ears.

> -People smell like they've taken tons of X &/or speed, dance all night, hit
> lotsa pot, smell really bad, and THEN wanna hug you.  Yeech!
> -You hear two people talking "Hey, is that Jeno?!?", "No, it's Garth!",
> when it's really John Howard or Mark Farina.

Or how about when they know the name of the DJ, and scream it out as if
"Garth!" and "Jeno!" were fucking rockstars or gods and they, silly 
sychohantic teenage fans straight out of BeatleMania.

> -When someone searching for a reason, or perhaps a clue, asks "Is this
> where the 'rave' is?"; time to leave.
> -Cops are everywhere.

So to recap:
Call:  "eweh-eweh"
Response: =(

=) Rok

From: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Reply-To: KaySEE <kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Intro
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9509291424.A21764-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I guess it's time to quit hanging around and start talking with a 
short intro.  I've been on the list for around a month.  I'm a relative 
newbie to the scene, having been introduced to it by my beautiful cousin 
about 8 months ago.  I just graduated from Cal this year, leaving me more 
time to go out, although I haven't capitulated on this fact recently.  I 
studied entomology and now I work doing biological research on healthier 
pest control strategies.  I feel like a freak admitting this because 
everyone else on this list seems to be into computers and the like.  
O-well, no one ever forgets the fact that I study bugs, so I guess I have 
my little claim to fame (or freak-hood as the case may be!!)  :]

I've been really enjoying this list.  A free exchange of ideas, 
communication and acceptance, as well as a lot of tolerance is expressed 
here, something I've been in dreadful need of.  

I don't remember the first rave I went to, it was at the Vallejo 
fairgrounds.  I found it interesting, but I was a bit put off by people 
showing off and trying to be the coolest person who had done the most 
drugs and had the coolest clothes.  (I had enough of that in high 
school)
However, because of my cousin Emily 
who some of you may know, I was able to see through this and realize 
there was something pretty special going on.  After going to a few more 
raves with some good friends, I loved it.  I think the thing I like the 
most is the fact that I don't have to deal with this perpetual mating 
game that I've had to deal with most of my life.  I've spent quite a bit 
of my life unknowingly succumbing to society's gender stereotypes.  I was 
so sick of having to fill some role, that when I found raves I felt so 
wonderfully happy.  I had finally found a place where I could dance, be 
myself, meet open-minded people, and not worry too much about a big 
game.  It was and is great.  (I give a special thanks to all the people 
on this list who help make this happen just by being yourselves!)

To make this quick, the thing I like the most about the music is its 
paradoxical nature; it climaxes without ever subsiding.  The best time 
I've ever had, and one of the biggest learning experiences, was at F&F in 
August.  I went literally with friends and family (my two cousins) and 
re-discovered a wonderful friendship with one of my cousins.  We had 
grown apart since coming to school and got closer at F&F.  Needless to 
say, it was beautiful.

Well, that's my hello to you all.  I hope I get to meet some of you , 
although I think I've already met a few in passing.

XXOO,

kirsten

P.S.  I'm 5'4" with now short brown hair and brown eyes, 22 yo.  I have a 
conservative exterior, but a very innate, liberal interior.  (AS the cliche 
goes:  You can't judge a book by it's cover! :]  )

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Kevin Keiper:
: this is what i have heard...
: house music was coined to describe the unique blend of musics being 
: combined by carter/may/saunderson/et. al. when they were spinning records 
: at chicago/detroit/new york clubs. certain individual styles became 
: identified with certain clubs and the resident dj at the time. the clubs 
: were the house, the music played therein was the music of the house, or 
: just house music... like a resident rock band is the *house* band, the 
: style of music of the dj spinning there was the *house* music.
: 

The "techno purists" among us might point out that House music had been
around a few years before Techno really started.  Chicago was the home of
the Wherehouse (I'm not too sure about the Frankie Knuckles connection).
Juan Atkins/Derrick May/Kevin Saunderson were influenced by House, Funk,
Gospel, Jazz, and of course, Kraftwerk when they put out the music they
called Techno.

There is a difference, but it was often lost on the Brits, and they called
it all Acid House.

At 05:10 PM 9/27/95 -0700, you wrote:

>There are folks reading this right now who are just getting into 
>"raving."  They like the music, they like to dance, they like the 
>openness and the love, they feel at home.  We older "list people" MUST 
>make it our responsibility to remind kids -and eachother- that 
>recreational drugs are dangerous and that they can fuck you up.  And 
>here's how.  Spell it out.  Tell us stories about what you've seen.  
>Maybe they'll think we're just being tiresome...but at least we will have 
>discharged our responsibility.
>
>Think about it.  If you knew someone who was having unprotected sex, 
>wouldn't you say something to them?  If you knew someone who was abusing 
>drugs, shouldn't you say something then as well?  
>

What I think is being forgotten, and was one of the points of Mr. Jones'
original posting, was that drugs are dangerous AND fun. I don't know why the
only response to drug education on here is with the attitude of informing
only of the dangers in usage. At least as important is the fact that MDMA
acts on the brain first and foremost fun-as-all-get-out and then
maybe-you-might-die, too. This seductive aspect of MDMA, and indeed
forbidden substances in general, acts as a sort of positive reinforcement
before health problems even enter the picture, not to mention the allure of
flipping a finger in the shape of a pill and megawatt luvdance to society.
When danger is ignored or desired by those being dangerous, how do you
communicate a deterrent? Everybody knows that any ol preacher, teacher or
parent can prohibit - "It's bad for you, don't do it," without having any
experience with drugs at all. But where do people inform new users on the
range of dangers - "X is sooo good..but listen to this..."

eh

Peter Jones writes:
 >    I wonder if MDMA users are as apologetic about their use of 
 > their drug as smokers are.  I don't know if they are, but from what
 > I have hear on sfraves I doubt that they are.
 > 
 >    I think they should be.

With smokers it's pretty obvious; their chosen substance is a known
physical irritant for many people around them.

But I just don't see what MDMA users should apologise for. Most people
I've talked to *like* going to parties where there is a lot of E. I
know I do. That is part of the point of throwing parties...to try as
much as possible to provide a safe place--a TAZ--where people can do
their own thing, be theirselves, and celebrate without much of the
negativity of the outside world intruding.

I believe that there is no need for MDMA users to apologise. On the
other hand, the lawmakers and police will never ever be able to
apologise enough for ruining people lives over consentual "crimes".

Sean
